title: A Pilgrim in the West.
content:
A Pilgrim in the West.
See yonder line of famished beasts
In search of scanty water ;
The splintered hoof but onward hastes
'Midst burning stones to clatter.
The sunken eye the wild dog frights ;
The panting sides so hollow
Will scarcely feed the carrion kites
On ragged wings that follow.
No limpid pool to quench your thirst
Lies cool in gum trees shadow,
But scorching winds and blinding dust
Your fainting footsteps follow.
No pastures green by silver stream,
No ehady groveB invite them hither ;
Here death and desolation grim
Seem to abide for ever. ~
How well the scene resembles here
The track of toiling man :
A hopeless -view, a scalding tear,
' And — life ends where it began.
Pooh Jim.

title: The Loss of H.M.S. Orpheus.
content:
The Loss of EM S. Orpheus.
To the Editor.
SIB,-I lately read in an old newspaper an account of
the loss of H.M.S. Orpheus, on the coast of New Zea
land, in 1863, and as that sad event was sourrounded
with painfully interesting circumstances, I have writ
ten the following lines, and should you consider them
worth insertion, their publication will recal to
mind an instance of herioc bravery and discipline for
which our seamen have ever been famed :
The Southern Cross illumed the sky on that eventful
morning,
Above, in heaven's canopy, its boundless vault adorn
ing.
When off New Zealand's lofty land, darkness around
prevailing,
With merry crew-a gallant band, a stately ship was
sailing.
And when the sun on wings of light proclaimed the
morn of day,
The gallant Orpheus, - out of night, comes sailing on
her way.
Onward she speeds, a lovely sight, her spars the royals '
bending, ? '».?
Like some glad bird with pinions white o'er waves of
ocean wending.
"The land's in sight I" with mountains bold-in joy
the cry was given, -
Upon the sea a path of gold that seemed to lead to
heaven.
The sentry viewed the cheerful sight, while to his
messmates hailing
"My lads, we'll rest in port to-day-the port to
which we're sailing."
While thus they gazed on visions new, bold hills the
coast defining,
Death raised a landmark to their view of cliffs with
Bilvery lining.
They cast the lead, but little knew that there they
sought their grave.
Where now the sad-the wild sea-mew, cries mournful
o'er the wave.
The boatswain gave his orders shrill, calling the men -
to quarters.
They all obeyed, as if on drill, amidst the surging
waters.
! The mountains back the echo sent from» caverns deep
and wide, .
! The cry " We're lost !" in breakers rent, with rocka on
every side.
They stood like men prepared to die, the ship from
rocks rebounding, ;.
Trembling as though in agony, with signal-gun re
sounding.
They faltered not, the signal given that shook the
empty air,
Was heard aloft in vaulted heaven-they found a
harbour there.
Then Burnett cried, " Let yards be manned !" as up
the shrouds he led, ,\ '
But Fate was in supreme command, with the roll
call for the dead.
1 The light of Heaven shone bright and clear upon tho
brave and dying, .
The crew went down with British cheer, with all their
colours flying.
* # # # * # «
Loudly and mournfully wailed the wind, as aloft their
spirits flew, .'
Britannia wept, in grief resigned, and sighed a last
adieu.
J. A. READ.
Meetings of settlers continue to be held in
various parts of the colony (Bays the ALBURY BANNER)
for the discussion of the important question of land re
form, and for the purpose of determining the particular
amendments necessary to promote settlement upon
the waste lands of the Crown. - At a meeting held a
few days since at Young, the following resolutions
were adopted :-" 1. That this meeting is of opinion
that an amendment of the present Land Act is re
quired, such amendment to embody the following prin
ciples :-That the interest on the balance of condi
tional purchases be abolished, and that such balances
be reduced by annual payments of one shilling per
acre. That a compulsory Fencing Act be passed.
That the improvement clause be abolished. 2. That
a Free Selectors' Association be now formed for the
purpose of uniting with other associations of a like
character, with the object of carrying out the fore
going resolution."
On Thursday night an accident occurred (says
the ROCKHAMPTON BULLETIN of the 4th instant), on
the new unopened section of the Northern railway,
about four miles from Dingo. The night was dark,
and nothing could be seen at any distance. A ballast
engine, with several waggons attached, was coming
down the line at a moderate speed, when a young bul
lock, which had been standing by the side of the rail,
suddenly got on the line, a few yards in advance of the
train. As it was impossible to stop the engine in time,
it was hoped that the animal would be caught by the
cow-catcher in the usual way, and thrown aside ; but
something different happened this time, for the bullock
got underneath, and the engine and tender, after a
rough ride over the carcase, came down again on the
metals, having escaped with two broken springs, be
sides a little other damage. The waggons, two of
which were injured, left the rails, but the engine waa -
soon afterwards brought to a standstill. One of the
waggons contained a number of women and children,
who were getting a " lift ;" but the danger on thia
occasion will make them cautious for the future as to
riding in the dark.
The Archbishop of Canterbury ("says the Times)
has determined upon holding a Fan-Anglican Synod at
Lambeth Palace in the autumn of 1878, and with that
view has recently been in communication with the
whole of the English, Irish, colonial, missionary, and
Scottish bishops, with a view to ascertain whether
they acquiesce in the propriety of the proposed Synod,
and whether they will attend it. The Archbishop of
York, the Bishops of London, Llandaff, Lichfield,
Oxford, and Chester approve, and will attend.
Many express doubts, but will attend. The
Bishops of Winchester, Norwich, and Peterborough
disapprove. All the Scottish bishops approve, with
the exception of Dr. Christopher "Wordsworth, Bishop
of St. Andrews, who doubts. Only one Irish
bishop (Cashel) disapproves. All the colonial and
missionary bishops who have replied to the Archbishop
approve, with the exception of Sierra Leone, Welling
ton, and Nelson. None of them positively say they
Will attend, but three-Nelson, Wellington, and New
Zealand-say they will not attend. Of the American
bishops, twenty-eight say they approve, but five-New
Jersey (Dr. Odenheimer), Western New York (Dr.
Close), Virginia (Dr. Whittle), Vermont (Dr. Bossel),
and assistant. New Jersey (Dr. Scarborough)-disap
prove, and will not attend. Amongst many subjects
which thc Archbishop proposes for consideration are
"Book of Common Prayer and authorised Version of
the Bible," "Doubts and Fears," " Counteraction of
"The Eastern Church/ " Old Catholics and Scandi
navian Church," "Unity among Catholics of the
Anglican Communion," " Position of the Archbishop
of Canterbury ÙY the Anglican Communion."
Infidelity," "Missionary BÍBIIOJ
and Missions,'

title: GONE TO THE WRST.
content:
GONE! TO THE WRST.
It was a bright May mom when they left us,
Our boys to co to the Wost,
. And we thought ns wo sadly watched them
Was the parting all for tho best?
They had taken their mob of horses, ' .
And their fortunes gone to soelc,
I wonder, my blue eyed laddies,
How long lt will bo oj'e we meet. ¡j ;
' It was Hal, who headed the horses
On a dancing chestnut colt, , , :
; ' And Jack was on a creamy, .. ?
Who' seemed Inclined to bolt. . > \
©h, .didn't they look bonnie,
Wheeling the steeds about,
And when they saw us at tho slip-rails,.
,'fhey, Igave us a farewell shout,
.: We watched them from the paddock rails,
; As. up 'the dusty road they went, ?
Guiding'the prancing horses.
Bound for the far off Weßt. . .
. .We watched till they faded from our sight,
And nothing was heard but the bells,
1 And we Hst till the sounds grew fainter,
And died away In the hills.
; And when we turned into the house,
We felt that they were gone, .
-?' No. longer boyish voices'
Tea-ced us with their fun. ,
. Oh, laddies we felt so lonely,
' We missed your bright faces at tea,
. We wondered where you were camping, ?
'- And wished that we could see.
.S '?
, Never mind, the time will pass,
And we'll see their dear faces once more,
? ; Though 'I guess we'll hardly know them.
For moustaches and whiskers -\vl\\ grow.
But we'll patiently walt the home coming,
? And hope all things for tin; best;,
Good-rbye, God guard them and bless them,
.riiir-'. hnvg nrlin lin vu imno tn tin. Wpat
' :-- ' M. E. G.

title: SELECT POETRY.
content:
?HSS
'laim-mvu.!. i
A GLASS OP GOOD BÇER.
(tfrom'tht People'« Advocate.)
Do yeasty it li poison, and certain to kill?
Thal beer it the source of all evil and ill P
That death'» in the cup. and that madness lies
«f there,
Combm'd with iU twin brother-Giant Despair P
That a glast of good ale it a demon of tin t
Thai the Devil himself is «mhodiedjn gin ?
Then you're welcome to think so, ob! ttttotal
leer;
Por our own part «e'r* fond of a glass of good
beer.
If you prefer water, we do not say nay
It's a matter of usté-let each have his owa way.
Although not a drunkard, a tippler, or tot,
If you say it is poison, we say that it's not.
Opinions may differ. Have you second sight,
To know Hut we're wrong, and to know that
you're right ?
Have you a peculiar title to sneer
At your neighbour, fer liking a glass of good
beer?
When the woikman tilt down, after toiling all
day,
To a glass of good ale, would you say to him nay ?
Does it make lum less strong and less fit for the
strife,
Of that great human battle-the battle of life,?
bxpenence has proved that naught can sustain
tang honra and hard work, like a moderate drain.
The workmen of England, the pride of our sphere,
Know the strengthening power of a glass of good
beer.
Oh ! woe to tht Cur. and ill-fated the hour
When he tempted the Lion to show forth his
power;
And bUclc was the day to his cause and his crown,
When th« brewers of Loudun exported the
.' brown,"
It is not " Dutch courage" we wish to inspire,
1'or a Brilon, though beerie«, will alwaya stand
Are;
But we know it will tend to encourage and cherr,
And that's why we send him a glass of good beer.
Oh ! woe to the Despot, his forts and his fleet,
When the forert of England he chances to meet ;
No tea drinkers they, yet these sons of the «ra
Are the eau»«of our land being glorious and free,
Had it not been for ttieai, we should all have been
slaves,
And have lost tht proud boast of commanding
the waves.
And yet, from the lowest to Charley Napier,
They all know the worth of a glass of good beer.
Oh ! Barclay and Perkins, we would not debar
Thy fluid from labourer, soldier, or tar ;
John Barleycorn's blood may be often abused
But we do not forget il'a much oftener used.
Then, lull.' to the national liquor of hume ;
And wherever our fate may oblige us to roam,
And wherever our fortune,may cause ut to steer,
May we never be far from a glass of good beer f

title: THOSE "WILLOW SOLDIERS."
content:
THOSE "WILLOW SOLDIERS."
(Dedicated to George Essex Evans.) |
Sweet singer of Toowoomba,
With tro strange poet c ways,
Kirdly *iavel si ghtly slower
AVith li-ia rhyming cricket craze.
If (ha: "Willow Soldier' poem I
You intend for mere than fun,
Just ecpect us in Toowoomba
With a nu la and a gua !
AVhon Australia rails for soldiers
AVlth the will to wade in gore,
And the warships of the foentan
Aio advincing on the shore,
They will como from every quarter,
tod prepared for deadly work.
One wild response shall answer
From Capo Wilson to Cape York.
From the far West Ii dian Ocean, ,»
To the Coral Seas In Bight,
From the mangroves of Fort Darwin!
"To the white cliffs of the Bight
/ From the sandhills of the desert
And tho land where Nature decks
The savage stony ridges
With the cruel spinifex __
From the lone gray mulga brushes,
From the de_o)ato dreaiy plains,
From the gidya wildernesses
Where au o,wful silence reigns !
From plains and hills and valleys,
Shall the scattered îanks como forth,
Trom the forests of tho Southland,
riom tho jungles of the North.
From scrubs where timber-getters
Cut down theil giant crops,
Where the eagle bu Ids her eyrlo
On the lonely mountain top
From 01 chard, farm, and station.
Office, stole, and bushmans camp,
From city, town and country,
We shall hear the martial tramp
Of (he men Vustralia musters
AVhen »he,proidly waves on high
The Standard of a nation
Sworn to conquer or to die
And the first foe to attack MA
When Vustiallas on the "charge"
Shall discover that his contract
Is. decidedly too "large"
Australia's noblest warriors'
Shall face the leaden pills
AVhen Evans's val aut cricketers
Aie sprinting for the hills '
In that war match of cricket,
A genuine deadly " test '
They'll carry out their bats all righi
Five hundred miles due west '
In arter day«, old bushraen,
When hunting native dogs,
Shall find bats and balls and wickets
lu a hundred hollow logs
And the bard of fair Toowoomba
On an old-mam kangaroo
Tar west of Wallumbilla,
Striking out for tbo Paroo ' I
A. MESTON,
Brisbane. "

Jemmy, good bye, tbe best of friends must part,
Tho' all ie gone, y»u have my band and boort ;
No cour-e WSB open bot boldly to resign,
Beleasamy colleagues-all the fault is mine.
Upon a fatal roch so blindly did I steer,
Wrecked my State ebip, two thousand pounds a year ;
I could Bot meet the "House," my palmy days aro o'er,
Robertson, impatient, awaits mo on the floor.
That ¡ron-alad man like adamant will stand,
My spoeob, blood-red, will hold up in his hand,
Be Banding justice--then what shall I say?
I've yielded ill position, place, and pay.
Stand by me, Jemmy, I require your aid,
The public sty it sees the card I played ;
'"Twa-! not for Duncan 1 resigned, no, not stall,
But conning strategy made to break my fall."
No cunning s'rategy was I ever known to do,
For truth of wbioh I can appeal to you;
Speak of me a« you think, my old oollesgue,
Gould Harry Parkes commit a dark intrigue ?

title: TANNA.
content:
TANNA.
--o--
TANNA is one of the largest islands in
group known as the New Hebrides. The
natives of it in common with all their
South Sea brethern, are generally titled
by the whites ' Cannachas.' They are
of the negro family, resembling in fea-
ture, very closely, the Feejee tribes . It
is said that they believe in the existence
of a Superior Being, whose earthly
dwelling they fancy is in the burning
volcanoes for which the island is remark-
able. They believe in a future happy
state, and call their heaven 'Arrochin.'
They are divided into small tribes or
clans; the largest of these are the
Ukingha-shaa and Attanam families. A
spirit of rivalry between these two last
mentioned often causes long and bloody
wars all over the island.
Tanna besids the never-sleeping volcano,
has its other objects of interest in the
many boiling springs that surround the
base of the burning mountain. Some
of these are held as holy, and none but
chiefs are permitted to taste their
waters. Such restriction, however, does
not extend over all.
When any of their great warriors die,
the aborigines believe that the spirits of
Arrochin prepare a great feast there for
their coming guest, and for fear he
should loose himself on the road thither
they (the spirits) call to him and blow
trumpets, sending some one at the same
time with torches to meet him and
guide him on his way to those blessed
regions.
THE 'CANNACHA'S' DEATH-SONG, OVER HIS CHIEFTAIN.
Shades of my father, the hour is approaching.
Prepare ye the 'cava' for 'Yona' on high ;
Make ready the welcome, ye souls of Arrochin,
The Death God of Tanna speaks-Yona mustdie.
No more will he traverse the flame sheeted moun-
tain,
To lead forth his brothers to hunting and war ;
No more will he drink from the time honour'd
fountain,
Nor rise in the councils of Uking-a-shaa.
His voice in the battle loud thunder resembling,
Has died like a Zephyr o'errunning the plain ;
His whoop like the tempest thro' forest trees
trembling,
Shall never strike foemen with terror again.
The ' muska' hung up on the cocoa is sleeping
And Attanam's spirits have gather'd a-nigh,
To see their destroyer ; and wailing and weeping,
Roll past on the night breathing winds of the
sky.
The lines are suspended, the ' muttow' is broken,
The canoe's far away from the waterwash'd
shore,
Mourn, mourn, ye ' whyeena's,' the word has been
spoken,
The Chieftain can bring ye the 'weepan' no
more.
Ye cloudseated visions, ye shades of my fathers,
Awake from your slumbers, the trumpet blast
blow ;
The moments are flying, the mountain mist gathers,
And Yona is leaving his campfire below.
The struggles are over, the cords are asunder ;
Ye Phantoms hold forward your heavenly light,
Speak on the wings of the sky-shaking thunder,
And fill him with joy on the path of his flight.
Come downwards a space thro' the fogs till ye
meet him,
Throw open the doors of Arrochin awide,
And stand on the thresholds, ye Shadows to greet,
him--
The glory of Tanna, the Uking'shaa's pride.
Thanks, spirits departed-heard I not your voices
Faint rolling along on the breath of the gale ?
Thanks, spirits departed, Le-en-na rejoices :
Ye've answered the mourner-ye've silenc'd
the wail.
The midnight is clearing; the Death-song is ended,
The Chieftain has gone, but ye've call'd him
away;
For he smiled as he listened, obedient ascended,
The voice in his ear, and the torch on his way.
H. KENDALL.
Explanation of Native Words used in the subjoined
Song.
'Arrochin'-Heaven. 'Cava'-a drink extract-
ed from a root. [The natives believe it is made
and drank in Arrochin where it grows as in
Tanna]. 'Muska' [corruption of the English
term musket-of late their Chief weapon in war.
' Muttow'-a fishing-hook. 'Whyeeua' - woman.
[This is not the original native appellation ; that
I could never ascertain]. ' "Weepan'-Fish.
[Their principle food]. 'Leenna' and 'Yona'
native names.

title: ORIGINAL POETRY.
content:
ORIGINAL POETRY.
THE TEAR.
When friendship or love
Our sympathies move ;
When truth, in a glance, shall appear,
The lips may beguile,
With a dimple or smile,
But the test of affection's a tear.
Too oft is a smile
But the hypocrlte's wile,
To mark detestation or fear :
Give me the soft sigh,
While the soul-telling eye
Is dlmm'd, for a time, with a tear.
Mild charity's glow,
To us mortals below,
Shows the soul from barbarity clear ;
Compassion will melt
Where this virtue is felt,
As its disc is diffus'd in a tear.
The man doom'd to sail
With the blast of the gale,
Through billows majestic to steer,
As he lends o'er the wave,
Which may soon be his grave,
The green sparkles bright with a tear.
The soldier braves death,
For a fanciful wreath,
In glory's romantic career ;
But he raises the foe,
In battle laid low,
And bathes every wound with a tear.
If with high bounding pride
He returns to his bride,
Renouncing the gore-crimsoned spear,
All his toils are repaid,
When embracing the maid,
From her eyelid he kisses the tear.
Sweet scene of my youth,
Seat of friendship and truth
Where love chas'd each fast-fleeting year ;
Loath to leave thee I mourn'd,
For a last look I turn'd,
But thy spire was scarce seen through a tear.
Though my vows I can pour
To my lov'd one no more,
My Mary, to love once so dear ;
In the shade of her bower,
I remember the hour
She rewarded those vows with a tear.
By another possess'd,
May she live ever bless'd,
Her name still my heart must revere ;
With a sigh I resign
What I once thought was mine,
Or forget her deceit with a tear.
Ye friends of my heart,
E'er from you I part,
This hope to my breast is most near,
If again we should meet
In this rural retreat,
May we meet, as we part, with a tear.
When my soul wings her flight
To the regions of light,
And my corse shall recline on its bier,
As ye pass by the tomb,
Where my ashes consume,
Oh ! moisten their dust with a tear.
May no marble bestow
The splendour of woe,
Which the children of vanity rear ;
No fiction of fame
Shall blazon my name,
All I ask — all I wish — is a tear.

title: Desperandum.
content:
Desperandum.
Magic music of the bushland ¡
Sounds around my lonely camp,
rWhile the sudden tropic sunset
Bids me light the evening lamp.
And the night's fast falling shadow*
Bear my thoughts V:ross land and sea*
To the country where I wandered*
In the gloaming, Love, with thee.
When we pledged those vows eternal,
Vows of love, so staunch and true;
fWhen we dreamed in Lover 'è
dreamland
'Neath those skies of roseate hue. '
NoW, alas, that sky o'er shadowed->
Storm clouds grey spread o'er the
scene.
And my heart is heavy laden
Gaunt Despair, Where Hope had been.
Money lost, and friends departed,
Love itself but Mockery seems.
Visions past arise and taunt me
Nightmares now, that once were
dreams.
Can it be that all Life's pleasures,
AH Life's fond illusions vain i
Are but phantasies and visions-- I
Does no gleam of hope remain?
'I ' '!,,'! if
Is life made of nought but bubbles,*
.We, like children, strive to seize,
Though they mock our mightiest
efforts, ,
Borne away by lightest breeze.
Or, if we do not rise and grasp them
What remains for our reward?
Nothing, where but once was bright-
ness.
Is there nought in Life but fraud?
? ?.? .,:<:: ui
Bear me comfort, Oh ye breezes,
For my heart is aching sore- /
Bear me once again to Dreamland, '
Let me dream those dreams once
more; ' . !, r [|JJ
Then, ere the visions ended,
Bear mo swiftly Death's dark sleep*
Bring it ere I burst the bubble, |
And1 thejeost lill fcjou'nt but /cheap. i
* I'
Then, perhaps, by God's great
ímerey, í ^ i ' , f
I may find that country first,
Where dreams are made that do not
Vanish, ? \[\
Bubbles Mown that (will not burst. ,
If that, too's, another vision i
And the grave's the only end, *
Let it fçofmle, fo,r I a¡m /weary,
Death himself must be a friend.
O.R.P.

title: ORIGINAL POETRY.
content:
ORIGINAL POETRY.
ON HAPPINESS
TRUE happiness is not the growth of earth —
Your toil is fruitless if you seek it here;
'Tis an exotic of celestial birth,
And never blooms but in celestial air.
Sweet flower of Paradise! the seeds are sown
In, here and there, a mind of heav'nly mould;
It rises slow, and buds, but ne'er was known
To blossom here — the climate is too cold.

title: REAL ESTATE.
content:
REAL ESTATE.
The fairies live in garden flowers,
As doth the caterpillar;
The mignonette a cottage is,
A larkspur is a villa.
In rose-trees' old embattled walls
Proud fairy earls are dwelling;
Campanulas are churches tall,
Where bells the hours are telling.
Acanthus flowers let out as flats,
Whose tennants are erratic;
I knew an artist fay who climbed
Twelve stories to his attic.
And there's a fairy architect
A curious gift discloses,
Restoring most artistic homes
From ruinous moss-roses.
ELLA MCFADYEN.

title: THE WEARY MILES.
content:
THE WEARY MILES.
L. N.
TRAMPING along the lonely track,
Winding through the forest timber,
When early sunbeams mild and tender
Glance on the rude swag upon the back;
While the day is young prem onwards,
Keep the inarch up in good style;
The next station 11m far forward,
Over many a weary mile.
Over ridge and gully and grassy plain,
The miles grow longer as the son attends;
The shoulders under their burden bend-
Before the road stretches ever the same.
Now the sun has reached its highest noon,
A brief halt in the shifting shade awhile:
No water nearer than the next lagoon,
Farther on many a weary mile.
Up and away—there is no time to loiter—
. The day's journey is but half way through;
The tired feet have further work to do
Era they reach the hospitable shelter.
Now comes a horseman hastening by;
The question he answers with a smile—
" How far away doea the station lie V
Alas 1 still some odd weary miles.
How the way lengthens, how the limbs drag I
And still no sign of a habitation—
Still on every side the forest's vegetation;
The daylight lessens, let not the footsteps flag;
And when, as the sun sinks in the west,
In sight appears the wbbed-for aisle,
A joyful cry escapes from the breast.
To Bud an end to the weary miles.
Look Out.—When you Me an old gentleman
of sixty on a clear, bright, frosty morning carry
ing a bine cotton umbrella, tied tightly about the
waist with a shoe-string—the umbrella tied, not
the old gentleman— you may Look out for rain
before night, but the probabilities are that you
will not see it.
When thb¥ Bsonr to Dbink.—During the
hearing of a case in the Court of Exchequer,
Dublin, the judge asked a witness, " How soon
do people begin to drink in your part of the
country—at what age?" Serjeant Armstrong:
" I can answer that —as soon as they are born."
(Laughter.) The witness: "At all ages, my
lord." His lordship: " That is jtut what I was
afraid of: he says they begin at all ages."
Sergeant Armstrong: " Oh, yes, my lord, I
know a part of the country where the day a
child is born the people bleed it in the feet, and
impart a glass of whisky."
PbescbiptioKs.—A physician, who was not
Tery familiar with the symptoms or the remedies
for the cholera, was called upon to prescribe for a
cobbler, who believed himeelf suffering from
the epidemic. He told him to take certain
medicines, and called again next day, when he
was told that Crispin was cured ; in fact, so well
was he, that he had gono to work. —" Indeed !"
said the doctor; " that is capital. You see my
prescription has answered admirably."—" Not
so," they answered; he would not take the
medicine."—" Indeed! What then did he do ?"
—" Impatient and hungry, he called for his
supper—a dish of beans and potatoes, along
with a red herring."—" Dear, dear !" exolaimed
our doctor ; and bettering he had discovered a
secret which Nature, by chance, had revealed,'
he drew out his pocket-book, and wrote the
following as a cure for cholera: " Cholera Pre
scription.—Beans, cold potatoes, and red her
rings ; to be taken plentifully and immediately."
But a few^lays elapsed, and our good doctor
was called in to attend a mason, also seized with
the cholera, to whom he at once gave the famous
prescription. Alas ! on the morrow, on calling,
he learnt, to his astonishment, that a quarter of
an hour after having taken the remedy, the poor
man died. —" Dear, dear!" murmured the doctor;
and again pulling out his pocket-book, he added
the following memorandum to the prescription:
—" N.B.—An excellent remedy for cobblers,
bmt tueleM for masons."

title: WAR! WAR! WAR!
content:
WAR! WARI WARI
ANSWER TO HENRY HAtXORÁN'S ADDRESS TO THE
VOLUNTEERS.
I . Te* ! dauntless and poetie Dravo,
I We're ready for tho fight,
! Oar firesides from invasion save I
: . - And put the foe to Hight.
What flare wo for the jibes-the jeera
That met our first oareor?
We ¡till are in«-,-bold,-volunteers, '
And so we wera last yoar.
Oar sword* ws'll draw for all we have,
And still uphold the name
Of England's sons,-so bardy-brave
That s now onrolled in Fame.
Th» foe may dome with slaughter's Ares.
He'll lind us still tm* blue,
Tho dauntless sons of bardy sires
Who won at Waterloo,
Bo singue now a'cheering strain,
Our coursgo it will fan
To meet the foe on Battle's plain,
And fight them man; to man. ,
God speed,our country and our cause
. Whatever may betide ' ,
Wn'll Unlit for homo-uphold our laws
nrnn^.h'.r,rA h. ml A»
CHUOKLEHEAD. .
YOUNO MEN'S CHRISTIAN ASSOCIATION.- Lase evening
the fifth of a series of lectures in connection with thii
association was delivered in tho now Temperance Hall,
Pitt.street, by the Rev. Joseph Beazley, subject
" Popular Amusements." Thnro was a very numerous and
highly respectable attendance, tho Hall being well filled
The chair was taken by Captain Martindale, R.E., whe
in a few appropriate observations introduced the lec-
turer, who commence! by remarking that, hy tho com-

ing strnnuly of onnoeriN similar to those, bold at the

title: LITER[?]TURE.
content:
UTm*¿ÜKE. I for

'<- j * AN AtJcJnoN.
A writer, whose delineations of scenes
in life possess extreme beauty .and a
lively reality, has called an auction, a
'stfe.yre-of mingled laughter and heart
"btfiali* "I <&n speak to the truth of this,
for ,1*"have just beçnjat one; to me
.however, it was rather of.the description
of the latter. The bankruptcy of LI. F. was
to be visited upon himself and his family
by the disposal of his property. I went
to »the sale rather early in order to have
a,full inspection, of the articles I designed
to bid for. Some of the auditory chieflv
'of the soft pex had assembled themselves'
aVthe end of the room and on the right
of the rostrum. They were chiefly en-
gaged as 1 entered in an exchange of ill
natured remarks on the family whose
^isfortunes had congregated them to-
gether. ,A tall, meagre looking old»
maid was the most prominent figure in
the group, both in point of size and
speech. She looked like one of that sort!
of beings who invite you a distance of1
five miles to tea, and then put on the
table a round and a half of dry toast,
and a plate with no more butter than one'
needs to swear by, and at last dismisses
you, with a glass of sweet wine, sans¡
'souper. A tone of bitter malice andj
'sjcprn distinguished all that she said. Byj
her jside stood a vulgar, little fat woman, j
iwith a couple of daughters whose high'
'cheek bones threatened to blind their
eyes, and bed post ancles promised'
"badly for ready made boots. Contrasting'
ia splendid piece of ,furniture with the!
fallen fortunes of Mrs. F. the former,1
triumphantly exclaimed that Mrs. F.V
" high airs and flouncing humours had'
brought her lower down than a grocers i
Wadi; now." Among others who had
,assembled ; I noticed a bustling person-
age, tlie cut of whose phiz, told me that
iheicould put low and high prices on the
.same article; there was a vast deal of
"professional consequence in his deport-,
.jiiúpt and he looked as if he would wil
.^îngly excuse the absence of nearly every¡
lone but himself. As he inspected each
article he was careful in enlightening his
neighbours on the flaws he discovered!
which he did wrih a knowing hypocritical
shake of the head, as much as to say,
* ratler you than I, buy that.' From a
'side door into the room, we were in, a
young, married woman, with two cherub
'children entered shortly after the sale
liad commenced, her dress seemed to
tB.aye been carelessly put on, her spirits
dejected, altogether, she was the picture
of misery. »The auctioneer was just at
Hbis moment exciting the laughter of Hhe
refined, by descanting op. the excellent
r qualities of some damaged culinary
utensils, and others unmentionable.
The rude laughter around, contrasted
painfully with the melancholy countenance
of the poor woman I have mentioned.
She was once mistress of the house we
were in. The next lot put up by the
man of the hammer, was a smalls mina
ture portrait The poor woman bid for
it, but was stoutly and to appearance,-?
warmly opposed by the old maid; to
whom it was at last knocked down. This
unfeeling wretch, I afterwards found out
to be one of those hopeless husband
^seekers, who disgust you by their assump
itdon of the airs of eighteen, after they
have arrived at withered thirty five, and
trwho received another damper to the many
,ghe had before experienced, in the mar-
riage of Mrs. F-to the man whom her
»folly 'had destined for its victim. I was
* subsequently enlightened as to who the
bu^t]ing ,personage who engaged himself
BP anxiously in detecting flaws in the fur
'niture was.-A broker I The fat lady
with the ox looking daughters, was the
vulgar wife of a pimple faced grocer,
over whom she exerted a queenly sway.
Denied the intimacy of Mrs. F.-who was
an accomplished woman, and a lady, she
caine hither to indulge the triumph of her
'header purse. I remained until the
auction was clpsed, witnessing the viru-
lence of human being against human
being,-the pride of creatures elevated
to stations in which ¿heir vulgarity became
more disgusting,-the meaness of petty
advantage seekers,-the cupidity and
heart-hardedness of the world. As I
burned away I involuntarily gaye utterance
¿oHhese feelings, but it was no matter.
-'They cannot be 'bid. Let them be ex-
pressed.
XINES,byJ-, K
The heart devoid of feeling
,, Is like a sileqt luje,
Í, i $° spun,d of song revealiflg,
... B,ut echoless <and mute. ;
tU < Yet while the lute will ever
\ To qvery,touch reply,
The chill heart wakens never
r, The tones of sympathy 1
nor; ' The marble statue seemeth
.w~ '! ' The being of the dreams
M1 The youthful poetdreameth
t t '-> ' Beside his native streams ;
.?.j< ,E'cn take the'brightest roset
'ij ' * Its beauty to enfold,
The same it'still reposes,
' u ' As motionless and cold !
How bpáutiful soever
/The föiijyform maybe,
' "" If,We,fri,Yáin endeavor
\ ' To wake its sympathy,
° If joy rio smile elicit,'
* 0r 'uoe no sorrow-shower»,
That soulless pne, what is it ?
A statue qrpiyned.with flowers 1
'Hpbart-town,' Way 1837.'
MAUKSBS fir oua ANCESTORS.-Lord Dor-
chester having no wife to do the honors of his
table at Thoresby, imposed that task upon his
» eldestdauguter, as soon as she had bodily strength
for the office, which in those days required no
small share, for the mistress of a country man-
sion was not only to invite-that is, urge and
tease-her company to eat more than human
throats could conveniently swallow, but to carve
every dish, when chosen, with her own hands.
The greater the lidy, the more indispensable
the duty,-each joint was carried up in its turn,
to be operated upon by her, and her alone;
since the peels and knights on either hand weie
so far from being bound to offer their assistance,
that the very master of the house, posted oppo-
site to her, might not act as her croupier ; his
department was to push the bottle after dinner.
As for the crowd of guests, the most inconsider-
able among them-the curate, or subaltern, or
squire's younger brother-if suffered through her
neglect to help himself to a slice of the mutton
placed before him, would have chewed it in bit-
terness, and gone home an affronted man, half
inclined to give a wrong vote at the next elec-
tion. There were dien professed carving mas
teis, who taught young ladies the art scientific-
ally; from one of whom Lady Mary said she
took lessons three times a-week, that she might
be perfect on her father's public days ; when in
order to perform, her functions without interrup-
tion, she was forced to eat her own dinner alone
an hour or two beforehand_Lord Jf harncliffe's
Correspondence of Lady W. Montague.
INFLUENCE OK AccincNTAL CIRCUMSTANCES
ON THE Arr-LicATioN OP'MIND.-The illustrious
French Naturalist, Adanson, was in very early
life distinguished by his proficiency in i classical
studies. In his first years at College, he ob-
tained the highest prizes in Greek and Latin
poetry, on which occasion he was presented with
the works of Pliny and Aristotle. Tlie interest
which such a circumstance could not fail to give
to the works of these ancient enquirers into ni»,
turc, led him to pay so much attention to the
subjects of which they treated, that when he was!
scarcely thirteen years of age, he wrote some1
valuable notes on the volumes that had been
given to reward his studies of a different kind.
Vancanson, the celebrated mechanician, who, in
every thing which did not relate to his art,
show ed so much stupidity, that it has been said
of him, that he was as much a machine as any
of the machines which he made-happened,
when a boy, to be long and frequently shut up
in a room in which there w as nothing but a
clock, which, therefore, as the only object of
amusement, he occupied himself with examin-
ing, so as at last to discover the connexion and
uses of its parts ; and the construction of ma-
chines was afterwards his constant delight and
occupation -Brown's Lectures on the Philosophy
of the Human Mind.
PROPHETIC POWER BEFORE DEATH.-Sir H.
Halford gives the following extraordinary in-
stance of this supposed prophetic power:-<* A
young gentleman, who had been using mercury,
caught cold while under its influence, and be-
came affected with fever. On the seventh day,
when Sir Henry was first called in, he was in a
state of the highest excitement, threatening those
around him, and not to be approached without
increasing his irritation to fury. He was put
under restraint, and tartarized antimony admi-
nistered at intervals, in doses of a grain each
time. On the eleventh day from the commence-
ment of the attack he became quite calm, and
to those about him he seemed much better. It
was observed that he had repeatedly said he
should die, and talked with the utmost compo-
sure of his affairs, giving directions for their ar-
rangement. Ile sent messages to his absent
friends, and spoke of a sister recently dead as
one whom he was about immediately to follow.
In answer to his interrogations, Sir Henry found
that he had not slept anterior to his quietude,
and that his pulse was quicker than ever. He
then became satisfied that the improvement was
but in appearance, that it was ' a lightning be-
fore death,' and that the hours of the patient
were numbered. He died that night."
HOME.-Plome is the place where a man is
principally at his ease. It is the place where
he most breathes his native air : his lungs play
without impediment; and every respiration
brings a pure element, and a cheerful and gay
frame of mind. Home is the place where he
most easily accomplishes all his designs : he has
his furniture and materials, and the elements
of his occupations entirely within his reach.
Home is the place where he can be uninter-
rupted. He is in a castle which is his in full
propriety. No unwelcome guests can intrude ;
no harsh »mnds can disturb his contemplations ;
he is the master, and can command a silence
equal to that of the tomb, whenever he pleases.
William Godwin.
EnucATioN.-No person of a sober and en-
larged mind can for a moment delude himself
into the opinion, that when he is delivered into
his own bands, his education is ended. In a sense
to which no one is a stranger, the education of
man andhis life terminate together. We should at
no period of our existence, be backward to re-
ceive information, and should at all times pre-
serve our minds open to conviction. We should,
through every day of our lives, seek to add to the
stores of our knowledge and refinement.-Ibid.

title: The Little Laureate's Competition.
content:
Tho Little Laureate's Competition,
THE SPELLING LESSON.
Jackie didn't like his lessons
Hated spelling worst of all;
Such a fuss about a letter,
If he wrote, "I play at bal,"
Who would care, except a teacher,
For a tiny fault like that?
Down went pen, and off flew Jackie
' For the postman knocked rat-tat.
Ha! a letter, too, for Jackie,
Come from Brighton. Uncle Joe,
What he needed for his birthday,. :
Straight by post would like to know.
No more grumbling now from Jackie,
Paper, pen, he called for quick.
"Dearest Uncle," wrote while smiling,
"I do think you are a brick."
"Rabbits I am very fond of
The new sort that's rather rare,
Mother sends her love and Susie,
Could you let me have a pair?
"Now good-bye, your loving Jackie."
Off the letter went at once.
But next week, upon the birthday,
Puzzled was the little dunce.
By a small brown paper parcel,
Coming from his "Uncle Joe,
With some common pears inside it
Three a penny ones, you know.
"Stupid Uncle Joe!" he shouted,
' Stamped his foot, and tore his hair,
Till his teacher softly whispered, .
"Jackie, how did you spell pair?"
Very red turned Master Jackie,
Nothing more had he to say;
Uncle Joe had taught a lesson,
And-the rabbits came next day.
Sent by Violet Skyring, E. Bundaberg, age 13
years. . .

title: On The Track.
content:
On The Track.
To some chaps whom I meet on the track,
£ would like a few words, to address,
Though I mayn't have a Tennyson's knack,
My words are sincere, none the less.
When you meet a man travelling alone,
Whom you fancy still tries to go straight,
Don's talk in a sorrowful bone,
But greet him the same as your mate.
Don't) be down-hearted, hopeless and grave,
Bat laughing, and merry, and gay,
And of fancied injustice don't lave,
The evils enough for the day.
Inspire him with hope If you can, ?
Just toll him the union 11 win,
Give him faith in his own fellowman,
Say ' goodbye ' with a shake of your fin.
Tbdthpcl Dick,

title: LINES
content:
LINES ON HEARING A LADY SING
"THE SOLDIER TIRED OF WAR'S ALARMS."
The Soldier, tir'd of War's alarms,
Still lets his Fancy soar--
When woman gives to music, charms.
It never knew before!
The brazen Trumpet, loud and shrill,
Blown by the Warrior strong,
Could not with such an ardour fill,
As lovely Woman's song!
And O! who lives, that oft alarm'd
Upon the Battle Plain,
Would not--to be again so charm'd,
Rush on--and fight again!
M.
THE Chief Justice recently observed in Court, that the
pressure of business, executive and judicial, prevented
his forming any systematic arrangements for the conve-
nient despatch of his duty. His Honor's health, natu-
rally delicate, is evidently becoming again impaired, by
intensity of application.
A RESIDENT in Pitt Street remarks, that on Monday
evening, some persons who were celebrating an Irish
wedding, with the marrow-bones and cleavers, (still
peaceable in their demeanour) were summoned by the
posse comitatus, and lodged in durance vile! At a later
and more unseasonable hour, a really disorderly assem-
blage annoyed the inhabitants, by fighting and creating
an uproar, but not a constable then was within hearing.

title: And So.
content:
And So.
Sive Isn't very witty, she isn't very "wise,
Bult when a girl has dimples, and glittering stars
for eyes,
And hair like sunshine gleaming, and voice both
sweet and'low,
A little blt of nothing is all she needs to know.
She does not talk of X-rays,, or internecine strife;
Of Eastern persecution, or ills ,that bother life;
Of massacres in China, inhabitants of Mars
And Bho adores lighJt vaudeville, not operatic stars.
She has no aspirations, she longs for no career;
She has no wish for suffrage, of tyrant man no
fear;. ? .". ? ?
She never wrote a novel, a poem, or a play
And she prefers a bonnet to laurel'leaves^-or bay.
She's never Iheard of microbes, bacteriaj and' the
like; ?
Of sociologie - questions-why workmen - have to
strike;
Why some haveuall the money, and some have .all
the work; .'
Or why the poor Armenian, is harassed by the
Turk. -
But, oh, ; ehiQ smiles and dimples at everything
that's said;
And, oh, her hair is golden, and, oh, .her lips are
red!
Her eyes aire real cerulean, her voice is sweet
and, so . ?
A little bit of nothing is all she meeds to. know.

title: Miss Walker—A Proposal.
content:
Miss Walker-A Proposal.
Will you marry a pardon, Miss Walker?
Will you wed with a reverend man ?
Will you live on a hundred per annum,
And he glad to get that if you can P
Will you go with umbrellas and pattens
To visit the poor in the rain ?
Can you give up your velvets and satins?
Wear ginghams and mousseline delaine ?
You have nice little feet, dear Miss
Walker, .
And a figure with scarce any faults?
Will you willingly give up the polka,
And only look on at a waltz ?
Can you lay by Mozart and Beethoven ?
Teach charity children to squall ?
Instead of your painting and sketching,
Draw plans of the journeys of Paul?
Will you please the entire congregation?
Keep all the societies hot ?
Work to death if you're fit for the station ?
Be abused like a thief if you're hot ?
Will you make morning calls round the
city
On people who bother and pester ye 1
Will you sit on the ladies' committee,
And work till it's dark in the vestry ?
Can you bear to let little Eliza
Use old hat bands for trimming her
bonnet,
Nor send her to school, 'cause the money
Must buy beef, we might have spent on
it?
Will you try, dear Miss Walker, to teach
' her>
French at home out of Levizac's
grammar?
Will you let little Bob be a preacher,
Though unwilling, and born with a
stammer ? '
Won't you marry a parson, Miss Walker ?
Won't you wed with a reverend man ?
Won't you live on a hundred per annum,
And be glad to get that if you can?
Will you stand by your husband when
slighted?
By men who make light of his pains,
Who have more than ten times of his in
come,
And less than a' tithe of his brains ?
Over 70,000 people in London live by crime.
Clifton Bridge, at Bristol, is 280ft above low
water mark.
Only about one out of every 1000 married
couples live to celebrate their golden wedding.
In China all wines ai e drunk hot. The thrifty
Chinaman believes that heated wine intoxicates
more expeditiously than cold wine.
The largest perfumery distillery in the world is
at Cannes, in the South of France, where over
500,0001b of flowers are used every year.
The first London Bridge was of wood. It was
built in 1014. The second was of stone, built in
1209. New London Bridge, the present one, was
begun in 1824.

title: On the Beach.
content:
On the Beach.
Sinuous southward and sinuous northward the shim
mering band
Of the sánd-heaoh fastens the fringe of the marsh to
toe folds of tho land.
Inward and'outward to northward and southward the
braoh linos linger and ourl < ,1
As a Bilver-wrought garment that dings to and follows
tho firm, bweet limbs of a girl.
Vanishing, swerving, evermore ourving ¿again into
sight,
Softly the sand-bea oh wavers away to-a dim, gray
looping of light.

title: ORIGINAL POETRY.
content:
ORIGINAL POETRY.
THE LAST SILENCE.
Silence across the waters of the bay,
Silence where floats a cloud upon the blue,
Some day the tired soul will slip away,
And only silence will be left to you.
Then will you sorrow? You, who cannot care.
Folding my weary hands upon my breast
Closing the eyes that are no longer fair --
Leaving the worn-out spirit to its rest.
If, but a little while, your eyes are wet,
If, but a little, for a life ill-spent;
Noting the silence-ere you quite forget;
If but a little. I shall be content.
Stanthorpe, Q.
M. BURKINSHAW

title: Tags of Verse.
content:
I Tags oí' Verse.
LINES TO A FRIEND.
Thou are ray dearest and my truest friend,
And thou hast proven it in--word and deed;
In giving thee just God hás given much,
Nor; would I dare to ask- a favor-more.
, ¿Thon wonder not that I should bare -my heart,
-Ànd tell to thee'the love that in it glows,
A.love that has nó¿mcasure to its depths,
A love .that few can feel or understand.'
Come, take my hand, and I will go with thee
Through ali this life content and satisfied;
Nor will I murmur if the."way be rough
With rock's that màké the flowers seem more,sweet.
Come, take'.my hand, and lead me where thou
. wilt;
In thee ray heart has changeless faith and trust; ¡
-Tis only in thy presence that I know
That happy sense of sweet security! J
When night has lent the earth its peace, and rest, j
And hallowed thoughts have moved my soul to
prayer, ? -
I kneel me long communing with my God, .
In deep contrition for mine every sin;
And in those prayers I murmur thy dear name, .
That lingers on my Ups in tenderness,
And plead for thee as few do ever plead,
And in that pleading know that God doth hear!

title: Befogged.
content:
Befogged.
My soul is siok with doubt and tribulation ;
The world to me a darksome chaos seems ;
My days ;. of promise fade 'neath fate's
negation,
And unrest finds me even in my dreams.
Uncertainty and doubt ¿re all around me,
And dark thoughts haunt my bosom day
by day ;
Weird shapes arise to threaten and con
found me
I hear the bell, but cannot find the way.
I cannot guide my barque across life'B ocean;
The fog is dense, and I have lost my
chart ;
I shrink with terror at the wild commotion,
And, as I listen, Lgrow sick at heart.
I hear the yesty breakers roaring near me,
And, in my agony, for help. I pray ;
But no one comes to counsel or to cheer
me
I hear the bell, but cannot find the way,
Out from the sunlight, heedless and un
thinking,
I have suiled onward till I've reached
the fog
Now from the cup of bitterness I'm drink
ing-- ?
I've lost my reckoning and kept no log.
Here I am sadly waiting for . the dawn
? ing- . . .?
The blessed dawning of a brighter day
And, while the fog-bell peals its solemn
warning,
Help me, oh, Pilot Bure, to find my way I

title: Original Poetry.
content:
Original Poetry.
A TRIFLE
(FROM THE BREAKFAST TABLE)
FOR EDESIA.
SWEET girl, I knew not thou was't free,
Or else I would have courted thee:--
One who can write with so much taste,
And sing so sweet, and sing so chaste,
II.
Indeed is worthy to possess
A being who such charms could bless;
Besides, I see too by your ditty
You are both sensible and witty!
III.
I might upbraid--yet how could I
A single look of anger try,
Towards one who smiles with so much grace,
And has too such an Angel's face!
IV.
Yet why have you so anxious strove
To make me be both "Hand and Glove"?
It needs no argument to prove
In this you must be wrong my love!
V.
And would I really sneak away,
And not a single Farewell say?
Oh! no--you have not lost me yet,
You'll find me in the next Gazette!
Fort-street, Friday morning.
NOT A GLOVE.
Tht're is an important notice from the
Collector of Internal Revenue in another column
respecting the quit-rents due from Sydney, to wh'ch
wepailicularly direct the attention of parties holding
property in the town.
A free man, named Kearney, hired
servant to Mr. G L. Poignand, the Solicitor, wai»
brought before the Police Bench, yesterday, charged
with making away w th several articles of silver
plate entrusted to his charge. The pris'oner, who
stated himself to be a Frenchman, had been only
fourteen days in his present employment and f om
the circumstance of his being absent from his service
during the whole oí Wednesday, and returning home
at night in a beastly state of intoxication, Mr.
Poignantl' deemed it prudent to relieve him,of tho
charge with which he was entrusted, but on mus-
tering the articles which had been delivered to bim,
one silver dessert spoon, two silver salt spoons, and
some otjier trifling articles were discovered to be
absent. Upon being questioned as to what had be-
come of his master's property, the prisoner was ex-
cessively insolent and abusive, anil denied having
received the aiticles which were missing, upon which
Mr. Poignand gave him into custody. When brought
befoie the-bench, the prisoner stated that he left
the whole of his master's spoons in. the kitchen when
ho went out in tffe morning, andas there did not
appear to beany evidence contradictory of this state-
ment, and as Mr. P. stated that other persons had
aeccss to the kitchen, the Magistrate did not think
there was a sufficient case made out to:be sent before
a jury, and the prisoner was consequently discharged,
l'ne bench, however, advised the prisoner, as ho
valued his repu ation to make diligent seaich after
the lost articles, in order that they might be restored
to his master, or the Police would have a sharp look,
out after him.

SCHOOL OF AKTS.-The debating class in
connection with this institution held its
usual weekly meeting last evening, when the
subject discussed related to the recent peti
tion of ccrtnin Tasmanian colonists against
the form of constitution now obtniniug in
that colony. The question to be decided
was-whether tho existence of such a peti-
tion was to bo regalded as indicativo of the
failure of responsible government iu that
colony ; and, after a warm debate, it was
decided in the negative by a largo majority.
The subject chosen for noxt Thursday even-
ing is as follows :-" Which would tend
most to tho advancement of Queensland
the discovery of a serios of gold-Qolds, or
the ostensivo cultivation of cotton ?"

title: ORIGINAL POETRY.
content:
0RI6MAI.P0ETRY.
TROPIC DREAMS.
Wag it a sail that flittered'past in the beam
of a wintry sun,
■Xiike' a mothwing caught on'a pixie'mast,
* where the 'spider halyards run.
Was it a ilbn'd that sfooped so .low that it
: seemed a mountain crest? . .
Ieannot tell, but 1. only know that my
thoughts "went hurrying west/
Right in the path of the gold sun's track,
where the tropic islands Jie,
Till I .saw a palm like a finger black on a
. .tailless sweep of sky. .
And a-clear lagoon, where a . lazy shark
' scarce^tumed:' as the fish' shoal -sped, ■
While the red and, snow. of. the "wild fish.
" "hawk swung out in the blue o'erhead. ■
And coiled asleep in the yellow sand at the
. edge of the jungle's hush . ■
A shining snake like a copper band lay under
.'a thorny bush. '
And in the depths where the forest heart
' as night in the noon hour lies
I saw where the leaves were thrust apart,
the glitter of golden eyes. ■
M. FORREST.

title: Our Country.
content:
Our Country.
You may sing of English homesteads,
With their fields of golden corn,
Or the hedge of pearly hawthorn
In the dewy summer morn !
You may boast the calm sweet beauty
Of the old home o'er the sea,
But, give me the yellow wattle
And Australia young and free.
You may sing old Scotia's praises,
Blooming heath, or stern hill side
Granite, peat, or fertile valley,
Where Bruce fought, how Wallace died.
You may boast her men unconquered,
And her freedom none would sell,
But, of better nobler triumphs,
Yet our history shall tell.
You may sing of Tara's princes,
Brave and strong, in days of old,
And may say, in Erin's service
One true heart shall ne'er grow cold.
But I'll sing of fair Australia,
And her onward destiny,
Of her acres yet unconquered,
Of her homes secure and free.
Where, from ancient wrongs delivered—
Briton, Saxon, Gael, or Scot
May rejoice in quarrels vanished—
Battles ended, feuds forgot.
—M.W.

title: Original Poetry.
content:
Original Poetry.
ON SEEING LORD BYRON'S WORKS BOUND IN
ASS'S SKIN.
SINCE Byron all poets in wildness surpasses,
His works have been bound (perhaps) in skins of wild asses,
No disgrace to the Bard---that they thought it no sin,
But the rudeness without suits the wildness within!
But as an apology for making so bold,
The binding is handsomely finished with gold.
His was the genius which conspicuous shone,
With splendid native brightness---all his own!
And 'twas his art each bosom to inspire,
With heaven-born rapture when he tuned his lyre,
His flights were daring, his ideas wild,
But all was beauty when th' enthusiast smiled---
As when some wild tornado rends the skies,
Through heaven's dark void the vengeful lightning flies,
And ten-fold thunders shake the solid land---
The scene, though dreadful, is sublimely grand!
But when again the sun's bright orb is seen,
And new-born radiance beams through heaven serene
Harmony reigns where discord raged before,
And fear, and terror, fright the soul no more!
T. K.
H. M. Ship Fly, Sydney Cove, 23d Sept. 1826.
newspaper: The Sydney Gazette and New South Wales Advertiser

title: Sidelights.
content:
Sidelights.
~-A
' By "IXION."
America.
I
THINK America must be
A most peculiar land,
According to the picture shows,
You see on every hand.
A place where cowboys ge about
The streets of every town
With sawed off shotguns in their
belts
For shooting people down.
Where fellows loaf around the pubs,
In Texan hatted pate,
Remarking to each other: "Well,
I guess an calkerlate!"
Or spend their days in galloping
Up mountain slopes and down,
And after them, in hot pursuit.
The sheriff of the town.
Where everybody seems to eat
A food they call "hot dogs,"
And criminals a fortune make
By selling poisoned grogs.
And, O the morals of the place!
The utter disregard of law!
But here, perhaps, it may be well
The curtain for to draw.
They're Off.
PN route to the seaside with his wife,
?Lj the Western squatter stayed off a
day in Brisbane to see the races.
Scorching and sweltering ni the
grand stand, he mentioned to his wife
that he would like to remove his coat.
"Don't you do anything of the
kind," she answered. "RememL-jr,
you're not out on the run now. You
can't do these things down here !"
He took off the coat, however, and
in a little while proposed also to re-
move his waistcoat.
"Do have some sense of decency,"
she said. "I'm really ashamed of you.
What will you do next?"
But he took off the vest all the
same. In disgust she turned her back
on him. "I don't want to let people
see I'm with you," she said testily.
Just then a woman who had been
watching the race start cried out,
"They're off. They're off."
The wife fainted.
With Wilkins.
O YOU who tread the narrow way
^ From house to office day by day,
Do you not long to be away
With Wilkins down in Grahamland?
Who face the stewy summer heat
In stuffy office, sweaty street,
Would you not like to take a seat
With Wilkins over Grahamland?
Enmeshed in routine, hopelessly",
To be the man you'd like to be;
To nam the world's wide spaces, free,
Like Wilkins down in Grahamland?
To take the risk and test your worth
In all the corners of the earth,
From nether pole to tropics girth.
With Wilkins down in Grahaimand?
But there he is and here you be,
A standardised epitome,
While Wilkins soars the Polar Sea
Away below in Grahamland.
And thus you stay and eat your rice.
And dream of him, and say: How nice
To oe with Wilkins o'er the ice
Down there below in Grahamland!
Looks Familiar.
XJE was an enthusiastic fisherman,
±x and had been spending the week-
end down the Bay. There was an
amateur photographer in the party,
and what should be more natural than
that he should have his picture taken,
rod hi hand, standing by the 601b. cod
that he had caught.
He showed it proudly to Jownes at
the Fisherman's Club. Jownes has the
reputation of having seen every fish
of any consequence that has come out
of the Bay.
"And what do you think of it?" ask-
ed the proud captor.
"Well," said Jownes, "It's a first
rate picture of you. But somehow that
cod looks familiar to me."
The Next Generation.
V\7ITH 1000 persons killed' and 15,000
wounded in Australia by motor
cars last year, the natural process of
eliminating the unfit is making great
progress. The next generation will
probably have evolved the following
characteristics:
Faculty of instantaneously springing
a safe distance either forwards, back-
wards, or sideways.
Ability to vault from standing, either
over the bonnet of a moving car or
over the hood, or even the full length
of the car.
Capacity to discern a car anywhere
within 90deg. of a circle of sight.
Ability to turn a back or front somer-
sault or handspring instantaneously.
Pedestrians possessing these qualifi-
cations will be licensed to cross streets
unaccompanied by the police.
The Southport Road.
Scene I.
("IN the Southport-road the sun was
v-' glaring down. It was the very
last day any motorist would select to
change a tyre. An awfully pretty girl
and a young man pulled in beside the
road. The youth got down to Investi-
gate the trouble. "Hang it all," he
said, "it's a blow out. I haven't
brought a Jack. Stop here till I go
and look for a sapling to lever the
wheel up!"
Scene 2.
Several cars driven by youths with
pretty girls pull up beside, and tact-
fully proffer assistance to the pathetic
young lady standing beside the car.
But realising how pretty she was, their
own girls became impatient and egg
them to go on.
Scene 3.
A couple of middle-aged married
men, out for the week-end, pull up,
and sternly insist on remedying the
trouble. Perspiring profusely they
work till they complete the job. The
young man concealed in the timber
sticks his head out from time to
time.
When the heroic middle-aged have
been thanked, and departed, the young
man comes out of his hiding place.
"By jingo," he said, "those old birds
made a good job of it!"
Original Ideas.
"TjEPOStTOR : I received a letter
J-/ from my bank manager the other
day notifying me that his directors
would be glad if I would reduce my
credit balance before the end of the
year.
I pulled myself together, and re-
read the document. Yes, it said
"Credit Balance" all right.
I reached for my hat, and went
down and saw the manager. "What's
the meaning of this?" I asked. "I
thought vou people liked to have
credit balances."
"The old directors did." he said,
"but there's a fresh lot in now with
very original ideas. Seeing that de-
positors will insist on hoarding up
money in bad times, they hold that
the practice only accentuates and pro-
longs depressions. The new policy is
to encourage people to save money in
good times, when it is plentiful, and
to put it into circulation when times
are bad and good investments are
going .begging."
"But the bank invests my credit
money?"
"Partly, but we, too, were wont to
tighten up and call up money in bad
times. In future all that sort of
thins will be done away with."
"Well," I said, "of all the muddle
brained, wild-cat, silly schemes I've
ever heard of, this beats 'em all."
And Just then I awoke.

title: NATIVE POETRY.
content:
NATIVE POETRY.
Nung-Ngnun.
Nge a runba wonung bulkirra umbilinto bulwarra;
Pital burra kultan wirripang buntoa
Nung-Ngnun
Nge a runba turrama berrambo, burra kilkoa:
Kurri wi, raratoa yella walliko,
Yulo Moane, woinyo, birung poro bulliko,
Nung-Ngnun
Nge a rumba kan wullung, Makoro, kokein,
Mip-pa-rai, kekul, wimbi murr ring kirrika:
Nge a runba mura ké-en kulbun kulbun murrung.
There is a god of Poesy, Wallatu, who composes
music, and who, without temple, shrine, or statue, is as
universally acknowledged as if his oracles were breathed
by Belus or Csiris: he comes in dreams, and transports
the individual to some sunny hill, where he is inspired
with the supernatural gift.
E. H. DUNLOP.
Mulla Villa, September 25.
Translated and Versified by Mrs. Dunlop.
Our home is the gibber-gunyah,
Where hill joins hill on high;
Where the turruma and berrambo,
Like sleeping serpents lie;--
And the rushing of wings, as the wangas pass,
Sweeps the wallaby's print from the glistening grass.
Ours are the makoro gliding,
Deep in the shady pool:
For our spear is sure, and the prey secure--
Kanin, or the bright gherool.
Our lubras sleep by the bato clear,
That the Amygest's track hath never been near.
Ours is the koolema flowing,
With precious kirrika stored:
For fleet the foot, and keen the eye,
That seeks the nukkung's hoard;--
And the glances are bright, and the footsteps are free,
When we dance in the shade ot the karakun tree.
Glbber-gunya--Cave in the rock.
Turruna and Berrambo--War arms.
Wanga--A species of pigeon.
Makoro--Fish.
Amygest--White-fellow.
Kanim--Eel.
Gheerool--Mullet.
Bato--Water.
Kirrika--Honey.
Nukkung--Wild bee.
Karrakun--The oak-tree.

title: THE BREWER.
content:
THE BREWER.
Jolly brewer! Go home and brew--
Your ale may be good, but it's rather new;
Stow it away for another year--
It's dangerous drinking--is all new beer.
Go back to your cellar, and bung the vat--
When liquor runs over, it soon grows flat;
New beer and sour we'll never endure--
Go back or the thing'll be past all cure.
Go back to your brewing! Go back, go back!
You gave us beer, and we give you the sack;
Go back to your house in Woolloomooloo,
Or it's mischief instead of beer you'll brew!
X. B.

title: ORIGINAL POETRY.
content:
© 'fGIWAL WOETRIf.
BY SUMMER SEAS.
' O Summer days!
Tlie dayswheh earth goes singing,
With sea and sky, ofie. full-toned paean ring
ing! ' . - r '
When great green waves up- to gold sand
" come flinging ~ '
Their lacy -wealth—so prodigal of dreams
Foam jewels, flashing to Heaven sapphire
• gleams, .' # •
While through Joy's leaping pulse' Life's
wine-song streams—
0 Summer days!
• O Summerinights 1
The nights'when-duslr comes stealing,
Mysterious, a-thrill, yet- h11 revealing.
Within the heart, its pain no more eon
' cealing,
Dear Grief, in ecstasy of longing, lays
Jier hallowed hands on doors of secret ways,
Where drift sweet odours from love-gar
nered days
O Summer nights!
. O. Summer dawns . . .
The dawns that waken burning
To fling aside pearl mists! W7hen blue
tides, yearning, ■
Swing outward for-your,kiss—the pale sand
spurning— '
.While' rose-red skies stjoop to the dark
green trees.
And through their glistening boughs limn
flashing seas—
The tiredest heart you wake to praise for
these,
O Summer dawns!
M. B. PATON.

title: Facts and Fancies.
content:
Facts and Fancies.
THE WRONG SHIP FOR BIDDY.
PORTANTER.
P ADDY, mon frere, we should but poorly fare
Throughout all dull and sober Christendom
Sons thy sweet tongue and humor debonnaire,
That have been, are. and shall for ever come,
as sparaunr mirth unto us graver fools,
Who wend through grooves and tamelv bow to rales.
If thou of piquant nose and mellow brogue
•should stoop to servile fashions more In rone.
Thou wonldst bnt ape severer man, and mar
The choicest, queerest gift to earth, thru far.
Biddy, ma chert, if bungling Pat seems queer
Twixt bis potato-face and native wit—
With crowning bine-black hair. then art!-)fol{l) dear.
Eyes set in glorious contrast, cheeks to fit,
Art nature's triumph I And we joy to see
Pat's vein in thee is drollest witchery.
Thus Pat, and Biddy true maid, thus remain,
Destin'd from fair ancestral Spain to tread,
Milesian lords and ladies, aptly bred.
But to my theme. Oar good ship had been oat
A hundred days, when darkly through the baas
Of ocean loomed a vessel, and the shont
That erected her caused mate and men to raise
Onr signals high, whereat tbe shadow's prond
Responsive Bags revealed the " Flying Cloud;"
Her speaking ribands told, to our dismay,
" Out seventy days;" " London to Moreton Bay."
We looked aghast, and groaning deep and load,
From our staunch "tub" uprose to yard and shroud,
Again waxed Luna, and again she waned
Ere our dull orbs winked wink with Horeton's star.
Scarce had the swarthy pilot welt explained
The " Cloud's " arrival hack a fortnight far.
Than thereupon sweet Biddy did aver
We should have sooner reached this Au.trilyer
Had we but stayed at home, nor thus have come:
Her dainty lips so spoke—our own were " mum."
(Tbe friends she bade adieu iu Cork that year
Adown the Brisbane came to welcome her.)
To become a lion of a party it it not necessary
to make a beast of one's self.
Why is a henpecked husband like an opera
hat F—Because he's very big when he's out, but
immediately shuts up when he gets home.
Rbabonabli.—" Why do you choose a single
life P" asked a fashionable idler of an estimable
young lady. "Because," she replied, 'I am
not able te support a husband."
Lboitucatb Business.—A doctor went out
for a day's hunting, and, on coming home, com*
plained tbat he hadn't killed anything. " That's
because you didn't attend to your legitimate
business," said his wife.
Judicial Joki.—ln Judge M'Arthur's court,
recently, a lawyer called the judge's attention to
the fact that a certain case had been upon the
docket for a decade. " I know it," said the
judge, " but the case has not decayed."
Hairs, not Bristles—" I am willing to
split bairs with my opponent all day if he insist*
on it," said a oelebratnd Irish lawyer, in a
speech at the bar. " Bpilt tbat, then," said tha
opponent, pulling a specimen from his own
head, and extending it. " May it please your
lordship, I didn't say bristles," was the response.
Truth ik Jest.—A Scotoh postmaster,
puzzling out a very unocrtain superscription to
an Irish letter, jocosely remarked to an intelli
gent son of Erin who stood by that the Irish
brought a hard set of names to Scotland,
" That's a fact, yer honor," replied the Irishman,
"but they get harder ones after they arrive
here."
No Laughing Matter.—ln the Paris.
theatres professional laughers are employed, who
engage to indulge iu tbe most contagious hilarity,
the time of their merriment being previously
arranged. A few nights sinoe the programme
was changed without the knowledge of one of
the laughers, and when he burst forth up
roariously in the midst of a touching couplet
about Alsace and Lorraine, the audience nearly
killed him.
Touching Gratitude.—A little boy, the
child of a wealthy mother, tumbled into the
river. He was rescued by a working man and
restored to his brokenhearted parent. The
woman gave him a penny postage-stamp, and
said she would be glad to have him come up to
her house and sit out in the entry and hear her
play tbe piano. He went away with tears in hit
eyes. He said he wasn't used to suoh over
whelming kindness.
Artful.—An engaged young gentleman got
rather neatly out o( a little scrape with bia
intended. She taxed him with having kissed
two youn^ ladies at some party at which she
was not present. He owned it, but said that
their united ages only made twenty-one. The
simple-minded girl thought of ten and eleven,
and laughed off her pout. He did not explain
tbat one was nine een and the other two yean
of age. Wasn't it aitful? Just like the men I
Judging by Appkabancbs.—A printer whose
voice and hearing were considerably impaired,
bat who wished to create as little inconvenience
as possible by these defects, found it necessary
one day to put a question to a short sighted
fellow-workman in aa o ' ce whioh he had just
entered. This he did in writing, but was asked,
in tbe proverbial Scotch style of asking another
question instead of answering tbat put: "Do
you think I am deaf booause I wear speos P"
A Caution to Housewives —The following,
of course, happened in Paris:—A servant
entered her mistress* apartments, crying and
sobbing, " Madame! oh, madame 1" " What is
the matter, Franchise P" " Madame, I have
stuck a fork into my finger." " Oh, that's
nothing, Francoise; you will not feel it to
morrow." " I should not be afraid, Madams,
if I was sure the fork was silver." " You may,
then, be perfeotly easy ; tbe fork is—all our
forks are silver." " Oh! then I don't feel
alarmed ; but I was dreadfully frightened, for I
thought the fork was plated." Francoise dis
appeared, taking all the forks with her.
A Goon Dinner and its Cost.—A couple of
flat-boat men on tbe Mississippi River, having
made an extraordinary good speculation, con
cluded that while they were in New Orleans
they would for once in their lives see what it
was to have a real first-class hotel dinner. Tbey
could afford it, and they would just like to see
how it would go. So they went to the St.
Charles Hotel and ordered the very best dinner
tbat establishment could afford. When tbey
had eaten to their complete and entire satisfac
tion (and the probable surprise of the waiters),
they called for their bill. Tbe waiter in attend
ance misunderstood tbem, and, supposing they
wanted the bill of fare, laid it before tbem,
with the wine list uppermost. " Whew, Bill,"
said Jerry, " hire's a bill! Just look at it!
Here, you add up one side, and I'll add up tbe
other, and we'll see what tho old thing comes
to." So Bill added up tho prices of the wines
on one side of the list, aud Jerry added them
up on tbe other, and they made the sum total
554 dollars. " Wh-ew, Hill," said Jerry, " that's
pretty nigh all we've gt! What are you going
to do about it ?" aWe can't piy that," cried
Bill) " it'ud clean us rk'ht out. Tbe waiter
ain't here now ; lot's jump out o' tbe window
and cut." " No, siree," said Jerry, " I'd never
do such a mean thing us tbat. Let's pay the
bill, and then go downstairs and shoot the land
lord."
Caution.—One day at Blair Alhol, the Duke,
having entertained a largo party at dinner, pro
duced in the evening many curious and inte
resting family relies for their inspection, anongst
them a small watch which hud belonged to
Charles Stuart, und hud boon givcu by him to
one of the Duke's ancestor*. When the company
were on the point of departing, tho watch was
suddenly missed, und was searched for in vain
upon the table and about the apartments.
Tbe luke was exoeedirgly vexfd, and deolared
that of all the articles be Lad exhibited tbe lost
watob was the one he most valued. The guests
naturally became exceedingly uncomfortable,
and eyed each other suspiciously. No person
was present however who could possibly be sus
pected, and courtesy forbade any stronger step
than the marked expression of tiro noble host's
extreme annovur.ee »"•<' distress. Euoh de
parted to his homo iu an exceedingly unenviable
state of mind, aud tbe mysterious disappearance
of the royal relio was a suljeot of discussion
for several months in society. A year afterwards,
the Duke, being again at Blair Athol.was dressing
for dinner, and iu the braast pocket of a coat
which his valet bad handed to him felt some- *
thing, which proved to be tho missing watch.
"Why, ," exclaimed bis Grace, addressing
his man by name, " here's tbe watch we hunted
everywhere in vain for!" " Yes, sir," replied
the man, gravely ; " I saw your Grace put it in
your pocket." " You caw me put it injo mr
pocket, and never mentioned it! Why didn t
you speak at once, and prevent all that trouble
and unpleasant feeling." " I didna ken what
might hae been your Grace's intentions," was
tbe reply of the faithful and discreet Highlander,
who saw everything, but said nothing, unless
' directly interrogated.

title: THE GENTLE WATER BIRD.
content:
THE GENTLE WATER BIRD.
(FOR MARY GILMORE.)
In the far days, when every day was long,
Fear was upon me and the fear was strong,
Ere I had learned the recompense of song.
In the dim days I trembled, for I knew
God was above me, always frowning through,
And God was terrible and thunder-blue.
Creeds the discoloured awed my opening mind,
Perils, perplexities-what could I find?-
All the old terror waiting on mankind.
Even the gentle flowers of white and cream,
The rainbow with its treasury of dream,
Trembled because of God's ungracious scheme.
And in the night the many stars would say
Dark things unaltered in the light of day;
Fear was upon me ever in my play.
There was a lake I loved in gentle rain;
One day there fell a bird, a courtly crane;
Wisely he walked, as one who knows of pain.
Gracious he was and lofty as a king;
Silent he was, and yet he seemed to sing
Always of little children and the Spring.
God? Did he know him? lt was far he flew-
God was not terrible and thunder-blue;
-It was a gentle water-bird I keow.
Pity was in him for the weak and strong,
All who have suffered when the days were long,
And he was deep and gentle as a song.
As a calm soldier in a cloak of grey
He did commune with me for many a day
Till the dark fear was lifted far away.
Sober-apparelled, yet he caught the glow;
Always of heaven would he speak, and low,
And he did tell me where the wishes go.
Kinsfolk of his it was who long before
Came from the mist (and no one knows the
shore)
Came with the little children to the door.
Was he less wise than those birds long ago
Who flew from God (He surely willed it so)
Bearing great happiness to all below?
Long have I learned that all his speech was
true:
I cannot reason it-how far he flew
God ls not terrible nor thunder-blue.
Sometimes, when watching in the white sun-
shine,
Someone approaches-I can half define
All the calm beauty of that friend of mine.
Nothing of hatred will about him cling,
Silent-how silent-but his heart will sing
Always of little children and the Spring.
SHAW NEILSON.

title: A LITTLE WHITE SHOE.
content:
A LITTLE WHITE SHOE.
A little shoe of milk-white kid,
A buckle, and a ribbon bow;
And grandma said, Not too small, dear,
The little feet will need to grow."
And father took my baby up,
And danced him gaily on his knees,
And asked, "How far upon life's road
D'you think our boy will go in these?"
And then they laughed, and asked me did
I call this vanity a shoe?
And vowed within a day I'd find
The little toes come lacking through.
A little shoe, of softest kid,
Uncrushed, unworn, for, ah! you know.
Those little, pattering baby feet
Had not so very far to go.
ELLA M'FADYEN.

title: To the Editor of the Colonial Times.
content:
To the Editor of the Colonial Times. .
