" THE RAP."
" Hetghosays the two-penny postman."
Who was it woke me from my nap,
I'm sure it was a " Tradesman's rap,"
I'm judge of BAH tho' a J. P., '
The " Times'' so often raps at me.
I
^ Oh is it Mr. Dash ?-a Head
Of a Department hither led
By proper feelings I can see, ;
To pay respects to the J. P. ,
¡ I
When I arrived I'd not a rap.
Although some sour wine to tap,
But houses now I build, you see, j
And ride my nag 'cause I'm J. É.
His Excellency did not nap i ..
; When he beheld me and did rap
My name Jn the Gazette ye see,
" Get out ye PÍEBS"
-for I'm J. P.,., .

title: SUCH NONSENSE!
content:
SUCH NONSENSE!
If rain would rain at night time,
And leave a sunny day,
If only all our lessons
Were better fun than play,
If birds came when we called them,
And all of us could fly,
If only bread and butter
Were nice as cherry pie.
If we could see the fairies
Who dance beneath the moon,
If only Monday morning
Were Sunday afternoon.
If lollypops and patties
Grew plump on every tree,
And all the boughs were laden--
How happy we should be!
ELLA MCFADYEN.

title: Theatricals.
content:
Theatricals.
ROYAL VICTORIA THEATRE.--On Monday
night last, Mr. Nesbitt performed in five dif-
ferent characters, namely, Richard the III.,
Rolla, Shylock, Othello, and Sir Giles Over-
reach. This was certainly a most arduous
undertaking--though only one act in each piece
was performed; but he proved to the public that
his physical energies were equal to his mental
endowments. We expected nothing less, but
we must say that he exceeded our most sanguine
anticipations. He was indifferently supported,
for with the exception of Simmons, Spencer,
and Mrs. Thomson, the other actors seemed to
have as much conception of their parts as we
have of the theological principles of the Great
Mogul. However, to speak candidly, we must
say that we do not admire the garbling and
cutting up of such splendid pieces, for no sooner
has the audience got interested in the act per-
formed, than it is ended, and they have to
bother their brains--always provided that they
have any--to get interested in what follows;
still such an attempt once or twice during the
season is not ill timed, and gives the actor an
opportunity of shewing the variety of his abili-
ties to the verdict of public opinion.
On Tuesday evening the Theatre was pa-
tronized by Colonel French and the officers of
the 28th Regt., which leaves in a day or two
for India, where, we are afraid, they will have
less amusement than they had that night. The
applause given by the audience even on the
entrance of the band shewed the good feeling--
we may say the commiseration--of their coun-
trymen to the proper defenders of their native
land; and we have no doubt but that they will
defend it nobly. The band did indeed "dis-
course most excellent music," and we sincerely
hope that its effect in the battle field will be as
great as it was in the Victoria on the evening
alluded to.
The play chosen for this occasion was the
MOUNTAINEERS, which Mr. Nesbitt performed to
great advantage. We would give a full report
of this piece, but our space will not allow us.
The duets "Faint and wearily the way-worn
traveller," "Oh happy Tawney Moor," and
"When the hollow drum," were very well sung
on the part of Mr. Simmons; but our opinion of
Mrs. Knowles continues unchanged,and we are
afraid ever will. The other entertainments went
off well. The Colonial farce of "THE MOCK
CATALANI" was repeated with great eclat. Pre-
vious to this, the following farewell address was
delivered by Mr. Simmons; it was, however,
much more creditable to the speaker than the
author:--
FAREWELL ADDRESS
TO THE
TWENTY-EIGHTH REGIMENT,
ON THEIR DEPARTURE TO INDIA,
SPOKEN AT THE
ROYAL VICTORIA THEATRE, SYDNEY, NEW SOUTH WALES.
ON THE EVENING OF THE 14TH JUNE, 1842.
To-night Mock Catalani reappears
To greet his friends--an office that endears;
For humbie though has been the Author's task,
'Tis welcom'd: and what more can author ask?
A kindly welcome, from indulgent friends,
Is rich reward to all intents and ends.
Thus far "Mock Catalani" makes his bow;
Another object has its author now:
To bid Farewell! unto a martial band,
About to leave us for India's distant land;
To add fresh laurels to their old renown,
And guard the honour of the British Crown:
Make the fierce, false Affghans, in far Cabul,
Grow meek to Paddy, Sawney, and Jobn Bull.
They, with their steel array will heal the sore
Inflicted, but two deep, by Forty-Four.
Bold Sale, who keeps in awe the murd'rous hashers, -
Will hail, with warrior's warmth, the gallant "Slashers,"
Their Chief will prove again their valour true,
Rememb'ring "Albuhera!"--"Waterloo!!"
The gallant "Slashers" quit Australia's shore,
And we may ne'er behold their phalanx more;
Yet in our mem'ry will they linger long,
A beau ideal of the martial throng;
And many a gentle bosom, void of guile,
Will feel a pang--sweet lips will sadden'd smile.
Brave "Twenty-Eight," who danger ne'er did shun,
Farewell! success we wish you every one.
The benefits come on shortly, but, as yet,
we are not able to tell the particular pieces that
will be performed. Mr. Nesbitt has chosen
the character of Macbeth, for his benefit, and
by what we have heard of the preparations about
to be made, it will be brought out in the most
splendid style. As to the acting of Mr. Nes-
bitt, it requires no comment.
THEATRE FRANÇAIS.--This Theatre was
tolerably filled yesterday evening. The acting
was really good, and might have passed off with
eclat in one of our largest metropolitan theatres.
We are really sorry that this was their last
appearance. The times or taste is bad in Syd-
ney when such a rational amusement is allowed
to fall to the ground.
newspaper: The Sydney Gazette and New South Wales Advertiser

title: Robes of White.
content:
Robes of White.
Morven. F. BENNETT.
In spotless white my love was clad
When first I saw her face:
On Wollondilly hill we met—
A wattle marks the place.
An iunooent and loving girl,
Her soul was whiter yet '
And purer than the robe she wore—
My own, my dear Jeannette t -
In spotless white—a dream of grace-*
My bride she stood arrayed:
Igen'ly raised her blushing face
And kissed my own dear maid. "
Half shy, yet wholly happy too,
She leaned upon my breast,
And, smiling through the starting tears,
Her trust and love confessed.
They decked her onoe again in white',
Her (ace was whiter still.
(The wattle shades her last, long sleep
On WollondiUy hill.)
The blinds were down—the voices trained;
Friends talked apart and low—
The mourners left me one by one—
I scaroely saw them go.
And once again in spotlesß white
My darling Bhall be dressed;
An angel there as hare on earth,
To endless ages blest.
Beneath the wattle oft I live
Our days of wooing o'er;
And wait on WollondiUy bill
To Join my love once more.

title: Original Poetry. [FOR THE SYDNEY GAZETTE.]
content:
Original Poetry.
[FOR THE SYDNEY GAZETTE.]
AUSTRALIAN MELODIES.
No. I.
'Tis sweet to hear the bell bird's pipe,
Like sheep-bells faintly tinkling —
To see the cloud, o'er corn fields ripe,
Its rain-drops gently sprinkling;
And rainbow's arch, of varied hue,
Extending o'er the tropic blue.
'Tis sweet to sit in shady bower,
'Midst shrubs with heav'n's dew weeping —
See Sol his rays, at evening hour,
In misty splendour steeping;
When but the lonely curlew's tale
Disturbs the silence of the vale.
But sweeter far the native maid,
Of youthful suitor dreaming —
And sweeter far the auburn shade
Whence her blue eyes are beaming;
And sweet will be N-nd-or-e's bell
When 't doth the nuptial morning tell.
YARALLA.
newspaper: The Sydney Gazette and New South Wales Advertiser

title: THE PLAINS.
content:
THE PLAINS.
--o--
The plains are silver!
The sky is white, and the fruit-blossoms are
white,
Shaking and shining in sun, an eddying haze.
The air hangs round them like unseen bees.
It rises from them laden and faint,
Beating its wings towards the mountains,
Settling on lips and nostrils.
The plains are gold!
The orange-trees waver in autumn haze.
The fruitage bursts through the green line
gold,
Or in the milder light dims and swells
Like great topazes moon-enchanted.
In the wind they are flames;
The stillness veils them in quivering smoke;
In the dusk they are vaporous echoes.
The plains are blue!
Beneath dawn, amethystine,
A runnel of lucerne-flowers;
Or, in the night-stillness of winter,
A mirror of heaven-calm,
Making flat earth an infinity
Where love creates rarer than heavenly stars.
L. H. ALLEN.

title: War a la Mode.
content:
War a Ia Mode.
(Written fois toe "Town ana Country journal."}
"Special Edition" Latest News!
The treacherous Dago bites his thumb!
M'Kinley's-own authentic views-> ? -
Spain threatens fighting. Let them come!
"We shall have seen the last of them e ?.
, To-morrow morn at 6 a.m.!"
Next day-"Poor Europe stands aghast!"
New York on all her hoardings saw;
"Those rotting kingdoms of" the past
Tremble before the Eagle's claw!
Spain grovels! For the treaty's text
Consult our columns, Tuesday next.".
Then, flashed beneath Atlantic waves,
The snarling echoes snapped the wiro:
"Pools!" "Cowards!" "Braggarts!" "Traitorsi**
"Knaves!"
"A' crushing blow!" "A vengeance dire!"
"Senors, the,Yanks are most unwise; :
We give them-what you call-surprise.'*
.With ruddiest type and caps galore .
Burst out the yellow journals' yell:
"The hostile fleet exists no more!
Five thousand Spaniards blown to hell!"
Adding, "The fight of which we speak
Will certainly take place next week."
"Our irresistible array"
(This wire was dated "Tampa, Noon"),
"Towards Havana takes its way,
And hopes to get there soma time soon.
Our correspondent makes it clear
j A battle must take place this year."
"Be sure tis not our ardor cools"
(Thus run the cablegrams to-day);
"The very children from "oúr schools
Are clamoring to join the fray;
Delay is for their sakes alone;
We wait but till they're fully erown."

title: Tags of Verse.
content:
J - * Tags of Verse, - v *
. . OPPORTUNITY. v ; i #
The "key of yesterday
I threw away, ?-;
And now, too late, ,
Before to-morrow's close-locked gata ?
Helpless I stand-in vain to pray»
In vain to sorrow ! . '
Only the' key of yesterday ,
Unlocks to-morrow!

title: Grandfather's Talks
content:
Grandfather's Talks
IN PROSE AND RHYME
TO Think and Remember.
(By WILL H. LITER)
Whenever you sec a soldier
Minns an eye, or a limb,
With armless sleeve, or on crutches,
Have a good thought for him.
There are many others disabled, .
Wheeled m sa Invalid chair,
And asms who lit helpless in cots,
And know not the out-door air.
Have a thought, my little children.
For these have suffered pain
That you should live in freedom
And ail its benefits gain.
Theirs was the spirit of Empire,
lb safeguard precious rights.
And twenty years ago to-day
They stormed OaUipoli heights.
And on other battlefields,
Life-blood was freely shed.
So as we think of the living,
Let us also remember the dead.
Don Bradman, our cricket hero,
learnt the rudiments of the gams
when he was a small boy. He made
his first century playing for his school
when he was 11 His 115 wag grati
fying, but any likelihood of conceit
was nipped hi the bud on the follow
ing morning when the headmaster
"slanged" the boys for leaving one of
the school bats on the grounds of
their opponents, and did not allude to
Bradman's score. After Bradman left
school he assisted his local team, Bow
rai, and in a game against Moss Vale
he scored 800. In tbe next match he
scored 390 not out!
The boys and girls of Switzerland
take a great interest in the migration
of swallows. As the passage over
the Alps is most difficult, the chil
dren are always on the look-out for
distressed birds. They pick them up,
place them in baskets, carry them to
the railway station, and the guard
of the next train that arrives takes
charge ol them. When the warmer
country is reached the basket lids
are opened, the little birds fly away,
and. the baskets are sen*, back for
another batch.
In England, at wells, in Somerset,
there are swans in the moat sur
rounding the Bishops palace, who
ring the bell when they want food.
Nearly a hundred years ago a
daughter of one of the bishops taught
the swans to do fhlg. She had the
•efl fitted up with a rope, and the
birds were interested in the danghng
rope, with which they played. When
ever it was pulled hard enough the
neU rang and some pieeag of bread
were st ones thrown awi, so when
they were hungry they found that a?
they nad to do wss to give ths rope
r tug. The trick has been copied iy
each generation since the first learnt
■it.
The waterhen is very eomsaon * in
war lagoons, and Us plumage ? **uth
admired. It is not shy as regards
human associatioii, but it is always
alert, watchful, and cautious. Its nest
is usually in amongst grass or reeds
on the water-side, and at lane, with
a depression in the centre. The hen
bird lays from seven to nine eggs
m each clutch. The young chides
are beautiful little things, covered
with almost black down; they leave
the nest as soon as hatched; and can
swim very adroitly. f
How many names can you find in
the following combinations-
SIDANELLENANWi
You will find the following, all in
their correct order:—Sid, Ida, Dan.
Nell, Ellen, Len, Ena, Nan,, and inn.
Write the word down, if it can be
called such and ask your Dad to find
the names, giving him TBkT for a
start. Yon win be surprised at tho
number he will miss.
Gad's Woadrowt Way.
One of . William Oowpers hymns
commences MOod moves in a mysteri
ous way. His wonders to perform."
and having in mind, at the moment,
the Ansae Day services and the uni
versal desire for peace, I would re
mark that one of the wonders at the
present time Is the Boy Scout and
Girl Guide movement. It to world
wide, and of every, clime and nation,
and God Is not far away from.it.
A muiion living men have come.
And a million women, toe
A billion youths from every land
Their elders to outdo 1
For Oodi for home! for native land!
Where'er that land may be.
Here is a conquering host at last
To set all children free.
When peoples and nations extend
the hand of friendship, the gospel of
love and a peaceful world will be the
glorious outlook, and that day will
come which we ask for when we say,
"Thy Kingdom come on Earth as it
is in Heaven."

title: An April Morning in Bowman Park.
content:
An Abril Morning in
Bowman Park
m
WIND in the blue gums whispering
low,
Twitter of birds that come and go;
Scent of blossoms and hum of bees,
Cool deep shadows 'neath tall bush
trees!
Eerie wail of a lone curlew,
Grasses wet with the silver dew,
Buttercups onening in the dell
Toll of a chapel's matin bell.
Distant hilltops kissed by the sun,
Stony brooklet where waters run;
The bell-clear notes of the butcher
birds,
And the distant lowing of dairy herds!
Gold of the bottle-brush in bloom,
Painted wrens in lantanas gloom;
Sombre green of the pines aloof,
Rising above a gabled roof!
Pigeons strutting in purple and blue,
Shy brown doves from the branches
coo;
A veil of mist on Taylor's Range,
Call of a storm-bird, harsh and
strange !
A purple butterfly floating by,
Clouds of white in an azure sky;
A curl of smoke from a cottage fire,
And the shrill of cicadas rising higher I
G. S. CICHOWSKI.
Newstead, April 3.

title: THE LAY OF THE MUSHROOM MEMBER.
content:
THE LAY OF THE MUSHROOM MEMBER.
Reformers may boast that their ballot
Makes working men sober and free,
But with taps flowing freely how shall it
With purest impression agree?
A fig for the flimsy delusion,
The rum men their rights will resign,
And nobblers abound in profusion,
And money to pay for them's mine.
"The Act" may provide against treating,
(The Act that made me an M. P.,)
But nothing it says of unseating,--
It's penalties don't affect me.
My purse, it is true, is much lighter,
But well the investment will pay;
The outlay that draws its strings tighter,
I'll turn to advantage some way.
I bought the boors all in a cluster,
And carted them down to the poll,
With brandyballs, babble, and bluster.
Their wills I could sweetly control.
They voted like lambs, in my favour,
In a style that my foes must astound,
And I then, for their handsome behaviour,
Stood sam for the sinners all round.
But I swear by the powers of parchment,
My foes shall all find their mistake,
They'll know what the middle of March meant,
When in Court "I the other side take."
In future I'll patronise few shops--
Those only who followed my tether,
And I'll shut up our shabby old shoe shops,
By sending to Sydney for leather!
Windsor, April 20,1860.

title: Australian Wine.
content:
Australian Wine.
HERE'S to the Christmas season, boys,
In ripe Australian wine
We'll drink to the merry Christmas joys,
In juice of the native vine.
Here's a health to those that we love best,
In ripe Australian wine ;
By all who drink it, 'tis confessed,
A nectar most divine.
Pure and sweet,
Is the juice we meet,
From Australia's clustering vine ;
As fine a draught,
As e'er was quaff'd,
In France, or on the Rhine.
Let thirsty topers try to lave
Their tongues with grog or beer,
The more they drink, the more they crave,
'Till drinking makes them queer ;
Not so who drink a goblet pure,
Of ripe Australian wine;
'Twill health and strength for all ensure —
Our own Australian wine.
Pure and sweet, &c.
May all of those who troubles bear,
Drink our Australian wine ;
'Twill banish from them evrey care,
And never let them pine.
Then health to those, whose efforts long,
Have given us this good wine ;
May strength and happiness prolong
Their days amid the vine.
Pure and sweet, &c.
G. B. M.

title: IN LIGHTER VEIN.
content:
IN LIGHTER VEIN.
One lieft Out,
She pronounced in sounding platitude
Her universal gratitude
For men of every latitude,
From the Tropics to the Poles ;
She felt a consanguinity,
A sisterly affinity,
A kind of kith-and-kinity
For all these foreign souls.
For Caledonian Highlanders,
For brutal South Sea Islanders,
For wet and thirsty dry-landers,
For Gentile, Greek, and Jew;
For Finns and for Siberians,
For Arabs and Algerians,
For Terra-del-Fuegians,
She was in constant stew.
Oh! it worried Miss Sophronia
Lest the men of Patagonia
Should all die of pneumonia,
With the phthisis or the chills!
Yes, indeed, she worried daily
Lest a croup or cold should waylay
Some poor Soudanese or Malay
Dying from the lack of pills.
And she toiled on without measure,
And with most unstinted pleasure,
For the good of Central Asia
And the. pagan people there.
But meanwhile her little sister
Died of a neglected blister;
But Sophronia hardly missed her,
For she had no time to spare!

title: A Recollection.
content:
i Â 'BQQ&Ueati&n*
DNLY a paper windmill, only a baby's sock,
Duly a piece of winsey from the, hem of a little frock ;
But' a gray haired woman holds them in her work-worn
wrinkled baud.
Holds them as treasures dearer than gems from a foreign
strand.
Not a fair gentlewoman, such as painters love to trace -
No polished trick of manner, no studied ease or grace ;
A plaiu hard featured womau, who has led a life of toil,
But sorrow's seed aye beareth kindred fruit in kindred soil.
And on plaiu and homely features, as on brows of queenly
grace,
Pain nud grief, with heavy footsteps, leave unalterable trace.
And a mother's heart's as tender, and her love as pure and
true,
Tho' it beats beneath a cotton gown, or silks of brilliant hue.
" Whv do I care for these things ?"-Well, I'll tell you if you
like
To listen. 'Tis nigh thirty years uow, since I married Mike,
And went to live on Buckinbah, that place beyond the hill ;
The little hut we lived in first stands near the slip-rail still.
. I felt it dull and lonesome, for I had'nt long been here,
And I'd left some merry sisters far away iu Devonshire;
This township wasu't laid out then, that road was just a
track,
It used to take us near three weeks to get to town and back.
But love, they say, eau brighten e'en the poorest lot iu life.
And I didn't care for hardships while Mick Bryan called me
PL WIFE ;
And when our little girl was born the touch of her soft hand
Made many thiugs seem clear that had been hard to under
? stand.
And th' iuside of that old slab hut that looks so rough to you
Was bright to me as morning sun upon the drops of dew ;
Ah well ! It didn't last for long. Perhaps it was too good
I might ha' got to value life far higher than I should.
The first hard stroke of trouble was just twenty years agone,
I mind as if 'twas yesterday the sunny summer morn,
They brought my poor Mick home. His face had just the
look of death,
And every time he sighed it might ha' been "his parting
breath.
A doctor ? Oh, out here there wasn't mauy doctors then,
And so I had to sit and watch, and hope and watch again ;
The winter passed, and springtime came before he could sit
up; *
The hands were kiud, we never 'xactly wanted bit nor sup.
But still the children hadn't had the care they used to get,
And Tom and Katie both looked pale, and when it set in wet
They sickened, aud through day and night I did all I could
do,
And watched, and thought, and plauned, aud praye d, ye
through it all I knew
That death stood in the doorway. And one night as I sat
still
Aud heard thé sweet sad music come floating down the hill
That dear old mother used to call ' . the messenger of Death;"
I knew it came for Katie. Yes, I watched her fleeting breath.
Ah me ! She's better off ! Although its very hard to see
I used to think she'd always be a loving help to me.
And Tom, poor Tom, he went that night, my boy so bold
aud brave ;
Don't talk o' grief till you have laid two children in one
grave.
I often used to say to Mike 'twas but a little way
Between the life we're living here and everlasting day ;
Aud't seemed to me when they were gone, although I didn't
pine,
The best and bligh est half of me had crossed the narrow
line.
We'd only one left now, and that was tiny little Ted, .
He'd play beside his father as he lay upon the bed,
While I went to the creek to wash, or to the homestead
where
I often did a bit of work if visitors were there.
One night I came home tired ('twas shearing time), ano
when I saw
My poor Mike's face my heart stood still, 1 looked at hin
with awe ;
Awhile he couldn't speak, and then he pointed to the bed .
Where lay some scraps of wood and string, and then he
whispered " Ted."
I knew, 1 seemed to know at once that Ted was gone. I rar
And never stopped till all were roused. They turned out t(
a man,
And I went home to Mike. Poor Mike, he told me how he'e
made
The tiny paper windmill, and how Ted had laughed anc
played
To see the little toy spin round.-We watched, anc
watched all night,
Aud all next day, with heavy hearts, while still the sun shorn
bright.
By evening one by one the men had all come back, an<
when
The last one rode up silently, I looked at Mike and thei
1 saw that in his .face I never, never, saw before !
Oh husband, father, loving, true, thou 'rt with them ever
more.
And I must stay and silent wait, until the time shall come
When you, and I, and they, shall meet in an eternal home
They tell me that before he died he raised his eyes and said
" Just wait a minute Katie, for I'm bringing little Ted."
Just where the deep dark river speeds, by the overhaugin¡
rock,
We found, among a bed of ferns, the windmill and the sock
And they alone, and memory, are all that's left below
To tell of all I loved and lost so many years ago.
M. W.
The recent misunderstanding between the departments
presided over by Messrs. Whitton and Cowdery, of the
railway service, has culminated in the appointment of
Commissioners, by whom the matters in dispute will be
investigatéd. The Government Gazette of the 6th inst,
had the following announcement: ''The undermen-
tioned gentlemen to be Members of a Royal Commis-
sion to inquire into and report upon the stability of
iron bridges erected on the existing lines of railway :
G. A. Morrell, CE. ; -Norman Seife, M.I.C.E. ; W.
M'D. Courtney, M. I. C. E. ; J. P. Franki, J. Edging
ton." The statements made by Mr. Cowdery are of im-
portance to every colonist, as all have to bear their share
of the cost of railway construction, but they have a
special interest to those who have to travel by rail.

title: Only an Outcast.
content:
Only an Outcast.
OUT in the coldy-an outcast '.--poor and ill,
Why beat so loudly ? Onward I must go,
Nb home to turn to-none to help me-no !
' How bleak the night-how cold the drifting rain,
The bitter blast howls wild, m if in pain ;
And I so thinly clad, with cold, bare feetw*
Only an outcast ! wandering in the street
How the lights dance and flicker in the wind,
While in yon " bar," the scene looks bright and k
Will no one ask me in, ray freezing feet to warm,
Or must I pass the night m this fierce storm ?
They heed me not-oh, courage !-I will speak i
" Kind sir. in pity help-the night is bleak j
I have no home-ah, do not pass me by- -,
A little help, kind air, or else I die !" ,
Gold ! did he give me gold? and bid me mend,
Ah ! 'tis too late-my life too near itB end !
He touched my hand, though I am steeped in sin,
And Bpoke so kind-God's blessing rest on him !
It's bitter cold I I feelT scarce can speak,
My heart beats fast, although I'm faint and weak
Oh, God I can this be death that chills my form ?
Yes-I'm an outcast, dying in the storm !
Once loved and happy-oh.
heart, be still !
E. B.

title: Dawn—Idyll.
content:
Dawn-Idyll
A LITTLE rustling breeze,
?**. Just waking in the trees,
A sunbeam peeping at the flowers
like bright eyes glancing;
The tender light of dawn
On dew-bespangled lawn,
Where you, on feet like petals white,
are dancing, dancing !
D. L. WARAKER.

title: DARTS AND DALLIANCE.
content:
DARTS AND DALLIANCE.
The fact that riches have wings does
not help a man to feather his own nest.
Matrimony, a river, and trouble are all
easy to get into; but getting out is
another story.
One half of the world is glad that the
other half doesn't know how it lives.
An egotist is one Who thinks he knows
more than you do, and doesn't deny it.
The less a man says, the more guessing
his wife has to do.
Get a reputation for early rising, and
you may sleep all day.
One only gets what one wants when one
stops wanting anything.
The last straw usually gets, blamed for
the whole load.
Man is a creation of habit, woman its
victim.
.ong-headed people are seldom short
sighted—From ""Eve."

title: ONLY A WOMAN'S HAND.
content:
ONLY A WOMAN'S HAND.
REBECCA CAMERON.
ONLY a woman's hand,
Shapely and white,
Rose-tipped and velvety.
Dimpled and slight.
Tapering white fingers,
Rounded and slender;
Palm a pure oval,
With pink flushing tender.
Melting so softly
To the snow of her wrist,
And set with twin dimples
Made just to be kissed.
Only a woman's hand;
How small a thing
To rule so royally
Peasant and king!

title: The Laureate's Mental Struggle
content:
Tho Laureate's Montai Struggle *
I (Before the Murder of his Muse.) : i j
If it. were done, when 'tis done, then 'twere: well
It were done quickly; if an assassination
Could put an end unto this jubilee, 1
And keep my pen clean from all fulsome bides,
I'd find a knife myself. Nay, place my soul*.
And let me rather bear the ills I have 1
Than fly to others that I know not of.
Methinks 'tis best perchance for me to suffer " (
These stings and arrows of outrageous fortune ,
Than to take arms against the King, my master, (
And with my popgun kill him. On his death
They'd make ruy lute tune forth a mourning song. >
Well, conscience does make cowards of us all.

title: Original Poetry.
content:
Original Poetry.
--0--
LOST IN THE BUSH.
AN AUSTRALIAN SKETCH.
Lost in the bush — the night encroaching fast,
And around loudening a cold-breathing blast!
A sad affair 'tis! Fancy squatter Will
Severely studying yon peculiar hill;
From which he learns a lesson of dismay —
It bluntly tells him, "Thou host gone astray!"
At this he backward hastes, intent to find
Some prospect more familiar to his mind.
How puzzling 'tis! still stranger seems to grow
The backward scene o'er which he hurries so;
Whereat Will mutters scanning o'er the ground,
"Dang it! the world is surely twisted round!"
And then, with sudden jerk, the anxious swain
Turns, just to contemplate that hill again.
God! which is which? — a dozen summits lie
As like as eggs against the twilight sky.
With tart alarm, and comical surprise,
Will opes his mouth at this, and eke his eyes;
Squats on his hams, and strains his neck, thus bent,
And this way bobs his head,and that — intent
To put the pleasant fact to final test —
Which done, he draws his breath and mutters " Well, I'm
blest!"
Scratches his head, and much that member loads
With execrations: "What! forsake the roads
For shorter cuts, no near the day's decline,
'Mongst hills and brushes? — Drat this head of mine!
The night, I know, will fall as thick as mire,
The bush too's roaring like a world on fire!
I am not one much given to foolish frights,
And far too knowing to believe in sprites;
Yet such a night, in such a cursed place,
Might almost put one in a raving case:
And somewhere here, for certain, it is said
The blacks have burial — oh, this silly head!
Besides, Peg may forget to bed the sow,
Big Bess, that is so near her pigging now;
Nor can she by herself, with all her care,
Secure the stack from that downdacious mare;
Or pen those gallows calves up from the kine —
I must regain the road! — Oh, this thick head o' mine!"
Thus bringing into catalogue his woes,
On, dogg'd and desp'rate, he at random goes.
Ah Will, dame Fortune surely owes thee spite !
Thy blazing hearth shall know thee not to night !
Vainly thy Peggy watches for her Will
To loom in sight upon the 'customed hill,
Thus saying to herself, with gesture grim,
"He's boozing somewhere, but I'll give it him !'"
And just as vainly dost thou onward toil,
Dismally cooeying all the weary while,
And wish — how kind! that thou hadst there with thee
Thy neighbour Wilson — just for company.
Now thickest glooms blank every forest path,
And, like a large Cyclopian eye in wrath,
Two huddled masses of dark clouds between,
One only star glares wildly on the scene.
Those dun clouds streaking as he sails along,
The owl pours forward his funereal song;
Sounds of strange waters in the hollow blast,
With distant howlings, frequent come and fast;
Startingly near, and spectre-like to see,
Sharp-shrieking squirrels stream from tree to tree;
And the wild cat, with breath suspending rush,
Whisks like a devil from the shaken bush !
Ah Will, such hour may well thy spirit grieve,
Most woe-begone, unlucky son of Eve!
Worn out at length, he throws him down — and sleep
There finds him, coiled beside a bleaching heap
Of drifted leaves, which patteringly alight
From the hoarse blast — while, loaden with its might,
Huge trees sway solemn o'er th' unconscious wight.
But now, when night, a limping hag, her shades
Had westward called, and gray had grown the glades,
Stung into partial consciousness, 'twould seem,
By the increasing cold, he dreams a dream:—
Himthinks, a banished man, alone he fares
'Neath polar skies, and battles hard with bears,
Gigantic fellows! shagg'd with ice, and still
Dev'lishly bent on dishing squatter Will:
And, just as in the strife a leg is lost,
(That luckless leg most bitten by the frost)
Sweating and wild, he wakes. His face forlorn
Then rubbed, he looks and hails the wished-for morn;
Scans o'er the unknown scene wtth rueful eyes,
And folds his arms, and shakes his head, and sighs:
When hark! distinctly, although far away,
He hears some house-dog's thrice repeated bay —
Starts from his huddled pasture at a bound,
And joyful, pushes for the grateful sound.
Not long his search: for now the morning star
Wheels from the eastern steep her shining ear,
And in her pallid but effectual glow
A hut and clearing stand revealed below.
Thither he hastens, and is welcomed there,
Consoled and fed with hospitable care;
And when the sun shall crown the wintry day
His kindly host shall set him on his homeward way.
CHARLES HARPUR.
Singleton, October, 1842.

title: The Ballad of Boozer Bill.
content:
The Ballad of Boozer Bill.
(Written for the "Town and Country Journal.")
Í^BM^tfcP^ÉT) HB man who kept th<
WpWf^l shanty on the old Gil
ly BÊÈF He^could set' the liquoi
&r fOraf'S^ if' out in proper style,
V lelV^i If you Planked youl
v---Sr«6^5 blessed money, whs
>««Ï fi iSSr y°u Sot y°ur blessed
^Vil-' whack,
Wa \T^XA /¿ An' you'd feel the Ha
rk 'l$Mw(¿f' VOr °£ ^ many a mile'
"~*Î?ÂÏÂ/ IIe didn't;run no palace
AB\ full of glass or silver
plate,
He didn't sport nc
Wf barmaid's ginget
But the "strike-me-dead" he gave you, and the
"scorch-your-soul" was great, ..
And you felt your very boots begin to flare.
Oh, fusel-oil was water, and neat vitriol was tea,
To the stuff the old man manufactured there;
A spoonful was a dazzler, and a nobbler was a
spree,
While half-a-pint was horrors and to spare.
Whichever, way you travelled you would strike
that liquor's reek,
Three miles from where the old man's shanty
lay;
He had to put new iron on the building every
week,
The liquor fumes corroded it away.
The fame of this establishment went over all the
land,
Till it reached old Ironbarky Bill's abode;
It stirred up all his envy, so, says he, "It would
be grand
To best that pub. upon Gilgyra-road."
His throat was like a drainpipe, and his mouth
was like a sink,
To his stomach mere asbestos was a farce;
He dined on iron rivets hissing hot, and all his
drink .
Was nitric acid with a dash of glass.
Said he, "I've drunk the country from the centre
to the sea,
I have drunk it hot, and cold, and wet, and dry;
Iii every blessed town of It I've had a flaring spree,
And I'm bound to best Gilgyra's pub. or die."
So he rode away galoojus till he smelt the booze
afar,
And he sniffed it, like a horse that smells a
creek;
He whipped his nag, and drove the spurs, and gal
loped to the bar,
The old man stared, and wondered at his cheek.
Now when two champions haply meet within the
deadly breach,
And look into each other's eyes aright,
There is no need for more than that, no need for
any speech;
They know what kind of men they be-and fight.
So, when the old mah looked at Bill, and when,
like furnace blast,
Came forth the tropic cyclone of his breath,
He spoke no word, but turned around, and o'er
the counter passed
- A quart of most especial sudden death.
But ere the pewter touched that bar, it seemed
much lighter grown,
And when he looked down ÍD the empty cup, .
The old man gasped in sheer surprise to find the
liquor flown
Old Ironbarky's breath had dried it up.
Ile brought a gallon of his best rip-roaring, red
hot blend,
But,Billy just one mouthful of it made;
xS.nd as he set the measure down he murmured
sadly, "Friend,
I didn't come this far for lemonade!"
The old man ground his teeth with rage; "Ive got
a cask," said he, '
"That will knock you off your perch In half a
shake;"
"You're stuff's too mild," said Ironbark, "to have
a decent spree;
. ? r A babe could drink the brand of booze you
mate."
The old man rolled the barrel in. Said he: "I'll
show you drink
That will give your little appetite a check."
In vain, tho forty gallons lasted just half a wink,
"There's not enough," said he, ' "to damp my
neck:"
"Bring, out the booze," cried William then, "set
up the drinks again,
I'm thirstier than when I first began;"
But never answer did he get, for in the corner,
there.
The old man died-a broken-hearted man.
Bold Billy still is flourishing, but, happy though
he be,
He very very often stops to think
There's one thing unaccomplished.- * "Now, be
for I die," says he,
"I'd like to ha_ve a satisfying drink."
E. J. Dempsey.

title: Vice and Virtue
content:
Vice and Virtue
Horrow, grief, tears are the brood of vice
Murder, plunder, infamy, greed its choice
War, pestilence, starvation, death its price
Of passion's gamble with the devil's dice
Thro' sottish sense
Love sighs for peace of sylvan bush-iike
glade
Where moral force by innocence is made
Truth, justice, faith in nature's light and
shade
Is virtne's wish by simple means to trade
For virgin sense
Sweet odors fill the air, and joyful sound
Where innocence gambols o'r vernal ground
Midst sylvan shades where melodies resound
In mossy nooks and flow'ry pads is found
To joy each sense
On riverbank where trees oerhang and sway
Through its foliage golden sunbeams play
And flitting birds make harmony all day
Where restless breese and whisp'ring leaves
essay
To haunt the sense
Tis only here that virtue's soul can rest
Far from the vicious crowd by greed opprest
Where charming bush home scenes by peace
is blest
And labors fruity and normal toil is best
For modest sense.
-CHUCK

title: Faulconbridge, Bine Mountains, N.S.W.
content:
Faulconbridge, Bine Mountains,
N.S.W.
THOSE "who look on theo, Faulconbridge, behold
The gardening of Nature amplified
By human art and taste j the gully's side
With terraces and stairways manifold,
So ounningly constructed as to hold
An added wealth of wild flowers fairy-dyed,
And native shrubs sought out from far and wide.
A veritable painted lily ; gold > . ..
Refined twice over art thou ; a joint-gem *
Of Art and Nature. But for me thou hast
Even a further interest than them,
Whose eyes aro merely windows, for thou wast
Tho chosen field wherein a statesman's mind
Food for artistic cravings strove to find.
DOUGLAS B. W. SLADEN.

title: LITERATURE.
content:
LITERATURE.
THE MEN AND WOMEN OF THE
WEST.
ARCHIBALD and HAROLD MESTON.
Ken of the strong and stern anylelding nee1,
"Who bore the Btiton'js banner far aloft , I
: Ttaroug? tropic jungles and the Arctla
snows.
Men of the generous-heart and open b*au«
Who walk in lltfrt of that undying hope >
That brave men' carry ever, in their soul*
Who faced the floods and droughts, dost*
flies, and heat.
And pangs and sorrows such as n?ne can
know
Save you who fought the fight and lived
to tell.
For you no marble, no Victoria Cress,
For you no wild applause, of cheering
crowds.
For you no grateful nation's public thanks.
In silence, through the desolate, dreary
years.
You tolled and suffered, and endured and!
dared.
And wen and lost and smiled-throaghout it
all 1 :
'And la that battle that you nobly fought, ;
'No bugled martial call, no roll of drums, ;
No rush and thunder of tho charging ranks!;
Fnries with serpent hair and vampire wines;
Flew o'er the West, and birds and beasts!
and trees • :
Were bligbted by the poison of their breath;
Some awful Maelstrom had involved all life,
A dreadful vortex tihat converged towards
A mournful realm of "hunger, thirst, aud
death !
Year after year the land grew desolate.
And pitiless Nature dug remorseless graves
For ruined fortunes, and the broken hearts
Of soldiers nobler than the men who face
The bayonet and the cannon, and far more
Deserving of a nation's gratitude.
Brave men and women of the lonely West
To you all honour for you are among
The heroes and the heroines of the lan*.

title: Original Poetry.
content:
3^É:®ttgíital floett»»
TÍ!
1 ' '$ [ron THE SYDNEY OAZBÏTÏ.]
,T0 A LADY IN A DECLINE.
'TUF hectic that flushes thy beautiful cheek
* .Tho datk halo that cirolos thino eye
?The dews on thy forehead-too plainly bespeak
That thou, gentío siiff'ier, must die.
Like iho rose-tho' thou blooraoBt awhile, lovely
maid,
Eru me worm had invaded its core
Now that Phthisis bath claim'd thoo, like it thou
must fado,
Like it thou must flourish no more.
Yet grieve not, dear seraph, tho' early thy death,
Tho' lorn fiom thy sorrowing friends
While youth breathes around thee its halcyon breath,
And with love ov'iy blandishment blends :
For blest is the spirit which quits this vain scene,
While virtuo and youth w arm the breast
Ere years sap tho strength, and ore earea interven«
To rob the fond bosom of rest
Ere the soul feels decay's with'ring fingers impress
Their cold clammy clnsp on tho brain
Ere the mind's labyrinthine voluminousness
, Is palsied by age's dull chain
Eie the friends whom wo love-oro reposed -in <the
tomb
Ere the memory shudders to gaze
On tho bavock of time, and the saddening gloom,
Whioh o'ershadows life's desolate days.
But over thv, tomb fond affection shall shed
The tear due to virtuo Uko thine ;
The sorrowing cypress shall wave o'er thy head,
And mark whëio thy fishes recline :
But thy spirit unfetter'd, and pure as the dove,
Shall triumph o'er death and the tomb
Shall return, swift as thought, to the " Fountain of
. Love"
And blest, shall immortally bloom,
H.H.
Sydney, August 1, 1831.

title: Santa Claus, 1891.
content:
Santa Glans, 1891.
From th» belfry aweet and low,
Hidden in the midnight's gloom,
Sound the bells across the snow,
Through the casements of my room.
And I cry a blithe " amen !"
To the burden of their lay,
As they singing seem to say,
Santa Claus has come again.
How the hells imprint a ßmile
On the child in happy sleep I
How they sleepless souls beguile
As they sound from deep to deep 1
How they preach to weary men
Grown half hopeless with the yea*" !
aHow they teach, 'mid joyous tears,
Santa Claus has come again !
For too often care and doubt,
"With their shadowy sister, pain,
Casting darkness all about,
, Quench the sunlight of the brain. '
So a joy comes o'er nie then
Which no words can ever frame,
When the merry bells proclaim
Santa Claus has come again.
Yet methinks that Santa Claus,
Though unseen, dwells ever near,
And through nature's august laws . .
Brings unceasingly good cheer j
And that all the sons of men,
If they listen in this life,
Hear above all earthly strife.
Santa Claus has come again.
For I see without, within,
Something whose resistless might
. Slowly crushes strife and sin
And with wisdom aids the right. '
So, no matter what has been,
Well I know that every hour,
. Clad in sweetness, love, and power,
Santa Claus has come again.

title: Home Interests.
content:
Home Interests.
TO THE MEMORY OF J.A.W
J.W.W.
BORN JUNE 9: DIED, 24. 1871.
AND thou art gathered for the skies, sweet flower of
promise fair:
And thou art chosen thus the crown without the cross
to wear;
Oh ! favored one, we joy for theo, that thou wUt never
kuow
That cross with all its weariness, its burden, and its woe
Ah : when we look'd with earnest love into thy youne
bright eyes, °
And traced in thought thy future course, thy pathway
to tho skies, J
We droa:ud of work prepared theehere. Alas! we little
knew
That Cod Himself was ttiting thee His work on high to
do.
He look into the summer sky, up through the clear
bright air ;
We gaze upon the midnight worlds, and think that thon
art there :
Yet is it well that we should deem our lost ones thus
afar,
Remote from all they loved below, liko some cold distant
star {
Nay, who shall say thou art not here, close to thy
mother's side,
Though hidden from her sorrowing sight and to her
arms denied ?
Who—who shall say that not to thee this mission hath
been given—
Her wandering steps to guard and guide nearer and
nearer heaven ?
Well diilst thou do thy work on earth throughout thy
little day;
The lightner of thy parents' hearts, the sunshine of their
way;
Ann now in mercy c'en to them, God may have giveu to
thee
A seraph's wing, that thou mayst still a better blessing
be.
The world unseen is surely near, upon its brink we
t cad;
The angels trace our daily paths, and watch around our
bed;
And dearer still than angels' care some loved one's guard
would be ;
We dare not say-but this we know-The Lord hath
need of thee.
Oh could we for one moment see thine heritage of joy,
And know, what here we seek in vain, a blias without
alloy;
That moment's gaze would hush the tears which still
for thee o'ernow,
Aud e-en thy mother's heart would be content that tbou
shouldst go.
That may not be—to see thee thus would be to walk by
Sight; *
And oh ! not so our souls are train'd to reach tho*e
realms of light;
But, taught of God, the chasten'd will, the meek sub
mission given,
Shall fit us by tliine early doom to shine with thee in
heaven.
Brisbane, July 15.

title: As You Go Through Life.
content:
As You Go Through Life.
- ______ -
Don't look for the flaws as you go through
life ;
And even when you find them,
It is wise and kind to be somewhat blind
And look for the virtue behind them.
For the cloudiest night has a hint of light
Somewhere in its shadows hiding ;
It is better by far to hunt for a star
Than the spots on the sun abiding.
The current of life runs ever away
To the bosom of God's great ocean.
Don't set y Our. force 'gainst the river's
course, 1 ??: ....
And think to alter its motion. t
Don't waste a curse on the universe
Remember, it lived before you.
Don't butt at the storm with your - puny
form
I But bend and let it go o'er you.
The world will never adjust itself
To suit your whims to the letter;:ï
Some things must go wrong your whole
. lifelong^ . » : . .
And the sooner you know it the better.
It is folly to fight with the Infinite,
And go under at last in the wrestle.
The wiser man shapes into God's plan
As the Water shapes into a vessel.

title: VICTORY.
content:
VICTORY.
Keep rich your hear[?] in hopefulness, my,
friend;
A rag of cloud is not obscurity:
We look beyond and know our des-

To loose the lightning that the veil
shall rend.
Lose' not your faith, the battle line motf
. bend,^
But Britain's sons will face the agony,
And still come singing .rom iicik*
semane, • .. •
To snatch the prize of Victory ia JQI
end. -
Shed you no tears for those vrlio gran'dlv
" .died ; . .
Keep bright your eyes to find the morn*
- ing star,
But humbly • pray the God pi WaP
abide :
With those who fight and ' face to*
things that are.
• * ■. • . '
"How went the fray?" ""Who to th'f
last 6tood true ?" • • • .
The everlatting days shall answer yoiTi
.. <■ ■■ ;.

Ie nude easier by adding a few drops ct
kmon juice. ■ ' " " ' -V

A tologram from Gulgong informs us that a largo
and influential meeting was hold on Monday, when Mr.
J. F. Plunkett, J.P., was presented with an; address
signod by 550 residents oxprossivo of confidonoo in
him as a Justico of tho Poaco.
A sad and fatal accident happenod on Tuesday,
i January 3, which has cast quito a gloom over Wollon
gong. On Monday a great wrestling match took
j placo betwoon T. Proudlock, of Bulli, and W. Smith,
of Sydney, E. Ollivor acting as umpiro for Smith, who
won. On Tuesday morning Ollivor, who accompanied
Smith down to Wollongong, and was staying at Mr.
Cheadlo's, mounted a horse to rido down to Lysught's
Hotel, whore somo other gontlomon from Sydney woro
Btaying, and upon nearing it, at a protty brisk paco,
tho horse appeared to Bworve and carno down heavily,
throwing poor Ollivor on to his hoad, at onco render
ing him insensible. Ho was immediately convoyed
into tho hotel and medical aid sont for, when it waa
doemod advisablo to roniovo him to tho hospital.
Mrs. Ollivor, who resides at Nowtown, was sont for,
and at onco mado preparations to proccod down to
Wollongong. Ollivor, notwithstanding that ho re
coivod cvory caro and attention that medical skill
could doviso, never recovered consciousness, and
lingered on until Thursday ovoning, when ho died.
The deceased, though ho had only.been a short period
in Sydney, had gained a numerous circle of friends by
his genial, good-natured disposition, and ¿is meian«
cfroly death, is sincerely mourned,

title: As a Flower?
content:
As a Flower?
WK droop baok to earth, like its flowers which bloom ,K.
Through the fugitive years of the ages of timo- v
Shall wo slumber for over, or waken to doom, ,
Or blossom again through far futuros sublimoP , _
All lives live for ever-however they ohango- '
Eternal as matter, whatever its form j _ " ,
I And tho soul of tho seraph, perchance in its range, j v ,
May havo shrnuk underfoot, in oarth's lowliest >
worm. . : ,
For thongh man in his littleness judges of things 11 J"
As they seem,-and himself, as tho standard of
sizo.
The augols may know that the sheen of their wings
Is matched by tho moth's, in tho Deity's eyes.
Who shall say what is small, or deolaro what is great
Or speak as a prophot of things yet to bo ? , i ; ? '?
When we know, wo but know, wo aro blind tools of ¡ .
fato,
Adrift without oorapass on timo's ohartlosa son.
Whore 'midst whirlpools and whirlwinds wo slave at
lifo's oar,
And with agony's strongth strugglo on for ita goal,. >
Whoso beaoon Sro fiamos on somo mist shrouded ?
shore,
Whioh can only bo seen by tho death shrivon soul.
Though tho oyo hath not seen, yet it surely must be,
Else woro God indood oruol, to give us a quest
Whioh leads unto nowhere,-but if BO, then Ho¿ - > ?>???
Who gavo us life's toil, will at leaBt givo death's 'i "<
rest. o S
A. .. ; I..

title: ORIGINAL POETRY.
content:
ORIGINAL POETRY.
the bbeath of the bush.
The hush of the night is upon me,
I have done with the might-have-been,
Yet ever a brook is crooning
In a forest of gold and green;,
And a voice that I know is calling
With the minahs from tree to tree-*
The tender, human voice of one
Who was all the world to me!
0! to follow her springing step
O'er the emerald breast nOhe wold,
Where the buttercups spangle the soft
green grass,
And the woods of the fern unfold!
0! for the Bcent of the flowering shrubs
That are wet with the sweet spring rain,
For the breath- of the musk and the sassa
fras
I never shall see again!
The fairy laugh of the leaves rings yet
In a silvery shower of sound,
The dew is ashimmer with golden light
On every mossy mound;
Down in the hollow the daisies dream,
And the violet's winsome face
Looks fragile and fair ae the maidenhair
In the charm of its dainty grace.
I hear the voice of the little creek,
And its musical monotone
Blends with the murmur of far-off brooks
In a song that is weird and lone.
Yet the joy of life's in the clear, pure air,
And the birds sing wild and high,
Their whirring wings are like soft harp
strings
The sky's deep blue anigh!
When the fever of youth is over,
And we'rt left hut the light of a star
Ere we ford the river of silence
That leads to the land afar,
Is there bliss or pain in remembrance
That clearer and clearer beams,
Of the days when the best within us
Was the glamour and glow of dreams?
Ah, God! for the olden glory,
For an hour of the happy past
Ere the flickering light'* and shadows
Are over for us at last!
But a mem'ry of love and brightness
Is all that we may retain—
And the flowers from heights immortal
That were plucked by the hand of pain!
—MARION MUXES.

title: "He Giveth His Beloved Sleep."
content:
"He Giveth His Beloved Sleep,'
"What would we givo to our "beloved,
The hero's heart to be unmoved,
The poefs star-tuned harp to sweep,
The patriot's voice to teach and rouse,
The monarch's crown to light tho bro wa?
" He giveth His beloved sleep."
. Oh, Earth, so full of dreary noises !
Oh, men, with wailing in your voices!
On, delved gold, the wailers* heap !
Oh strife ! oh, curse that o'er it fall !
God strikes a silence through yon. all,
And "giveth His beloved Bleep/"'
His dews drop mutely on the hill,
His cloud above it saileth still,
Though on its slopes men sow and reap 5
More swiftly than the dew is shed,
Or cloud is floated overhead,
"He giveth His beloved sleep."
1 MÜS. BBOW'

title: Selected Poetry.
content:
Selected Poetry.
THE " DEAD LETTER."
[TN the pages of Goethe's remarkable prodnotion
entitled "Wilhelm Meister," Ifiud thoiollowing strik-
ing passage apropos of returned, or '* Dead Letters:"
-"If we happftn, nuder certain circumstances, to
have writton and sealed and despatched a letter to
a friend, which, hovrover, does not find him, but is
brought back io ns, and wo open it at the cistanoeof
BOBO considerable time, a singular emotion is rtro
dnoed in ns on breaking up our own seal, and con-
versing with our alter id self aB with a third person." I
BEN FBANKLIN LANGFORD.
Delamere.
I.
Oh ! Thou who nonrißhest the stricken soul
When crushed by cold negloot of heartless man»
Lookdown upon this being ! Short theapan
Whioh now retains hin within Time's control !
Seasons unnumbered pass, wild tempests roll,
Earthquakes and lightnings, wonders of earth
and air,
He heedeth not, he knoweth not ; for oare
Hath bowed him to the dust. Hia senses reel,
His footsteps totter aB he Beens the ßhore,
Where the pent waters thro' lone oavernB roar
To (raia the boundless sea-from whenae first driven
They mount to hiss the stars, and dash the spray
towards Heaven !
II.
He had a son-a blue-eyed.gentle ohild.
In days agone, when he himself was young,
And loved the world, and smiled and danged and
t Bung .,,
With gladsome heart. But, oh I adventurers wild
Entered his home, and, ruthle*B, lured away
The darling of his soul, whose mother lay
Within the tomb, nor saw her son beguiled
To flee a tender sire's proteoting hand.
And mínele with a vile, blaspheming throng,
Who dwelt, a plague-epot, in his native land,
Blasting yonng innocence ; while borne along,
He vainly struggled-as when torrents roar,'
And bear some mountain shepherd, battling for the
shore !
III.
And while the stream of vice still onward bore,
He felt repentance, wept, and sinned again !
Till time passed on ; repentanoo seemed in vain.
And still he viewed the far-rooeding shore '
(The smiling ever-pleasant shore of truth,
Where, whilst intact, his soul rejoioed iii youth),
But trod upon its pleasant paths no more !
Tossed on tho bosom of a doubtful ocean,
j He gave himself to pleasure-false tho name,!
j The paat forgot, unwept his sire's emotion,
He basely lived and bade adieu to shame,
I Till foul disease, with life-destroying breath',
Passed o'er the wanderer's oouch, and doomed his
frame to death.
IV.
Still was he loved-not cursed, as many ara
(Tho only gift that to hie sire was given.
By her ho loved, ere yet she passed to Heaven) I
And whilst the wanderer dwelt in sin afar
i The sire, tho' young, bowed down by bitter
, care,
! With furrowed brow, and lightly Bil verod hair,
Sent forth a letter as a guiding star
To lead the err in ir one. Bat, ah ! too late !
The words of pardon found him in the grave..
And long and patient did the parent wait,
Nor deemed the wild weeds yet could o'er him wave,
Until a letter came-his own again,
Returning messenger, to charge his soul with pain !
V.
He gazed upon it once. Enough-he knew
The trembling characters noon it traced
Were writ by his own hand j and half-effaoed,
By burning, scalding tears, the emblems true
Of deep, parental love-that love whioh dwells
Within a father's boacm when it swells
A breaking heart for a loved child disgraoed.
Thenceforward beauty never met his eyes
Earth's blossoms, trees and sunshine, what were
they ?
What were the still ni«ht's starry, cloudless .
BkieBp
When all he loved on earth Ijad passed away
And left him, like a soathed and withered oak,
Struck in its pride and atreagth, by the dread light-
ning's stroke ! .

title: TO DELTA.
content:
. TO DELTA; .

title: ORIGINAL POETRY.
content:
ORIGINAL POETRY.
SHIPS OF HOPE.
The Ships of Hope are sailing
To meet the sea to-day,
Tin? dimpling roadstead whitens
Beneath their brave array.
Young breezes fill their canvas.
That swells like rounded pearls,
Each scarlet, silken pennon
A gay defiance hurls.
Beyond Home's happy haven
Life's 6urge beats ou 'the shore;'
Behind, the landlocked harbourj
Uncharted seas before.
All. bells may ring thanksgiving
Amid the inerry din.
If still with sails unsullied
The Ships of Hope come in.
The Ships of Hope, returning,
Are beating up the bay:
But some are sore disabled,
And some were cast away.
And some, faint-hearted, foundered
For Jack of star to guide.
And some have passed unspoken
And drifted down the tiae.
With pennons scant and tattered,
With ragged sails and thin,
A broken brave Armada,
The Ships of Hope come in.
King, ring ye bells, your dirges,
The sea hath reft her due,
Befit ye. for vour voyage.
Ye gallant barques and true.
Tiie seas are yet to conquer.
The wide, wide seas and lone,,
The voyage, long and wear}*,
With diverse perils sown.
The reefs have fangs to pierce ye,
The sea hath depths to hold,
Your freight of brave endeavour
Is more than gear or gold.
But. oh, my barque stout-hearted,
Hide out the storms and win,
Ah. grant that all unfailing.
My Ship of Hope comes in!
ELLA MTADTEK. j

title: THE CONVICT'S LAMENT.
content:
THE CONVICT'S LAMENT.
How often in the silent night
When others calmly rest,
Does mem'ry in her backward flight
Perturb my wakeful breast.
I think of all that I have been
And all I now might be,
Had crime not placed a bar between
Home, freedom, friends and me.
The days-the years-I have misus'd-'
The devious path I've trod
Talents, tho' humble, yet abus'd
Have alivu'd me from God.
Whilst she who bore me in her womb
Who nurs'd my infant years,
An aged widow-wails my doon
In solitude and tears.
0 God ! of all the pangs that e'er
Distract the guilty heart,
The having caused a mother's tears
Gives far the keenest smart.
Ah wherefore did I ever leave
The life I led in youth.
Why suffer error to deceive
And lure me from the truth.
Religion! had thy holy pow's
For ever rul'd my breast,
I ne'er had felt this friendless hour
Lone, exil'd and distresses
'Tis not too late-on bended knog
To Christ this very day,
In genuine humility
# For a new heart I pray.
He never scorns the coatrite sigh,
The anguish'd, broken hearted tear,
The uplift hand, the down cast eye
Betok'ning penitence sincere'.
Then cease to throb my flutt'ring heart
Humbly rely on God,
He portions to thy strength the smart,
Of his soul-chast'ning rod.
