title: TRANSACTIONS. OF THE GREAT AUSTRALASIAN SOCIETY.
content:
TRANSACTIONS OF THE GREAT AUS-
TRALASIAN SOCIETY.
(Continued.)
SECTION B.--THE BELLE LETTRES.
A Little Book on the Origin and Nature of
Poetry, by the Scrubb Family--the Prose by
Timothy, and the Poetic Illustrations by
Jeremiah.
CHAP. V.
Othello's occupation's gone.--Bard of Avon.
This chapter opens with a great flourish of
trumpets, a tremendous revolution in poetry, and
a terrible blow to professional criticism. In fact,
I mean to suggest to all suffering bards an
effectual cure for the evils incident to their pre-
sent situation, as well as to foment a rebellion
against the unjust and odious domination of re-
viewers. I hope, therefore, to obtain a patient
hearing from all living poets, and also from all
who intend to court the muse at some future
time. I do not doubt but that I shall be re-
garded as a benefactor of the species; for,
assuredly, the panacea which I have to promulge,
will not only revolutionise every department of
rhyme, but also be of inestimable advantage to
every son and daughter of song.
Evey bard is doubtless aware that, under
existing circumstances, his reputation depends on
the authoritative dicta of reviewers. Unfor-
tunately, the public take very little interest in
the fate of poetical works, and hence, numbers of
people estimate the merits of books in accordance
with some reviewer's testimony. He reads--or,
at least leads those who read him to suppose that
he reads--the various works which he reviews,
and, as his readers do not read such works, they
naturally adopt his conclusions and act accord-
ingly. If he condemns, they condemn; if he
praises, they praise; and the tone of their praise
or blame is regulated in a great measure by the
tone of his critique. Under such circumstances
an ill-treated poet has no fair chance for fame.
Nobody regards him as a great man, simply be-
cause nobody reads his works. Of what use are
all his beautiful apostrophes, astounding com-
parisons, and splendid passages! They might as
well have been written for the moths and beetles
to mutilate and destroy, as for reasonable men to
read. They are tabooed to the public; they have
the ban of the critic on them; they are
labelled "not to be read;" and the writer of
them, instead of commanding the applause of
multitudes, glides down the stream of life as
noiselessly as an ordinary man. Though this is
a hard case, it is far from being irremediable.
It is not like those chronic diseases which baffle
the skill of the most experienced physicians, and
tempt them to doubt the power of the Esculapian
art. In this instance, "hic jacet need not finish
what recipe begins;" although such is the fate of
most persons who abandon Professor Holloway.
The case of the ill-used bard is not hopeless.
There is as much blue sky over his head as would
make a pair of breeches for a Dutchman. The
clouds are breaking in the boundless heavens.
The storm has done its worst, and must now be
hushed for ever. The sagacity of my uncle has
discovered a sure and efficacious remedy for all
the critical ills that bards are heirs to, and that
remedy is comprised in the advice--let every
poet become his own critic.
That the adoption of this plan would be pro-
ductive of many important advantages, is a
proposition, the truth of which is transparently
evident. It would enable the bard to point out
to the reader all the beautiful passages and lovely
metaphors in his work; and which the reader
might otherwise omit to notice. It would afford
him an opportunity of magnifying his candour in
the reader's esteem, for, on this plan, he would
be enabled to note those parts of the poem which
were poor, bald, and thin, and which hed been
inserted for the sole purpose of showing that a
great mind, like a great mountain, has chasms
and hollows in it. But the greatest advantage
of all would consist in the fortification of the
reader's mind against future defamatory criti-
cism. The generality of readers receive their
opinions on the shopkeeping principle of "first
come first served," or, in other words, imbibe
whatever views may be first laid
before them. Hence, when about to
commence the perusal of a poem,
their minds may be compared to Locke's tabula
rasa, or more accurately, to a sheet of foolscap,
on which the bard may register almost any
opinion he pleases; and, when they once form an
opinion, their natural stiff-neckedness forces them
to retain it with surprising tenacity. By taking
advantage of these peculiarities and idiosyncra-
cies of the reading public, the poet would make
the very obstinacy of human nature an auxiliary
to his success; and a clique of such readers would
pooh-pooh, and put down all hostile criticism,
and give such an impulse to the bard's fame as
would suffice to send it puffing, and splashing,
and snorting like a steam-boat down the broad
ocean of posterity and time. My uncle Jeremiah
will now practically illustrate, both in prose and
song, this important discovery.
THE WOODMAN'S CHILD.
An Australian Tale, founded on a fact which
the writer imagined.
CANTO I.
N.B.--The reader is particularly requested to
observe that this story is intended to be very
pathetic.
The setting sun a rosy light
Flung o'er creation's wide domain;
And, thron'd on stars, the monarch night
In solemn state began her reign.
The bittern pip'd her shrilly song,
The dingo dog forsook his lair,
And darkness slily stole along
The dusky woods, and sleeping air.
Then sail'd not a cloud o'er the vault on high,
To dim the glow of the starlit sky;
There stray'd not across the forest a breeze,
To stir the tops of the highest trees;
No ripple play'd upon the rill;
No mist hung o'er the brush-clad hill;
No light shone on the weeping stream,
Save that of the pale sidereal beam;
For the sovereign lord of the day had set,
And the merry moon had not risen yet,
And darkness reign'd on every hand,
And silence brooded o'er the land.
This scrap of song serves to introduce the story
to the reader. It excites curiosity, and prompts
the inquiry--what next? What follows in the
next four lines is put in because the writer could
find nothing better to say, and, what follows in
the subsequent four is added with a view of roman-
ticising the flatness of the allusion to the clock, &c.
As I have undertaken to criticise myself, I con-
sider it my duty to acknowledge my poetic frail-
ties, as well as to appreciate and laud my
surpassing excellencies; and therefore hope, that
should the reader be unable to admire my poetry,
he will, at least, be compelled to praise my can-
dour and discernment. Thus I shall gain my
end, to wit, his admiration, either by hook or by
crook.
The woodman's clock, with heavy stroke,
Portentously the silence broke,
And echo from a neighbouring rock
Responded to the warning clock.
The passing stranger heard the sound,
And with quicken'd steps pursu'd his way;
For many a weary mile of ground
Between him and his homestead lay.
In the next part of the poem the story begins.
The only purpose which this introduction can
serve is, that of showing the time when the story
opens. Scene--Night--would have done just as
well, but then it would have been a too matter
of fact sort of introduction to an octa-syllabic
drama. Had I plunged into the story at once,
the imagination of the reader would not have
been appropriately excited. I have avoided this
defect by noting the principal features of the
scene; and, also, by the introduction of the
passing stranger. What business that stranger
had there--who he was--and where he came from
--are questions which the reader's imagination
must answer. This vagueness is what all modern
critics admire in Coleridge's "Christabel;" though
strange to say, they admire the very
opposite in Wordsworth. My business, as
a bard, is, to follow the advice
which Sir Walter Scott gave to a celebrated
painter of battle scenes--"Just put in a leg here,
and an arm there, and raise a great stour (dust),
and leave the rest to fancy." My tale will now
run on very smoothly to the end of all the
cantos.
The shout of childhood's revelry
Was heard around the woodman's fire
And one cherub boy, laughing merrily,
Clamber'd upon his father's knee,
And looked in the face of his sire,
Alas! alas! that blue-eyed boy,
With a face all smiles, and a voice all joy,
And a heart as merry as heart could be,
Stood then on the verge of eternity;
And drew in laughter his latest breath,
In the hollow that lies 'twixt time and death.
O! life is a state of uncertainty;
There is poison-juice in the fairest flowers;
There's a sting near the bag of the honey-bee,
And a cloud on the face of our brightest hours.
There's a bitter dreg in the cup of joy;
There's a canker worm in the calmest mind;
The sweetest pleasure hath some alloy,
And life and death are intertwin'd.
We rise and sleep, we laugh and sing,
Like flowers, we put forth all our bloom;
Like flowers, a stroke of Time's strong wing
Consigns us to an early tomb.
The woodman's child took his father's hand--
The father press'd and held it fast;
For a sad presentiment unmann'd
His soul: as when the vengeful blast
And bounding billows, and angry sky,
Flash on the shipwreck'd sailor's eye,
And paralyse his stalwart frame,
And, all but, quench life's sinking flame,
And fill his soul with horrent fear,
And tell him death--stern death is near.
Two hours had fled since the setting sun
Proclaimed the approach of the dreamy night,
And the deed of blood had not been done,
Though the victim sate in the murderer's sight,
For, crouch'd behind a ragged stone,
Like a fierce and deadly beast of prey,
In silence, and sin, and all alone,
With 'bated breath the murderer lay;
And he held his rifle on the cock,
And drew from his leathern belt a knife,
Which he savagely whetted upon the rock,
For he sought the woodman's life.
The one had married a maiden fair,
Whom the other loved too well,
And the latter swore by the Prince of Air,
That if ever he met the woodman where
No eye could see, he a deed would dare
Too horrible to tell.
And now some demon fate had brought
Him close to the foe whese life he sought,
Had chosen the weapon, place, and time,
Befitting so foul a deed of crime--
Had seal'd the conscious eye within
To the dreary issue of his sin--
Had fired his soul with ruthless hate,
Which ruin only could abate.
And by the fire's blazing light,
He rais'd his piece and took deadly aim,
And there shot athwart the brow of night,
A sudden flash of lurid flame.
The night-hawk, screaming, swept the sky,
And from under the shelt'ring stone's broad base
There issu'd a faint and hissing cry,
As a snake look'd full in the murd'rer's face;
And hollow laughter rang around
The cavern'd hills and forest wide,
While distant mountains caught the sound
And in hollower tones to it replied.
The deed of blood was rashly done,
The wreath of darkness madly won,
The murd'rer's hellish vow was cross'd,
The father liv'd, the child was lost.
As he on his father's name did call,
And press'd his cheek with lip so red,
A flash was seen, and a rifle ball
Flew, crashing, through the boarded wall,
And the cherub boy lay dead.
O! then the forest echoes woke,
With the shriek of a mother's anguish wild!
And her cheek grew wan, and her heart was broke,
And she sank beneath the fatal stroke--
For it was her first-born child!
O, ye! who sound the depths of space,
And trace with philosophic eye
The unknown planet's fitting place
In the vast obscure o' the starry sky,
And ye! who know all living things
That swim beneath the ocean's tide,
Or, cleave the air with joyous wings,
Or on the breath of evening glide;
And ye! who on the marble breathe
Life's all but stern reality;
Or round your brows a chaplet wreathe
With sweetest flowers of poesy.
Say! can you on the block pourtray,
Or on the canvass pencil fair,
Or sound, in high poetic lay,
That heart-struck mother's dread despair?
There's a grief that crushes the strongest heart,
As corn is crush'd by thunder rain;
There's a sorrow too deep for the poet's art,
And which highest song would but profane!
CANTO II.
Away! away! to the mountain glen!
Unvisited by the feet of men!
Where the brush is thick, and the crags are rude,
And the silver streamlet sadly moans
As it winds along in mournful mood,
O'er beds of shale, and moss-clad stones.
Where monstrous snakes their vigils keep,
And in hollow oaks rank lizards sleep;
Where the laughing squirrel leaps in the dark,
From the topmost boughs of the ironbark,
Where scarlet flowers their bloom display
To the eager parrot's observing eye,
And the woods resound, at the dawn of day,
With the Waunga-Waunga's plaintive cry;
Where kangaroos and opossums feed,
And wild birds cheerily wing their flight,
And mountain blossom and verdant weed
Adorn the cracks in the stalagmite;
And nature frowns in sternest mood
On the vast unbroken solitude.
Away! away! to the mountain glen,
Where the wild dog sleeps in his strong den;
Where the prickly shrub sheds sweet perfume;
Where the mountain rose displays its bloom;
Where bronze-wing'd pigeons swiftly sweep,
O'er stunted pine and tow'ring steep;
Where the wintry torrent's foaming wave
Leaps through the halls of the schistose cave;
Where the snowy eagle plumes his wing,
And the thunder shouts like a living thing,
And vernal storms their force display,
Then away to the mountain glen! away.
Away! away! to the wilderness
The murderer spurr'd his jaded steed!
Revenge was sated with success,
And his inmost soul began to bleed.
And he saw at hand, and on every side,
A vision of a murder'd child,
Whose yellow locks with blood were dyed,
As it spurted out in a living tide,
And he shrunk from a sight so wild.
He spurr'd again, and onward dashed
Away to the lonely mountain waste,
But the vision still before him flash'd,
As if it mock'd his haste.
And when he reached his hiding-place,
And the rising moon just show'd her face,
And had bath'd his brow in a mountain rill,
And stretched himself on a lonely hill,
'Twas there, behind a ragged stone,
Just such as he knelt by hours before,
When in silence and sin, and all alone,
The skies were rent with his rifle's roar.
He tried to sleep, but tried in vain.
Remorseful tear-drops banish'd rest,
And horror with its harpy train,
His sinful soul possess'd.
The bright and blessed morn arose,
And with fragrance sweet embalm'd the air;
But it shed no balm to heal his woes,
Nor cast a ray on his despair.
And whichever way he turn'd his eye,
It met the gaze of the murder'd child;
Now, it shone like a star on the sky,
Anon, it lay on the earth and smil'd;
One moment, it stood on the mountain steep,
The next, 'twas gilding among the trees;
And, at last, it seal'd his eyes in sleep,
As it floated by on a passing breeze.
The murd'rer slept in his stony hall,
Such sleep as might come to a wretch like him;
While unearthly hands, an unearthly pall,
Spread over each weary and stalwart limb.
And as he slept, he dreamt a dream
Which fill'd his soul with terror wild;
He woke, and at that moment, a lightning gleam
Disclosed the face of the murder'd child.
When slumber o'er his senses stole,
Despair forsook his guilty soul,
But when he from that slumber woke,
Horror again on his spirit broke,
Hope fled for aye, and with it, joy,
Crush'd by the frown of the murder'd boy,
Who still beside his murd'rer kept,
Whether he woke, or whether he slept;
Like a wrathful vision, in vengeance sent,
A guilty conscience to torment.
"O, who can bear this horrid curse?
What heart endure this vision dread?
Death with its terrors can't be worse!
Nor what is after death!" He said.
Then bounding off, like a stricken deer,
Away through the waste of the lonely glen,
He perish'd, where none could shed a tear,
Nor mourning kinsman dress his bier;
The last sad offices due to men.
Oblivious time had onward sped,
And, as it roll'd, had left a trace
Of snow upon the woodman's head--
Of age upon his rustic face.
Just seventeen summers wing'd their flight
From that disastrous, starlit, night,
When heav'n, illum'd with a rifle's flash,
Beheld a murd'rer hotly dash
Through brush and brake, o'er field and flood,
Along the hill, and through the wood,
With whip and spur, on foaming steed,
Away from the scene of his daring deed.
Just seventeen years had rolled away,
When on a sultry summer day,
Chance led the woodman's feet to roam
(Far from his solitary home)
To the very spot, and the very den,
In the silent, lonely, mountain glen,
Where the murd'rer of his first-born child,
Had slept, and woke, in terror wild.
And as he slowly wound along,
He stumbled o'er a pile of stones,
And found beside them, and among,
A human skull and human bones.
They bore the mark of the wild dog's tooth,
They harmonis'd with the scenes uncouth,
That stretch'd around on ev'ry side,
And fill'd the mountain landscape wide.
And 'neath the edge of a ragged stone,
In contact with a finger bone,
Which on the trigger once had been,
Which gave the fatal pull, I ween,
There lay a long and rusty knife,
Still stain'd with the crimson tide of life,
And on the handle was a name,
The shudd'ring woodman knew too well!
Twas his, who fir'd with deadly aim,
On the starlit night that a cherub fell!
It is quite evident that I might have stayed
my poetical career at the conclusion of the first
canto, and have allowed the reader's imagination
to have finished the story. Had I done so, how-
ever, I would have been guilty of flying in the
face of poetical justice. To hang the villanous
hero of the tale, immediately after the committal
of his awful deed, would have been a very common-
place method of getting rid of him; and would
moreover, have been far too like the Draconic be-
nevolence of modern legislators. I was, therefore,
obliged to conduct him into the lonely wilderness,
and there compel him to become his own execu-
tioner. In the management of this important
matter I have carefully avoided explicitness,
because I consider explicitness as the evil genius
of poetry. Vagueness and obscurity are the
staple elements of rhyme. The poet ought
merely to supply the skeleton of the story, and
leave the fancy of the reader to clothe that skele-
ton with flesh and blood, and skin. This is the
very thing which I have done; and, by doing it,
have the merit of transforming the reader into a
poet by the stimulus which I have given to his
imagination.
In no part of the poem is this vagueness more
conspicuous than in the allusions to spiritual
agency. On this topic I have spoken obscurely from
necessity. Australia is a most unpoetic place.
From Cape Leeuwin to Cape York there is not
so much as a single goddess. We have no
witches, no kelpies, no brownies, no spunkies, no
leprechawns, and, worse than all, "no good
people." I have seen many queer-looking folks
in Sydney, but I never saw a ghost there; nor
have I ever heard of a haunted house having
been discovered in any corner of our huge island.
It is true that we have a god, but he is too yellow
for poetry, and would, if put into a rhyme, make
it look as if it had the jaundice. Besides, it is
almost impossible to get hold of him, for the
common people are so devotedly attached to his
person that they always carry him about with
them buttoned up in their pockets. Under such
circumstances, it was impossible to do more
than obscurely allude to the spiritual beings
that spread an invisible pall over the som-
nolent murderer. The very obscurity of these
allusions, however, will render them applicable to
any spiritualities that may be discovered here-
after; and thus the poem may be truly charac-
terised as written for all time.
And now, courteous teador, ere I finish this
critique, permit me to say a word or two on a
subject that lies very near my heart, namely, my
own surpassing merits us a poet. As I have un-
dertaken the task of criticising my own works, it
is imperatively necessary that I should do
justice to this point. In common, then,
with every son and daughter of song, I do
regard my own poetry as uncommonly
beautiful. Others may dissent from my views on
this head, but what of that? Is not censure the
tax which great men invariably pay for being
great? Do not owls hoot at the sun? Do not
swallows twitter around hawks? Do not dogs bay
the moon, and fleas nibble lions? And, are not
men proverbially envious, shallow-pated, cen-
sorious, and malignantly critical? Believe me,
gentle reader, that I would rather be a kitten,
crying mew, or a snail, travelling up a cabbage
leaf, than rank high in the estimation of those
who are incapable of appreciating true merit.
Hence the opinion of would-be critics, with respect
to my status in thd poetical world, scarcely
costs me thought. Men who agree with me
display, by that agreement, their taste and dis-
cernment; and men who dissent from my views
--why, they merely display their narrowness and
obliquity of judgment, I am independent of the
applauses of the world; I can applaud myself.
And even should you, courteous reader, grumble
at the little book, I shall always attribute yonr
displeasure to the fact that I have very properly
taken the business of criticism out of your hands,
and vested it in the proper authority, to wit, the
bard himself--who is henceforth to be regarded as
the only person competent to judge of his own
merits.
END OF THE LITTLE BOOK.
SIR ASTLEY COOPER.--It has often been re-
marked that some circumstance, apparently ac-
cidental, has tended to influence the future career
of those concerned; and an anecdote is told of
Sir Astley, which, if true, seems to bear out this
idea. It is said that, when a boy, he saw a lad
fall from a cart, and tear his thigh in such
manner as to wound the femoral artery. Our
young hero immediately took his handkerchief,
applied it round the thigh, and twisted it so
tightly as to control the bleeding till further
assistance could be procured. Sir Astley received
some very large fees, among which, not the least
remarkable was that of a thousand guineas
thrown at him in his night cap, by a patient
whom he had cut for the stone: an anecdote
which he told with no small degree of animation,
on retiring from a patient upon whom he had just
performed the same operation, and who had like-
wise, in his agony, flung his cap at the surgeon,
but without it containing, on this occasion, the
cheque which gave so much force to the original
incident. In 1815, when at the height of
his reputation, he removed to Spring-gardens;
and he was one of the few with whom the migra-
tion from the City to the West-end proved fully
successful. A few years afterwards, he was
employed professionally by George IV. to remove
a small tumor from the scalp: an operation which
he performed with all his wonted coolness and
dexterity. Probably, no surgeon of ancient or
modern times enjoyed a greater share of reputa-
tion during his life than fell to the lot of Sir
Astley. The Old and New World has alike rung
with his fame; and we cannot give a better ex-
ample of this than the fact of his signature being
received as a passport among the mountains of
Biscay by the wild followers of Don Carlos. A
young English surgeon, seeking for employment,
was carried as a prisoner before Zumalacarrequi,
who demanded what testimonials he had of his
calling or his qualifications? Our countryman
presented his diploma of the College of Surgeons;
and the name of Astley Paston Cooper, which was
attached to it, no sooner struck the eye of the
Carlist leader, than he at once received his
prisoner with friendship, and appointed him a
surgeon in his army. Sir Astley long enjoyed a
large share of public patronage; but we believe
the actual amount of his fortune, when stated at
half a million, is considerably over-rated. His
personal expenses were not great; but he was very
liberal to his relations, on whom, we have heard,
on what we believe to be good authority, that he
bestowed between two and three thousand pounds
annually. He is also said to have spent £20,000
in bringing his brother into Parliament. Nor
was his liberality confined to his own family.
When Dr. Baillie and some others made up a
purse for Dr. Pemberton in the difficulties
brought upon him by his ill-health, Sir Astley
contributed the munificent sum of £500.
THEATRICAL WIT.--Hatton, who was a consi-
derable favourite at the Haymarket Theatre, and
particularly in the part of Jack Junk, was one
night at Gosport, performing the character of
Barbarossa. In the scene when the tyrant makes
love to Zapphira, and reminds her of his services
against the enemies of her kingdom, he was at a
loss, and could not catch the word from the
prompter. Another moment and a terrific hiss
would have driven him from the stage, when,
seeing the house crowded with sailors, and re-
gardless of the gross anachronism, he exclaimed,
with all the energy of tragedy--
-----------Did not I,
By that brave knight Sir Sydney Smith assisted
And in conjunction with the gallant Nelson,
Drive Bonaparte and his fierce marauders
From Egypt's shores?
The jolly tars thought that it was all in his part
and cheered the actor with three rounds of
applause.
RARE VIRTUE.--The paucity of some persons'
good actions remind one of Jonathan Wild, who
was once induced to be guilty of a good action,
after fully satisfying himself, upon the maturest
deliberation, that he could gain nothing by refrain-
ing from it.

title: THE PRUNING OF THE VINE.
content:
THE PRUNING OF THE VINE.
C.F. GERLER.
" My Father it the husbandman."—John xv., v. 1—8.
A HUSBANDMAN with careful hand.
In pruning vines much time does spend,

The Husbandman our father it :•—
Thit is a thought of joyful blisa—

Cariiborg. May SO, 1572.
• Amnu. Panßna. Born, June 2, IBM; died, Msy 24,
187 S.
Hohob tottb Bvstvbss.—lt is a good sign
when a man is proud of his work or calling.
Tet nothing is more common than to hear men
finding fault constantly with tbeir particular
business, and deeming themselves unfortunate
because fastened to it by the necessity of
gaining a livelihood. In thia men fret, and
laboriously destroy all their comfort in the work;
or they change their buaineit, and go on miser
ably, shifting from one thing to another till the
grave or the poor-house gives them a fast grip.
But while occasionally a man fails in life because
he is not in the place fitted for his peculiar
talent, it happens ten timea oftener that failure
results from neglect and even contempt of an
honest business. A msn shonld put his heart
into everything tbat he does. There is no pro
fession that has not its peculiar cares and vexa
tions. No man will e-cape annoyance by chang
ing his business. No mechanical business is
altogether agreeable. Commerce, in ita endless
varieties, it affected, like all other pursuits, with
trials, unwelcome duties, and spirit-tiring neoet
sities. It is the very wantonness of folly for a
man to search ont the frets and burdens of bis
calling, and give bis mind every day to a con
sideration of them. They belong to human life.
They are.inevitable. Brooding over them only
gives them strength. On the other hsnd, a
man has power given him to shed beauty and
pleasure on the homeliett toil, if be it wise. Let
a man adopt his business and identify it with
pleasant associations; for Heaven has given us
imagination, not alone to make us poets, but to
enable all men to beautify homely thingt.
Heart-varniih will cover up innumerable evila
and defectt. Look at the good thingt. Accept
your lot as a man doea a piece of rugged ground,
and begin to get out the roota and rocka, to
deepen and mellow the soil, to enrich and plant
it. There is something in the most forbidding
avocation around which a man may twine plea
sant fancies, out of which he may develop an
honest pride.
Thb Islabus nr Bass Stbaits.—Of Cape
Barren Island, Bast tayi: "The rocks were
covered with fur seals of great beauty, of a
tpeciei approaching; nearest that named by na
turalists ss the Falkland Island seal" And
Flinders gives a more particular description of
them. In speaking of Cone Point, on the ex
treme S.E. or Cape Barren Island, hia words
are: " The number of teals exceeded everything
we had any of ua before witnesaed, and they
were smaller *>nd of a different species from
those which frequented Armstrong's Channel.
Instead of the bulldog note and thinly-set
sandy hair, these hid sharp-pointed noses, and
the general color of the hair approached to black,
but the tips were of a silver grey, and under
neath waa a fine, whitish, tbick fur. The com
motion excited by our pretence, in this assem
blage of several thousand timid animali, was
very interesting to me who knew little of their
manners. The young cubs huddled together
in the holes of the rocks und moaned piteously;
those more advanced scampered and rolled down
to the water with their mothers; while some of
the old vale* stood up in defence of tbeir fami
lies, until the terror of the tailors' bludgeons
became too strong to be resitted. Thote who
bave seen a farm yard well stocked with pigs,
calves, sheep, oxen,.and with two or three Utters
of poppies, with their mothers in it, and have
heard them all in tumult together, may form a
good idea of the confused noise of the seals at
Cone Point." Of Patriarch Island, Bait re
marks that "he found the outermost island
well inhabited Tbe various tribei had divided
it into districts; obe part wat white with gar
nets, breeding in netti of earth and dried grais;
petrels and penguins had their underground
Invitations in those parts of the island which
had most grass. Tbe rocks of tbe shore, and
blocks of granite, were occupied by tbe pied
offensive sh»g and common gull; geese, red
billa, and quails, lived in common, and the rest
was appropriated to the teals, wbo teemed to be
lords of the domain." " The males, who pos
sessed a rock to themselves, -where tbey sat sur
rounded by their numerous wives and progeny,
on his drawing near them, hobbled up with a
menacing roar, and fairly commenced the at
tack," Ac— Beport of the Eoyal Society of
Tasmania.
Madaoascab.—Few geographical researchei
of modern times hare been more interest ing
than those carried on in Madagascar by It. A.
Orandidier, whether we consider our previous
ignorance of tbe region in quettion, or the num
ber of striking and important tcientifio novelties
brought to light. Thii gentleman has lately
returned from his third expedition, the first
having been commenced in 1865. On this oc
casion he attempted to reach tbe heart of the
island, but in vain; and in the following year
he explored the southern region, but did not
reach the mountain!. In 1869-70, however, he
traversed tbe entire breadth of the itland three
times, from wett to east, through its whole ex
tent, making various lateral excursions to inter
esting pointt, and vititing the peak of the
mountain Ankaararatre, the hijheat tummit in
Madagascar. According to M. Grandidier'a re
port, Madagascar comprises two diitinct regions
—the northern, which ia mountaiuout, and that
to the south and east, which ia flat. He ascer
tained that there are fire chains of mountains,
which have generally the same direction—
namely, from north-east to south west. These
are separated by sand* and arid plains, inter
sected by shallow ravinei. After crotting the
fourth chain, a region it reached of which the
general level it from 1000 to 1200 meteri in
height, extending to the Indian Ocean, a vait
sea of mountains, with no level lands except a
few small valleys used for the cultivation of rice.
The eastern coast it intersected at almost every
step with rivers and torrents *, and the north
western provinces pour into the sea a large
number of important rivers. On the southern
and western regions, however, the case it quite
different, there being dittances of fifty leaguea
without the smallest brook. The reputation
poeeeaaed by Madagascar for luxuriant vegeta
tion and fertile soil, according sa M. Orandidier,
is by no means merited, its provinces being
neither rich nor productive. The secondary
plains are sterile, and tbe population is con
fined to the immediate banks of tbe water
courses. The entile matt of tbe granitic
mountains, situated to ibe west of the eastern
slope, is naked and arid, and there is no vegeta
tion, excepting here and there little bunches
growing in tbe ravines.— Harper's Weekly.

title: The Omen.
content:
The Omen.
A FRAGMENT.
EXILE.
A RAVEN flew across the land
lerne with a hollow croak,
And each to each the witches spoke,
"Calamity is nigh at hand."
Bat onoe before that voice was heard
O'er fen and reek, from coast to coast;
And lo! a famine-stricken host
Crouched down to die, all wan and soared.
Thro* vale and mountain came the breath
Of pestilence for many a day,
Sweeping the best-beloved away,
Smiting the sea-girt isle with death.
And yet again the bitter wail
Rose up to Heaven, and fell, and rose,
And fell upon the spim repose
Of ragged hill and blighted valeT
The Death and Ruin, hand in hand,
Stalked here and there and everywhere:
Behind were years of blank despair, '
And want, and woe, from strand to strand.
All heaven and earth seemed leagued to braise
The bruised reed still more and more,
And on the land fierce wrath outpour,
Breaking a struggling nation's thews.

title: Original Poetry.
content:
Original Poetry
WISDOM.
Say what is Wisdom ? Ah 'tis but to know
That all is vanity, or worse, below.
'Tis to be fated with a prophet eye
Without the stength to dare, the power to fly :
O'er past Times' shameful history to brood
Without the hope of better, if as good.
Intending ease to find the body whole
The sickly captive of th' ambitious soul;
Or with an intellectual flight designed.
The brutal body dragging down the mind.
To have a touch so keen — a glance so staid,
Life's seeming substance proves an empty shade.
'Tis while o'er others' meannesses we groan
In self discovering naught that might atone
To read in others' littleness, our own.
To dread that if explored Fate's stormy night-
Rapt in its lightennigs to their farthest flght
Would be to perish in insufferable Light !
C. HARPUR.

title: Cooking Eggs.
content:
Cooking Eggs.
. A LEGEND. .. .
There lies -within the China Sea
'An island small-though what may bo
ItB name is quite unknown to me
To which a sailor landing there,
Gave, in return for friendly care,
Some poultry of the common breed;
(A valuable gift Indeed,
You'll say, on hearing that till them
The natives never saw a hen!)
'And thus of eggs they learned to eat;
Boiled eggs were deemed a special treat;
No other mode the people sought
Than boiling-as the sailor taught
God bless him-for the proper way
Of cooking eggs; until, one day,
Some lucky fellow tried the plan
Of cooking in a. frying-pan ;
And with such excellent success
That all who ate, at once confess
The trick worth knowing. By-and-bye
Some innovator chanced to try
If baking eggs might not by chance
The culinary art advance.
The people eat and answered: "Good!
Baked eggs are most delicious food!"
Invention is contagious; soon
Some cook essayed the stirring spoon,
'And, lo! an omelette appears!
'iWhich all receive with hearty cheers
For him'who, by some god'inspired,
Left nothing more to be desired! . :
At length, some daring artisan
In cookery essayed the plan
Of stewing eggs; whereat he cried
(When, he the precious dish had trièd):
''Eggs with tomatoes stewed are best;
Let all who doubt the truth attest!"
"Good!" said the people, "very good;"
'And so thenceforth their eggs were stewed;
Until, one day, a stranger came,
.Who straightway won immortal fame,
The while the miracle he taught
Of eggs cooked a la Huguenot!
But why proceed to tell the tale
Of all the fashions that prevail
Of cooking eggs? How they increased
To half a hundred, at.the-least?
And how the latest, all protest,
Whate'er the mode, was still the best?
These flippant eulogies to.hear,
Offended much a sage's ear,
'And thus he spoke: "Prate, as ye may;
Call this or that the finest way
Of cooking eggs; but, as for me',
What praise in' cookery may be'
I leave to other tongues and pens;
God bless the man who,brought the hens!"
' ' ' MORAL !
The reader of'our modern books.
¡Will often see what ;cie'vèr cooks
May' do' with' eggs-who' never name,
'She ancient-poultry whence they came!

title: LITERATURE
content:
LITERATURE
Original Poetry.
An Episode of Bush Life.
BY "DRAMINGO."
THE hot fierce sun above; below, the river
In glittering sparkles flashing back each ray:
Scarcely a breath to make the tree tops quiver,
Or rustle 'midst their leaves in idle play.
Scarcely a sound to tell that life is teeming
In the dense scrub that lines the winding creek
In drowsy stillness sleeps the forest—dreaming—
Save where a parrot wakes it with a shriek.
A long harsh shriek! like one in anguish dying,
Or eldritch cursing with unholy ban ;
As though the frightened bird had seen there lying
The dead horse, on the living breathing man ;
And, in that startled glance, instinct had told it
The meaning of the tragedy below,
And ere it flew, in pity to behold it,
It cried aloud, in one long wail of woe.
"Is this a dream ? Can I be really here ?
The dead horse lying on my shattered bone;
No chance of life ! No friend, no comrade near !
Nought left but death—a lingering death—alone,
"How many dreadful hours must I await
Death's coming?—for he is my only friend,
Who in his mercy kindly will abate
My sufferings, and console me at the end.
"Will he come quickly? Shall I see him stand
And gaze at me with eyes of solemn greeting?
Then will he stoop, and with an icy hand
Touch my warm heart, and still its weary beating?
"Or, in the evening's shadow-haunted gloom,
When through the trees I hear the night-wind roam,
But as a darker shadow will he loom,
And gently comfort me, and take me home?
"Ah night! dear night! so cool, and calm, and still;
Could I but drink once more, in peace I'd lie
In your dark arms ; let me but have my fill
Of that sweet water ! God, then let me die.
" In the deep silence I can hear it splash
Amongst the rocky boulders far below.
Oh! could I only reach the side, and dash
My fevered body in its cooling flow!
"Keep back, you fiend! I see you hiding there
Behind that tree-trunk, mocking me in scorn:
Grinning and mowing, with a wicked stare
That could not come save from a thing hell-born.
"You'll go away when the hot day is done,
And the kind night cools me with dewy rain;
But when the east glows red before the sun
You will return, and torture me again;
"Showing me where the sparkling river falls
Over the rocks—so close! O Heaven, and then
Delude me with false answers to my calls
For aid and succour from my fellow-men.
"Give me quick death, if you have mercy, Christ,
And are the God of love, and not of fear!
Why torture me? Surely it had sufficed
To take my life—not leave me lingering here.
"If fiend you are, then work your fiendish will;
Burning me with fierce sun and fiercer thirst:
Crushed, lone, and helpless, I defy you still;
I'll pray no more, but hold you for accursed.
"Ah! do not bind me! Give me water, pray!
And I'll not struggle more, but let the flame
Consume me calmly; only take away
Those haunting eyes—that head, bowed in shame.
"Call no more ghosts; there are enough here now;
If this is hell I cannot now atone
For past misdeeds. O cool my aching brow !
Keep off, you devils ! Let me die alone.
"How balmy feels the air! and the soft sound
Of chiming bells comes on the evening breeze,
So rich with fragrance, from the flower-decked ground
From hawthorn hedges, and from chestnut trees.
"This well-known lane! The old familiar place
Left years ago, but never quite forgot—
This hand in mine! Is it my sister's face?
How little changed! To think I know you not!
"True, I am weak and faint; but we will go
To the old churchyard, and when there we'll stray
Amongst the quiet tombs, and you can show
Me those of friends, lost since I went away.
"Strange! it is falling dark; and where I stand
There seems an open grave. Surely I live!
And yet—I'm blind; and now—how cold your hand!
This must be death ! Have mercy—God—forgive."

title: THE BRAVE OLD PLOUGH.
content:
THE BRAVE OLD PLOUGH.
A song to tho plough, tho bravo old plough.
That hath ruled the wido world o'er,
For lifo and good faro on his strong stool sharo
Shall dopond for overmere :
Thoro is strength in his boam, as tho toiling team
Turns tho furrow so long and deep,
Whilo it mellows tho tod, wo havo trust in God
That His promise Ho will surely keep.
Thon a health to tho plough, to tho bravo old plough,
"Who hath fed all tho nations gono ;
And glory ns now to tho bravo old plough
' "When a thousand years have flown.
Thou hast scon tho timo when no pealing chimo
"Was hoard tho wido world through ;
Whon tho King's broad hall and cottago small
[ Of a Christmas never know.
And many a day along the highway
Havo hundreds starving lain,
Thoy aro dead, thoy are gono, to earth's bosom borno
But tho.plough it still doth roign.
Then God speed tho plough, tho bravo old plough,
"Who hath fed all tho nations pone,
And glory as now to tho bravo old plough
When a thousand years havo flown.
Thou hast soon tho time, in many a elimo,
Whon tho broad was hard to win,
Whon both groat and small, at hunger's call,
Woro led into deadly sin ;
But thou no'er can'st say thou hast soon tho day,
When want bowed the strong man's hoad,
Tho rightoous man's seed, in his greatest need,
Ever bogged for his daily bread.
Thon God speed tho plough, tho bravo old plough,
Who hath fed all tho nations gono ;
And may glory as now oncirclo tho plough
When a thousand years have flown.

title: LINES.
content:
LINES.
SUGGESTED BY CERTAIN DISGUSTING ATTACKS
UPON PRIVATE CHARACTER, CONTAINED IN A
SCANDALOUS AND OBSCENE PERIODICAL.
Curs'd be the wretch (to man a living shame)
Who casts his venon o'er his neighbour's fame
Who, snake-like, lies in ambush on the ground,
And who delights the virtuous breast to wound.
Whose business seems, from covert dark to fire,
And wound the worth to which he can't aspire.
The MAN of honest worth and noble heart,
Receives, unhurt, the demon's hellish dart.
Not so the gentler sex: if liars assail
THEIR spotless fame (though ne'er can they pre
vail),
Yet, though that fame survive unhurt the blast,
The HEART accutely feels the shock that's past.
Let, then, the wretch droop low his guilty head,
Despised, abhorred, to manly feeling dead;
Nor ever more allow his filthy pen -.
To raise the scorn of honest upright men.
Civia.
"The schoolmaster Is abroad."
Brougham.
IN the Cornwall Chronicle of the 3rd instant,
there appears an advertisement, headed " homo
genious dinner." The writer was evidently in
want of a pompous adjective, and like Mrs. Mal
aprop, has made use of a most heterogenious one.
Query-What sort of a dinner Is really meant?
Querist.
THE BUSHRANGERS.-We announced in our
last that Jeffs' and Conway had been captured.
The party, headed by Mr. Thomas Connell, had
explored the ground in the neighbourhood with
out success, and the constable had intimated to
the Campbell Town police magistrate that the
bushraigers were not then there.- Having heard
nothing of their movements since the 17th ultimo,
Mr. Stuart ordered that the party should continue
on the same field, until positive intelligence of the
appearance of Jeff's and his companion at some
other point should be made known. But on Fri
day last, as the constables were approaching a hut
on the South Esk, occupied by Mr. Youl's shep
herd, both the bushrangers rushed from the dwell
ing, and endeavoured to elude the party by dog
ing behind trees. Jeffs, we believe, threw down
his gun, but afterwards resumed it. - However,
upon being repeatedly summoned to surrender,
and seeing escape impossible, they both cast away
their weapons, and held up their hands in token
of submission. It is gratifying to learn that these
men have been apprehended without farther blood
shed. The hut-keeper and another free man
found in the hut, were arrested on the suspicion
of harbouring Jeffs and Conway, and are now in
custody at Campbell Town. .
ROBERY.-A most impudent but successful
robbery was committed on Saturday night. A
large iron safe, belonging to Mr. Rocher, was re
moved from its place adjoining his bedroom, and
forcibly broken open. The considerate thieves
did not disturb the documents to them of
no value, but of the greatest importance to
Mr. Rocher- but they walked off with all the
cash the safe contained. The thieves must have
been well acquainted with the locality, and adepts
at their profession.
THE LATE RAINS.-There is nothing which
contributes so much to the health of the inhabit
ants of a town as a thorough and proper system
drainage. Hence the recent extensive enquiries
made by order of the imperial parliament, as to
the sanitory statistics of the different towns and
cities at home. It has been found that some
towns, situated in elevated localities, and gene
rally considered in healthy districts, but where
the duties of the public scavenger and proper
ventilation were neglected, have been the most rife
with those diseases and fevers which malaria
makes our poor flesh heir to: and, on the other
hand, where the site was low, and consequently
strongly suspected of being unhealthy, was found
the reverse-from the very circumstance of its
situation causing precautions against those natural
evils which were so apparent. Of this latter class
is Launceston. It is low, and confined by hills
on all sides, except when the river displays its
banks of mud flats, with the extensive swamps
beside it after such a rainy winter as was the last.
The summer told a fearful tale of death, from
dysentry, fevers, and other similar causes; while
the miasmata from the stagnant pools and un
drained portion of our streets ascended unchecked
and unheeded, We believe Sir John Franklin
made some particular enquiries on this head,
while here lately ; and we trust that there is truth
in the report that since the last heavy rains the
Town Surveyor has turned his attention to this
point, as he is in expectation of orders to carry
out an efficient system of good and thorough
drainage. From the favourable site of the town,
having a complete fall to Margaret-street, its
lowest level, and the velocity with which, in wet
weather, the water runs off from the streets
around the Windmill-hill-a course of subdivided
surface drains, which would be quickly dry and
easily repaired in case of accidental damage-it
might be easily accomplished. We trust the at
tention of the authorities to so essential a point
will be instant and energetic.-Communicated.
DR. LANG--Thls highly talented, bold, ener
getic, but eccentric individual has arrived at
Port Phillip per "Sea Horse," via Launceston,
for the purpose of personally canvassing the elec
tors of that district. While at Launceston he
published in the Examiner an address to the pres
byterians of that town. We regret to see that the
Examiner, the agent of the Doctor's own paper,
the Observer, permitted the insertion in its co
lumns of a very violent attack upon the Doctor.
Its object may be very good, but that the Exami
ner should be the vehicle of its appearance, was
not in the best taste. This journal differs very
essentially from Dr. Lang on many subjects po
litical and religious, but so long as we act as the
agent of a newspaper, personal assailers of him
must go elsewhere. We shall insert the most Im
portant passages of his Launceston address in our
next number.-Murray's Review.
SYDNEY-AUSTRALIAN BANK.-A typogra
phical error occurred in a short paragraph under
the above head, in our last number. It was stated
that the directors of the Bank of Australasia were
to discontinue business. It is the local Bank of
Australia which is about to wind up its affairs;
and respecting which so much animadversion has
appeared in the public prints. The Bank of Aus
tralasia is a very different establishment. It is an
English bank, and has branches at Hobart Town
and Launceston, in this colony; Port Phillip,
and South Australia. The similarity of the names
is apt to induce mistake, and we therefore take
the opportunity to state that the Bank of Austra
lia is a Sydney local bank, while the Bank of Aus
tralasia exists in all the important towns in the
Australasian settlements.
MECHANICS' INSTITUTE.-WE understand that
the Rev. Mr. West has postponed his lecture, and
allowed Dr. Udny to occupy the night advertised,
so that the Mechanics' Institute and teetotal lec
tures may not clash. There will, therefore, be no
lecture to-morrow night at the Mechanics' Insti
tute.
TEETOTAL SOCIETY.-A lecture will be de
livered by Mr. Nichols, at the Infant School-room,
to-morrow evening.
FENTON'S FORD.-On Saturday two persons
attempting to cross at this place in a chaise-cart
narrowly escaped drowning, and were indebted
for their lives to the servant of the police magis
trate, who was accidentally there at the time. The
horse was lost, but the cart will be recovered. It
is rather remarkable that the man and woman
who were rescued from a watery grave were, with
two other men, apprehended on Sunday morning
by that active gentleman, Mr. Hortle, for the
robbery of a house in Longford. The parties are
committed for further examination.
PORTLAND BAY.-An absurd affair of honour,
as it is called, took place on the beach at this set
tlement, and.hns been duly chronicled in the pub
lic prints. The parties immediately concerned,
were Dr. Corney and the postmaster; and they
were determined to prove by fighting which was
the gentleman, as the one had denied the propri
ety of this appellation to the other. The seconds
with commendable humanity, furnished the belli
gerents with pistols loaded with powder and
paper: the duel was not attended with fatal con
sequences to any one.
THE WATER CONTRACT.-Mr, Wakefield has
very properly taken occasion of the refusal of
government to ratify the contract with Captains
Cheyne and Swanston, to direct public attention
to the subject. Want of space precludes us from
noticing the matter at greater length this number,
but we will have a few suggestions to offer in our
next.
PORTLAND.-This place is fast rising in impor
tance, and it is happily free from that distress
which so fearfully affects the other settlements.
Speculation in land has there been yet almost
unknown, and a superficial show of prosperity
has not deceived those connected with the place.
We are Informed that the imports last year did
not exceed £22,000, while the exports during the
same period, are estimated at £40,000. Including
202 bales of wool from Port Fairy, about 2050
bales were shipped from Portland.
THE following was Sir George Arthur's opinlon
of the colony, expressed in one of his despatches
in June 1832, and was given to the public in the
last Review:-" A young colony, and especially
one based upon a convict population, is always
liable to great and sudden changes. There is no
substantial, solid, capital accumulated to sustain it
against those calamitous events to which every
country is more or less exposed; and until the
stability is acquired, it is impossible to be too
guarded in every act which is to affect the com-
munity; and at least all measures generally un-
popular ought to be avoided, unless they are ab
solutely necessary, and then public opinion will
eventually, when the ferment of the moment has
subsided, support their introduction."
THE brig Leo, Bell, from Liverpool, arrived
here on Wednesday last, with a general cargo.
This vessel left England on the 3rd January, and
from the evening of that day to the 18th expe
rienced a series of gales and severe weather down
the channel and in the Bay of Biscay. Last Tues.
day week the Leo was struck over the stern by a
sea, which carried away the wheel and part of the
round-house, and threw the helmsman with con-
siderable force against the skylight, severely in-
juring the man's breast and arm. The Leo brings
a few papers, which, not being later than the 31st
December, add but little to our stock of English
intelligence.-Courier.
SPORTING INTELLIGENCE.-The midland bea
gle pack had their first meet on Saturday last, in
the vicinity of York Plains. The day was beau
tiful, and the field well attended; and the sport
was allowed, on all hands, to be exceedingly good
-allowance being made for the pack having been
so recently brought together from various quarters
where they have been dispersed during the sum
mer months. At the conclusion of a successful
chase the gentlemen present, consisting almost ex
clusively of members of the hunt, were hospitably
entertained by John Lord, Esquire.
The first appointed meeting of the Clarendon
hounds took place at Campbell Town on Wednes
day, and was attended by a well mounted field,
and favoured with a fine moist day. A stag was
provided by that liberal patron of the sports of
the field, James Cox, Esq., of Clarendon, and at
eleven o'clock was released from a cart in a judi
cious position contiguous to the township. Unlike
his antlered brother of the last season, he took a
northerly direction for M'Leod's mill, followed
after ten minutes' law (the fairest law that's
known) by the hounds and huntsmen. A short
gallop brought to a check, when it was found the
game had taken the water, and was seen swim
ming majestically up.the Elizabeth river, followed
by several of the foremost hounds. It was thought
prudent, however, by the assemnbled sportsmen to
whip the dogs off and again to give the privilege
of the law, of chase to the fugitive, who repaid
them with an admirable run, being finally taken
in the Wanstead pastures, and secured for a se
cond day's sport, arranged to take place from
Tunbridge Wells, on Wednesday, the 14th inst.
The pack was hunted in his usual. good style by
James Lord, Esq.-Ibid.
THE BUSHRANGERs.-A party of police, led
by a New South Wales native, is busily engaged
in tracking these depredators; and it is confidently
believed, from the encouragement attending the
pursuit, that they will soon be under the safeguard
of Mr. Capon. At the stock-run of Mr. Austin,
in the vicinity of Lake Echo, they had the teme
rity to slay and dress a fat beast. Here the con-
stables were not far behind them, and soon after
wards, in colonial vernacular, "sprung a portion
of the plant" taken from Captain M'Kay. The
horses lately in their possession were found in the
vicinity of Victoria Valley.-lbid.
INTEREST.-We are glad to learn that the Der
went Bank has really reduced the rate of interest
on mortgages due to itself, to 8 per cent. One has
been effected at that rate, and we understand
the measure will become general from the 24th of
June. This, of course, does not affect those
mortgages of which the bank holds the agency for
other parties, but we believe the principal mana
ger, Captain Swanston, has recommended them
to pursue the same course; advice too salutary

title: Original Poetry.
content:
Original Poetry
--o
SONNET.
When you arrive at Sydney, sailing up
The harbour, a small central isle you'll see,
With two or three low huts-but not a tree,
Nor blade of gro?s-upon't ; and, on the top,
A score of men In coarse habiliments,
Hewing the rock away. You may romember,
Among the many evil-traced events
Of a town life, some robbery, when December
lrought on the long, dark nights-a neighbour's boy
Tried for't, and banished. Ile, perchance, is olne
Who yonder lills the pickalxe in the sun,
To level Pittcintgt Island! If e'er joy
Gllulden'd your helart on Englatnd's shore, oh never
Forget that Englishmen are banished here for ever.
H. PARKES.

title: OWED TO R. T. JAMISON, ESQ.
content:
OWED TO R. T. JAMISON, ESQ.
John Chinaman, my Joe John,
I wonder what you'll say,
When you find that you're compelled
Ten golden pounds to pay;
Ten pounds per head to pay, John,
A tax on young and old,
Before you have the privilege
Of digging up our gold.
John Chinaman, my Joe, John,
When New South Wales began
To test her hidden treasures, John,
She welcomed every man;
And you among them all, John,
To come here were not slow
With your cradles and your bamboo canes,
John Chinaman, my Joe.
John Chinaman, my Joe, John,
It was a brave conceit
To let all poor adventurers
Upon our gold-fields meet;
Though some folks thought it odd, John,
We did not deem it so,
But let all nations share alike,
John Chinaman, my Joe.
But soon we found, John Chinaman,
You were not like the rest,
For thousands of your countrymen
Upon us quickly pressed;
To put a stop to this, John,
And keep you within bounds,
The Act has now been passed, John,
To make you pay ten pounds.
John Chinaman, John Chinaman,
Oh! When we knew you first
We did not think for gold, John,
You'd show such mighty thirst;
But nothing keeps you back, John,
Each vessel that arrives,
Brings several hundred Chinamen,
And all without their wives!
John Chinaman, my Joe, John,
It seems quite clear to me,
The myriads that keep coming, John,
From your dear land of tea,
Would very soon quite swamp us,
And that would never do;
You'd better stay at home, John,
Or bring your sweethearts too.

title: The Little Laureate's Competition.
content:
Thc Little Laureate's Competition.
A WRECK AT SEA. ;
(By Amy Hogue.)
The shrieking wind had lulled àt last,
The clear bright air was scarcely, chill,
And after that ono awful blast,
The cruel waves were cairn "and still.
Above the wide now cheerful sky,
Where blue succeeded black and grey;
Where rose one earnest mother's cry,
As grim night lightened into day.
Below the brilliant placid sea,
" So lately tossed by angry storm;
Below-all round-tranquility,
On waves the .sun was turning warm.
The captain's wife was up on deck,
To see the first faint streak of dawn ;
A child's warm, hands had clasped her neck;
A child's kies pressed a face grown worn.
The sun rose higher in the sky;
The sea flashed beautiful and bright;
But lower sank the ship to die,
Away from all that glorious light.
Down, down, why looked the world so fadr.
So beautiful-so full of light?
When they must go far, far down there.
To darkness, cokl, and black os night.
Strong men with brown hand clasped in hand.
Think of a sweetheart, child, or wife;
Lcok at the trio as they stand,
Together to the last in life.
The child lies on the mother's breast,
Sleeping with tranquil, sweet-drawn breath;
Perhaps, unconscious, that brief rest
Might deepen to the sleep of Death.
Down, lower yet; then one swift rush .
Startles the water into waves; .
Waves that all seem to murmur "Hush!"
A requiem o'er so many graves.
'Tis over now; the waves grow wide, v
Whispering still so mournfully;
Mourning for those brave souls that died
With only their great God to see.

Not with the tongue of flame, the word ef fire,

a bit."
Theii's is tbe grief which does not show its sores,
And seek compassion by the beggar's art ;
It is the sorrow which in silence pores
Upon its ills, and bides tbem in its heart;
It stretches forth its hands for help-shall wa
That succour give f A voice is heard on bigb,
The answer of a people great and free,
" We will relieve, and stay that bitter cry.
That almost mate appeal, wbioh tharne and pride will

PADDIKOTON Sunny HIXXS Firczs.-A meeting of th]
company was held OD Thursday night, for the pnrpos
cleoting a corporal, rice Greville, resigned. There «et
I loor candidates, and the voting terminated in favour <
Mr. Albeit Manton, At the conclusion of this bneints:
! a committee ef seven members was chosen to carry on
i all tbe arrangements for fotuie shooting matohep; Th
: appointment cf a permanent stttf.sergoant was also not]
( Qed to Ibe company.
COEOKEB'S INQUEST.-The city coroner held an in
qaeat on Thursday morning, at the Bush Tätern, Par
ramatta-roed. Barwood, respecting the death of i
married woman named Margaret HaDcneld, aged aban:
fifty-eight years, wbo, in company with her husband
ai rived at tbe tavern, from Parramatta, on Tuesday
afternoon. Deceased, it appeared, was a native of Cork,
Ireland, and had been over thirty-four years in ibe
colony; she came ont a prisoner of the Crown, On Toes
day morning last d'ceased and her bnsband left Parra,
matta, where both were inmates of tbe Benevolent
Asylum daring the three preceding weeks, to walk to
Sydney, where they intended procuring medios] treat,
ment for the husband's eyes, wbioh were in some wry
affected. Th*y had a little money in their possession
when starting, and they arrived at tba Bush Tavern,
where they obtained leave to atop all night, about fire
o'olook in the afternoon. They had something to drink
on tbe way. Before geing to bed at night, deceated bad
. glasa of ram. She then went rjp.Bt.air«, and threw
herself across tbe bed, with her clothes on, her face
downwards, ber feet rested on the floor. Her husband.
»ho was also lying in bis clothes, then fell asleep, and
awaking shortly before daylight, found deceased qiite
dead. Dr. Woodnoak made a pott mortem examination
on the boJy, and found the remains of extensiva and
lorg standing disease. He stated death to have been
the result of asphyxia. Verdict-Died from suffocation J
wben labouring nader the effects of liquor. |

title: Mrs. Pratt and Her Cat.
content:
Mrs. Pratt and Her Gat.
(A Lodging-house Incident.)
Of oourse it's the cat-there's no doubt about that-«
Who has hacked off a hunch of my cheese !
Your oat, Mrs. Pratt, is a wonderful oat,
But his wonderful ways do not please.
None know better than I that he'll make butterfly,
But grub such as cheese seemed secure ;
Broad goes slice after slice-cribbed perhaps by the
mice,
Though of that I by no means feel sure.
Meat the same fate has shared, eggs but seldom are
Bpared,
Tea, sugar, and other things go ;
Every day, Mrs. Pratt, I am robbed by your cat
I have never caught sight of him, though.
I wish that I could, for then, ma'am, I should
Take nine of his lives, at the least ;
I always seem out when he's prowling about
With intent on my victuals to feast.
Why, look, Mrs. Pratt !-your cat has been at
My wine ! He is doomed ! He will die !
For I poisoned it! EhP Why, she's fainted
away I . . .
Ha ! ha ! ha !.. . She comes round with a sigh.
No, no, Mrs. Pratt, you won't die ; but the oat
Will be dead in-Be calm, madam, do !
You dying P No, no ! It cannot be so- , >v,
You have not drunk the poisoned wine, too.,
You "just tasted a dropP" Oh, indeed ! Did you
ston
At the urop, or-? How much did you drink?*
" A-a mouthful or two ?" Then it's all up .with
y°u ! ...
You will soon want a coffin, I think.
Come, oome! don't give way to hysteria, pray . , .
Ha ! ha ! ha ! Puss will soon see Old Nick , . ,
Now, don't he phrenetic. Take a mustard emetio ;.
You'll be safe if you only get sick.
She is gone from the room, but not gone to her doom.
For there's nothing amiss with the wine !
She shall never know that-neither she nor the oat j -
They won't touoh it henceforth, I opine !
_, 0, J,

title: Original Poetry.
content:
Original Poetry.
Impromptu on reading in an Irish newspaper that
nine hundred thousand Orangemen had pre-
sented a loyal address to the Lord Lieutenant
of Ireland, and offered at a few days notice to
raise a force of ten thousand armed men to de
fend the laws and Constitution against the
Catholic movement in that country.
A NEW ORANGE SONG.
For the Argus.
When treason rais'd her bloody hand
And spread rebellion through the land,
A noble and devoted band
Of Orangemen alone,
Ready to enter on her wars,
And to protect their country's cause,
And to support her glorious laws,
Her Altars and the Throne.
In numbers near a million strong,
A noble and a gallant throng,
Whose deeds in story and in song,
Have of't pass'd in review,
With swelling heart and glancing eye,
They rais'd their banner to the sky—
See it now floating proud and high,
The Orange and the Blue.
Can Erin be in danger then,
While she can find a million men,
Collect on mountain, moor, and glen,
And ready to defend her.
When every man will do or die,
And when were any known to fly,
Who use the famous battle cry,
The gallant "no surrender."
J. P.
Melbourne,
2nd October, 1848.

title: An Emigrant's Blessing.
content:
An Emigrant's Blessing. !
Â prophecy of the f ature greatness of Australia,
written in 1845, and published in 184G, in a volume
entitled "Voices From The Crowd." (By;Charles1
Mackay). I
Farewoll England ! Blessings on thee, '.. -j
Stern and niggard as thou art, \
Harshly, Mother ! thou hast us'd me 5 !
And my bread thou hast refus'd me. ;
But 'tis agony to part. |
'Twill pass over ! for I would not :
Bear again what I could tell- j
Half the ills that I have suffer'd !
, Though I lov'd theo twice as well. ¡
So my blessings on thee, England, !
And a long and sad farewell ! i
Other regions will provide mo Í
Independence for my age 5 !
Recompense for hard exertion ; |
For-my children the reversion
Of a goodly heritage. :}
England ! this thou oouldst not give me- J
England, pc-mperer of squires,
Landlord, priest, and lawyer-ridden, ?
Quencher of the poor man's fires, .
But farewell ! my blessings on thee ! ?' " 1
Thou art country of my sires. j
Though I love, I'm glad to leave thee. . . » Í
Who would live in hopeless toil, 1 i
Evil-stoep'd, and ill exampl'd, : |
Press'd and foster'.d, orush'd and trampl'd, j
Interlopers oh tho soil, ; j
If there wore one other "country j
Where an honest man might go, j
' Winning cornfields from the forest . ? -.-..> î
; 1 AU his own.'tooj blow;by blow ? * , v i
, Farewoll England ! I regret theo ; , ¡ i . ' !
But my tears refuse to flow.
Haply, o'er the Southern Ooean ?????< ? ¡
: I shall do my part to rear , . . ;. ! . . ¡
. : A.new nation, Saxon-blooded, . ; , . ; j
Which, with plenty;crowned and studded, . ; .-.., i
To its happy children dear, ¡
Shall eclipse thy fame, oh England ! i
Taught and warn'd alike by thee, ?.... 1 ?? .. !
Mightier with unsha'okl'd commerce, . i
Mightier with her men more free, i
. Mightier in her virgin vigor, \
1 And her juste ualitv! . *¡
But farewell ! My blessings on thee ! ? ;¡
Never till my latest day .!
Shall my memory cease to ponder ?? ? ..
,On thy fate where'er I wander ;
, Never shall I cease to pray . !
That thy poor may yet be happy, : j
' That thy rich their pride may quell,
That thou may'st in peaceful progress, ? ¡
All thy misery dispel.
Queen of nations, once their model,
God be with thee ! Fare thee well !
? i
Among the writers in prose and poetry .who
haye'ever' been faithful to: the popular cause in
the present century, Charles Mackay must always
be accorded a prominent place. Although not
brought before the public by his writings quite
as much as heretofore, he is still held in kindly
remembrance by those who have not forgotten the
t good work which he did with his pen. . Born in
Perth'(Scotland) in 1814, and descended from the
Highland family of which Lord Eeay is chief
he moved in his infancy to London, where he re
ceived much of his education. Proceeding to
Belgium to complete his studies, he was a witness
of the startling events of the revolution whioh
broke out in 1830 ; and he published in 1834 a
small volume of poems, which led to his introduc
tion to the late Mr. John Black, then editor of the
London MORNING CHRONICLE, through whom he
became connected with that paper 5 and he con
tinued to be so for about nine years, during which
period he brought out another volume, entitled,
" The Hope of the World," and other poems. -He
became editor of the Glasgow ARGUS in 1844, and
retired from that paper three years later, in con
sequence of a schism in the Liberal party. In
1846 the University of Glasgow conferred on him
the title of LL.D. Upon the establishment of the
London DAILY NEWS, under the editorship
of the late Charles Dickens, Dr. Mackay
wrote for that. journal a series of poems
entitled, " Voices from the Crowd," afterward
published in a collected form. He subsequently
produced many other poetical effusions; among
them being the universally popular songs,
" Cheer, Boys, Cheer," " To the West," " They
Aro Coming with the Flowers," and"many others
which the famous singer, Henry Bussell, rendered
so long to the delight of thousands, and his own
profit, as some of us remember yet. , For some
years he contributed leading articles .to the
ILLUSTRATED LONDON NEWS 5 and he established
in 1860 the LONDON REVIEW. His best known
prose work is " Memoirs of Extraordinary Popular
Delusions," first published in Í841 ; and he has
contributed articles to many of the principal
English magazines. As a traveller he has visited
the United States, and written the inevitable
book in consequence. This was in 1857-58 ; and
in 1862 he returned to the States, where he re
mained, residing in New York as correspondent
of the London TIMES during the civil war, return
ing to England in 1866. His later works haye
been greatly of an etymological character, in
which he has brought conspicuously forward the
obligations of the English tongue to Celtic
sources.
In th© winter bf his life he has fallen on evil
days, and his friends are seeking to make matters
easier for him. To this end public subscriptions
have been originated. The Governors of New
South Wales and Victoria have given valuable dona
tions, as have many others, who hope to make the
declining days of the "British Bcranger," as Doug
las J errold called him, pass calmly and comfortably.
And, if any man deserves that these efforts should
be made on his behalf, Charles Mackay does.
Throughout his long career-he is now 73 years
of age-he has been an earnest and consistent
advocate of every measure which had for its
object the physical, social, and intellectual
elevation of the people. He was one of the most
active pioneers in the cause of popular
education j and his- powerful letters to
Lord Morpeth (published in 1846) exercised
an important influence in preparing for
the legislation which has since been fol
lowed, and which he clearly foreshadowed.
His labors in this direction were highly appre
ciated by the late Prince Consort, who instigated
the reprinting and circulating of " The Souls of
the Children," which had no small effect in stimu
lating public opinion. His efforts in the great
cause of temperance were equally zealous, and
have been generally acknowledged.
Subscriptions to the "Charles Mackay" fund
will be thankfully received by the Eev. George
Walters, " Tara," Stanmore-road, Sydney (rastor
of the Unitarian Church, Liverpool-street.
Sydney), who contemplates giving a concert
lecture on Charles Mackay, with readings and
songs from his works. It is earnestly hoped that
there will be a generous response to this appeal
on behalf of a writer who over forty years ago
foresaw the greatness of Australia, as may be
seen in his poem printed above.

title: POETRY.
content:
POETRY.
WILr.rAar Race Ar.rason, 7. L.C., V. D. L.:
author of a pamph'et in favor of transportation, anti
two elegant epistles lalel publishied in tie columns of
the " Launceston Examiner." wshich eor orthography,
punctuation, and beauty of composition, are perhaps
unsurpassed by any in the Englhsh language.
In council when young IRace appear'd,
Fresh from the string where he was rear'd,
His friends and felluw.councillors sneer'd
At the Yahoo of Launceston I
He smil'd, and such a ghastly smile
Such as sea-sickness wears awhile,
And quite as vulgar as his tile
And bird's*eye sky.blue neckerchief.
As soon as he the book had kiss'd
lie spoke n hot ho litonilst :
Sthen clenchi'd an ? hoo k angry fist,
And charg'd with all his orat'ry.
Ills speech (and he did nobly stammer)
Was independent of all - grammar;
And full an hour Yahoo did hammer
To death poor Lindley Murray.
'Gainst nouns and verbs he drew his sword,
And adjectives and adverbs gor'd,
'Till every member present roar'd
To hear the castigation i
And trasnsportation he maintain'd,
Tho' by some would-be-patriots brain'd,
By it alone there could be gain'd
A virtuous population I
And when the ill-bred dlogs were tax'd
His heart congenially relax'd,
As with a gracious smile he 'ax'd'
' If dogs e'er brought forth puppies ?'
Talk not of this isle's ruin, see
The vessels near the battery
Freighted with England's felonry:
All hail Lord Grey's isopathy I
Now, as for thistles, why, his votes
Should go with Leake to import goats
And donkeys, but he'd take his notes.
And bray next term vocif'rously I
And when, grown old and grey with toil,
He had wound up this mortal coil,
Perchance a credit to the soil,
Had lie but stuck to orat'ry !
But ah I he op'ed a paper war
About rebellion on this shore,
When Retribution kill'd him for
The death of poor old Murray I
Poor Race, thy race was sadly run,
1Hy vanity and ignorance done,
And not a wreath of laurel won
That mutinous Examiner /!
HARRY LoalLnotUER.
Bothwell.

title: Happy Christmas Bells.
content:
Happy Christmas Bells.
Bing out the gladsome tidings ye bells from far
and near,
Pour forth the thrilling chorus throughout each
hemisphere.
In accents clear and joyous Jet every sound be
heard,
Tho true heartfelt thanksgiving that struggles
into word.
And now yo hills re-echo those joyous strains
afar,
To ocean's deepest crevice-to heaven's bnghtost
star,
Till with a sound triumphant through wood and
dale and dell?,
Wo hear the glorious murmur of happy Christ
mas bells.
Now glow, ye youthful faces, and beat, ye swelling
hearts,
With rap turo still increasing each nerve and
heartstring starts,
Yo bosoms over tender and still moro tender
now,
Your eyes with brightness sparkle and gladness
beams on brow,
So now yo youths and maidens uplift tho tuneful
voice,
With cadence soft and lowly to bid tho world
rejoico,
Now gratitude o'orwhelrcs us, -with joy each glad
heart wells,
For now we hear the music of happy Christmas
bells.
The old, old joyous story with sunshine fills the
soul,
This ever-welcome tidings stretches from pole to
polo,
So lift once more your voices, bid care and discord
cease,
And live and lovo in unity, in joy and hope and
poace.
Wo raise our hearts to heaven and thank the God
above,
For this most bounteous blessing that tolls but of
His love,
And now with hope in Jesus each bosom wildly
swells,
Hark now ! that sound of mercy, the happy
Christinas bells.
