title: Tranquillity.
content:
Tranquillity.
! Fair are the groves where Deo's pure stream
Pours her silver flood along ;
And where ten hundred throats, I ween,
Break forth in melody of song.
Sweet are those dells, with tinkling rills/
Where blue-bells bathe in crystal spray,
And pinks retreat in mossy cells,
And throw perfume by stealth away.
Rich are thoso meads, with choicest flowers,
By Nature's hand so lavish Bpread.
A softer bloom bedecks the bowers,
And cowslips blossom in the shade.
Enchanting scene ! How sweet to stray
By murm'ring brooks, or walk the vale,
The heath her purple dyes display,
And throws a fragrance on the gale.
Oh ! let me pass this blissful life,
And nature all my thoughts employ j
From folly, ignorance, and strife,
And from all unmeaning joy.
Calm study seeks this soft retreat j
Contentment dwells in this abode j
No wrangling doubters here I'll meet,
But studying Nature, see my God. >
Thus may the years glide softly paBt,
Tilldußt to dust returned shall bo ;
The soul from mortal free at last,
Flies fleet into eternity.
I ALEXANDER LITTLEJOHN.
Sydney. _^^_
APPLE OMELETTE.-Stow eight large apples and
mash fine ; add four eggs, one cup of sugar, and a
small piece of butter; season with cinnamon and
nutmeg. Bake until brown, and serve hot.
USE THE CRUSTS.-Instead of wasting all the crusts
left at table, it is better to colleot them, and put
them aside into a large earthenware pan, for puddings
and raspings. To make an economical bread pud-
ding, tako about 3oz of the crusts and soak them
well in a bowl of cold water. Strain off the water
whon they are quiet soft, have ready a quart of skim
milk, half a pound of sultanas and two eggs. Beat
up the eggs and add thom to the milk; pour
all over the soaked crusts, adding the sul-
tanas, two dessertspoonfuls of moist sugar,
and a pinch of nutmeg. Bake for about half
an hour, till well risen, after mixing thoroughly.
ThiB makes a most excellont pudding, and one which
ia as good cold as hot. Whon the orusts have accu-
mulated largely, and are very hard, put them on to a
baking tin, and bake in a hot oven for 20 minutes or
half an hour till quito brown, but not burnt. Put
thom on to a piece of newspaper on the kitchen tahlo
and roll them backwards and forwards with the roll-
ing pin till they are reduced to fine raspings. These
are most useful for frying fish and cutlots, for dredg-
ing over scalloped fish and mince, and for macaroni
cheese. The raspings should be kept in a tin or a
1 corked bottle.

title: The Green Tide.
content:
The Oreen Tide.
(Written for the "Town and Country:Journal.")
(By Henry Lawson.)
The loud, brave laugh and the well-worn jest
Or we'll fail at the pinch to smile-; .
You'll be dull to-day If I know you best,
And I'll feel sore-heart awhile. , ? ^
A grip over rail with your hand in mine
For.the future and what has been;
And. the wharf and the deck roaring
Auld Lang Syne,
As the green tide slips between. : :
As the green tide slips between, old man, ?
:- And the green tide flows between; \ 1
"You'll drop me a line," and "I drop you a line,"
When. the South Sea rolls between.
But you'll be afloat on a New Year's boat,
For i seek good luck for two;
And you start a' cheer, when you sight the pier.
And I'll raise one there for you. .
A grip ;over roil with your hand in mine
For the future and what has been.
And the wharf and the deck roaring
Auld Lang Syne,
While the green tide spreads between.
And the green tide runs between, old .man,
And the green tide flows between,
"I drop you a line," and "You drop me a line,"
When the South Sea rolls between.

title: ORIGINAL POETRY.
content:
ORIGINAL POETRY.
TO INA.
Fond memory still recalls the hours
We sweetly passed together,
When round my brow you twined those flowers
Which bloom in every weather.
Of love and hope, and all those blisses
Which, though they linger, never cloy -
Oh ! would I had again those kisses
Which brought me never-failing joy.
I miss thine eye for ever speaking
Language to mine ears unheard,
But which my spirit without seeking
Comprehended without word.
I miss thy form so vine-like clinging,
As if I were thy parent tree,
And thy voice, for ever ringing
In mine ears so merrily.
I miss thy thousand nameless graces.
Shedding o'er me such delight,
That I wish in those embraces
I could pass my life-long night !
T. A. Brisbane.
T. A.

title: THE RIGHT ROAD.
content:
THE EIGHT ROAD.
"I Lave lost'the road to happiness
Does anyone know it, pray ? , . '
I was dwelling there -when the morn was fair> .
But somehow I wander'd away.
" I saw rare treasures in scenes of pleasure.
' And ran to pursue them, when, lo !
I had lost the path to happiness.
And I «new not whither to go.
" I have lost the way to happiness
Oh, who,will lead me back?"
" Turn off from the highway of selfishness
To the right-up duty's track!
" Heep straight along,' and you can't go wrong.
For as sure as you live, I say,
The fair, lost fields of happiness. .
Can onlv be found that way." .

title: Love and Mammon.
content:
LOTO and Mammon.
Mr lady sita in listless grace,
And the noblest in the land
PreSB round her with many a courtly emile,
AB they bend o'er her jewelled hand3
Her lord is mighty, her station high,
And beauty and wealth her own ;
But amid the gay and glittering throng,
My lady Bits alone.
Those gilded halls, and brilliant guests.
Are faded from her eyes,
Again she walks with one Bhe loved,
Beneath the moonlit skies ;
Again Bhe hears that tender voioe
Whioh thrilled her heart with joy,
When gazing in his face she felt
Her bliss had no alloy.
All idle dreams-those days are paBt ;
She ohose for pomp and pride,
An<3 orushed that manly, faithful heart,
In distant land he died.
What had he but an earnest soul,
A world of love and passion ;
She lives now in a grander world
The world of rank and fashion.
The musio sounds with louder strain,
And allßeems joy and pleasure ;
The countess with a noble lord
Now treads a Btately measure ;
Her words are light, her voico is gay,
She smiles and looks happy now ;
And who could tell of a tortured soul
Fromlthat calm and gem-deoked brow?
H.L.

title: Sweet Silent Moon.
content:
Sweet Silent Moon.
fl D. CAMnEON.
A million years kave passed away,
O'er land and sky and sea;
A million years are but a day,
Sweet silent star to Thee.
Scene of the scone thy beams have lit,
Recurring year by year,
As If in wster they were writ,
And thou of granite sear.
Face afterfaee have gazed on thee
That long ago was dust,
And tender eyes thy form did see,
That now are mould and must I
Still sailing on abose the strife
Of element and man.
Thou seest the shifting scenes of life,
Tho struggles of a span.
And when this hand's resolved to dust,
Three eyes but earth and air,
Thy orb will sail o'er heaven as first
it dawned on world so fair I
We are as shadows, passing motes
That dance upon thy beams,
Fike some poor seort-lived midge that floats
A second in thy gleams.
Yet science tells that thou must fade,
That thou art sear and dead,
And that in some dark doomed decade
Thy glories will be fled.
snd science tells the world will die,
The universe as well,
chat through all space no globe will fly,
And chaos weave Isis spell.
it science tells the solemn truth,
sat out of thsledread state
niverse will rise in youth
o work another fate.
silent moon roll on in light,
f past, of future, tell,
1d bless each generation's sight
Withl all we love so well.

title: Universal Affluence.
content:
Universal Affluence.
Thus London "World" on the alleged
turning by Dr. Emmens of silver into
gold :
Klondyke-you may take a back seat,
Westralia-don't give yourself airs!
The soft-foot, the man in the street,
Henceforth will be all millionaires;
Rash bulls and lugubrious bears
No longer need bellow and groan,
Or thrive upon panics and scares
They've found the Philosopher's Stone.
Bimetallists, growers of wheat,
Pinched parsons whom poverty stares,
West Indians beaten by beet.
Henceforth will be all millionaires;
No more the economist spares,
Ncr bankrupt state raises a loan,
Since opulence everyone shares
They've found the Philosopher's Stone.
The Ottoman, curst and effete,
The Greek, on his Kalends who squares
The bill he can't otherwise meet
Henceforth will be all millionaires.
Alike are now paupers and heirs;
You won't know the bee from the drone.
The tortoises gallop like hares
They've found the Philosopher's Stone.
Envoy.
The prince royal purple who wears,
The beggar with pitiful moan,
Henceforth will be all millionaires
They've found the Philosopher's Stone.

title: Tags of Verse.
content:
Tags of Verso,
REST. I
My feet are weary and my hands are tired,
My soul oppressed
And I desire what I've long desired
Best-only reat.
'Tia hard to toil when toïl ia al moat vain,
In barren ways;"
"Ks hard to sow and never garner grain " .
In harvest days.
The burden of my days ia hard to bear,
But God knows best; -
And I have prayed, but vain has been my prayer,
For rest-sweet rest.
'Tis hard to plant in spring and never reap
The autumn yield;
'Tis hard to till and when 'tis tilled to weep
O'er fruitless fie1'".. ,
And 00 I cry a weak and human cry,.
So heart-oppressed; ?''
And so I sigh a weak and human eigh,
For rest-for rest.
My way was wound aerees the desert year«,
And caree infest
My path, and through the flowing of hot tears
I pine for rest.
And I am ree tl ese still; 'twill soon be o'er,
For down the west .
Life's sun is setting, and I see the shore
Where I shall rest.

title: CARLINGFORD BAY.
content:
CARLINGFORD BAY.
"With ample room for yard and boom,
For bumpkin spar or spanker,
And ground to hold the iron-wold
Of the heaviest triple banker!"
That Bay--with its trembling waves--
In the lap of the mountains hoar
And its sweeping swell, that proudly laves
Killowen's classic shore.
II.
As a wandering bird will fly
To the home of its nightly rest;
So the Exile's happy dream-lands lie
In the home of Erin's breast.
III.
And, that bay, in the noon of night,
And the towering peaks of Mourne,
To the dreamer's eye-of-soul are bright
As the sunniest scenes of morn!
IV.
Fair harbour! whom England's pride
Safe moored--as the seaman knows
Could, at double, or single anchor, ride
Through the heaviest gale that blows.
V.
Full many a shadowy lay--
Like the mist on great Bennian's* brow--
Still flits, in the light of that glorious bay,
As the foam o'er a shallop's prow.
VI.
Time's pearls lie on its shore;
Dark legends of Nial Caill--
Of Castles--Forts--and that Pass+ of yore,
That guarded the English-pale.
VII.
The battle of Cair-linn-joird,++
Base Cecil, and fierce Mountjoy §
Or of treachery's wiles at their festal board
Defeating the Clan-Aodh-Buidh. ||
VIII.
Greencastle's¶ seawashed wall;
Killbroney's** ivied cells!
Each olden name, on our memories fall
As a chime of fairy bells.
IX.
Bright ringlets are changed to gray,
And the eyes gleam dim and cold;
But the heart, like a wave of that beautiful bay,
The heart can never grow old!
X.
And a valley 'mongst mountains wild,
Where oaks and sycamores grow,
Is mirror'd to age, as when loved by the child--
In the morning of long ago. E. H. D.
Mulla Villa, Wollombi.
* Slieve Bennin, a rugged, and at many points a precipitous
mountain, stretching along the south side of Carlingford Bay, on
a sheltered slope at its base. Within and around the present town
are the remains of ancient castles, towers, and monastic build-
ings, the vestiges of De Bourgh's Fort, were lately traceable, and
the stupendous walls of King John's castle, 11 feet thick up to
the turrets, were in 1837, rich and redolent in the blooms of wall-
flower and sea-pink. St. Benin or Benignus, who, according to
Usher, succeeded St. Patric in the see of Armagh, died in a mo-
nastery, founded by him at Carlingford, A.D. 486; the Slieve (that
is, mountain), doubtless had its name in memory of him, as Slieve
Donnard (an immense cone, highest of the Mourne mountains,
north-east of the bay) is so called, from a pious anchorite, who
built a tower near the top. St. Donnard's chapel is still visited as a place of pilgrimage.
+ This Pass, on the borders of Argoil, a frontier county of the
Pale was the scene of many hot and bloody conflicts. Moryson
tells that the "Lord Deputy Mountjoy, when in Newry, on his
way to the Pale, proclaimed a reward of £2000 for the capture of
Oniall, and then marched by the way of Hathorn; but at the
Pass of Carlingford Oniall was on him again and a battle ensued,
where Sir H. Danvers, Mountjoy, and many other officers were severely wounded, and after heavy loss, the English fled to
Dundalk."
++ Cair-Linn-joird is literally the "rocky pass by a narrow water."
§ Charles Blount, Baron Mountjoy.
|| Clan-Aodh-Buidh, relatives and retainers of Hugh-the-yellow.
¶ Green Castle, one of many fortresses built by De Courey; it
was bestowed with the earldom of Ulster by King John, on
Hugh De Lacy.
** Killbroney was an Abbey renowed for learning and piety in
the earliest age of the Irish Church. Its original founder is said
to be Tarlath, Bishop of Armagh, the son of a pagan prince, of
Mourne. The ruins embrace a considerable space; the walls
are massive and covered with ivy; large trees, also, have sprung
up and grown old in the inner chambers of the sacred edifice.
Within the present century, a wintry storm of snow, followed by
a tempestuous gale, solved a mystery which the tradition of ages
connected with Killbroney; the story was--that a monk had neg-
lected to toll the bell to call the brotherhood to prayers when a
ship in the bay was sinking, and that "the Abbot put the penance
on him for a thousand years, that in every storm, if the wind
was north, he must arise from his grave to toll a bell." And it
was true that during many a high wind the solemn tone of a bell
had mingled with the rush of the tempest. Some averred it
sounded from the ground; others had "heard it come down the
road;" while those of cooler judgment believed, that if the sound
ever had been heard, it must have been that of a ship's bell,
borne on the echoes of the hills. The simple peasant of the
mountain, or the fishermen of the hamlet, when the wonder was
spoken of, piously invoked a blessing, and silently prayed "for
all Christian souls perishing at sea." The so long unseen and
unsearchable cause was, however, left visible to all eyes;
branches of an ash tree, intertwining with the ivy, had penetrated
into crevices of the eastern gable, and when bent down by
weight of snow, had borne away from the top the stone facing of
a secret niche containing the "Ghost's Bell."
Mulla Villa, Wollombi. E. H. D.

At tho Boarding House.
I can smell lt in the morning;
Ham and eggs.
I can smell it noon and evening;
Ham and eggs.
I can smell it, smell it, smell lt,
If you read lt or you spell it,
In whatever tone or language you may
speak,
I can .smell it, smell it, smell it,
As they yell lt, yell lt, yell it.
Twenty-one times .every week
Ham and eggs.

title: POETKY.
content:
POETRY.
We have been requested to publish the following metri-
cal effusions of "the best of Sisters" to an absent
Brother; They may be considered affectingly
pretty. The fair Writer is in England ; the happy
Brother has lately emigrated to these Colonies.
MY BROTHER ! thou hast wander'd far,
But true thy friends remain,
And there is one who thinks of thee.
Thine only sister JANE.
There's one who sees thy upright form,
Thy cheerful voice can feign ;
Nor ever chides thy fancy's flight,
Thine only sister JANE.
There's one who sees thy clear blue eye,
And oft repeats thy name ;
Who sheds for thee the silent tear,
Thine only sister JANE.
There9s one, who prays that He abor«
May thy return ordain,
To bles* a parent's longing eye^
Thine only sister JANE.
And when thy sunny day« o'ercasfc.
And friends untrue remain!
Remember one, who loves thee still.
Thine only ¡sister JAME.
When health forsakes thy manly limbs.
And weakneis shakes thy frame,
r Brmember one who prays for theep
Thine only sister JANE.
And shouldst thou e'er thy GOD foi get,
Or his bless'd will profane,
Remember one, whose heart will break.
Thine only sister JANE !

Humors of the Day.
WHEN WOMAN SHALL HAVE HER RIGHTS.
M. ST. JOHN.
AH, who does not see that the age is at hand
When man shall no longer be lord in the land!
When the woman shall lay by the needle, and take
The aceptre and sword, the plough and the rake!
«v? th^t lh the falr **c the favorite beaux !

Shall rest from Id. labor, hu'wor^andurtfe^"'
And resign aU hi« caret to hit itrong-minHed wife 1
O brother* ! how sweet, how delitiou. iwUl be
To ait all the morning a-sipping your tea.
With nothing to do from dawning till night —
No ipeecbu to »pout, and no aermou* to write
ho bargain* to make, and no battle* to fight,
> To klndliugi to split, and no fires to light
And onlr to handle a fork or a ladle;
Or perhaps—very rarely—to joggle tue cradle •

A lady who drew a gent's wrapper at a k*»Mr
a few evenings since, now wanti to draw a man
to put in it.
A F«w Aphouuu.—Keep your temper, and
your carriage. Never lose an opportunity, or an
umbrella. Misers are alwayt civil, for civility
costs nothing. Be contented with your lot,
especially at a publio auction. Avoid disputes {
never be a wrangler, except at Cambridge. The
darkest hour (as a rule) it just before the gas it
lighted. If you are in a public offioe, be punc
tual —at all events in leaving.
" Yon can't stand there, said a watchman to
a thin man in a suit of rusty black, who was
endeavoring to maintain a favorable position for
viewing a late Are; " you must oome down, sir."
—" Allow me to remain, if you please i I am a
reporter, and it is necessary I should see what if
going on." —"I don't care," responded the
guardian j "if ye want a report of it you'll see it
in the papers to-morrow."
A ratuib amusing anecdote is told of toe
landlady of a hotel in the west of Scotland, who
one Sunday, in church, during divine servioe, fell
a victim to the fascinating and ted uotivo charms
of sleep. She was, however, suddenly awakened
from her somnolent state by the falling of her
gilt-clasped Bible, and forgetting for a moment
but that she was in the home of spirits, and
fancying a smash had taken place, ejaculated
with stentorian voice, " Ye jade, ye hae broken
anither joog."—B.
A school visitor lately gave a teacher the
following sentence to spell: " Robert Wright,
the beautiful writer of Wrightville, down in
Torrington, claims the exclusive right to write
the rites and ceremonies of his church, and has
secured a copyright for his writiugs; but Henry
Wright, the writing-master, al»o writes those
rites; now is it honorable for the Bight Honor*
able Henry Wright boldly to write himself up
right in the presence of tie right-handed wheel*
wright, Robert Wright P"
In one of the Buohan flailing villages a
stranger had occasion to call on a fisherman
of the name of Alexander White. Meeting a
girl, he asked, *' Could you tell me far Sanny
Fite lives P" " Filk Sunny FiteP" "Muckle
Sanny Fite." " FUk Muckle ganny FiteP"
" Muckle Lang Sanny Fite." " Filk Muokle
Lang Sanny FiteP" "Muckle Lang Gleyed
Barmy Fite !" shouted the stranger. " Oh, it's
Goup-tbe-Lifc ye're seekin'," cried the girl i" and
fat the deevil for dinna ye speer for the man by
his rieht name at anoe P
Exteactj Fbom Punch's Auc&xao. —When
a vulgar husband drops his H's, a good wife
drops her eyes. Alluding to chignons, Mrs.
Clever said, "A girl, now, seems all head!"
" Yes, till you talk to her," replied Mr. Clever.
A Warning to Wags—Respect my intellect, and
don't tell me that the Hirer Plate flows with
gravy. No Costs—lf you want to e.ijoy the
luxury of the law for nothing, all you have to
do is to prosecute an inquiry. A Very Vulgar
Sell—"You ought not to oome to our danoe
in boots with nails in 'em." "I haven't."
" Then you've had your toei cut off." A Bait
able Appointment—lf the right man were
always in the right place, the Cuaplain-Greneral
of the army would be the "Dean of Battle."
At a recent examination of a Sooteh farmer,
on bis sister entering the box to be examined,
the following conversation took place between her
and the opposing agent:—Agent: " How old are
you P" Miss Jane : " Ob, weel, sir, lam an
unmarried woman, and I dinna think it rieht to
answer that question." The Judge : "Oh yes,
answer thegentleman how old you are." MiM
Jane: " Weel a weel, I am fifty." Agent:
" Are you not more P" Miss Jane: " Weel, I
am sixty." The inquisitive agent still further
asked if she had any hopes of getting married,
to which she replied : " Weel, sir, I widna tell*
lie ; I hinna lost a' hope yet." And she soorn*
fully added: " But I widna marry you, for lam
sick and tired o' your palaver already." The
examination ended.
Ik a trial at Cork for murder, the principal
witness swore strongly against the prisoner. He
particularly swore that a hat, found near the
place of the murder, belonged to the prisoner,
whose name was James. "By virtue of your
oath, are you sure that this it the same hat P"
" Yes." " Did you examine it oarefully before
you swore in your information that it was the
prisoner's?" "I did." "Now, let me tee,"
said O'Connell, as he took up the hat, and began
to examine it oarefully inside. He then spelled
out the name of James, slowly, in this manner—
" J-a-m-e-s." " Now, do you mean to say this
word was in the hat when you found it P " I
do." "Did you see it thereP" "I did."
" And it is the same hat P" "It is." " Now,
my lord," said O'Connell, holding up the hat to
the bench, " there is an end to this case—there
it no name whatever inscribed in the hat."
A poos Yankee doctor was onoe oalled from
his bed on a stormy night with the startling
summons :—" Doctor, I want you to oome right
straight away off to Banki's. His child v
dead." "Then why do you oome?" "He's
pisoned. . They've given him laud'num instead
of paregoric*. " How much have they given
him?" "Do'no. A great deal. Think he
won't get over it." The doctor pushes off
through the storm, meets with divers mishaps by
the way, and at length arrives at the house of
his poisoned patient, and finds all dosed. He
knocks at the door, but no answer. He knocks
furiously, and at last a nightcap appears from •
chamber window, and a woman's voice iqueaks
out, " Who's there ?" " The doctor, to be sure |
you sent for him. What is the matter P w
" Ob, it's no matter, doctor. Ephraim is better.
We got a little frightened—that's all." " How
much laudanum did he swallow ?" " Only two
drops. 'Taint huit him at all. Wonderful bad
storm to-night." The doctor turns away, but
toning up his overcoat under his throat, and
tries to whistle away his mortification and anger,
when a voioe calls, " Doctor, doctor!" " Well,
what do you want P" " You won't charge
nothing for this visit, will you P"
How Jm Wick**'* Hbad Got Bald.—Jim
Wicker was a comical looking fellow, with a
very young face, but by reason of having no
hair, he looked very old. He accounted for bis
baldness after this fashion:—" You see the hair
always did grow rather scarce 'bout my soalp,
and I was always rubbing one thing or another
to fetch it out, for I was sartiu the roots wasn't
dead, though thar was-, little to be seen above
ground. I'd heard of bears' grease, but couldn't
buy any good ; so I thought I would have the
genuine artiole, and I got old Dun to go out and
kill something for my especial benefit. Dan
told me it was spring, and that the bear was in
bad health, and out of season ; I believed be
was trying to quiz me, and I wouldn't take no
fcr an answer. A short hunt fetched a critter
at bay, and Dan, by a shot in the vitals, saved
the varmint; but the bear was in a bad condition,
and had hardly enough ile in him to keep his
joints from squeaking. However, what he did
have I got and used i and, gentlemen," laid Jim,
looking sorrowfully round on the company, " in
two days, what little hair I had commenced
falling oil, and in a week 1 wan us bald as a gun
barrel. Dan was right. The rarmint was shed
ding himself, and had nothing in him but hair
shedding ile."

title: Bewitching Evolution
content:
Bewitching Evolution
The fabled witch of olden time
Was scrawny, cross, and old ;
She wore a number seven boot
Most dreadful to behold.
ITeri nose bent down to meet her chin,
Which had an upward turn,
And in their sunken sockets deep
Her eyeballs seem to burn.
Befriending- none except her cat,
In darkness she abode;
And when1 she Wished I to take the air,
A broomstick she bestrode.
The modern witch ls beautiful,
.Mild-tempered, young-, and sweet;
A pair of cunning Oxford ties
Incase her dainty feet.
Her nose is slightly retrousse,
A dimple dents her chin;
Her eyes are limpid, magic pools
Where hearts keep falling in.
Surrounded by a loving throng,
In splendor she abides;
And on the lively boulevard
A wneei sne nettly rides.
-WaJlace D. Vincent.

title: Reverie
content:
Reverie
Day after day my weary' brain
Reviews the hard up past
And trusts ray wish may not be vain
Good time may come at last
I hold my head up and feel brave
Where want and hate fall fast
Time tells me I am near my grave.
Love on, whilst life thou hast.
And keep each sense in perfect tone
For nature's mystic play
Of wondrous things from each zone
That charms me day by day
CHUCK

title: NIGHT-THOUGHTS IN THE AUSTRALIAN BUSH.
content:
NIGHT-THOUGHTS IN THE AUSTRA
LIAN BUSH.
The jewelled bosom of motlier night
Is bending around the earth;
Her child she lulls to reposo as soft,
As the hour of Eden's birth.
And what is night, but the wing of Him,
Wbo tho heavens nnd earth hath made,
A wing let down to enfold the earth
In its silent starry shade V
I'd rather be where these glorious stars
Aro shining, so great and bright,
Than mix with the mirth of city halls,
AVhere diamonds reflect the light.
Neither jar, nor glare, nor Btunnin^
lu this placo distract tbo breast;
But the forest's primal stillness breathes
Its deep and unbroken rest.
Unbroken,?though strange nocturnal birds (
Their notes capricious raise:
And the shy opossum leaves its tree,
And around my pillow plays:
Unbroken,?although tho kangaroo
Bounds past me to feed and play ;
AU heedless of rifle or boomerang,
He lives, and for me he may:
Unbroken,?although a pulse of air
The gum-leaves stirreth among,
And the flying squirrel's sudden leap,
Awakes the buggcry-goug."
Thc bushman slept: and tho God besought
Made bis sleep secure and sweet;
Though spear -armed savage stalked near bis
head,
And thc snake glid near his feet.
Ho floated nwny in golden dreams,
And reached the emerald shore;
And clasped tn bis heart the cherished ones,
¦ From whom lie would purt no moro.
Ile saw, by tho batiks of Strool's sweet steam,
A tree-girt mansion rise,
AVhere bright-eyed little onos climb'd his kneo
For the tales of other skies.
Again ns a youth, he lived tho scenes
Of his early golden days j
He saw tbo menning or Jacob's dream,
When lo ! bo woke, with praise !
He awoke ; and morning's golden beam
Through tho treos shone clear and warm,
And squirrel, opossum, nnd kangaroo,
'.""i'Wore scanning tbe stranger's form.
Kev. J. Graham.

of New York, who ao liborally attempted to
introduco the Canadian salmon here somo
short time since. Mr. Youl says that Mr.
Cameron, boing determined to repeat the at- |
tempt until successful, ho had givon him
every informntidn on tho subjoct, showing
him hy actual experiments tho best way of
proceeding- Mr. Cameron said that, by soma

would send forward somo ova. Mr. Wilson
reported that ha had obtained permission to
hold tho dog show in tho Exhibition Build-

day and Friday, tho 7th and 8th of April. The
prizo lists are now complete and oan ho ob-
tained, as well as every information on tho
subject, from Mr. Gcorgo Sprigg, tho
honorary secretary, ot tho society's oflico,
No. 30, Swanston-stroot. Tho applications
for tho office of superintendent were placed
upon tho tabla, and wore referred to a sub
committeo for examination. Tho council ac- |
knowledge, with thanks, tho receipt of 1
native bear, from Mr. Tom Chow, of Piincoss
strcet, Fitzroy ; 1 porcupine, from Miss
Elizabeth Kernot], of Lonsdale-streot; 10
magpies, from tho borough council of Sand-
hurst; 2 pigeons, from Mr. Ni Kinsman, of
Moor-Btrcct; nnd 1 Japanoso dog, from Mr.
John Robertson, of Lonsdale-streot.
Lucifeb Matches.?At a lecture recently
delivered by Dr. Procter, of York, before tho
York Instituto, tho lecturer gavo tho follow-
ing useful information about lucifer matches :
?MesBrB. Dixon, Newton and Heath have a
stock of timber of tho valuo generally of
from £8000 to £10.000. They produoo yonrly
2,100,000,000 matches, Reokonlng tho length
ol' each match at 2J In, they would exceed tho I
circumference of tho globe. It is estimated
that 12,000 to 15,000 gross of boxes of I
matches aro produced weekly in London
alone Tho yearly consumption of phosphorus [
in this country for the manufaoture ol' ¦
matches is estimated at six tons, which, at
3s. Qtl. per lb., represents £1080. Our daily
Consumption of mutches is considered to be
230,000,000, or moro than eight matches a
day for every individual in tho kingdom.
But the great scat of match-making is in
Austria. For example M. Polia1*, at Vlonna,
and M. Furth, in BcJicmia, consume together |
abou.t twenty tons of phosphorus annually,
and omploy about C0O0 persons. "This quan-
tity of phosphorus iB sufficient to produce
tbo amazing, number of 44,800,000,000
matches. The cost at which boxes and'
matoheB are mado is. equally startling. Mr.
Furth peUu his ohoapost boxes at ld. per
do^en, oaoli box containing eighty matches.
Harrop, a Prussian, sells his plain boxes at
2d. per 100, and 1400 splints for Jd.; and Do
Majo, of Moravia, sells a caso of fifty hoxos,
each containing 100 lucifsva, for ii.?Building

title: "The Poor Man's Heritage."
content:
" The Poor Man's Heritage;"
Not in halls of regal splendor,
.", . Not to princes of the earth,
Did tho herald angels render
Tidings of their Monarch's birth;
. Not to statesman, priest, or sage,
They proelaim'd the golden age;
'Twas the poor man's heritage
For on shepherds lowly
. Burst the anthem holy
In excelsis gloria,
Et in terra vax.
NEWMÀH HALL.
What poet has not sung of Christmas ?-from the
" Ring ont, ye Crystal Spheres," of Milton, to the
'* Ring ont, Wild Bells, to the Wild Sky," of Tenny
son, and alwayB in one key of hope and gladness, yet
with great contrasts.

title: When We Grow Old
content:
When We Grow Old
By E. M. ENGLAND
WHEN we grow old, with all the sullen thunder
That shakes our hearts to-day, be still at last?
Will there be nothing left of faith and wonder.
With fever of these aspirations past?
Will glamour light upon the hills no longer,
And will there be no secret path or stair?
No magic in the rose? no furtive rapture
Of sudden hope, and following despair?
Shall we then sit unmoved by whisperinq waters?
Will music leave no thrumming pulse behind?
And lovely mellow phrases of the poets
Wake not the smallest echo in the mind?
Or will Life rather lead to sheltered doorways?
No more of burning, and of sudden cold?
Ah well, maybe, with no dreams left to shatter,
It will not matter, when we have grown old!

title: The Empire.
content:
Cfte Cmptre*
SA.TTJBDAY, JUNE 1, 1807.
I ALTHOUGH to residents on tbo spot the re-
trospect af a month may not present many
noteworthy features, owing to the gradual
development of events ? and tho familiarity
which thia gradual process causes, yot when
we come to summarise the month's inoidents
: or tho information of readers at a distance,
it is found that there is much to be reoorded.
Our last summary, despatched by the Panama
mail steamer Mataura, was issued on the 1st
of May. Sinoe that time tho objeotioas to
the proposals of the late Postal Conference
whian bad then prevailed amongst certain
interested classes in Viotoria have still further
! diminished. Although the Legislative Coun-
cil, or Upper House, of that colony has re-
oorded its disapproval of the arrangement,
tho Government there has suoceedod in
scouring tho assent bf the Assembly, whioh
body, having the constitutional right of con-
trol over the public purse, must be
considered as "by far the most influential in
thc matter. A now argument, and one of
very considerable foroe, has been urged with
muoh ability in favour of adhering to the
I compact. It has long been regarded as most
desirable by many persons in Victoria that a
I line of mail steam packets should be estab-
lished between that colony and England, by
way of the Cape of Good Hope. The very
successful ' trips of tho steamship Great
Britain aro held to support tho belief that
long ooean voyages may be still moro suc-
cessful when performed by vessels propelled
by a larger amount of'steam power; and
negotiations are understood to be already on
foot for the purpose of establishing suoh
I a line. Now it is oorreotly maintained that
if a contract were entered into by tho
Viotorian Government for a fortnightly
service by way of Gaile and Suez,'
aa desired by tho Melbourne Chamber
of Oommeroo and others opposed to the
Panama sorrioe, tho realisation of the Cape
of Good Hopo route would become impossible ;
whereas if the three liuos by Panama, Singa-
pore, and Cape Leuwin were adopted, as pro-
posed by tbo Conference, no suoh insurmount-
able difficulties would exist with regard to
the subsequent opening of the Cape of Good
Hope route. This is an argument which is
likely to have mach influence even with those
whose opinions had hitherto been confessedly
swayed by their desire for the exclusive
aggrandisement of Melbourne. It may,
therefore, ba safely assumed that the recom-
mendations of the Postal Conference will be
backed by the gen oral assent ot all the Aus-
tralasian colonies. Tho only objections aB yet
have been raised in Melbourne, and there, as vre
have stated, they are rapidly fading away.
From returns presented to the Conference,
it appeared that the numbers of those whose
geographical position in these oolonies made
the Suez or the Panama route most desirable
wore very niarly equal ; and considering that
all Australasia is interested in making a general
compaot, the point may bo considered as
almost, deoided, so far as. she.is concerned
The assont of tho Now South Wales Legisla-
tura has not yet been obtained ; but the Par-
liament of this colony is now summoned to
meet for . despatch of business on the 2nd of
July, next and although many other subjeots
! of great importance are likely to bo brought
under consideration, that'of tho oeean postal
servioo is suro to be entertained with a duo
regard to tho ¿advantages that must aooruo
from a (general agreement.
His Excellency Ibo Governor has recently,
returned from a tour in tho Southern dis trio te,
whenoe he prooeedod by railway to Mel-
bourne, returning to Sydney by sea. As it is
now known that Sir JOHN YOUNO expeots to
be immodiatoly recalled from this Govern-
ment, his period of service according to ordi-
nary UBDge having expired, and the stato of
his health rendering it desirable that he should
enjoy a change of oliniate, tho publio manifes-
tations of welcome that greeted , him during
his journey wero watohed with muoh interest,
it being considered probable that they might
elicit some political hints with regard to the
future His Exoellonoy, howover, avoided
politioal allusions aa far as possible I but he
made some statements whioh aro of great
value to tho colony, as tonding to provo all
that had been assorted of the fertility of vast
traots of country whioh tho present occupants
desire to rotaln as mere sheepwalks,
under the pretence' that they aro
unfit for anything else. The Governor told
the inhabitants of tho JBordor distrlots that
ho eonsldored a largo portion of tho lauds
alluded tb to bo capable of the highest degree
of productiveness, and'that while the sheep
farmers might e»pect by industry and im-
provement, to produoe wool equal to tho olips
of Saxony and Spain, tho great sueoess that
had attended tho wine producers in that dis
triot led to a hope that they might heroaftcr
rival tho vineyards of France and the Rhine.
Testimony liko this, coming from such a
quartor, forms a sufficient answer to tho
in tores tod statements of tho squatters in that
locality,' who have persistently endeavoured
to make it appear that the lands they occupy
are totally unfit for any othor purposo than
tho grazing of stook, and are so poor and
Barren, even in that respeot, that, although
they have already been oocupiod for very
many years, a still further extension of tho
leases is absolutely necessary in order to
make them profitable Another contradiction
of this solfish misrepresentation is given by tho
rapid growth of tho farming interest in the
same quarter, owing to tho operation of free
seleotion. Attempts havo been made to show
that beoause thc free selectors have clustered
themselves together in groups on tho most
favourable soils, instead of scattering them-
selves far and wide over the oountry, the
prinoiplo of freo seleotion has failed, and tho
selection by the Government of areas for
agricultural occupation would bo tho mest
judicious course. But tho faot alluded to
points directly the other way. It shows that
the free soleotors, instead of pouncing down in
mero wantonness upon all the sqüattagés far
and near, have beenjoaroful to take possosion
only of the land most suitable for their
own purposes, and of whioh they must
naturally be able to form a' sounder
judgment than any Government or
any other porson. This Minister for
.Lands, «rho accompanied the Governor
on bis tour, must have soen sufficient to con-
vince him of this; for, while holding out
hopös to the squatters that their leases would
be extended, he was oautious enough to state,
most emphatically, that no interference would
be allowed with the operation of free seleotion,
as tho law of the land. Tho whole subjeot
will no doubt be brought under review in
Parliament «.ext month, or shortly afterwards
and it will then bo for the Gorernmeat t<
show how the maintenance nmd extession o
free seleotion oun be reooncilad with an indis-
criminate and continuous renewal of the pas-
toral leases.
The birthday of her Majesty the Queer
was celebrated in Sydney on the 24th Ma]
in a manner whioh,-while it denoted the uni-
versal prevalence of loyalty to the institution!
of tho mother country, was utterly free frons
any of that truckling subsorvicnoy wbiot
marks a degenerate people. Probably
not less than twenty-five or thirty thousand
oitizons made holiday on the occasion, anc
distributed themselves over tho numerous
places of recreation in the city and suburbs,
and on the shores of Port Jackson. About
fifteen thousand spectators, in holiday attire,
attended the military spectaolo in the public
domain, where nearly two thousand volunteeri
woro reviewed by the Govornor, who after-
wards held a levee, which was largely
attended. The obaraoter of the last news
from England, received by the Suez mail,
was suoh as to revive and strengthen those
feelings of attachment which found a vent on
this occasion, for tho threatening attitude oi
Prance and Prussia; the,rumours of an
alliance between tho two great northern
powers, and the evident restlessness of Italy
in anticipation of coming events, seemed
to indioate am impending storm, from
which Great Britain may be unable to
keep clear. In suoh an event, il
her causo bo a good one, it is tho ardent wish
of the colonists of Australia that the children
of the same raco may be found side by sido,
and that the two kindred nations whioh have
been tho homes of freedom while military
[ despotism ruled the European and Asiatic
continents, may unite to preserve that freedom
for the rest of the world. While on this
subj cot, it may be mentioned that we have
just received a friendly visit from a repre-
sentative of one of the nations that has
recently arisen from a state of dependency to
the condition of a great power. In our last
summary for Panama, we had occasion to
mention a signal servioè whiotr*had been ren-
dered by a Frenoh ship of war to tho morcan
tilo marine of th'iB oolony, and wo have
now to announce the arrival in
Sydney harbour of the Italian frigate
Magenta, whioh came into port
yostorday morning, and was reoeived with and
exchanged tho customary salutes. The
Magenta is engaged in a. service of peaoe,
having been fitted out for a soiontifio oruiso.
She has already visited Gibraltar, Teneriffe,
tho east coast of South Amorioa, Japan,
China, Singapore, Batavia, and Melbourne:
and, after being dooked at this p rt, she will
proceed to Lima and the west coast of
America, beforo returning to Genoa. She is
of somewhat formidable proportions, but only
carries twenty sixty-eight. pounder guns on
the lower deck. As this is the first timo that
tho flag of an .Italian man-of-war bas over
been displayed in thesq waters, the vossel
will be visited by numerous citizens as soon
as she is thrown open to the publie, espe-
cially, as the commander, Captain AHM ia ON,
seems to have created a most * favourable
Impression in Melbourne by bis oourtesy and
affability.
AB a nucleus for a fature navy here
whenever tho day may como for its full growth
-wo have already a vory olBoient .Naval
Brigade; but, in addition to this, a nautical
training ship has recently beon fitted out and
moored in the harbour, for the reception of
wandering and destitute boys, and their train-
ing in marltime¡exeroisoi. Tho object is a
most laudable one, and has for many years past
had tho earnest advooaoy of this journal j but,
unfortunately, tho means adopted for carrying
it out wero not suoh as could moet with un-
prejudiced approval. During a Parliamentary
recess, anofflftbout giving an opportunity for
any oompJtition, the Governmont entered
into a private arrangement with
a mombor of Parliament, and pur-
chased from him, for a large sum of money,
an old .vossel. built thirty yoarssgo, an 1 whioh
had been found quite unfit to sond to sea.
The strictures that wero justly passod upon
this dubious transaction, and tho oritloi.«ras
bestowed upon tho oonvorsion of this old
hulk into a training ship, havo in sorao
quarters been misrepresented as marking
disapproval'Of tho objoot. But tho oxpoRura
and condemnation of an unauthorised act of
this kind no moro argues any objection to tho
serviao.for which, it wai ostensibly, intended
than a public or political offence can bo
covered by tho cloak ot philanthropy.
Last month wo were able t o announce that
the two brothers CLARICE, whose busbranging
oareor had long kopt a portion of the colony
in terror, had at last been apprehended and
lodged in safe custody. They havesiDoebeon.
oonvioted, and sontenced to suffer death-nob.
fer their orina os, whioh aro almost without
number, but for ono of them, namely, shootiog
a policeman with intent to murder him when-,
they wore arrested. The Supreme Criminal
Court is still engaged in the trial of others/
accused of participation in tho heinous offences
.f these men, and it is hoped that the exam-
ples to he made, and the increased vigilance
of the police, will redeem the oountry from
tho disoredit whioh had been brought upo»
it, owing to its protection having been con-
fided to a constabulary erroneously organised'
upon a military system.
Tho annual commemoration of the Sydney
University took placa on tho 18th May. It
possessed peouliar interest from the foot that
the new Prinoipal and Professor of Classics,.
Dr. BADHAM, who had recently arrived fron*
Enp,land as successor to tho lato Dr. WOOLLEY,
was expected to deliver his inaugural speech
on tho occasion. Ho did so aooordingly, and'
in a manner whioh has met with general
approval, owing to its earnestness and sound
practical sense, and tho unmistakable exhi-
bition of a desire on tho part of a soholar of
the highest attainments to develop the more
familiar and useful purposes of tho institution
as well as to cultivate the more profound
studies. Tho University of Sydney has long
stood in need of a reformer, and it is hope!
that the now Professor will aooept and accom-
plish the task whioh lies beforo him.
At the date of our last summary it had beea
raining for a month, and we regret to say
that t here has been no permanent improve-
ment in the weather ns yet., We have had »
few âne days, and strong indications ot
winter ; but the clouds aro still humid, and
no weather-prophet oan foretell when they will
olenr off. t
PADDIKOTON AK» WOOLLAHRA BBHTSVOWHT SbcrxTTi
-Tho bazaar in aid of tbs finds of this benevolent
society was opened yesterday, and,'considering tbs
threatening aspect of the weather, waa well attended.
It will bo open again thia day, aa advertised, and no
doubt a largo number of visitors'will attend, under tb»
distinguished patronage of Lady Youno: and a large
number of resident ladies in the neighbourhood.
APPOINTMENTS.-Edward Wardloy, Esq., M.B.0.S.,&V
to be surgeon and medical superintendent of th«
Ltinatio Asylums at Parramatta; W. E. Shorts«, Esq,,

ment at Morpeth, in the . room of Kr. Campbell, de«
ceased; Dr. Crosby AY. Morgan, to be vaocinator for
tho district of Forbes ; Riobard Bligh, Esq., tobo vac*
cioator for the distriot of Woollahra.-Qovernmost

TjxcTtmi ow GKOVCTRY.-Mr. "Walter M. Adam»,
B A., delivered his fifth and concluding leoturo on th«
elemente of " Geometry" last evening, In the School of
Arts. Tho chair was taken by N, Ü. Stenhouse, Esq.,
President of the Bohool of Arts. Thero was a consider*
able audioncp, who evinced Ihoir appreciation of tb»
lecturer's ability by frequent applause.
BSRJADB ORDER.-The OlftW commanding tb»
Volunteers has much, pleasure in conveying (by com*
mend) to tba officers, non-commissioned officers, and
members of the Volunteer force, tho pratificatloa of
bis Excellency the Govornor ot tbs largo attendance
and soldier-like appearanoe presentod by the Volunteers
?t the Review7 in honor ot ncr Majesty e birthday. He
congratulates them on their spirit and dlsoipllnp, and
is doslrous sf impressing upon all ranks of the force,
the necessity of a consistent attendance to their duties,
from whioh will necessarily result that Improvement,
morally and physically, which has accompanied, and
continues to be characteristic of tho Volunteer aove*
ment in England. His Excellency ls sanguino that th»
re-introduotion and adoption, during the ensuing
sessions of the Parliament, of tho Amended
Act and Regulation», which tho pross ot
business unfortunately delsysd in the, last
session, will have thoefloot of forwarding- tho Volunteer
interest ia the colony, B£ command, Tnoe. BATHS»,
Captain, Brigade Adjutant. "
PEINOB or WALIS OEBA HOUSE.-Julia Mathews,
last evening, took ber farewell benaQt, and for a long
timo her leave of an Australian audionco. . Sbehsinow
successfully fulfilled a short engagement at this theatre,
and has impersonated a variety of characters, and for
the last fortnight has appeared with great success ia
" Ixion." Last evening tho house was crowded ia
every part, and tho dress circle was filled with on« of
the moat fashionable audiences to witness the comedy
of " An Unequal Match," followed by tho burlesque of
" Ixion," which passed off most satisfactorily. Julia
Mathews may ba said to have graduated from the stag»
of tisis colony. 6he appeared before tis a fe« years ago
qnlte a child, but steady persereranoo and careful train
inghava mads her the accomplished aotress that is now
about to leave with a Vary considerable reputation and
a ltadlnt; publia favourite1, and, there can ba little
doubt, la destined to command tho position of a promi-
nent star haforo sn English asdienoe, Mre. Mumford
leaves for London by tb» Danbar Castle, and should
she again return te tho colonias sb« is sure to roooiro a
most oordisl woloomo. After tho conclusion of
tb« first piece she appoared before th»
curtain, and when th« applause that greeted
ber had subsided, she spoke as follows i
" The littlo word ' Good*bye* is under any oircamsUnoe»
fraught with painful associations. Thsro are occasions
on whioh the.leave-taking is hallowed by greatelul recol-
lections of the psst, and sanstiflod by regret for,lh»
prassnt. Such occasions may bo truly called green spot»
on memory's waste, and lights on life's dull stroam, to
whioh the heart of the wanderer will often ro'vort with
prido and ploaaure. Ono of those occasions in my
caretr presents itself tonight, and I should, indeed, b»
wanting in fosling were I to allow lt to' pa«« without
expressing ia heartfelt terme tba doop regret I eipori»
enos at bidding farawell to n publlo with whom I hive
boen associated sines my childhood, and from whom I
hare received si many acknowledgments of favour ind
support. It is with mingled sensations of feelingsnd
pride I remember it waa ia the oolony of New
South Wales that tho germ of any dramatic ability I
may possess waa first developed. To say that I ins
proud of your oountenancv, and grateful for your kind*
ness^ ts an old tale, and ef ten told, and tho languige
ot thankful acknowledgment is soon cxhauatod, how«
ever, unbounded, may bs tho feelings tbat prompt lt»
When I quit . thia stago to-morrow evening, our
connection for a time must cesso, but I
shall boar ; away with ' ma over 10,000
miles of ocean, pleasant memories of warm hosrts tbat
beat banoath Australia's sunny skios | nnd, should dis*
tiny ovar bring mo baok again to this beautiful lind;
I shall fool myself »alf returning home, not to th» hom»
of birth, 'tis trae, but th» homo of my lifo's spring
time, and all its oherlshod memories and ssjoolatlons
tho homo of all who mnniullv fight lifo's sattle be-
neath tho banner of honour and independence. Atti
now I beg once more to relterato my thanks, anti nun
you ono and all happiness and prosperity, '
Nor time, nor clrau malenca caa arer part
? This sweet ramomtiranee from ruy a«alliu| heart.
May mr concluding wish not vainly fallt
May health and happy h jura attend rou all.
Though In a far orr land my lot la oast,
. I'll I «ar with ma the meal ry of tba past.
Ileareu blois yon all-no lo«|ter must I dwell
OD this sweat sorrow-onoo mora, friends, larawa l.

title: IN LIGHTER VEIN.
content:
IN LIGHTER VEXN\
Her Suggestion.
I told her I could never speak the words I fain
would speak, .
That every time I tried it on my courage sprang a
leak;
That when I gazed into her orbs, blue as the
skies above,
My coward lips refused to voice the story of my
love.
She gazed at me with sympathy in her, expres
sive eyes, .
And once or twice her bosom heaved with quite,
emphatic sighs; ':
Then, with a nice, becoming blush, and In a ten
der tone,
She said: "Perhaps you'd better call me up by
telephone!"

title: The Grand Hotel.
content:
The Grand Hotel.
WITH THE HOLE IN THE
IWALL.
Ttíe Grand1 Hotel was very small,
Bu|t still it was a 'Tort of call:"
A' sort of place where "boys" could
And have a "jamboree/" you know.
The structure was of modest plan,
Thle architect-a Chinaman.
" ' Eliabethan' too much styleV
Thjp architect said with a simile;
"I makee plenty simple pjlan,
More better* cajll it * Mary-Ann.1 T
No Supervisor ran the show
For George, he was the Chief you
know.
He had1 no liquor licence, and
(Would! riot transgress laws of the Jand.
No "requisitions" troubled him,
He'd tapi the wall and call for Jim.
"Some bottled1 beer, quick," Georg«
would1 say- »
And Jimmy, brought it straight away.
Of bottled beer Jim had a stock,
Arid never pointed to the clock.
No sly grog), as I said' before,
Was sold here-so the landlord swore.
But still they got the grog, you see,
For Jimmy said "You savee me,
I^got too plenty been inside;
I makee door 'bout one foot wide:
You pushee money through the door,
I pushee beer back, plenty more."
And then the "boys" ate oyster stew,
And well boiled tripe and onions, (toot
And then they, sat and talked and
smoked,
And often sang-more often joked.
Arid when their "hoppers" got too
Ur,y
Thley, càlle'd for Jim, who said ,"All-li°
Arid1 quick the beer came through the
hole,
And quicker back the coins would
roll;
And fhbn more tripe and oyster stew, x
And soon the crowd got "unco fou."
The full committee one night sat
To deal with this and settle that.
A balance sheet was brought to light,
The figures, somehow, weren't right.
Although the totals did agree,
The cash was three quid "out" you
see." \ * %
This caused' an argument and noise:
Tihb Chairman said, "Now, look here,
boys,
I am the Chairman here to-night,
I'm going to say that things are
right;
Your auditors won't pass this sheet
fl've passed1 tift/ent ou$ itíío the street.
I'll pay the three quid in to show
The books are right: and now ypu
know
I've got a shooting iron here
That talks as loud as all your beer,
And if my ruling's set aside
I'll bore a hole through someone's
hide." '
Th'e Chairman looked "tremenjousr*
wild,';
_ And1 then the boys were tamje arid
mild,: i j
They said "hooray/' and then "hear,
hear-'*
And1 called up Jimmy for more beer.
They had more beer and good tripe,
too,
And1 said the Management would do."
The tripe was good, the beer was
cheap*
Inspiring harmony and sleep.
Some left for home and others-well,
Some secrets some men never tell.
But they came back again next night
And* thought the Grand Hotel was
"right." ' ?
-LEONARD MORRISON.
Darwin; 16.6.16.

title: Flotsam and Jetsam.
content:
Flotsam and Jetsam.
Songs of the Bush.
[Some readers who have been kind enough to send
in contributions for this column evidently do not
understand that only bush songs are wanted. The
majority of so-called songs sent in are simply poems,
often of the sender's own composition. While some
of these are worthy of publication, and are therefore
held with a view to future insertion, they can have no
place in this column, which is reserved for songs and
songs only.]
THE STOCKMAN.
Air.—" Boorooloola."
I'm a stockman, yes I am;
They call me "Ugly Sam"—
I'm old and lame, and only got one eye.
In a yard I'm good, of course,
But put me on a horse,
And I'll do what plenty young 'uns will not try.
I can lead them through the gidyea,
Through country rough and ridgy,
I can lose 'em in the very worst of scrub;
I can tide 'em rough or aisy,
With a head-rope I'm a daisy,
And a right down bobby-dazzler at a pub.
You should see me use a whip;
Can't I give the beggars zip,
Make 'em roar and make the echoes ring,
And with a brand—Ah ! well
I'm a perfect blooming swell—
In fact I'm good at any blessed thing.
I'm a star at spoiling hide,
And can't I put on side,
Come the silvertail as if my blood was blue.
Strike me blue or green or red,
I can stand upon my head,
And be then as good as any other two.
I've a notion in my pate,
It is'nt luck, its fate,
For I'm far above the common blessed run,
Oh ! strike me pink, oh! do,
Come, cut me up in two,
For I'm far too jolly good to be in one. CROOKED MICK.

title: A PLEA.
content:
A PLEA.
When our world is filled with sunshine,
dearth and trouble far away,
When life's path is strewn with flowers,
and the heart is glad and gay;
Many an outstretched hand will greet
us;
Many an eye to ours may smile,
Not until our days are darkened shall
we know the ones worth while!
Friends of rank, and wit, and fortune,
haply sorrow shall betray;
Poorer mates, with hearts more honest,
stand before them in that day.
God of life ! If there's one treasure I
would ask, all else above:
When the gloom-clouds thicken o'er me,
give me friends, and grant me
love 1
And if that should be denied me, more
than thou art pleased to send,
Then to all who grieve or suffer, fit me
well to be a friend.
M.H.

title: LITERATURE
content:
LITERATURE
Original Poetry.
The Shepherd's Last Sleep.
CHRISTOPHUS.
IN the old log hut the shepherd lay,
His fevered cheek by the hot wind fanned;
And he dreamt of the dear ones far away,
And the fields and the flowers of his native land.
And o'er his face crept a tender smile
As he dreamt of one who was dearer still,
And the old home in his native isle.
Ah! if dreams could only their vows fulfil !
To the old log hut by the lonely creek
With naked sword came the Angel of Death;
Pale grew the sleeper's hectic cheek
As no felt the touch of that icy breath.
In the lonely bush in a far-off land,
Where the wattles bloom and the brigalows
wave,
Laid to his rest by a stranger's hand,
The exile sleeps in his nameless grave.

title: To the North Head of Port Jackson, New South Wales.
content:
To the North Head of Port Jackson,
New South Wales.
I'VE seen thee from the mountains, from the sea,
The harbour and the Academic tower :
I've seen thee at the summer's waking hour,
And on a winter's eve. Thou mindest me
Of clashing rocks of Greek mythology,
Through which, to win her golden, fleecy dower,
The Argo passed to Queen Medea's bower ;
Or of a giant of German legendry
Guarding the gate of an enchanted land.
And ne'er Teutonic ingenuity
Fabled a scene more fairylike or grand
Than that which in thy watch and ward doth lie,
With glassy coves girt to the edge with trees,
And palaces brooding on ship-lined quays.
I went one morn to stand upon thy brows,
One morn in spring ; and climbing the hill side,
Trampled a carpet, marvellously dyed,
Of spring flowers-native violet, native rose,
And heath of almost every hue that grows,
From the pink-tinged epacris of our pride
Down to the white-bloomed dwarf which chill defied^
Before the wattle breaks the spring's trance blows.' I
I climbed until I came to a wet moor |
Whereon the breath of the Pacific blew
Whereto the waves and reefs send up their roar ;
And then I hastened to the brink to view.
Two majesties-the blue horizon, bound,
And the great city which the harbour crowned.
-DOUGLAS B. W. SLADEN.

title: THE FIRST PRIMROSE IN AUSTRALIA.
content:
THE FIRST PRIMROSE IN AUSTRALIA.
Well, matcs,iit was awhile ago,
Soinewhoro in fifty-one
I mind it well-'twas just tho time
The-diggings had begun.
And thousands then werojfooking hore
To dig the goldou soil,
They thought, poor souls, to free themselves
At once, from years of toil.
Some did no doubt, yet many a ono
Long mourned tho day that he
Left friends and home in England dear,
To cross the raging sea.
For oh ! such sights as I havo seen,
Such misery and pain ;
I'd not for Ballarat's red gold
Behold the like again.
Whole families beneath a tent,
Where scarcely room to lie,
Andfjjabios'ibornlwithjnaughtîbotween
The mother and the sky;
And all their small belongings
Spread out for sale. Ahme !
How many an aching heart there were
Upon that Melbourno quay.
But, to my yam : There came one day
A vessel to that shore,
With many a heart, impatient to
Dig up the golden ore.
And some had monoy-more had none,
But left it all to chance :
Then- only thought was-Ballarat,
Their watchword-On, advance 1
Now one had brought his wife with him,
And Jane, their little girl,
With Saxon eyes and head o'orrun
With many a'flaxen^curl.
And Janey, she had brought with her
(The fact I well remind)
A Primrose-in remembrance of
The homo she'd left bohind.
'Twas in a tiny flower-pot, and,
Among their little things,
Says she, "Dear mother, put it out,
We'll take whate'er it brings
Perhaps, a loaf of bread." Just then
A bushman passes by,
With curious glance on all around,
The Primrose caught his eye.
He stopped, then thought, "Why that's the first
I've seen for many a year,"
Tho only one I've ever seen
Since I've been over hore.
" What want you for tho flower1, my lass ?"
"A shilling, Sh-," sho said,
" I would not soil if we did
Not want it to buy bread :
"For all tho way from Devonshire
I've brought tho little flower,
And tended it upon the voyage,
And watched it hour by hour :
"And now it's hard to part with it-"
" You sha'nt," tho bushman cried,
" Hero is tho shilling ten times told,
And keep tho flower beside :
"And I say, lass, just water it,
And put it up for show ;
There's scores will pay to look at it,
Aud glad too, sure I know :
" For hundreds hore have nevor seon,
Since first thoy took to roam,
A flower to call them back to mind
Their dear old English home."
And so poor Janey kept tho flower,
And hundreds came to view
Her Primroso ; and the lassie found
Tlie bushman's words como true.
For luck set in that veiy day,
Her father struck tho gold.
Now manya night by the camp-fire light
Tho Primrose yarn is told.
It's true-I saw it all myself ;
So never moro disdain
Thc palo hodge-llower : if o'er you do
Remember Primrose Jane.
D. M. 0.
LAKGE PURCHASES OP SHEEP.-Two very largo pur
chases of sheep in tliis neighbourhood have just been
concluded by Mr. Robert Patterson, of Conargo. Tho
first was effected through Messrs. Powers, Rutherford,
and Co., Melbourne, and consisted of 13,000 stores
from tho Billabong station, delivery of which have
already been taken by Mr-. Patterson. The second lot
were bought through Messrs. Dalmahoy, Campbell, and
Co., also in Melbourne, and consist of 15,000 store
wethers, which arrived hero a short time since from ]
Queensland, and aro now boiug shorn at Pomingalarna :
5000 mixed sheep of Mr. Sheriff's, sold on Monday by
Mr. G. A. Elliot (Messrs. Powers, Rutherford, and
Co.'s agent), crossed tho bridgo yesterday for delivery..
- - Wagga Wagga Express.

title: Original Poetry.
content:
Original Poetry. FOR THE SYDNEY GAZETTE.
OPINION.
Opinions, like the vapours on the wind,
Wander diverse, nor leave a trace behind;
Reason and candour are high sounding names,
Which folly echoes and presumption claims;
And shallow critics, in this flippant age,
Pour forth their crude remarks on every page--
Distort each sentence, and make nonsense plain,
With notes and comments, impudently vain.
The luckless bard, whatever be his aim,
Can please but few unless he have a name.
Whether his muse some luckless wanderer guides
O'er dreary plains, or deep and boisterous tides;
Whether his fancy paints the enchanted spot,
The murmuring fountain, or sequestered grot;
Whether, in mournful numbers, he should tell
How passion triumphed and how virtue fell--
With retrospective visions charm the eye,
And claim the tribute of reflection's sigh;--
The critic blames--the luke-warm dolt admires,
And, in affected rapture, half expires;
The Misses sigh--the drowsy dotards whine
"How very pretty!"--what a charming line!
Observe the critic!--mark his vacant stare--
Sagacious shrug--and all-important air;
Distorted mouth--knit brow--and half closed eye;
His solemn gait--his itch for mystery--
His profound nothingness--his obscure phrase--
His adoration of the "Ancient Days;"
And what a combination will you find
Of senseless words and barrenness of mind!
He prates of genius as the punch goes round,
And, dozing, groans forth many a vapid sound:
He dwells with rapture, on some jingling chime--
The most unmeaning is the most sublime;
All common sense bespeaks a want of sense,
But palsied drivelling marks intelligence;
A coarse hyperbole ia feeling's voice--
A tumid sentiment refinement's choice:
Of taste he prattles in incongruous strains,
And all sobriety of thought disdains.
Nor do I wonder that these dolts abound,
When such unmeaning rhymsters, too, are found.
So much for critics. Let us now behold
A thing as senseless, tho' perchance less bold:
The whining boy-bard, just escaped from school,
With nonsense crammed--enough to make a fool--
With fractured sentences of morbid rhyme,
And thoughts absurd, mistaken for sublime;
Some sceptic doubts the strippling's head possess,
Which make him err the more, but think the less.
But, good or ill, t'were cruel to condemn
With cynic dogmas and capricious phlegm.
He will improve, if nature be his guide;
If not, he sinks in Lethe's soothing tide.
He may indulge in many a harmless strain,
And teach his muse her sallies to restrain.
Again he sings--the aid of fancy craves--
"Thy star-like eyes have made a race of slaves;
"Thy lovely form with Juno's may compare;
"Nor can e'en Venus boast a cheek so fair--
"Where the pale lily mingles with the rose,
"And music's breath in every accent flows:
"In dreams, I meet thee in some ocean isle,
"Where fountains murmur, and where vallies smile--
"Where Spring, with flowery vesture, clothes the
ground,
"And seraph forms seem ever floating round;
"Thro' the moon's beams their fairy figures glide,
"Bathing their tresses in the dewy tide."
A verse like this e'en censure would not blame,
Nor crush the enthusiast's visionary fame.
But there are shameless coxcombs who presume
To pillage sacred genius in the tomb:
With volumes fenced--with magazines beset--
And duns and punch to keep him on the fret.
He dives for lines, with most industrious skill,
And twists, and turns, and moulds them to his will.
No bard is safe. The flash of brilliant wit
Is crampt and hampered, his coarse brain to fit;
Nor Pope, nor Beattie, nor the Prince of Song,
Escape these would-be minstrels' paltry wrong.
To jingling Tauze we lend an aching ear,
And for his dancing rhyme return a sneer.
Bid ---------- no more, to gain a fame,
To Southey's number's tack his own poor name.
To puling JUVENIS, we say again,
Stick to thy desk, and spare thy barren brain.
Before thy pen affrighted reason flies,
And, in convulsions, gasping rythm dies.
May, 1832.
H. H.
newspaper: The Sydney Gazette and New South Wales Advertiser

title: LITERARY
content:
LITERARY
Original Poetry
[WRITTEN FOR THE QUEENSLANDER.]
The Choosers of the Slain.
[In Memoriam E. O. Meston, aged [?].]
A. MESTON.
Brisbane, November.
[In the old Norse mythology there were "Three
Sisters"—the " Valkyrrior"—who went forth from the
halls of Asgard to select those who had to die.]
The iron gates unfold again,
They come—the " Choosers or tbe Slain 1"
Weird f isters from the Asgard City,
'With steel blue eyes that know no pity.
They go U a mother with endless fears;
To a father with grief too deep for tears.
They seek for a child serenely fair,
A blue-eyed girl with golden bair.
A sudden dreadful shadow falls
Across tho floor, along the walls I
And awful aa the words of doom
Tho silence of that lonely room t
The mother kissed the dying child,
The fair young face looked up and smiled.
She saw the shadow on the wall,
She heard the voice from Odin's Hall t
Cold was the Fatal Sisters' breath,
The soft bloc eyes are closed in death.
And slowly through tbe Iron Gate
Ride back the Messengers of Fate!
But not alone, between the Pair
A blue-eye J girl with golden hair I
And elsewhere in a darkened room
A mother sits in voiceless gloom.
Hot tears are falling on the bed,
Her heart is icy as the dead.
And in a graveyard, still and lone,
Two stand by a recording stone.
And read of one new bnrisd there—
A blue-eyed girl with golden hair.
And both in silence bow below,
A parent's first and bittor woe.
The child they loved has gone before,
Where pain and sorrow come no more.
And angel spirits guard her well
On Asgard meads of Asphodel.
But oft the tears unchecked will flow
From those who loved her here below.
She lives upon that bnrning scroll,
The " Younger Edda" of the soul I

title: SONGS FOR THE MINERS.
content:
SONGS FOR THE MINERS.
NO. I.
Away, away to the Bathurst ground,
Where the " dust" is brightly shining:
Away, away to the " Diggins" found,
Where the boys are busily mining.
And Midas, my boy, in thy turn thou'lt be,
If dame Fortune but smile on thy clay ;
But, while rocking the cradle right merrily,
Keep the ass's ears far away !
Away, away, to the Ophir glen,
Where the boys the sands are laving ;
And the "Diggins" ring with gladness again,
To the songs of the miners slaving.
And Midas, my boy, &c.

title: POETRY, BUT NOT ORIGINAL.
content:
POETRY,
BUT NOT ORIGINAL.
*LAMENT OF THE SINGLE LADIES OF
SYDNEY,
'te're ready, we're ready, it really is hard,
That from Hymen's sweet bonds, we so long are
debarr'd;
'The men are so cautious, the hard-hearted crea
tures,
That they care not for all our blandsmiles or fair
features.
There are plenty of red coats, we like them the
best,
B3ut they're just like the others, when put to the
test.
They tell us we form the delight of their lives,
Yet they very weIl'manage talive without wives;
Of dinners and balls, our papas give them plenty,
:Of hints'it is true, our mamas throw out twenty ;
They accept all, the dinners, they dance at each
ball,
They hear all the hints, but won't take them at all!
They bow when they meet us, and say we look
charming,
'Or the weather is cold; .'tis their hearts that want
warming ; -
They laugh and they chat, and thea pass for our
beans,
Yet 'tis very provoking they never propose !
If they knew all the graces and glances we learn,
They surely would offer to make some return
What is it they want ? Oh ! sadly we fear,
That the charms they require are some hundreds
a year.
'It is said they are rather deficient in purse,
But we'd venture to take them " for better for
worse."
We parade thro' the streets, and we walk on the
pier,
And all for such cold sefish wretches-oh dear !
Our Mammas (poor vld souls,) trudge about ev'ry
day,
'rill their legs and our patience are near worn
away;
The men might possess some respect for old age,
And by taking their daughters, their troubles
assunge ;
And put altogether we're a good-looking set,
A better assortment the Gents will not get.
We very welLknow, all men's tastes dont agree,
iBut we are as complaisant as women can be,
We're to some sentimental, with some we coqnet,
We languish and smile, but no husbands we get!
Our ohs! and our ahs ! pass quite harmless by,
What a torment that men now-a-days are so shy.
Oh ! if 'twere the fashion for women to ask,
(To some, by-the bye not a difficult task,)
flow delightful 'twould be to pick and to choose;
Of course the men would not attempt to refuse !
-But'alas ! we are doomed " not unsought to be
won,"
If it rested with us, 'twould be very soon done.
'Tis a terrible thing that men wont understand,
They are really the plague and the pest of the land
Our Papas and Mamnmas, get cross and look glum,
As much as to say, "yot've been too long at
home."
We're reatdy,.we're ready, will nobody try,
MOr in single felicity are we to die'?
. POOR-THING.

title: Dead Leaves.
content:
Dead Leaves.
THE leaves fall soft in Autumn's qulet^breath,
The leaveBfall soft unto their mother earth,
The leaves fall soft asleep in peaceful death,
To form the cradle for some newer birth !
The leaves fall soft-their fluttering life is done,
They fading fall-their summer life is o'er ;
No more their def ted edges to the sun
They lift-but fall and fade for evermore !
Ah, happy leaves-that know some quiet end '
Is theirs for ever, when their work is past ;
Ah, happy-with vast Nature's frame to blend ?<
And moulder into peacefulness at last !
No more the strong wings of the wind shall Bhake
Their tender fringe, and strain their pulsing veins,
No more the tempest's wrath the boughs shall break,
And bruise them, scattering o'er the wild wide plains.
Nor evermore the quiet mists may fall,
And fill their graceful frondage with soft dew
Nor summer sunlight, in the dawning, call
The forest sap to fill their veins anew !
The springtide saw them in their opening sheen,
Ana autumn burnt them into golden red
Andjrusset-mellowing summer's vivid green
Andi winter bleached them when their life was fled.
They lived their life pf sun, and dew, and rain,
And peaceful fading, fell to earth's calm breast.
So may we pass away at last from pain.
And aleen for ever in unbroken rest !
m_ R. A.

He's so vory fond of buying, 'tis but fail ho should bo

A robber band from Avontivo await Cornelia's son,

Long years slnco thou havo passed, but uow no san-

title: TO YOU.
content:
TO YOU.
Did angels shatter two blue, blue stars
And shape them into eyes,
When twilight covers the grey helars
And curtains the evening shies,
Or. lest for this earth they be too wise,
Are they but flame of the fireflies?
Did spirits steal, when the dawning glows,
Down ipto the dew-wet fields,
And snatch the red from a drowsing rose,
The magic a poppy wields—
When, slow and seldom, that curved mouth
yields,
Do lovers dream of the poppy-fields?
Or, as the languid lids unclose,
Where the snamed warm blood will rise,
Do they ponder on a dew-cool rose
That budded in Paradise,
Or of groves, where the wild flower grows.
Whose strange deep rooting no mortal
knows?
Did fairies pluck from the thistle-down
The white that is delicate,
Did they leave the tall stems, stripped and
brown,
And free from that feather weight,
To make the snow, 'neath the dark hair's
crown,
Of brows where the love-locks cluster
down?
Did the God of Day, when hours were fair,
Lean out from his arch of blue,
Mix sun and shadow to make your hair,
And twist it in a wreath for you?
Ah! well did he blend the sunlight there
With deeper tones of your nut-brown
liair!
Did the prisoned soul of a violin
Break out from its polished wood,
To find in the songs of trees its kin,
And its yearning understood;
Did your voice gather the beauty in
Of the sweet strayed soul of a violin?
And where did they find your complex
heart?
Deep down in some mermaid's cave,
Where the long green seaweeds sway and
part
To kiss of a reckless wave.
The harps of syrens were rived apart
For strings to twine in your complex
heart!
M. FQRBEST.

title: NIGHT SCENE IN EUROBODALLA.
content:
NIGHT SCENE IN EUROBODALLA.
Eurobodalla! euphoniously named,
Why are thy flora and fauna unfamed?
Wherefore in silence still reigning among
Charms that but wait for a wooer of song?
Wild is the westwind and wilder the weird
Flutter of leaflets where wild men were speared;
Murmuring voices too, seem to bemoan
The midnight disturber in language unknown;
Or are the sounds simply intoned by the breeze
Brushing its way through the native oak trees?
Who were the many that moulder beneath
Mounds now encumbered with mazes of heath?
Fled are their spirits from mortals--but where?
Point with the finger, who can, and say, there!
Secrets, enwombed in the ages to come
Leave all our boasted philosophy dumb!
If there be spectre-like visitants seen
Where aboriginal battles have been,
Oh! that they would to my vision unfold
What through the cloud-rifts saw Ossian of old!
This is the field where dark warriors encamped,
Stolid self-will on each visage enstamped;
Here, where their forefathers quietly slept,
They fought and they feasted, they laughed and they wept
Sweetly the wattle trees shed their perfume
Over old mysteries mantled in gloom:
Wherefore attempt to unveil them? 'Tis knaves
Only who gloat o'er the opening of graves!
I am no pansophist: nor would I seem
More than I am in my own mystic dream.
Thread we our way through the thickets to gain
Glimpses enchanting of moonlight's domain.
With visions of beauty our senses are fraught
Ever expanding and filling with thought!
Cottage-lights beaming from regions around--
Tell where the settlers' new clearings abound--
Culture of soils is extending across
Valleys enrich'd by the teeming Tuross.
Sweetest of scenes, as if meant to allure
Waters so peacefully flowing and pure,--
Carpets of verdure, as if to sustain
The brightest and best--yet must I with pain
Tell of dark spots on the picture? Oh can
Blots from my pen fall alone upon man?
Party strife rages--profanities roll
Where but love's image should shine in the soul!
Fierce animosities often enflame
Neighbours who neighbours are only in name!
Wherefore do nominal Christians surpass
Heathens in heathenish feelings? Alas!
Eurobodalla! To mourn o'er the change
The white man has wrought--is as painful as strange;
But ere he distracted thy beautiful dream,
Savages knew of no God to blaspheme!
August, 1870.
W. M. C. C.
