title: The Editor Miscellany.
content:
®p$Witot'& Jttí*rcUant>. j
" lA multifarious suni
*..Of« Wnims and Oddities :'-« The Dooion's stwdï'
-To «how the crude conceits of every body :
An 0»iNi>GATiiEnuM."
Soirée IV.
Editor. What shall we say to the pub-
lic ? Our friend Jjjvenai., in consequence
'of the cavalierahip of our late treatment of
him, has declined all further connection with
our " Miscellany." To the public this is a
very serious, and, we fear, irreparable loss.
Juvenal is caustic, but he can also be kind.
He has a keen perception of the follies and
faults of others ; but, we know, that at the
same, time he bears about with him a heart-
felt admiration of excellence in everyshape.
We have no doubt that had his " Botany
Bay Eclogues" been differently received, the
bile of his composition would have soon
been expended, and we should have had a
valuable collection of family portraits sus-
pended in our literary gallery for the benefit
of our latest posterity. To our own feel-
ings, we confess, the loss of Juvenal, as a
contributor and companion, is a distressing
event :
" As every kind of parting bas its stings."
'We had reckoned upon him as a constant
attendant on our soirées. Our reliance upon
his judgment, in relation to " men and
things," here, gave a sort of confidencee to
our opinions, which we felt likely to stand '
1 WS in good stead on many a needful occa-
sion. How his place is to be supplied we
do not yet foresee. In our present soiree,
. we are under the necessity of examining our
literary contributions by ourselves. There
is wanting in consequence, on our part, all
the cheerfulness which is the usual compa-
nion of an agreeable chit-chat.
It is odd how one loss will suggest ano
"ther. We have lost our friend Juvlnal,
and the public their friends of the XXXIXth.
We could not resist following the gallant
fellows to the wharf on Saturday morning,
.and witnessing their embarkation. The
" game of war" all over the world, is now
less likely, we trust, than ever heretofore,
to be played again. The growing intelli
* gence of mankind,-their experience of the
i horrors and conviction of the useleasness
and folly of most of the wars that have been
waged in time past, tend, we think, to ren
' der them less and less eager to
--" cry havock, and lot sup the dog« of war."
In other words, the occupation of a soldier
is becoming of less consequence every day.
Yet the " pomp and circumstance" of mili-
tary discipline creates a deep interest in the
movements of a military corps. Besides,
these gallant fellows, who have just stepped
from our shores, have been the protectors of
our property and the guardians of our civil
rights, as well as our safeguard against the
invasion of foreigners; and we confess,
although no peculiar bond of intimacy had
been formed between ourselves and any of
the corps, our feelings got fairly the better
of us, as the band struck solemnly up the
affecting tune of " Auld lang syne," and
the boats were towed slowly from the wharf.
We imagined that the cheers were heavy
hearted, and that there was a loathness to
-part, on the side of those on shore as well as
. of those who were moving away, highly
creditable to both parties. We are sure
they carry with them the best wishes of our
. community ; and we feel convinced that
they are not likely, in any future canton
jnenr,"to enjoy more real happiness than
^they have experienced, as a body, during
the time they have been stationed in this
Colony. And Colonel Lindesay, good
honest soul, carries .with him the good will
and affection of all who know him. The
kindness and conciliation which have nni
? for ml y marked all his proceedings here will
ever render his memory beloved. If we
mistake not, he has the best claim to the
Crawford title. The present Lady Mary
Lindesay Crawford is now an old woman.
'We should rejoice to learn that he waa en-
rolled among the' Peerage of Scotland.
Parting with the heroes of Albuera very
naturally leads us to insert a very pretty
sonnet expressive of feelings somewhat in
- .accordance with our own at present, which
we owe to the kindness of our respected
contributor " Eta."
SONNET.
I've seen again the spot on which we stood--
The shell-strewn beach from which I saw thee part,
When thoughts of deepest grief rush'd on that heart
Whose anguish'd swellings rose as did the flood;
And still the sense of that remember'd hour
Comes with new force across my fever'd brain:
'Wakening those pangs which o'er my soul have power
To break its spell, and burst its earthly chain.
And still the tones of that remember'd voice,
In soothing accents, strike upon my ear:
Soft'ning that heart which can no more rejoice
In all it has borne--all it still must bear.
But, like the music of a well-tun'd lute,
The sounds still vibrate, tho' the strings be mute.
ETA.
Sydney, 1832.
'We have received, too, some very spirited
.* Anacreontic verses" from our truly poeti-
cal friend H. H. And we are sure, from
the opinion we do not hesitate to pass upon
the merits of his contributions, he will give
us credit for sincerity when we express our
extreme regret in not feeling ourselves at
liberty to give them insertion in our " Mis-
cellany." Our position, as a public jour-
nalist, leads us also to consider ourselves as
a guardian of public morals; and, as we are
decidedly of opinion that every well-wisher
to this community ought to check, in as far
as his influence goes, the unfortunate pro-
pensity to make too free use of wine and
ardent spirits, which prevails throughout
the colony, he will understand why we would
deem it a direliction of our public duty were
we to publish {which we could not do with-
out approbation of its merits) the present
contribution of H. H" which is a very
elegant and spirited drinking song. By the
bye, we have learned that Doctor Lang, of
the Scots Kirk, has it in view to preach a
sermon on the subject of drinking next
Sunday morning ; with the view of rectify-
ing, to some extent, the habits of the po-
pulace, in preparation for their approaching
encounter with the contagious principle of
cholera morbus. The experience of all the
physicians of Europe goes to assure us that I
habits of dissipation and debauchery emi-1,
ncntly predispose the frame for imbibing t
the contagious poison. Of course, wert
the disease to get footing on our shores, wt
are to expect the most melancholy conse-
quences from the established prevalence oi
this predisposition among the mass of oui
population. This sanitary effort, on tin
part of Doctor Lano, is the only one whicl
we have heard of as being taken with tlu
view of guarding against the inroads of oui
approaching foe. We confess that we an
not sanguine in expecting much good iron
a solitary sermon from a solitary pulpit.
The town, as we suggested before whei
treating formally upon the subject, ought ti
be divided into districts, and the clergymen,
with proper assistants, ought to ply theil
daily walks among all ranks of the populace ;
with the view of cleansing out, ere the
cholera morbus commences its ravages, the
Augean stable of habitual impurity, which
has its ramifications throughout every street
and lane, and alley of our town. A society
of ladies, too, ought to be formed, for the
purpose of aiding in accomplishing the
general rectification of the dissolute habits
of the people.*
These observations haveded us away from
several topics of less grave import, which
would have been more appropriately noticed
in our Miscellany. We had a lengthy poeti-
cal piece marked out for insertion, and a
prose jeu d'esprit besides. Both of which,
however, we must keep in reserve. Mean-
while, as a relief from the sombreness ol
these observations, our readers may not
dislike the following stanzas from our friend
" Erin" :
STANZAS.
When thou wert true
The earth was dear and fair to me;
Joy shone in every bell of dew,
The sunshine always spoko of thee,
And swiftly every moment flew,
When thou wert true I
When thou wert true
The sky in clouds was never drest ;
Eternal flowors their fragrance throw
On valley's lap, and mountain's crest :
Thorns on roses never grew,
When thou wert true 1
When thou wert trne
No tempest churned to wrath the woves ;
The winds were calm, or only blew
In gusts around false lovers' gravea I
Oh, no! I ne'er misfortune-kuew.
When thou wert true!
When thou wert true,
There was a smile on every brow ;
No seasons paled the rose's hue.
And fruitage hung on every bough ;
Birds warbling through the gardens flew,
When thou wert true 1
Now thou'rt forsworn !
And earth seems chaos to my view ;
A prison on a dark sea borne,
And mortals all a demon crew.
Who smile on crime and virtue scorn,
For thou'rt forsworn !
Now thou'rt changed,
Tho 6kv is ever dark and drear;
Owls flit where gentle linnets ranged,
And fruits are harsh, and flowers are sear,
And hopes are dead, and friends estranged,
For thou art changed !
E. O'S
* We promised not to return to the subject
of cholera morbus unless with a view of
giving such extracts or condensed informa-
tion respecting its history, or progress and
treatment, as we should deem likely to in-
terest our readers. We are unwilling to
dwell unnecessarily long on one topic ; yet
we think public attention is not sufficiently
awake to the importance of preparing for
the worst. There cannot be needless alarm
upon such a subject : and of this we are
sure, that, granting cholera "morbus never
were to visit our shores at all, in the act of
making proper preparation for its reception,
in getting rid of the filth and fulsomeness of
the dissipated and debauched habits of our
general population, an amount of good would
accrue to the community which could not
easily be accomplished, without the aid of so
powerful an incitement to moral reform as
may be made of the fear of falling victims
to the pestilence.
The following quotation from the " Spec-
tator^ will show the sentiments of those in
London who were inclined to treat with
contempt all fears upon the subject ; who,
at all events, held the prescriptions of the
Board of Health of a precautionary nature
in " utter abomination."
" The great question is not whether cholera is
contagious or not, but how are we to manage it, now
that, notwithstanding all our attempts at barring
out, it has come among us 1 Of the way in which
the quarantine has been kept, a good deal has been,
said. We honestly believe, that it has been kept as
well as quarantine is ever kept. Common sense
revolts so strongly against the confinement for three
or four weeks of men in perfect health, without any
obvious or intelligible reason, that they are never so
confined. Where actual sickness is on board a ves-
sel, we believe the regulations are pretty strictly
insisted on ; where no sickness exists, they never
have been, and never will be. The vessels by which
it is alleged the cholera was brought to Sunderland,
only attracted attention after it broko out there ; no
one thought of isolation before. We ourselves saw,
four yellow flags floating in Ramsgate harbour, in
the midst of three hundred vessels, without any
visible means of preventing intercourse between all
of them. If vessels coming from a suspectée] port
were subjected to a medical inspection, and if such
of their crews mid passengers as were in health,
after a careful ablution and fumigation if necessary,
were permitted to take the mail as their lotters are,
the public would have all the security it ever can
have, and no personal inconvenience would bo the
result. But the twenty-one day's quarantine is an
easier-applied remedy ; it requires no thought-that
bane to the peace both of the makers and executors
of law.
" We who, being the greatest naval power in the
world, and possessing the most active and numerous
coast guard, are most oopable of enforcing it, hove
seen the inutility of quarantine; is land quarantine
more efficacious 1 Russia, with a population of ma-
chines rather than freo agents-an nrmy which
obeys and murmurs not-functionaries disturbed
by no considerations of reason or mercy towards the
publio or individuals-tried land quarantine, and
failed. What is the conclusion from all this, but
that cholera, he it contagious or non-contagious
whether it travel by * the highways of human in-
tercourse,' which the one party aver, or as the crow
flies, which is the opinion of the other-cannot be
shut out by legal enactment-that it will be in if all
the world gainsaid it 1 Does not every principle of
reason, then, as well as of fear,.dietate to us that we
should piepare like men to grapple with the enemy
whom our long balla coimat reach t
ti
lie
.*' AU tbe doctors seem to agree that filth, cold,
damp, famino, or bad food, ero predispoaors to olio«
lora. Let us, then, heartily and rationally, and in a
kind spirit, sot about the romoval of tilth whero it is
matter of publio nuisance, and tho counselling of its
removal where it is purely domestic. The poor are
tho most porsuasiblo of all persons whero (hey have
no suspicion of tho adviser- Thoy will demur to
beadle, with his mop and pail and big looks ; but
lot a respectable neighbour only point out calmly
the danger to themsolves nnd to otbors from acou
«nulntionü of nastiness, and there will bo an imme-
diate flourishing of brooms among tho laziost and
most aputhetio of the race of Maclaines that hive
in Dyot-stroot. For cold nnd damp, and bad food,
the remedy lies in tho putses of the rich. Let them
be freely opened. Finn no1 waistcoats for tho men,
flannel potticoats for tho women, a blanket for their
beds, a bag or two of coals for their chimnios, a bit
of meat for thoir pots,-theso are quarantine regu-
lations which have never failed of ofioot, because
those who aro subjected to them have no interest in
evading their application. Let tis havo boards of
benevolence in the first plaoe ; and let the boards of
health follow when thuy are called for.
" The poorer class are at prosont set against tho
rich ; thoy are taught by ' errant' scoundrols, who
speak to tlieir sufferings, that not only tho uppor
but the middling classes are their natural enemies
und oppressors. Let the rich hy their gifts, and the
middling classes by their labours of love, prove in
the most effectual way the falsehood of this mon-
strous doctrine. Let them oppose to the oratory of
the Rotunda the prevailing voice of warm-hearted
Charity ; whilo Hunt declaims about political dis-
abilities, let them apply a ready remedy to physical
evils, and instead of noisy applause bestowed on
thoso who inveigh against the rich, thero will bo
hisses as hearty as ever visited the ear of a borough
monger or a political bishop. If when we have
blankets for every bed, shoes and Blockings for
every pair of feet, and, as far as wo can, a morsel
for every mouth,-if when sowers are dug and cess-
pools drained, cholera doos como to us, as porhaps
it will, then wo may safely say, oven to that most
formidable physical affliction, ' Rejoice not against
us, O our enemy 1'
" On the subject of modical treatment, it belongs
not to us to speak. When the disease has once
shown itself in a largo town where there isa doctor
in every street, common sense says that tho wisest
course is to call for his cousel. As, however, the
oholera is extromely rapid in its strides, and as pre-
liminary measures of cure ara quito capable of boing
taken by tho members of the patient's family, we
may be excusod for giving from an excellent autho-
rity the following simple directions :
" ' Although safety is scarcely to bo hoped for
in the absence of a professional mun, it is neverthe-
less of great importance to point out to the friends
of tho patient what steps may bo safely taken be-
tween the accession of the disease and the arrival of
the physician. The patient ought lo be immediately
placed in warm blankets, and surrounded with bot-
tles of hot water, bags of hot sand or salt ; end
every other means of applying di y hoot which may
be within reach, ought to bo resorted to. The whole
body ought to bo rubbed with hot flnannel, and the
belly should be covered with mustard poultices,
which should also bo applied to the calvos of tbe
legs.
" ' I have seen so littlo good to result from the
application of the hot-water bath, that, even if it
should be nt hand, I should not put a patient into it.
Ono great objection to the application of hot water
is the fatigue which it occasions the patient, besides,
that any benefit attending it is generally neutralized
by the difficulty of drying the body, or by the eva-
poration which takes place during that process,
" * Laudanum is usually to be found in overy
house, and certainly ought to be so during the pre-
valence of this disease; but the friends of the
patient must be cautions of administering it in large
doses without the sanction of a medical man. A
tea-spoonful of laudanum, added to six table-spoon
fuis of brandy, may be prepared, however; and one
table-spoonful of this mixture may be administered
in half a wine glassful of hot water every quarter of
an hour,-five drops of essence of peppermint and
ten drops of sulphuric ether being added to each
dose of the brandy and laudanum. In caso the sto-
mach reject the liquid, pills containing three groins
of camphor, and half a grain of opium inay bo
given ; and if tho irritability of iho stomach bo so
great that it rejeots all that is swallowed, a warm
glyster of arrow-root, with a tta-spoonful of lauda-
num in it, should be injected into the bowels.
'' ' As a measure of precaution, all these remedies
ought to be at hand; but in towns, of course, medi-
cal attendance will probably be obtained in time to
admit of their being applied under saaotionof a pio
fessional man.
" ' Early bleeding is of so much importance in
this disease, that, if possible, it should be resorted
to even before the arrival of the regular medical nt.
tendant of the family.. The rule is to bleed until
the blood, which is black and thin when a vein is
first opened, assumes a red and more natural colour,
and until the oppression of tho patient is relieved.
In the couise of my practice I have always found
tbat the danger is, that too small rather than too
large a quantity of blood is removed."
We may notice, moreover, that our last
accounts from the Cape show that our fel-
low-Colonists are taking the matter to heart.
" This disease," says our fellow-Journalist
of the South African, " is contagious,
rapid,-eminently fatal,-and tlie medical
profession have as yet discovered no certain
method of treatment on which they can re-
ly-much less do they pretend to have
found any specific remedy, as in the case of
intermittent fever« I
" The question for the Colonist» therefore is,
what measures should be adopted by the Govern-
ment and individuals when vessels arrive here from
infected ports'! .. . . We would strongly re-
commend the formation of aboard of health in Cape
Town without an hour's delay, and we are confident
that the good sense of the inhabitants would induce
them to adopt their suggestions-or, if compulsion
should be necessary with a few, the publio safety
would justify its use."
In the accounts from Scotland, the case of
Musselburgh is mentioned as peculiar.
Musselburgb consists of a group of four vil-
lages on the East coast of the Firth of
Forth, about six miles from Edinburgh.
The population is between five and six
thousand. It is one of the healthiest places
in Scotland, with wide streets, a beautiful
river running through its centre, and a har-
bour unconnected with the river, formed by
a double jetty or stone pier, capable of con-
taining vessels of SOO or 400 tons burden*"
Its only trade is with the Baltic for wood.
From the accounts we have perused with
regard to the extraordinary prevalence of
the cholera in this town compared with
those around, we have no doubt that it must
have been imported direct from the Baltic,
and not have been introduced along the line
of communication from Sunderland. What
confirms this idea is, that among the deaths
are those of Mr. Mitciiel, the chief wood
merchant belonging to the place, and some
members of his family. We think that the
case of Musselburgh forms a very strong
addition to the many proofs now admitted
as sufficient evidence of the contagious cha-
racter of this fell disorder. /., i
A Temperate Medical Adviser,
About three years before Swift's final decay, Dr. '
King observed he was affected by tbe wine which
he drank alter dinner, and, next day, on his com-
plaining- of hil health, he took tbe liberty to tell
him he was afraid he bad drank too muoti wine.
The Dean was startled, and replie J, that he always
looked on himself as a very temperate man, and
""' -never exceeded the quantity his physician pre«
re scribed. " Now hie physioian," continues King,
" never drank less than two bottles of claret jrfter
dinner."-King's Anecdotes of hil own Times,
newspaper: The Sydney Gazette and New South Wales Advertiser

title: Original Poetry.
content:
Original Poetry.
"England! with all thy faults I love thee still."
COWPER.
OH! who has not valued the blessings of home?
With all its endearments and ties which rest there,
And though to more favoured warm climates we
roam,
There are moments when memory owns them less
dear.
Whatever's the motive that prompts us to rove,
Tho' more envied the station the "Exile" now fills,
Yet remembrance will turn where his first early love
Was foster'd and bless'd, though on less sunny
hills.
For there's not any breathing, possessing a soul,
But they feel the link BINDS them, the farther
they roam;
So in this distant land--the extreme of the Pole--
There are times I regret the endearments of home.
Sydney, 11th August, 1830.
A. V. E.
newspaper: The Sydney Gazette and New South Wales Advertiser

title: Such is Life.
content:
Such is Life.
STRAWS ripon tho stream of timo !
. Dabbles on its ebbing wave;
? Dreaming of somo lifo sublimo,
Drifting downward to tho grave !
. Striving strongly after good,
Fainting feebly by tho way ; ?
Seeking spirit brotherhood, ,,
Sinking ever back to olny. ?
? So we oome, and so we go,
As tho passing of a breath ; ''?
Shadowy drifting with time's flow, ' i
Down tho Maïlstrom deena of death !
: / R.A.

title: The Premier and the Socialist
content:
The Premier and the Socialist
The Premier and the Socialist
.-.ere v. iiikmg liuougii liie State;
They wept to see the Savings Bank
Such funds accumulate.
'If these were only cleared away,'
They said, 'it would be great.'
'If three financial amateurs
Controlled them for a year, __ . .
Do you suppose,' the Premier said,
'That they would get them clear?'
'I think so,' said the Socialist;
'They would — or very near!'
'If we should try to raise some cash
On assets of our own,
Do you suppose,' the' Premier said,
'That we could float a loan?'
'I doubt it,' said the Socialist,
And groaned a doleful groan.
'Oh, Savings, come and walk with us!**
The Premier did entreat;
'A little walk, a little talk.
Away from Barrack-street;
My Socialistic friend will guide
Your inexperienced feet.'
'We do not think,' the Savings said,
'A Socialistic crank,
Although he chance just now to hold
A legislative rank.
Can teach experienced Banking men
The way to run a Bank.'
The Premier and the Socialist
They passed an Act or so
To take the little Savings out
And let tiiem iiave a blow.
'We'll teach the Banks,' the Premier said,
'The. way to run the show.'
'There's Tom Waddell — in Bank Finance, -
Can show them what is what.
I used to prove not long ago
His Estimates were rot.
But that— like many other things —
I've recently forgot.'
'Advances on a dried-out farm
Are what we chiefly need,
And loans to friends of M.L.A&.
Are very good, indeed.
See how the back-block Cockatoos
Are rolling up to feed.'
'But not on us,' the Savings cried,'
Falling a little flat,
'We didn't think a man like you
Would do a thing like that;
For most of us are very small, -'
And none of us are Fat.'
?This haughty tone,' the Premier said,
'Is not the proper line;
Before I'd be dictated to
My billet I'd resign!'
'How brightly,' said the Socialist,
'Those little sovereigns shine.'
The Premier and the Socialist .
They jtiad their bit .of fun;
They tried to call tie-Savings back
Bat answer cc — e there none.
Because the back-block Cockatoos
Sftd «aUa evutr *tt«» ?

title: Nature's Gentleman.
content:
Nature's Gentleman.
HE ploughs his own potato paton,
And hoos around IIÍB Indian corn,
And homestead, barn, and shod can thatch,
And yet is inly, gentleman lom.
Ho trains tho vino above his door,
And clustering rosus round his roof,
Yot husbands close his h.trvest store,
And liolps to weave the warp and woof,
Hough woven from his own flock'H fleece ;
And makes and mends his homely shorn,
And careful of his farm's increase,
Yet watcheth sun and star and moon
Amidst the watches of the night,
And tracks their gleaming path immoHse,
And inly prayeth for "more light,"
Yet humbly and with reverence.
To him, a star is as a flower !
Tho arch of Heaven ! the Earth's erroen sod !
In purpose-speak alike tho power,
And majesty, and might of God !
He earns his bread " i' th' sweat of his brow,"
And wins his way with manly toil,
And watches, with a heartfelt glow,
His crops burst through the teoming soil.
Wiso Providonco, ho feels, oaretaker
Of him and his-so long aa they
Work for no master but their Maker,
And Nature's simple laws obey.
Tho fading stars of night bohold
Him rising vigorous with tho dawn,
And reverent gazing whore the gold
Glows eastward of tho gathoring morn.
Labour iu him is dignified ;
And as ho gathers from tho soil
God's gifts, so liberally supplied,
As guerdon for all earnest toil,
He thanks the Giver for tho gift
Which he and bis together sharo,
Yet deals it forth-with generous thrift- ,
Enough for each-that all may spare
Some portion for tho weaker ono,
Who, fainting, falls amid tho strife,
Or falters ore tho day bo won,
Which crowns thc battlo-field of lifo.
" Wasto not and want not" is his rule
(Waste is ingratitude to God, ,
And servos to provo the selfish fool
Deserves adversity's stern rod) !
And thus his household, trainod to servo
Tho wants of all with deeds of love,
Perchance may find such efforts norve
Their souls to win their way above.
His wife and ohildren watoh him oomo
At even with the setting Bun,
And happy, wait to welcome home
The husband, father, friend, in one.
He ronds God's gospel as 'tis mean
(For in his household he is priest)
And teaches them the message sent
Is " morey unto man and beast,
"With love of love, and hate of hate,"
And open heart for all distress,
And sympathy with every fate,
His life is activo kindliness.
God speaks to him in every wind,
In sunshine, thunder , and tho cloud !
And Heaven's oloar oalm, he sees behind
Death's shadowy darkness, and its shroud.
And as this lifo draws near ita end,
He hopeful waits the happier time
When passed from earth-with God for friend,
HQ wakes in Heaven to life sublime.
_________ B-A'

title: FAIRY TALES ASTOUNDING.
content:
FAIRY TALES ASTOUNDING.
There are fairy tales astounding
That are harboured by adults;
That are fostered by -professors
Shrewd, of ease and comfort cults.
They are fairy tales of fear,
That still hold the mass in awe ;
Fairy tales of sheerest fiction,
With the force of unwrit law.
But these fairy tales unreal
Do not hold me in their thrall.
I am free, and would pronounce it
Loud, defiantly to all.
Now I've broke from human oxen
Who are shackled etill with fear,
I can see the herd, and hear it
Lowing, yoked to fear here.
Ah, these fairy tales astounding
Do not make me lie to men ;
But they make me want to flail them, till
They'd cast their yokes and then
I would meet men laughing happy,
Whose religion would be truth.
We would feel no yokes of falsehood
In our intellectual youth.
D.A.S.

title: XIII. AN INTELLECTUAL BELIEF.
content:
XIII.
AN INTELLECTUAL BELIEF.
Truth, in its universality, is God
In manifest operation round about :
And in so far, in our apportioned sphere,
As we evince or vindicate the Truth,
The Parent of all good, do we serve God.
And also, in so far as we endeavour
To champion or educe it, but fall short
Of our intent through thwarting circumstances
Superior to our measure of control ;
Then the mere WILL must represent the seed
To the advantage of our souls, beyond
The passage of the Grave ; and with the amount
Of actual good attained to in the Past,
Continue to advance them on their starry-march
Of infinite progression. This believing,
I must believe as well, that in so far
As we abet, perpetuate, or induce
Error, the Parent of all wrong, that just
So far we serve the Devil ;-or that principle
Which, through the Spirit of Humanity,
Opposes Truth ; and for which dereliction
From the straight purpose of benevolence,
There must in justice be some penalty
Here or Hereafter-yea, a penalty
Proportioned in its wrath to the Offence ;
And for so long as this, in its effects.
Refers to its occasion. "Wherefore VIRTUE
Is HAPPINESS;-not here? then elsewhere; through
That everlasting harmony which attests
The final fitness, as a complex whole,
Of this grand Universe of the Living God.

title: THE DREAMS OF CHILDHOOD.
content:
THE DREAMS OF CHILDHOOD.
IMMIGRANT.
Caboolture.
THE dreams of my childhood have faded for ever,
No more shall I have their sweet bliss at command.
But mourn o'er the cause that did cruelly sever.
Those charms of any fancy from bright fairy-land.
N? £** ™ too lonx, not a thought was iHsli—lns :
«L I2Hi* kbt§ ion wl»erepl«uuresmil'crooad;
And ailcat I wept o'er each new joy I foaaC
How fair dawned the moraine; how nallow'd Ua brsakuc
Katnaeiac the aenaes wita perfanM aad aoac •
las sool was iaspirM by the flicbts it was uSi.
Amoof suußj spirits I carou'd aloaf. ""
No BaooMdta of sorrow, or iawardlj pialar
E'er broke the Ulastons that peopUdaiij brain.
TwaanußßMr! aUsumnMr! thesuaarsr<Uala&
With all was I bleat tbat I sifbed to attaia. ;
Those days of » 7 childhood. atiU rwad ms are ttatiag
Their fresaaasa, aad beauty, that shines throash the
doosi; •
The iaeense they breathed ia my soal U there cujHrfag.
ABdsadwUlUbewbeaUeaaaestobloosa.
So BsaiUr how ealloos the world ia its dealing,
•"-r' — ' I*"imiti ft all Hlri a nsli Sabhsth dllnw.
Aroosiac, aad waraaiag the deadest of feeiiac,
the mlad to acliiae.
Hb who would rest must work.
Pounnu U real kindaaM kindly expressed.
▲nu faith is on* of th* boat divinities | a
good life is the beat philosophy; a *i*ar eoa>
science the best law; honesty th« only tra*
policy | and temperance the best physic
B> Obatbvvl vok Pasjt BnriCß*.—Maegill
mentions an old oun»l which h« m dm a hat
pawing th« evening of her days in plenty tad
tranquility j " for it is • human* prineipU of the
Turk*," h« adds, " th*t an old servant ought
never to be deserted when age or sickness hat
diaahled him from being anj further useful.
Here eh* lay basking in the eon's raje beeid* a
fountain, or browsing in the •hade, while the
children of the Tillage playing around her were
taught by their parent* to be grateful for pa*t
services, and to reepeet and venerate old-age."
Ra*itt o» Mm of Busman.—Bare, almost
m great poet*, are consummate men of business.
A man, to be excellent in tbie way, must not
only be variously gifud, but hu gifts ahoald be
nicely proportioned to one another. He mutt
have in a high degree that virtu* which men
have alway* found the leaet pleasant of virtue*—
prudence. Hie prudence, however, will not b*
merely of a cautious and quiescent order, but
that which, being ever actively engaged, i* more
fitly called discretion than prudence. He re
quires a great knowledge of character, with that
exquisite tact which feels unerringly the right
moment when to act. A discreet rapidity must
pervade all toe movements of his thought and
action. He must be singularly free from vanity,
and is generally found to b* an enthusiast who
has the art to conceal his enthusiasm.
Thb PHOsrHomxaoHnca or m B«4.—Every
one recognises the beauty of th* singular
phenomenon that w* call th* phosphoreseeoee
of the sea, and has watched th* track of foam
and diamond point* of light left behind as th*
steamer cute the wave. For a long time th*
cause of the shining appearance was a puxtle to
philosophers. But the naturalist* finally cam*
to the conclusion that it is produced by animal
cules which are excited to luminosity when the
water is agitated. It was also shown that th*
phosphorescence is brightest, and th* sparks
most numerous immediately preceding an at
moepherie disturbance. Thus th* littl* animal
cula must be included in th* long list of d*lieat*
organisms that feel the approach of bad weather.
Professor Deeharme observed this coincidence
and has been diligently studying the habits of
the tiny creatures and their shining propensities.
He tells us, as the result of his observations,
that they are visible in tlie daylight with a glass
magnifying about forty tunes. They are, under
this magnifying power, of a lens-shaped form,
and from seven to fifteen hundredths of an inch
in diameter. They are of a transparent natare,
more diaphanous in th* esntr* than around th*
periphery of their little bodies. The specimens
experimented on by the Professor lived in a bottle
for sever*! weeks, and beeam* verr brilliant
when the water was shaken or starved, or when
ever a small quantity of exciting fluid, alcohol
or add was introduced into it. These infini
tesimal baromters, when fully developed, attain
the sue of from two to four thousandths of an
inch.
What thi Pabuium Bat.—Th* bakers,
the butchers, the grocers, cheesemongers, fish
mongers and poulterers have sent in their annual
bills to the Parisians, and pretty ones they are.
The bakers charge for 359,964 tons of bread,
betides about 1800 tons of floor. Th* value of
this nice little lot is not specified. The butchers
are more pro is*, and, in order to show the
character of the meat consumed, we copy the
invoice: Bullocks, 175,1*2; cows, 45,678;
eilves, 143,428; sheep, 1,068,062. This is in
addition to pork, and the total is estimated
at £6,306,499. Of game and poultry, 20,730
tons are consumed, and the cost of this lot is
£1,606,588. Fish v a heavy item—2B,B9l tons,
including 1010 ton* of oyaters, the total of the
fishmongers' account being £1,179,728. The
French are fond of vegetables, as bear witness
(he following figures: Potatoes, 12,603 tons;
carrots, 41,102; turnips, 7,744 < cabbages,
40,981; leeks, 25,200; parsnips, 2,402; salad,
12,060; cucumbers and gherkins, 7,080, and
melons, 624 tons; altogether 189,798 tons. Of
butter, upwards of 20,000 tons are consumed ;
5,104 tons of cheese; and among other kick
shaws and sweet things, 570 tons of pat**, 600
tons of gingerbread, 416 tons of sugar plums,
110 tons of sweet biscuits, and 148 tons of pre
serves and preserved fruits. On the favorite
cafe, £660,000 is expended. The French are
not a tea-drinking people, the value consumed
of that beverage, which " cheers but not in
ebriates," being only £24,000, or but a 27i part
of that of coffee. About a like sum is spent on
ehoeolate; £18,000 on mustard j on pepper,
£22 354; truffles, £13,84*1 and saver kraut,
£10,080. These goodly sums are for the
stomach alone; and seeing that the Parisians
are the dressiest people in the world, what must
be the expense of belly and back together ? It
appalls one to think of it.— Scottish Farmer.
Thr Australasia*, of the 21st instant, says t
—" About seven months since, Herr Yon Grue
rard, the well known artist of this city,
sent to the Emperor of Austria, through Pro
fessor Hoclistetter, a copy of his 'Australiau
Landscapes," published by Hamel and Fergu
son, of Queen-street. Bach of the lithographs j
was tinted by the artist, so as to gire full
effect to bis original designs; and th* Em
peror was so much gratified by the work
that he signified his intention of conferring some
distinguished mark of his favor upon Herr Yon
Guerard, whose father had been court painter
to the Emperor Francis Joseph the First, while
one of his ancesrors hud received from the Duke
o( Lorraine the hereditary knighthood which
has devolved upon the artist. By the present
mail Viscount Canterbury has received the cross
of the order of Frauds Joseph from the Em- |
peror of Austria, with a request that he will
forward it to Herr Yon Ouertrd, which has
been accordingly done. It may be interesting
to mention that Professor Hochstetter made
these ' Australian Landscapes' the subject of a
paper read before the Geographical Society of
Vienna, illustrative of the physical aspects and
character of these colonies, with whtoh the pro
fessor's voysge in the Novara had made him
personally acquainted. It is satisfactory to find
that local art is thus assisting to popularise a
knowledge of Australia in central Europe, and
that Imperial honors are being bestowed upon
colonial artitU."

title: Music.
content:
Music.
SPHERE is music of sadness and
x longing
In the breaking of waves on a shore;
There is a cadence, strange and ap-
pealing.
In the soughing of winds on a moor.
There is murmur of peace and of
softness
In the falling of rose leaves apart;
There is whisper of passion and sweet-
ness
In the beating of heart! against
heart.
BERNARD ARCHER.
. Corinda. April 2. 1

title: THE SOUTHERN SEAS.
content:
T'HE SOUTHERN SEAS
BY MRS. HOWITT.
COME down, come down from the tall ship's side !
What a marvellous sight is here !
Look—purple rocks and criison trees,
Down in the deep so clear.
See ! where those shoals of dolphins go,
A glad and glorious band,
Sporting among the day-bright woods
Of a coral fairy-land.
See! on the violet sands beneath,
How the gorgeous shells do glide !
O Sea! old Sea, who yet knows half
Of thy wonders and thy pride?
Look how the sea-plants trembling float
All like a Mermaid's locks,
Waving in thread of ruby red
Over those nether rocks.
Heaving and sinking, soft and fair,
Here hyacinth—there green—
With many a stem of golden growth,
And starry flowers between.
But away ! away ! to upper day—
For monstrous shapes are here,—
Monsters of dark and wallowing bulk,
And horny eyeballs drear.
The tusked mouth, and the spiny fin,
Speckled and warted back,
The glittering swift, and the flabby slow,
Ramp through this deep sea-track
Away ! away ! to upper day,
To glance o'er the breezy brine
And see the Nautilus gladly sail,
The Flying-fish leap and shine.
But what is that?— " 'Tis land! 'tis land!
'Tis land !" the, sailors cry.
Nay!—'tis a long and narrow cloud,
Betwixt the sea and sky.
" 'Tis land! 'tis land !" they cry once more—
And now comes breathing on—
An odour of the living earth,
Such as the sea hath none.

title: THE FRACAS.
content:
THE FRACAS.
Fair as the sun e'er looked upon,
There is an isle ruled by Sir John;
Who travelled far from peat and coal,
To grasp, with both his hands, the Pole.
This sailor was a jolly soul,
But though the Pole he could not gain,
(The icebergs made his labour vain,)
When he obtained his share of fame
He got a wife--'twas all the same.
The Lady F. as you shall see,
Was rather partial to the sea,
(As every sailor's wife should be;)
And gdod Sir John to please her whim,"
(And it was very kind.of him,)
Lent'her a. ship-she could not swim.
. IY
Then off sho with the vessel darts, f
Full of the sciences and arts,
To manufacture maps and charts,
And having made a merry cruise,
And filled a book with notes and views,
I Returns again to bring the news.
Now this had all been very well,
But for the matter I must tell,
llWhich to her ladyship befel.
There was an ill-skinned Nothing-do,
Whom they called Captain Montagn,
Who in a mighty passion flew,
And vowed that ship's wer'nt made to soil,
That stem and stern in some foul gale
Would all be swallowed by a whale.
That if Sir John did let his wife
Lead such a wandering kind of life
'Twould breed betwixt them dreadful strife.
" Well," says Sir John, " a pretty pass I
And do you think me such an ass
That I can't manage my own lass?
I tell you what, 'twixt I and you,
She shall sail, Mr. Montagu ;
She shall sail, sir, and so shall you."
The captain was a clever man,
So say the folks that well can scan,
And after Lady F. lie ran.
" Now, madam, listen if you please,
I've got into a pretty breeze,
To save you from the raging seas.
Says I, ' Sir John, pray take more care;
Sir, virtuous clever wives are rare,
We can't your precious lady spare;
If you don't mind for your own sake,
My duty is to be awake;
To lose her, all our hearts would break.'
And thus for looking after you,
The knight says ' Mister Montagu
She shall sail, sir, anld you shall too.'
Now, madam, as you knew before,
I've got a pretty berth ashore,
Worth fill eight hundred pounds and more;
And if you please to speak for me,
I will your humble servant be,
For I've no wish to go to sea."
" No less, good Mister Montagu,
Could I or any lady do,
For one so very kind and true."
Off to tile knight, Sir John, she flew.
Now old Sir John lie raised his eyes,
As if examining the skies,
And looked both very nice and wise.
Says lie, "my dear, I rather think,
And why should I the matter blink,
He'd not much mind to see you sink :
And should I let you interfere,
He'll say, in truth 'tis very clear
That your advice is weighty here.
So to show Mister Montagu,
There are some things you cannot do,
Madam, I shall not yield to you."
Now if my story seems but tame,
And I confess 'tis rather lame,
The papers only are to blame,
For they are very much the same.
T. W. R.

title: Original Poetry.
content:
Original Poetry.
MY MOTHER'S PICTURE.
[Written by a Lady when very young, on an inci-
dent of early childhood].
My mother, ere my infant tongue could lisp
Thy name, I knew thy perfect semblance drawn
By painter's art; I knew and clapped my hands
For joy--then wept, and nought could quiet me,
Because those beauteous lips would press no kiss;
Those loving arms refused to clasp the warm em-
brace;
That silver voice was mute, nor with sweet song
And lullaby, would lull me soft to rest.
Poor hapless child! I little knew that grief
And bitter tears would follow riper years,
And I be left to mourn that mother's loss.
Though time has softened keener pangs, and dried
The tears of childhood, I shall ever think
On years long fled, with fond regret, and keep
Thy memory fairly graven on my heart; e'en now,
While gazing on the life-glowing canvass,
I feel the infant longing still within me,
And vainly wish those eyes could look, those lips
Could breathe the language of a mothers heart:
But thy pure spirit rests in Heaven. May I,
Like thee, by Christian faith, and well-spent life,
Receive a crown of righteousness, and join
Thy seraph voice in heavenly choir,
To chaunt the praises of a Saviour's love!
ELLEN AMERICUS.
newspaper: The Sydney Gazette and New South Wales Advertiser

title: Original and Select Poetry.
content:
TRANSLATION
OF MELEAGER'S EPITAPH ON (HIS
DAUGHTER OR WIFE) HELIODORA.
BY HENRY HALLORAN.
Oh, buried Heliodora ? o'er thy head,
My tears I pour, my tears of yearning love;
O'er thy lamented tomb sad tears I shed,
Tears, which my grief and deep affection prove.
I wretched, wretched Meleager, mourn,
Mourn thee, beloved one, soon, too soon departed:
Unprized by Acheron, and harshly torn
From me, alas, alas! half broken-hearted.
Where is my flower? By death and dust defiled,
Oh! thou supporting mother, I implore,
My much beloved one, like an orphan child,
Earth! to thy gentle bosom, clasp for evermore.

title: AUSTRALIAN WAR SONG.
content:
AUSTRALIAN WAR SONG.
By Henry KENDALL.
Men have said that ye were sleeping—
Hurl— Australians — back the lie;
Whet tbe swords you have in keeping,
Forward stand to do or die.
Hear ye not — across the ocean,
Echoes of the distant fray,
Sounds of loud and fierce commotion,
Swiftly sweeping on the way?
Hearts have woke from sluguish trances,
Woke to know their native worth;
Freedom with her train advances —
Freedom newly sprung to birth.
Despots start from thrones affrighted—
Tyrants hear the angry tread?
Where the slaves, whose prayers were slighted,
Marching — draw the sword instead.
If the men of other nations
Dash their fetters to the ground;
When the foemen seeks your stations,
Will you willing slaves be found ?
You the s0ns of hero fathers —
Sires that bled at Waterloo !
No— your indignation gathers—
To your old traditions true.
Should the cannon's iron rattle
Sound between your harbour doors,
You will rise to wage the battle
In a just and righteous cause,
Patriot flres will scorch Oppression
Should it dare to draw too near
And the tide of bold Aggression
Must be stay'd from coming here.
Look upon familiar places,
Mountain, river, hill and glade;
Look upon those beauteous faces,
Turning up to you for aid.
Think ye— in the time of danger,
When that threat'ning moment comes, —
Will ye let the heartless stranger,
Drive your kindred from their homes?
By the prayers which rise above you,
When you face him on the shore,—
By the forms of those that love you,
Greet him with the rifle's roar.
While an arm can wield a sabre,
While you yet can lift a hand,
Strike, and teach your hoslile neighbour,
This is freedom's chosen land.
Professor Henslow has been appointed to de-

younger branches of the Royal amily.

from the temple of Bacchus" (? a bar-maid), and
that they have sailed from Liverpool for
America or Australia.

title: Loaded Wains.
content:
^Loaded Wains, -
I FROM the broad fields, their golden glory shorn,
And sunny uplands of their beauty reft,
Through the still sunlight of the Autumn morn,
And hedgerows with thoir lingering jewels left,
By the brown river, through tho leafy lanes,
On to the farmsteads move the loaded wains. -
The stalwart reaper bears his brightened soythe,
Or tracks the course tho great machine has made,
And bonnie lass and lad, sunburnt and lithe,
Bound whose straw hats woodbine and poppies fade,
Wake all the meadow-land with harvest strains,
Clustering and laughing round the loaded wainB,
'Tis soft September nature's harvest yieldß,
But all through life our ripening fruit we reap,
Now storing violets from sweet April fields,
Now roses that bright July sunshine steep,
Now garnering gray October s sober gains,
Now Christmas hollies pile our loaded wains. ; . '
Ah me 1 how fast the fair Spring-flowers die,
How Summer blossoms perish at the touch,
And Hope and Love in useless sympathy,
; Weep for the Faith that gavo and lost so much !
From half our sheaves drop out the golden grains, (
Small is our portion in the loaded wains. ?
Yet, ere the mighty Reaper takes it all,
Fling out the seed and tend it rood bjr rood ;
One ear is fuh"} though hundreds round it fall, ...
One acre 'mid a mildewed upland good ;
Eternity will rear on heavenly plains ^
I The smallest treasure won from loaded wains. .] . _ .

title: THE POETS' CORNER.
content:
j THE POETS* CORKER.
In the Twilight.
In the twilight., still and shadowy,
Memories come of long ago;
Beaming eyes and furrowed faces,
Curls of gold and locks of snow. "
Happy hearts and merry, voices,
Smiles of joy and tears of woe
One by one they crossed the river,
Dear ones loved so long ago.
Ofttimes in the shadowy twilight,
Loving tones I think I hear ;
And tho sounds of well-known footsteps
Seemeth to be drawing near.
Gently, then, upon my forehead,
Rests a hand whose touch I know ;
OfL it soothed those heart-felt throbhinga
In the days of long ago.
Soon for me will come life's twilight,
When things earthly fairiter grow;
And I, too, will cross the river
With its silent, ceaseless flow. '
Maybe then I'll see the faces,
Curls of gold, and locks of snow- -
Hear the tones and merry voices
Loved so in that long ago.

title: WHEN THE WATERMELONS BLOOM.
content:
WHEN THE WATERMELONS
BLOOM.
There is joy at hut and homestead, in
the muster camps as well,
When the rain drowns out the horrors
of a dry and hungry spell.
There is joy when spring is early,
when the bush is new and spruce,
And the river holes are fuller since the
nooa gave tnem a siuice.
There is joy in far-out places when tho
mailmen's motors loom,
And a joy, somewhere near Christmas.
when, the watermelons bloom.
Where the rushing creeks backwasbinz
leave tho silt l-eds finely spread,
There the drifting seeds find harbour,
with the wide trees overhead.
And the pale green vines eoon riot in
the warm protected shade,
'Till the pink-fleshed wonders ripen, and
the musterers make a raid:
Then with waist belts quickly loosened,
oh, it's 'give us stomach room!'
What, a joyous, (gorge)ous banquet
when the watermelons bloom 1
When the chinky at the homestead
does the job for which he's paid;
Where desert is oft related to the
southern canning trade.
Where the human palate hungers in
the everlasting heat,
For a taste of something different from
the variegated meat.
There the squatter and his missus, all
his toilers — even 'Choom'
Find new joy somewhere near Christ
mas when the watermelons bloom.
When the melon vines are blooming in
the creeks and silted dams
Where life's routine is steers and
beeves, and ewes, and Iambs, and
rams.
In a world that's old and simple,
where there's little that is new;
Where the vastness and the wideness
narrows down the pleasures few,
And there's not that city tenseness,
there the little joys find room,
And there's one, somewhere near Christ
mas when the watermelons bloom.
L. A. SIGSWORTH.
Felt slippers1 are popular— mainlv be
cause thet aren't felt.

title: Faithful to the End.
content:
Faithful to the End.
(See illustration on this page.)
He watches at the sick man's side,
Still constant at the latest breath;
With love that will not be denied
To follow, and unterrified,
His footstep down the ways of death.
And we behold and question not;
So common is the wonder grown ;
How man such miracle has wrought
That to a brute's dull spirit is taught
A faith more faithful than his own.
Nor in some brute of gentle mood :
Not so; or were the marvel less;
"He watches at the sick man's side,
Still constant at the latest breath."
But in the grey breast of the wood,
Athirst for rapine and for blood,
Is risen this soul of tenderness.
Man, if thou wilt explore the cause,
Ask of the deep and of the height,
And question of eternal laws
The power that all creation draws
Through darkness to the Infinite.
In sight nor word the answer lies:
Yet, humbly listening to thine ears,
Faint as from far, may murmurs rise
Of Love's majestic harmonies,
That rule the concord of all spheres.
C.P.
The man who patented the brass spring fingers
one sees on lamps for holding the chimney in

ing to £10,000.

title: Ladies Column
content:
Ladies Column
Chit-Chat.
MRS. W.B.GRIFFITHS.
"WHAT, Ellen, yet another bill
For dress? You will not stop until
My credit is quite gone."
"Oh, do not fear," she made reply:
l dressed as well when Bingle t I
Intend to still keep on.
I know the cost; I also know
How much away on dice you throw.
Cigars, and costly wine.
*Tis woman's right to make the most
Or any charm that she can boast;
'Tte hers by right divine.
Say, did you ever know a girl
Who did not wish to be a belle,
And wear the latest style?
Or was the woman ever born
Who did not wish to deck her form,
And manly hearts beguile?
If there is such, full well I know
She is a dowdy, anyhow;
None care to win hor heart:
For, let tho men rave as they will
About our dress, we know they still
Like women to look smart.
There Is no doubt good Mother Eve
Who was so easy to deceive,
About her dress would fuss;
She cut the fig-leaves into Bhape—
I wish she'd kept the fashion-plate,
And passed it down to us—
With feather fringe she trimmed the skirt;
To out and gore she was alert;
With basque and polonaise,
Sho made the best of what she had.
We may suppose the best was bad;
But still she merits praise.
Unlucky Eve! she did not know
The grace a pull-back can bestow.
Or else wo may be sure
She would have made poor Adam stare.
Sho trimmed red rosos in her hair,
Then took a bridal tour.
I don't suppose she spent much time
On Adam s shirts to make them fine,
Because it is well known
The thoory that men profess
Is not to care a jot for dress,
But blame tho girls alone
For wasting time and hard-earned cash
To follow style and cut a dash;
And in that thought they revel.
But let tho sexes both be weighed
With even balance, I'm afraid
You'll find It pretty level."
Charters Towers.

title: THE LADS IN KHAKI.
content:
THE LADS IN KHAKI. .
TO THE IMPERIAL CONTINGENT.
We hear a voice that calls to-day,
A voice that greets you as you go,
From the drought-cursed far selection,
Or where Barwon's waters flow,
'Tis the voice of many a mother,
Sister, sweetheart, left alone,
Loving all the lads in khaki,
For the sake of one lad gone.
And to-day it swells our voices,
Deepens still the undertone,
Praying for all lads in khaki,
For the sake of one lad gone.
From the bridle tracks we hear it,
Where the shingled cottage stands,
And in fancy see a woman
Praying, with uplifted hands.
Pleading that the God of Battles
In His strength may lead them on,
Watching o'er the lads in khaki,
For the sake of one lad gone.
Women who have never seen you,
Girls to whom you are unknown,
Cheer to-day the boys in khaki,
For the love of one lad gone.
So from fern-grown Burnett ridges,
And from mountains far away,
Voices of the lone bush women,
Cheer the lads who leave to-day.
- M. BURKINSHAW.
South Brisbane, 10th May.

title: ORIGINAL POETRY.
content:
0B161I«L1»©ET«¥.
WHEN THE MOON IS ON THE
HARBOUR.
When the moon is on the harbour, take
your thrilling violin,
Open wide the latticed window, let the
Bhapes of. faeries in.
And across the isles of Bilence wandering
thoughts of mine perchance
Will touch fingers with your fancies, in the
measure of a dance.
Every thought will be gowned gaily in some
garb of star or sea
Pink of sbell or snow of blossom, £or a
royal revelry;
Shod with moonshine or with star-gleam,
jewelled on the brow and hand,
With the pearl drops of the ocean or the
gold dust of the land.
When the moon is on the harbour, should
you wield your magic bow
Far away beyond the mountains, I at least
shall wake and know.
And if others pause to listen, surely they
can never guess
How the domino is loosened to reveal the
rainbow dress.
You can make a bridge of music, Pixy feet
must footing find,
Lest they sink beneath the waters, and
leave never trace behind.
You must set tbe silver transoms, low and
tender, smooth and sweet,
So they form a shining stairway as a wel
come to their feet.
It need not be strong and martial—fairy
shoon fall very light;
ailed '
But it must be railed with moonrays, lest
they miss it in the night.
And remember, when they signal, from
the dawn, a last good-bye
That vou must not seek to stay tlieiu, for
the fairy folk are shy!
M. FORREST.

title: BY THE WAY
content:
The climate of Manchuria plays an Importa
role In the war between Russia and Japan. 1
to the present we have had but little preci
Information upon thlB point. M. J. Ross h
lately given some indications as to the clima
of that region, and the character of the d:
ferent seasons. He states that In the mont
of March and April there are. strong south-we
winds, which bring with them heat and moi
ture. At the end of March the winter sena*
ends. The under-soil is still frozen at th
time, but the ground can be worked for agi
culture. April appears to be tho only mon
of spring. At the end of thia month tl
sowing of wheat commences. Suramor begii
in May, and at the end of June or the begti
nlng of July the wheat is cut. Up to the ei
of June rain is rare, and the sky ls general
clear, while cloudy weather is an exceptio
The heat reaches a maximum at the end
July and first part of August. Afterward con
heavy rains or storms. If often rains for si
veral days and nights without stopping. Tl
soil is completely saturated, and inundations ai
frequent. September is the harvest month, whi
October gives some of the finest weather (
the year. At this time the heat is agre<
able during the day, and the sky is clear, wli
bracing air, while vegetation 1B at its heigh
At the end of the month the first night fros
begin to appear, and in November the cold wei
ther commences, and keps up until March. J
Moukden the temperature sometimes goes dow
as low as -33deg. C. During the day, hov
ever, the cold is not excessive, and aometim«
in the middle of winter the sun'a raya becore
very warm, on account of the southerly posltlc
of that locality. Tho maximum temperatui
of summer is 98.6deg or 100.4deg F. Aboi
ten months of the year are dry for the mos
part, and the excessive wet season only occui
during a month or so. At Newchwang, o
the north shore of the Gulf of Liao-tung, th
mean winter temperature is lGdeg F., and th
mean for the summer 74.8deg. The mean ar
nual temperature is 47.1deg F. The Russia
maritime provinces have a very low mean ar
nual temperature. Thus at Vladlvostock th
average for the winter ls 10.2deg F., and for th
summer it is only 3i).9deg F.

H. Stockdale: The Australian aboriginal ha
many different forms of canoe, from the prlml
tlve riding of a log at Cambridge Gulf and th
five or aix mangrove sticks, about seven or eigh
feet In length, tied or pegged together, in us
by the natives of Roebuck Bay and other place
on the nor'-west coast in Kimberley, to th
great sea-going outriggers of Cape York an
the eastern side of the Gulf of Carpentaria
These canoes, which are capable of holding an
carrying with perfect safety from twelve to flf
teen people, and even more, with all their fish
lng apparatus, etc., are in all cases made fror
the trunks of the silk-cotton tree (bombax)
When felled they are mostly hollowed out a
once, then dragged to the sea by means o
ropes made from the tough creeping plant
growing profusely around thom. Some of thes'
cottonwood canoes are ns much as from fort;
to fifty feet in length, with good width at th
stern. When brought to the edge of the wa
ter two long tough and light poles of a wooi
growing among the mangroves, about twent;
feet in length, are bound across the gunwale
about midships. The ends are secured b:
pegging and binding to another long canoe
shaped piece of light wood, with turned-u]
pointed ends. At right angles across the tw(
first laid down, long poles there are then se
cured a number of shorter and lighter polei
that form a kind of stage or platform, on whlcl
is carried much of their gear. About the centre
of this platform a large lint stone is fixed, or
which they usually keep a small tire burning
when going any distance from land. This fire
serves the double purpose of warmth and foi
cooking any game or fish that they may cap
ture. They also carry wi til them an anchor-c
large stone very securely attached to a stout
rope of twisted creepers or climbers, which are
so strong as to bo almost beyond breakage,
I have seen the natives in these big outriggers
quite fifty miles away from the nearest land,
riding with safety and apparent Indifference
over rough, high seas. These outrigger canoeis
are fitted with sails, and also are propelled dur
ing calm weather by short paddles. This kind
of canoe, not only the largest but safest of all
In use on our Australian coasts, is said to be
impossible to upset, nnd I really believe such
to be the case, otherwise splendid long distance
swimmers though the natives aro, they would
hardly leave land so far behind them.
Strange that on some of our big Inland wators
canoes are unknown, or at any rate, I never saw
them there. Take, for Instance, Cooper's Crock,
With in places Its successive broad and deep
channels, which in Hood times run milos broad,
and oven in ordinary seasons have magnificent
broad and doop watorholos, many milos in
length. I never saw any form of canoo what
ever. Two of tho finest of those waterholes,
NappamerrI and Coolyamirra, often called Inna
mincka, aro even, during tho driest of seasons,
Still milos. In longth, and broad and doop enough
to hide ñ sunken battleship. On the last
named hole perished tho lllfatod leaders of tho
Burke and Wills expedition. What makes tho
apparent absence of tho canoo tho more re
markable ls that largo trees of a kind suit
able for the making of thom aro anything
but scarco In tho immodlato vicinity.
I have Been tho native worner cross some bread
tidal waters In tho nor'-west by simply casting
therein a big lengthy log of light wo-d-one with
a fork preferred-across which they made a rude
ctage, and placed their piccaninnies, dingo pups,
and the yams and seeds they had been gathering.
Then they pushed off, holding on to the log wllth
ene hand, and swimming with their legs the
while. They set up a great noise of shouting,
laughing and splashing, to keep off "ol© man
ailllgator" (all call crocodiles alligators) "that
one plenty shout'em make 'im big one prlghten
ed." I have at times during a lengthy bush career
had to make use of aborigllnal canoes more than
once for the saving of sheep during Hood time,
when we used the ordinary bark red-gum canoe
of large size from 12ft to 15ft or lGft in length,
md supported by spreaders and little, piles of
worked clay at each end. These canoes carry
about eight or ten sheep (with their legs se
curely tied), besides the native who acted as fer
. ryman and the white man to assist in unload
ing.

In their fascinating and attractive costumes,

A Farm Public School at Hawkesbury.
Mary Salmon: The Australian Farm Public School, Hawkesbury, ls typical of dozens of small struc
tures dotted along the rivers and on the plains of the country. They are full-time or half-time, according
to the attendance. The Australian Farm School has nn enrolled attendance of 23. Of these 17 aro State
ohlldren. These portable buildln s are so constructed that they may be shifted ir there ls a falling off
In attendances, and the whole bag of tricks, Including master and forms, desks, water tank, and every
thing, can he trundled along to a more deserving neighbourhood. The facilities now afforded and thc
penalties for non-compllimce with the Education Act make the untaught child almost an Impossibility.
The cost of erection of such a farm school is just under £100, and very neat, and nice they look in the
landscape.
tien of Edén" attire, plus a towel round the
waist.
"Evil be to him who evil thinks" would bo
an appropriate rejoinder.
I do not advocate reverting to the "national
costume" of the South Sea Islanders, yet we
have something to learn from them, as their
Ideas of morality aro, in many cases, far more
"Idealistic" and "lofty" than their civilised
white brethren, and "vice," as wo call lt, ls
practically unknown to them. Our farcical laws,
dealing with "transgressors" who Cvon in a
full suit of clothes dare to bathe In tho clear
lucid waters of our harbour resorts require
urgent amendment.
We have one of the most glorious harbours
In the world, but a visitor to our shores ls
struck with the paucity of bathing facilities, nl
, though Nature has done her part in providing
choice nooks and shelving beaches that with
the small outlay of a few piles and coils of
wire netting would make Ideal bathing resorts.
Our various Governments In the past havo
squandered untold wealth over log-rolling rail
ways and other "luxuries," and neglected one
of the essential requirements of tho city and
suburbs-where nearly half of the residents of
the State reside-viz., tho orectlon of baths.

"Watllngton:" Strange of cats and dogs, that
the former, though tho more timid animals al
ways go in advance of their mistress on egg
hunting excursions in the cool of the evening,
while tho dog, her guardian, walks behind. Tho
Thomas Cat ls a quoer cuss, and no man, not
even his rightful owner, knowoth tho exact mo
ment when Thomas will pack up his swag and
clonr out. I had onco ono that mndo a spring
from tho armchair In which ho had been sleep
ing, gave ono wild look round tho room and then
darted out. I novor Baw him again till ono
tempestuous night five years after. It was ono
of tho so nights In which trees and fences and
shoots of galvanised iron and looso bricks am
algamate in their own queor wny, and the wea
ther's. I had just opened tho front door to poop .
out In order to ascertain if tho poach tree had
blown down, when in pops Tommy. Not the
least obeisance made he, not a moment stopped
or stayed he, but walked straight up to a box
that ho used to tucker out of, sniffed for, tuc-...
ker, and finding nono curled himself up on ;the
hearth and went to sleep, That's a year ago.
He may bolt again to-night.
fy fy fy fy
BABY'S ASLEEP.
(Written for this paper by Will. Carter.)
"Baby's asleep"-"The house seems still!"
"Baby's asleep"-"Thine eyelids fill!"
"Baby's asleep"-"But why that sigh?"
"Baby's at rest with the Lord on high."
There in his cot he is lying, rest;
Angels have called-the Lord knows best;
Life up the coverlet; mark the grace,
Gaze on the smile on his poor wan face.
Angels have flown with my heart's soul joy,
Leaving the mould of my lovely boy,
And these fair curls that I clipped to-day,
Are all that are left of my darling Ray.
So think not, friend, if my eyelids fill,
If the room seems hushed, if the house seems
still,
It is strange, or vain, that I sadly weep,
The Father hath hushed my babe to sleep.
fy fy fy fy
H. S. : Thero is considerable speculation UL
the present moment OB to the chances of Timor
being purchased from the Portuguese by the
Germans. Should they succeed in purchasing
it I do not think they will huve made a bar
gain that ls at all likely to be a successful ono
from a commercial point of view. Both the
towns and harbours of Koepang and Dolli are
very unhealthy places. Many visitors are
stricken down with intermittent fever within a
day or so of their landing; in fact, tho native
boys themselves have severe attacks. During
a very short visit I saw some pretty doer,
which were kept as pets by many of the Ti
morese; also some small, common-looking sorts
of monkeys; but neither tho ordinary or tree
climbing kangaroo. Thc ponies are vory much
prized, and kept domesticated, very much after
our own fashion, though at times they aro
found to have been indifferently broken, and
some nro rather vicious. There aro many very
handsome animals nmongst them, running in
height from twelve to thirteen hands. I also
saw some long-snouted, half-wild pigs, and ate
some very palatable honey. One of their prin
cipal exports ls beeswax, which is gathered
from the wild bees, which build their nests on
the under side of the top limbs of tho highest
of the low, scrubby trees they can find. The
nativo Timorese climbs up the tree, taking willi
him In his girdle a knife for chopping off
the nest. Ho also takes with him a lighted
torch, which emits a strong stream of smoke,
in climbing the tree he uses a kind of creeper
rope, holding ono end in each hand, and, placing
the soles of his bare feet against Hie trunk,
v. rlgglos his way up very much the same as
our Queensland natives climb tall trees by the
aid of the creeper which they call "kainin."
I did not think them as expert as the Austra
lian. Once up, they creep along tho limb to
wards tho nest, mid when nenr enough they so
swing tho torch ns to cause a heavyish smoko
to surround tho nest, which is often close
upon a yard in diameter. As the smoko did
not cover the man, his bare legs and arms were
soon attacked by the bees, of which be ap
peared to talco little notice, merely brushing
them steadily off tho while he was affixing a
long cord around the nest, which completed he
used ids knife or chopper to sever thc nest
from tho limb; and having first taken a turn
of the rope round thc limb, he gradually lowered
lils prizo to his friends on the ground, when
thoy oat their lill, taking home tho remainder
in buckets made from the big leaves of a kind of
fan palm. Then the wax ls extracted for sale.
Thoro is no doubt that both gold and copper
aro to bo found in Timor; but from what I could
gather, and have since learned, oxperts consi
der thore ls very little likelihood of either be
ing got In payable quantities. Travelling ls n
matter of some difficulty In Timor, nt olthor end
of lt, as tholr roads aro Indescribably bad, be
ing very llttlo bettor than narrow, rough cattle
traoks, Trees as we understand thom aro oon
Jßpiöüoüfl only by their absence Though the
il evora aro so prevalent anti aevero near these
coastal low-lying towns, the climate might bo
much more enjoyable anti healthy on the lofty
hills a little Inland, where tho soil ls re
ported to be bettor, and capable of producing
most oxcollent corn and whoat and coffee. Ti
mor ls a long, narrow Island, being about six
times as long as lt ls broad. Tho natives are
inclined to be toll, with thin, well-formed noses,
and aro not at all aggressive to Europeans, of
whom there aro a considerable number in Koe
pang, some of whom reside In well-built stone
houses. The Timorese aro a reddish-brown in
colour, and have very little hair on either faco
or breast; a few that had come down from the
Inland mountains were darker, and had thicker
and more frizzled beads or bair, and, if any
thing, lower in stature than the coast natives.
Their dress ia something like a long Scotch
plaid, and is worn twisted around the body,
the fringed ends falling to tile knees. A great
many of their houses aro oval-shaped, with the
roof coming right down to tho ground, the
doors of all being very low.

title: SWEETENING
content:
SWEETENING
We need a recipe for living,
We need another cookbook giving
The rules successfully to make
A life as well as mix a cake.
Ah, yes, with living, as with
cooking,
We need a little forward looking.
Let's study living for a while,
And with our labor mix a smile.
When life is rather tasteless, it'll
Be wise to sweeten it a little.
There's really not another thing
Life needs as much as sweetening.

title: AN ELECTION BALLAD.
content:
AN ELECTION BALLAD.
No wonder indeed, that the robbers of Sydney
Are boiling with rage from the crown to the
kidney--
To see our electors renouncing their charters,
And yielding their rights with the patience of
martyrs ;
Determined to be represented no longer,
In councils where plunder makes robbers still
stronger ;
Where government minions, and government tools,
So oft picked our pockets, then, laughed at their
fools,
And so they can still do, we cannot resist,
Our five puny delegates scarce will be missed
In such a proud conclave of graziers and lawyers ;
Where ours were the pitmen, but theirs the top
sawyers--
Where they found invention, and we supplied
labour,
To pamper our greedy tyrannical neighbour--
To fill the exchequer of Botany Bay
And hear how they voted our money away.
Before we e'er thought of electing Lord Grey,
Methinks, I can now see Sir Charlie in fits,
Commanding D. Thomson to issue new writs.
If so, kind electors despise not advice,
The Grey horse won once, if he start, he'll win
twice.
Don't venture your money on government hacks,
Let the brutes stay at home at their plentiful
racks,
Or, graze in the paddocks, unbridled, unknown,
Until they can run for a prize of our own.
But, if we must send our Hohynyms to run,
Let Perkins, the oysterman, be the first one ;
Tis thought by a number that Peter would win--
Would go up Peter Perkins, come down Peter
Finn,
Or Sir Peter perhaps, if he could once get in.
The next should be Blatherum, famed for his
force;
He could talk for a twelvemonth, and never be
hoarse.
And if it be true, as Demosthenes said,
That his gesture is half of the orators trade--
I'll warrant if once they put Joe in a rage,
He would scatter their wigs and silk gowns on
the stage.
The others, I leave you at random to choose,
You might pitch upon Foster, should Perkins
refuse.

title: ORIGINAL POETRY.
content:
ORIGINAL POETRY.
NEW YEAR.
By M. Forrest.
How the Old Year is dragging his feet!
His cloak is frayed and wet at the hem,
And his crown, that once was a diadem,
Has gone to the junk of the centuries
street;
But naked and soft and light, they pass
The feet of the New Year on the grass.
The gay balloons of the tired year
Are crinkled wrecks with all colour
flown,
And the New Year comes with his
brightly blown,
His head is high and his eyes are clear,
There are fresh rose petals for such as he,
For the Old Year—only a pot-pourri!
Yet that pot-pourri has a lingering spice,
And the dead rose petals still smell
sweet;
I shall strew some over the Old Year's
feet
As his breath grows faint and his heart
turns ice.
He shall know that one of us feels regret --
That he once was young, I shall not forget.

title: WHY NOT WINTER?
content:
WHY NOT WINTER?
By Maurine Cahill
WHY do poets always write
Of lovely spring or summer bright,
For a change just let us see
What winter brings for you and me.
Winter has its frost and snow,
But we don't care if cold winds blow,
For we can jump and skip and play,
And so keep old Jack Frost away.
Violets, wallflowers, daphne fair,
Shed soft, fragrance on the air;
And at night around the fire
Of weaving dreams we never tire.
Winter days are sunny, too.
Bright and warm for me and you;
So you see though winter's cold,
It brings joys to young and old.
Prize Card to Maurine Cahill (18), 4 Muttama
Road, Artarmon.
PRIZE CARD to Stan Rose (13), 91 North-
cote Street, Aberdare, via Cessnock.
._

title: POEMS BY CHARLES HARPUR.
content:
POEMS BY CHARLES HARPUR.
XX.
ON THE DEATH OF AN INFANT RELATIVE.
And art thou gone-so early gone ! dear Child ?
But yesterday, and thou amidst us grew
Fresh as a breeze upon the mountains wild,
Bright as a blossom bathed in morning dew :
Another day is past-and thou art found
A mouldering fragment of the common ground.
Over the threshold of thy Father's love,
A voice of gladness hath gone forth for aye !
Nor Earth again, with the wide Heaven above,
May to thy Mother's heart, as day by day
She wakens to its grief, aught seem to be
But one vast Tomb of her sweet joy in Thee.
In vain she listens-through each silent room
Thy little footsteps come not as before!
Even passing things a look of loss assume--
Thy tiny finger points at them no more!
And thus thine Image ever claspeth she
Unto the bosom of her misery.
Ah me! what purpose had thy sojourn here?
Tow'rds what did tend thy transitory bloom ?
Cam'st thou but to exact Affection's tear,
And swell the mournful trophies of the Tomb?
Or like a colour of the closing day,
Only to smile thy little Self away ?
But watchful Heaven, perhaps, looked down, to know
The Spirit of thy destiny was prone
To wreck thee where the waves of Error flow
Round Sin and Shame and Sorrow's triple throne;
And pitying, ere thine innocent blue eyes
Saw evil, snatched thee to the loving Skies.
Or thus, or not,-yet thine's a full repose;
And thine a shelter from each future storm :
The hand that crushes the disclosing rose,
Destroyeth also the engendering worm,
Giving it, so, a victory o'er the might
Of coming Tempest and inbreeding Blight.

title: THE BALLAD OF COCKATOO DOCK.
content:
IfiE MMD m
Of all the Docks upon the blue
There was ho Dock-yard, old or new, , ; .
To touch the Dock at Cockatoo.
Of all the Ministerial clan ?
There was no nicer, worthier man
Than Admiral O'Sullivan.
Of course we mean E. W.
©'Sullivan, the hero who
Controlled the Dock at Cockatoo.
To workmen he explained his views —
'You need not toil unless you choose,
Your only work is drawing screws'.'
And sometimes to their great surprise
When Votes of Censure filled the skies
He used to give them all a rise.
'What odds about a pound or two?'
Exclaimed the great E. W.
O'Sullivan at Cockatoo.
The Dock-yard Superintendent, he
Was not at all what he should be—
He sneered at all this sympathy.
So when he s;ave a man the sack
O'Sullivan got on his track,
And straightway went and fetched him back.
And with a sympathetic tear
He'd say, 'How dare you interfere,
You most misguided engineer?
'Your sordid manners please amend —
No man can cossibly offend
Who has a Member for a friend.
'With euchre, or a friendly rub,
And whisky from the nearest 'pub,'
We'll, make the' Dock-yard like a Club.
'Heave ho, my hearties, play away, j
We'll do no weary work to-day.
What odds — the public has to pay!
'And if the public should complain
I'll go to Broken Hill by train
To watch McCarthy making Tain.'
And there, with nothing else to do
No doubt the great E. W.
Wtti straightway raise M'Carthy's screw.

title: ORIGINAL POETRY.
content:
THE 'CELLO.
Long waves of grey regret on beaches lost, Or glimmering thro' the fabric of a dream
An empty boat upon a pale sea to'st,
Or, seen thro' driving mist, a lighthouse gleam:
Sand winds in pines, a pathway on a hill
Rain swept and desolate, and haunted still,
A forest without end of dark boled trees;
A fern brake, full of crouching mysteries.
Straight lines of chairs a large, slow-moving fan;
A row of footlights, and a small stout man
Drawing the echoes of old tragedies
From the brown 'cello gripped between his knees.
—M. FORREST.

title: To a Lady.
content:
To a Lady.
MARY HANNAY FOOTT.
Brisbane, 23rd July, 1896.
Not "far from Home," girl-mother,
With your first-born you bide ;
Though you hear no more the fir-woods
And the calling linns of Clyde ;
Not " far from Home," dear Lady,
Though severing seas are wide.
When misty plantain niches
Lit first with primrose flame
And amid the mossy tree-roots
Spring's frail blue hyacinths came,
The friends of other spring times,
Remembering, named your name.
When shone the summer hedges
Asnow with hawthorn bloom,
And the fragrant air was telling
Of clover and of broom,
The loving of old June-tides
Kept your old place and room.
Not " far from Home," believe us
Lady you dwell even here,
As the New Picture rises-
Gracious and sweet and clear—
None but will pray " God bless you !"
Mother and child are dear !
