title: LITERARY
content:
LITERARY
Original Poetry.
A Sheaf of Sonnets.
I.-JANUARY.
A.J. ROLFE.
Over the peaceful earth the early dawn
With tender tints breaks slowly, and the world
Again begins its toil with waking morn;
E'en as a stately ship with sails unfurled
Glides from the harbour to the seas' unrest.
Morning wears on to noontide, and the air
Is calm and still: the Sun God from his breast
Shoots down his scorching shafts on flowers fair
Till they begin to droop; but soon the sky
Is overshadowed and the mighty rain
Falls, and the thunders roar relentlessly,
But early dawn brings peacefulness again.
So after toil and trouble in this life
The "silver lining" calmly ends the strife.

title: The Opening of the Brisbane Bridge, June 15, 1874.
content:
The Opening of the Brisbane
Bridge, June 15, 1874.
RALPH DE PEVERIL.
Polly-Hymnia and Clio.
Likewise dear Miss Callio-
Pe, now let me try, O,
To hymn this famious day.
Begorra I'd give something
For power to sing a rum thing.
And without ye I'm a dumb thin;,
On thi» sillybrated day.
Och ladies, jewel aid me,
To Helioon't fountain lade me,
Than, darlins, jell bare made ate
Quite up to nii( this day.
TU of Brisbane bridge I'm singin*,
Bat it's very hard to bring in
Three line* iv due rhyme ringin'
Notwithstanding this great day.
It require* Borne whisky pouch, sir,
Even aftber the Town Hall lunch, sir,
Whore was lashins of prog to munch, sir,
To narre me for this lay.
Agfa, in George-street what a fiusther,
When the sowlt began to clusther.
And in ranks commenced to musther
In the forenoon of the day.
There were Hawneys wid their bagpipe*,
And some wore smoking " shag" pipes ;
Faith we missed the wather drag-pipes
To lay the dort this day.
For the wind it was so gay
That it set the dost to play,
As it* compliments to pay
In honor of the day.
Then the Foresters were seen
With their collars of Lincoln grata,
And their flag of silken sheen,
Marching proudly on this day.
Then came the noble Templars,
To sarve as fine exemplar*,
Faix they formed a famous sample, sin,
Of Brisbane folks this day.
The Fire-brigade, too, starred it,
And their praise you might have " hard " H,
With some good jokes interlarded,
Aatong the crowd this day.
But the Vabanteers—och, bother,
Bs me sowl it makes me smother,
To think upon their pother
On this glorious f estial day.
Their jumping and their rnnnin',
Their screeching and their funnin'.
(BtjabanH was ■tannin')
Bound the Uuv'nor's trap thk aw/.
And their qnare parade did crown aIL
Jist afore our spkndid Town Hall,
But their pride recaved a downfall
From the Larrikins this day.
For the great Unwashed keptehanUg,
At our martial harow laughing,
While the mobs iiuide were quaffing,
Well—not wather, by-the-way.
But to oome back to my tale,
" Uorporations" stout and hale,
Boldly faced the dusty gal*
On this highly Cavond day.
Bays a aoorner, " this procession'
Is simply the precession
Of the equine-ox-ial fashion"—
A purty thing to say !
Now, there bad been a dispute,
(By some scoffer set on footX
What sort of dress would suit -
To walk in, this great day ?
Then out the soorner dashes,
Whh " In sackcloth and ashes.
Or ia emblematic katkts
Ye should open the bridge this day 1"
" I don't mean to upbraid, Sirs,
Bat aueh hashes ye hare mad*, Sirs,
That it must bar* been your trade. Sirs,
To keep back the opening day."
Well, the luncheon was a " One-er,"
And the wine it was a stunner,
While each bombardier and gunner
Kept thundering away.
And when all were full as leeches,
Och! the party " dinner speeches "
Were recayred with lovely screeches
Of applause ou this graad day.
But the speechifying sport
Ends abruptly (see report),
For the Guvnor cats it short.
In the middle of the play.
Bays the Marquis of Xoruurwoy,
" My promise 1 mtut stan' by,
1 hope I shant offend by
Sloping right slick away." .
Than, rising from his chair,
lie walk'd iutue the air,
While that Tilisml mutf, our Mar*,
With the Marquis cleared sway.
Bad scran to that same Mare,
Was our strong " inverted prayer."
Why the (something) leave the chair
Upon this jovial day?
Why the wine is not half drunk,
Yet the erayture off has slunk.
Troth, he's nothin but a skunk.
Is our chairman, this; gnat day.
Amh ! many a fine oration,
Aftertadjous incubation,
Has rvcayved ■— it instiow
Ere its birth, on thk ski a»y.
Thus, the party was shut up,
Afther tasting but a sup
From the tantalising cup,
Oathisdtaippoiatiag day.
And when the gath'rin' broke up,
The Valiantosts aaaa woke up,
And their aoble eapiiag spake up—
" Htorat the fsrt, my teas ! heoxay r
Then the galliant ValiaataMa,
Like the British Oraany-dean,
WUfc hearty Aaward) ehsers
Storat'd the banqaet-roaaa that day.
Lard! aaah hay«« than they aMd*,
And a* fariaasly they prey**.
That, suaaMiitur-Mke (/tut said),
Tbeyll not fast for many a day.
Well now it's time, I wsea.
Taataa* thb fsstial seta*.
And a» "ttaa amve the <J«aea"
Kads fittingly my lay.

title: Dame Durden's Post Office.
content:
Dame Burden's Post Office.
Dame Durden "will be pleased to receive letters
every week on various subjects from the young
readers of the TOWN AND COUNTBY JOUBNAL.
They may have pets she would like to hear about,
have seen places or sights of interest, had harrow
escapes from injury, or been nearly lost. They
can tell their own hobbies and amusements, anec-
dotes of animals-anything that they think may
he interesting to their fellow-readers.
Letters must be neatly written, and must hoar
the name and age pf writer, who must not be
more than 18. The envelope must be addressed,
Dame Durden's Post Office,
TOWN AND COUNTBY JOUBNAL Office, .,
Market-street.
This is the last publication for letters received
in last month's competition. Next week the
space must be given to the new letters, of which
there are piles waiting to see the glory of print.
To get through these present ones in many cases
only a line or two can be given, so the writers
will understand.
"X May Ashmore .(Galathera) writes about her
pets. She has a dear little butcher bird that whistles
and a dear little piebald pony that is not broken yet.
Jessie Jamieson (Macleay Heads) has a
oat named Lucy, a bantam, three little chickens and
a native curlew. Her father, she says, is a pilot and
she has two brothers and two gardens.
A. W. Snipe writes an interesting letter about
Newcastle, the coal pits and coal trains, and about
Belmont, which is a pretty watering place where great
crowds go on holidays camping, shooting and fishing.
Edith Parr (Kenthurst) tells of a Behool pic-
nic they had to Berowra, how they went for a row and
then paddled, how she lost her shoes and stockings
and a search party went to look for them, and how
they were at last discovered under a rook.
Alma Purtell (Germanton) has three poddy
lambs and one of them will born you, and four pretty
little canaries and one of them died the other day ;
and two parrots and one of them can sing, and two
tame magpies and one built a nest in an old box and
laid two eggs and brought out a young one, and one
cold night she left it and it came into the house to
roost and it died.
Lizzie Merrick (Redfern) says it has not
been a very nice day, for it has not stopped raining
very long together. She won a prize at school, which
is called " Little Fishers and Their Nets."
Ruby Whittaker writes oï a pleasant day they
all had at their grandma's at Auburn.
Clara Parsons (Singleton) takes up a pen to
write a few lines. She came to Sydney onoe, and
thinks it ÍB a very big place, but very dangerous for a
stranger on account of the many cabs, trams, and
'buses, for if yon don't be careful you. may be
knocked down ana trampled on before you know
where you are.
Mary Arber writes to say she lives at Oakey
Forest, near Bowenfels, and likes reading the TOWN
AND COUNTRY and doing the competitions.
Jane Chant (Wombat) has had .;a trio to
Sydney, and visited the Zoological Gardens and other
places, and had lots of fun, ? ; , : '. ?'
Ada May Jones (lïyngan-road) writes on
both sides of the paper. Perhaps she and others are
shortsighted, and the rules in too small print. She
says they have a nice orchard and vineyard, and a
number of pets-a parrot that follows her wherever
she goes, a little mallee hen, and a Shetland pony.
She and her brother go but rabbit-coursing, and have
six dogs.
George Bourke (Oakhurst Farm, near
Canowindra) writes a nice little letter, but is
afraid Dame Durden will think (since he is ll) it.
I ought to be better; but he has always_ lived far away
from schools, and bèen very delicate. He "and his
i sister ride four miles now every day to Behool, and
I wish they could attend more regularly.
Arthur Walker (Weldborough, Tas-
mania) says the place where he lives is very Bmall,
consisting of 150 Europeans and 100 Chinamen. - It
has been a good mining district, and stands on the
River Weld.
Laidley Grainger (Singleton) has a very nice
calf at home. He has only been to Sydney once, and
he likes reading. v -
Ada Whittaker (Marrickville) writes of a
pantomime she has been to see. She is going to live
at Auburn presently, and hopes to have more uéws ;
and she is learning music, and thinks it very nice to
be able to play when there is company.
Lilian Winter (Lismore) describes the publio
buildings in her town. .
Elizabeth Woodby (Newbridge) tells of the
occupations of the people at Newbridge, and describes
the fruit in her garden. . " ..
May Potter (Taralga) says there are -four
hotels, three stores, one post office, and two fruit
shops in that town. Also_ there was a band of hope
last month, and she recited a piece called " The
Disobedient Mouse."
Linda Burrows (Penrith) speaks of the show,
just over. She got a special prize for a smoking cap,
and a joint second prize for other needlework.
Frank Stenz (Paradise Valley, Kangaroo
Camp) likes going to school very much, but does not
like the walk there, which is two and a half miles.
Also he has an objection to the cane.
Agnes Lugdon (Cootamundra), Florrie Pot-
ter (Werris Creek), Maudie Luckie (Bundulla), Edith
Cummings (River View) all send nice little letters
about pet3 or tho places where they live. ,
-Christopher M'Callum (Coldstream)-says
they are milking 37 cows for the factory, and he feeds
the calves night and morning.
Cecil Green (Surry Hills) describes a trip to
Manly and another to Bondi;
Evelyn Cubis (Coolabah) is 10 years old, and;
walk six miles to sohool every day. For pets she
has two kids, a ca*, and a dog called Topsyi . .
Sophia Wood (Balladoran, Dubbo-road)
bas no dolls, but owns a oat and a dog. She has
never been to Sydney yet, but would like to go.
Mary Oorrin (Sunnyside, Tenterfield) has
a little pet calf, white, with red ears. She goos to
sohool everyday where there is a garden. The pupils
have to keep in order.
Mary Drake (Pocolbin) writes a long letter
too long-but full of interest. She describes her life
from the time she came from England, and tells of
two narrow esoapes from drowning.
Lilly B. (East Kangaloon) also was born in
England. She is very fond of reading and gardening.
Edward Cubis (Coolabah), Septimus Mar
timer (Yarra Mundi), Edith Whitaker (Marrick-
ville), Mary Little (Coolabah), Bernie Owen (Ter-
meil), Thomas Elliot (Grangbalang), Isabel Gamble
(Leadville), Violet Wunsch (Peak Hill), Charlie Kuhl
(Gunnedah), H. M. Turner (Tambar Springs),"'all
send interesting letters, but there is no- room to pub-
lish them..
: Clyde River, Nelligen.
Dear Dame Durden,-The little town ' in " which,
I live .is situated on the right ' hand bank of
the Clyde River, about 10 miles from ."Bateman's
Bay. It has a population of about 400 people,
whose chief support is the timber industry..
The new gold find near Brooman has oaused great' ex
ment, and numbers of workmen are daily .passing
through to the rush. I hope that/the report of the
gold find will prove correct, as it will give employ-
ment to numbers of poor people who are at present
wandering about in searoh of work. Our home is
situated on a hill, and commands a finé view? of the'
river, which is about 50 yardß distant. Tho' chief
sport ia boating and fishing, as many fine schnapper
and bream, as well as other fish, may bo caught in- the
proper season. There are many varieties of Btag
hornB and tree ferns growing about Nelligen, as '.well
as the cabbage-tree palm, which is very pretty.-.
Yours truly, ARTHUB1 CLARKE.
Wantabadgery.
Dear Dame ? Durden,-We hate a lagoon close to
our'door, and the Murrumbidgee River is only a'short
distance away. We have a little cow. She is such a
quiet little thing, she will let us milk her anywhere,
I have got three brothers and two sisters, but ! am
the oldest. My eldest brother has a little Timor,
pony, and it has a foal. We live out in the country.
We have no neighbor nearer than two miles away, rso
it is very lonely living here. We had a parrot;.it
had only a few feathers on it. It could not fly much,'
and it would not eat, and then it died. We have got
a boat, and we^ go for a row sometimes.-I remain,
your sincere friend, .. r'\
IDA JORDAN'
(Age 13 years)..
Wollombi.
Dear Dame Durden,-I am very sorry to say that
everyones crops is gone, and it -washed everyone of
the poor Chinaman vegatable away. And the quinces
are nearly ripe. And there was a lot of peabhes this
year, and there was a lot of figs this ye&r. Andi
have got a brother he is.14 years old, and I am only
IO years old. And there is a lot of melons this year.
And there is not much work to be got. And there was
a lot of grapes this year, and there was a lot of apples
this year. And Uncle Pinchen lost all his sagrnm,
this year, and he has nearly lost all his corn, and he
has a large family. Ho has got ll children. And
my name is Jane Efford, and my brother's name is
Charlie Efford.
(I would rather have a letter like this, where
conjunctions flourish, than one that shows grown-up
help.)
Martindale.
Dear Dame Durden,-Having seen that you have
offered a prize for the the best letter writton by a
child, I thought I would have a try for it. I live in
the country, eight miles from the town of Denman,
which is situated on the banks of the Hunter River.
The town consista of two hotels, post and telegraph
office, and a publio school. My father has .been taking:
the TOWN AND COUNTRY JOURNAL for over 20 years.
I like reading the children's corner very much. It is
very kind of you to put them in. I won't trouble you
with any more this time: I will write and tell you all
about our pets if you wish it.-I remain yours truly,
is. . . ALBERT WOODHOUSB
'- (Aged 12 years).
Pearce's Creek.
Dear Dame Durden,-I am very pleased to write to
you. We live on the. Richmond River. Havë you
ever been there ? The scrub is very thick, and vineB
growing from one tree.to another. We had a native
bear, but it died, and we.have.a cockatoo! We hada
nice sohool picnic I got a prize called " Esther Reid
Yet Speaking." We had racing ; I got a doll. There
was a Christmas tree, and it had a lot of bags tied ou
it; they had togo blind-folded and poke with a big.
stick. I poked a potatob, and then a tin money-box.
A girl there got a green frog. I am in the third class
at sohool. We are having very wet weather just now.
I would like to get the prize, but this is my first
letter.-I remain, yours truly, . ? ; .
- ALICE BUBTÖN
(Aged 9 years).
Bradley-street, Goulburn./
i Dear Dame Durden,-I live in Goulburn ; it-is a
i larga city. There are very pretty hills ' round it ;
I they are called Governor's Hill and the'Rocky. Hill.'
They are" parts of the Cularin Range. There "are
several nice narks in Goulburn, but the prettiest one
is Belmore Square. There areJalways'plenty of chil-
dren playing in it. Auburn-street is the business
street in Goulburn. Our show is this week ; it is on
the 15th and 16th; all the schools go in free. It is
raining now, and it looks as if it is going to be wet
for the show. It will disappoint a good few people.
I am 9 years old, and I am in upper third in the big
sohool.-I remain, yours truly,
FLORRIE SALMON.
. Beresford, Cathcart.
Dear Dame Durden,-As this is the first letter I
have written to- you, I hope that you will enjoy
reading it. I will giveyou an account of our harvest-
ing this year. I am sure you would like what tho re-
sult is here. It has been a very wet season ; it has
rained frequently since Christmas, and has therefore
greatly interfered with the crops, to such -an extent
¡ that they have been destroyed. But this is not the ease
everywhere. Some were enabled to get their crops in
betweenrainy days. I believe that those who were BO
fortunate will have a very fair return. I am sorry that
there was so much rain and. BO many crops were
spoiled. The reapers first ont the wheat or oats with
a sickle and make sheaves of it, then make stooks of
the sheaves ; they then cart it in to a shed or make a
stack bf it. The threshing-machine comes round and
threshes the grain ont of the heads ; what is left is
called straw. The grain is next sent to the flour mill
and is gronnd into flour.-I remain, yours truly,
- -'- - - - C. HAMMOND -
, : ' : . - (Aged 10 yeare).
(instead of a letter, W. H. Christie sendB a poem,)
ANOTHER WORD FOR THE OLD FLAG. ;
Exalt the Union Jaok on high,
And from the mainmast let it fly,
. For all our foemen we defy
" To stay its gallant streaming. ,,
Triumphant did its colors play .
Within Trafalgar's fated hay,
When, joining in the awful fray,
Unnumbered guns wore gleaming.
It bids its brave defenders meet ;
Death, rather than from foes retreat,
And binds thom as a winding sheet
lu their eternal dreaming.
God grant that it may ever wave
An emblem of the true and brave,
And provo unto the serf and slave
A star of freedom beaming.
W. H. CHRISTIE
.. : '? . (Aged 17 years).
, ; , Wilberforce.
Dear Dame Durden,-I-live in Wilberforce, a vory
small township and very quiet. There is one laker,
twp butohers, two stores, and ; one constable, andi
would hq glad if I could get out of-ic. I have four
(sisters and two brothers. My father is a farmer.
My oldest sister is married, and has one son.
I My other sisters are beautiful-looking girls. My
I greatest delight is in riding and driving. I am very
restless, and like going about a good deal. - We have
a very large house and garden. Tho peopla about aro
very "kind. Trusting this will meet your^wishos,-I
remain, your sincere friend,
"VIOLET ADELINE CORFIELD.
Ingleburn.
Dear Darno Durden,-This is tho first time 1 have
ventured to write to you, but I hope it wilFnöt bethe
last. I read your letters every week, and think they
are very interesting, so I hope to eoe my own among
them next week. I'm afraid mine will not bo a very
interesting one though, as I have only a magpie to
tell you about. Ho is-very young, and is learning to
speak splendidly, his only fault is, ho is too fond of
fighting, and that gets him into great trouble with tho
fowls.'-With kind regards, T am, your sincero friend,
MAIBEN COLLINS
; (Aged 13 years).
Tamba Telegraph Office.
Dear Dame Durden,-1 do not suppose you over
thought of visiting the. Clarence River ; if you did, I
do not think you would be disappointed, for it is very
pretty to go up the river in the steamers, and seo all
along the bank nice green corn and sugarcane grow-
ing. The last two weeks it was raining nearly every
day, and to-day it is fine and very hot. I am 15 years
of age, but not very tall. I have three sisters and
four brothers, some are older and some are younger
than myself. I of ten go along the Bonthern beach
and gather shellsj' and also go in bathing in tho sea.
I hope my letter will please yon.-I am, yours
sincerely, ^ FLORENCE PEGUS.
Bundaberg, Queensland.
Dear Dame Durden,-I suppose you have novor
been to Bundaberg. ldc not think you would be
disappointed with it. The town is just recovering
'from the effectB of last year's floods. ' They were tho
largest we ever had. They did a great deal of
damage to the town, and the remains of dead trees
and bushes can still be seen on tho banka of the river.
The country is beginning to look very green after the
rain.. It has been raining very hard this week, but I
hope we will not have a flood. The town is surrounded
with sugar - plantations, many of which can bo seen
from the town. We live on the bank of the river,
and we get all the breezes from the river. Tho only
pet I have is a magpie, and he whistles and talks very
well.-I am, yours sincerely,
JANIE JOHNSTON
(Aged 14).
South Arm, Bowraville, Nambucca Eiver.
Dear Dame Durden,-l am going to write a^out
the farms in general about here. They aro very
heavily timbered ; in placee where the undergrowth is
not so thick the ground is covered with coarse gras3.
The principal' product is maize, most peoplo only
growing enough vegetables for their own use. Most
of them have about five br six cows, and rear all the
calves. A dairy factory is in course of construction
at Bowraville., The farmers generally keep.about 20
pigs. There has been a flood again this year on the
Nambucca Eiver, and it did a considerable amount of
damage.-I remain, yours truly, ,. s >,
. MINNIE LOUISA ÍLAUN
(Aged 13 years).
Coomber.
Dear Dame Durden,-I am going to try to win the
prize you offer. I am 10 years of age. I go to school,
and I am in the third class. I have three sisters and
three brothers, and three of them go to school besides
myself. There are fine mountains about here. It is
a grand sight to watch the wallabies coming down
from the mountains in the evening after sunset, but
they are very destructive to the garden. We have
two hordes, one called Prince and the other called
(Nugget. Hoping my letter will please you,-Yours
sincerely, 1 LOUISA VINCENT.
- - . Coolabah.
J Dear Darno Durden,-I have seen in your column
many letters written by.ohildren competing for your
prize, w.ho live in nioe towna, but I am not so fortunate
as they arei I live in the bush, my father is a con-
tractor of fencing, so I nave plenty of moving about
from ono placebo another, and plenty of amusements,
sometimes fishing in the Bogan Eiver and also hunt-
ing rabbits with my brothers (for I have four), and
we hayo Buch fun; May I write to you again ?
Hoping this will meet with your satisfaction-I re«
main, yours truly, EMILY TUBNER
,(Aged 13 years).
Dungog.
Dear Dame Durden,-I am going to try for the
prize you offer. I am 10 years of age; I am very
short and stont. I have one brother and three sisters.
I am the youngest, and the baby of the family. I
have some dear little pots which I am going to tell
you about. I have three little kittens ; I have one
little pet chicken. I had two, and the mother of the
kittens^ ate one. She is very fond of carrying off
our neighbors' young chickens and ducks. ."-Mother
vows vengeance on the cat, but I cannot hear ofcher
being hurt. I have a rosella parrot; he is veryvoung
and he talks beautiful ; when he sees anyone coming
with his food he hops round the cage as fast as be
can go. I have a pet canary which sings beautiful.
I have a pet terrier dog ; I am teaching it-to jump.
It can jump as high as my head now. I wondecif
you have ever had a letter from any little girl in
Dungog before. It is a very pretty place, 'the- hills
are .very beautiful and green. I love to run'-afid-io
gather ferns with my pet dog.-I remainVyouri tínifi
MART JBRÓOKSÉÍ ..?

title: O HEART OF SPRING!
content:
O HEART OF SPRING!
[By Shaw Neilson.]
O Heart of Spring!
Spirit, of light and love and joyous day,
So soon to iaint beneath the fiery summer;
Still smiles the earth, eager for thee alwayj
Welcome thou -art, so ever short ihy stay,
Thou hold, thou blithe newcomer!
Whither, oh whither this thy journeying,
' O .Heart of Spring!
O- Heart of Spring !
After the stormy days of Winter's reigD,
JYhen trie keen winds their last lament are sigh
ing, . 1 ? '
The fun shall raise thce up to life again.
In thy'' dim death thou snaJt not suffer pain; '
Surely thou dost not fear this quiet dying?
Whither, or whither this thy journeying,
O Heart of Spring!
' O Heart of Spring!
Youth's emblem, ancient as unchanging light,
Uncomprehcnced, unconsomed, still burning;
Oh, that we could, as thec, rise from the night
To find a -world of blossoms lilac-white,
And long-winged swallows unafraid returning—
Whither, oh whither this 'thy journeying,
O. Heart of Spring!

title: THE DERBY GOLDFIELD.
content:
THE DERBY GOLDFIELD.
* ?
[Bt DiooKa.1
Gold is now tie only theme,
Of nothing etae the people dream,
Botn young and oil distracted seem
About tie Derby Goldfield.
Excitement everywhere prevails,
Folks anxiously await tie mails,
Or liBt to all the new details
About the Derby Goldfield.
For Gold is now the only cry,
r m selling off my boys, good bye !
I mean to get some gold, or die
Upon tie Derby Goldfield.
Steamboats nailing everyday
Bring crowds of diggers ou their way.
Who mean to try their luck, they say.
Upon tie Derby Goldfield.
Bakers go to sell their bread,
For diggers they know must be fed.
The two-pound loafs a crown 'tis said.
Upon the Derby Goldfield.
The butcher, too, is in his glee,
A fortune's to be made, says be,
For beefs four bob a pound, yon see,
Upon tie Derby Goldfield.
The merchant, too, makes up his mind
That he must not remain behind,
For tea's six bob a pound, we find,
Upon the Derby Galdneld.
The banker takes bis scales and weights,
With his colleagues diBrnmeB rates
At which to buy from Bill and mates,
Their dust at Derby Goldfield.
The lawyer packs up wig and gown
And joins the throng with Doctor Brown,
The parson, too, gives up his gown.
And off to Derby Goldfield.
The snob packs up his tools and last.
And thinks he'll tiere make money fast,
For diggers wear tie leather fast
Upon the Derby Goldfield.
The sailor, too, his goose and shears
Packs up, and on the road now steers,
For pants are in demand, he hears,
Upon the Derby Goldfield.
The tinker sailor, shepherd, cook,
Have tinware, ship, sheep, pots forsook,
Clerks, too. throw coirn their pen and book,
And rush to Derby Goldfield.
Think not the publican's forgot,
He'U make the largest pile, I wot,
Nor care forups-and-downs, one jot,
He meets ou Derby Goldfield.
Policemen have been sent in bands,
To guard the gold from lawless hwds,
And see tiat orders just demands
Axe kept on Derby Goldfield.
Where is this fever going to end ?
Lots will lose yoa may depend,
And wish. Old Nick to Hades may send
The gold from Derby Galdfield.
There some would follow, I believe,
The thirst for gold, one can't conceive.
And if that feat they could achieve,
Would still rush to the Goldfield.
' The Gully,' October l.

title: The Flying Dutchman.
content:
The Flying Dutchman.
The night ia dark, the storm is high,
The foaming billows lash the Bky ;
But boldly, though with shattor'd sail,
The gallant vessel breasts the gale.
Nine weeks the winda have held her here,
Nine weeks the Btorms have barr'd her oonrae}
Yet still, aB if she knew no fear,
She battles with the tempest's foroe.
Do what men will, do what men may,
She'll never oroas yon angry bay,
Thongh there she taok till Judgment Day.
Poal npon peal the thunders oraBh'd,
Bright overhead the lightnings flash'd:
And, seen by glimpses, dark and dread,
The frowning Cape still lower'd ahead.
But evon as wilder grew the Bky,
And louder still the breakers tossf;
Bold Vanderdeoken shouted high
" By God, and by tho Blessed Cross,
Lot come what will, lot como what may, ? Ia»
We'll round yon poak, wo'll oroas yon bay,
Though horo we taok till Judgment Day J "
Still, still the waters roar beneath ;
The sky above is blaok os death,
Till forth the awful lightnings leap,
To show tho terrors of tho deep.
Long yoars have pass'd ; but here alone . i
No ohangoB oomo, but Time doth wait ; <
While oontnrios have oome and gone,
The Flying Dutohman droes his fate. '
Let como what will, let oome what may, . ¡ '
He'll nevor oross yon awful bay ;
But thoro he'll taok till Judgment Day.

title: Facts and Fancies.
content:
Facts and Fancies.
MR. KENNEDY'S INVITATION TO DALBY.
DALBYITE!
THE EMBODIMENT OF DALBY OPINION ON THE SUBJECT.
Is Kennedy comin'! says Sauners to Jack;
He'll hardly be thinkin't worth while I expock.
To hear him tell stories and lilt a bit sang,
The folk aboot Dalby are a' thlnkin lang.
W; Wm a heartenin' gin be wllleome tew;
We 11 count it obleegin' gin he will ca' roon.
We're fldgin' to hear o' •' The Lan o' the Leal"
How Auld Eobin Gray " an* the « Laird o' Oookoen "
Were charmea wi' "Sweet Jeuie the Flower o^Dum.
blane.
We're maUUy forgot aboot" Watty an* Meg,"
Aa' the " Auld Gudeman at E'en " wunnemi' slot
We'd fain be remin'et o' flddlin Nell Qow,
An' o' Burn*' crabblt " Wife wi' tUe weary pun' tow."
If muiic has charms that will soothe the wild brtaat.
We're as muckle in need o't as ony o' the rest;
Here the white savage reigned at a gey reuent date,
An* we're hardly reclaim't frae oor barbarous state.
The Bcotts. men an' women are a' in a swither
Aboot the socht sicht o' their musical brither,
They're fley't 'cause they hear that he's nae comia doOßa
An' they'd think it a bius disgrace to the toon.
John. Patrick, an' Banners, they tow gin he'll ca*
They'll fill the new biggin' commodious an' braw;
I hae but a sovereign, I'll brak it in twa.
An' gie him the half o't ere he gang awa.
Gin ony ane spier, by whilk name or wbilk rif ht
These precedin' lines I hare dared to indite.
My answer is, Wha has mair claim to invite
Than a caUant that styles hlmsel' the
To avoid oorpulenoe—Quit eating.
Whin a young lady gives herself away, doM.
she loose her self-possession.
Whkn is a man like a tea-kettle juit on th*)
boil P—When he's going to sing.
Why is ooffdo like an axe with a dull edge.P~
Because it must be ground before it is used.
It is rather odd that when a street ii to be
widened a contractor is engaged to do it.
" Iv all the world were blind," said an Irish
politician, " what a melancholy sight it would
be!"
When deaf mutes are married, two members
of the wedding party are sure to be unspeakably
happy.
What comes once in a minute, twioe in ft
moment, and but onoe in a man's life P—The
letter M.
Why is a ballet dancer a most inhuman
creature P—Because her greatest delight it to
execute her grand pat.
Thb man who comes on a stage exaotly at
his oue is prompt t but the man who does not
I come on at all is prompter.
Melancholy Huigidb.—A young lady, on
being asked by her lover if she'd be his, and hie
only, hung—her head.
A tovxg woman, being asked by a politician
whioh party she was most in favor of, replied
that she preferred a wedding party.
A K£W paper starts with the announcement t
" In religion we are conservative, and we intend
to adhere rigorously to the cash system."
" The verb 'to love,'" says a wicked French
writer, "is an active verb, whioh runs until it
sinks exhausted into the easy chair of marriage."
" Whihb are you going to P" asked a little
boy of another, who had slipped-on an ice
pavement. " Going to get up!' was the blunt
reply.
Qucby.—What kind of oattle do they have
in the North ? A man there advertises that he
" wants a woman to wash, iron, and milk one
or two cows."
Tet it.—" What's the use in these days of
trying to be honest P" exolaimed a grumbler.
" Oh, you ought to try it onoe, and see," re
torted one of his companions.
Iv a debating sooiety in the backwoods the
last question up for discussion was, " Should •
young man quit his music lesson to split wood
when his mother is at home in robust health t" '
An Absubd Requirement.—A shoemaker
with one eye complained that one of his lamps
did not burn. An Irish shopmats with astonish*
ment exolaimed: " Faith, and what de you
want with two lamps ? Ye have but one eye."
A Yohkbhibb woman was recently bereft of
the faculty of speech by being hit by a snow
ball, and many married men in that part qf the
country have been heard to remark that, after
all, winter has advantages cot afforded by any
other season.
Sights and Sounds or Cities.—Paris comes
with a ?heerful flash of light, a sudden multi*
tudinous chorus. The paved streets rattle, the
voices chatter, the note is not so deep as the
hollow London echo that we all know, that slow
chord of a great city.
At a party, Smith, the funny man, pioked
from the floor some false hair, and, holding it
aloft, wickedly asked who had lost it. Impul
sively the hand of every lady within earshot
went to her back hair. It was cruel po throw
them off their guard and expose them so, but
Smith says it w.un't his fault.
Pbopbb Quotation.—" I should like," said a
French medical charlatan, "to place over the
door of my surgery an inscription, either in
Latin or Greek, borrowed from one of the great
authors." " Giro Italian the preference, re*
marked one of his patients ; " nothing oaa equal
that verse of Dante's, ' Abandon hope, all ye
who enter here.'"
Prevention Bettbb than Cvbi.—Remem
ber that a new egg will oure your throat of fish*
bones. Put one in a little hot wine, and some
sugar, and the fishbones will slip down all the
easier. P.B.—You can take the egg, wine, and
sugar anyhow. They are good as a preventive |
and you dou't know at what moment you may
get a fishbone in your throat.
Faub.—" Mr Speaker," exolaimed a member
of a Colonial Legi»lature, " my colleague taunts
me with a desire for fame I scorn the imputa
tion, sir. Fame, sir! What is fameP It is
shaved pig, with a greased tail, whioh slips
through the hand* of thousands, and then is
accidentally caught by some lucky fellow that
happens to hold on to it. / let the greased-tail
quadruped go by me without an effort to clutch
it, sir!"
How they Do it.—Tho following oonvers a
tion between two clever lawyers was over
heard :—" flow does your client like it t"
" Not very muoh ; be begins to complain of the
expense." " Mine is all right, bound to fight
it out. Can we manage to get the jury to
disagree again P" " Dan't know; we must
work for it." " You get beat, of course, in the
end; but you'll appeal, of course P" "Of
course."
One of the humoristto papers of Paris re*
lates the following :—" Monsieur X—— was
comfortably sleeping and snoring in an orchestra
stall at a theatre, which it is needless to name.
The ocoupant of the adjoining seat, losing all
patience, proceeded to awaken him. ' toinoo
when,' asked X——, rubbing his eyes, 'is it
forbidden to sleep at M 's pieces P' • But
you make too much noise.' ' I prevent you
perhaps from hearing the play ?' <On 'the
contrary, you hinder me from sleeping, and
force me to hear it; that is what I oomplain
of.'"
Thb late Lord — was decorating one of
his country mansions, and was having the
central hall door either painted or tesselated.
A young man, tall and powerful, was at work
on one of the walls, when the Earl ordered a
number of slippers to be placed on the door*
mat, desiring this young man to order anyone
that came in to put on a puir before crossing
the passage, and added to tho order, "If any
body does not do it, you must tuke him by the
shoulder, and turn him out." Soon after a
hunting party pa**ed, and the late Duke of
Wellington, with his splashed boote, opened the
door and rushed along the hall. The young
man immediately jumped on" the ladder on
which he was painting, and srizing his Grace
by the rhculder, fairly pushed him out of the
house. The painter said afterwards very em*
phatically, that " the Duke's eagle eye went
right through him," but, us he did not know
the Duke, he only kept wondering who the
individual was. In the course of thj day the
Earl, on hearing of the circumstance, summoned
all the household and men at work in the study,
and, tenting himself beniJe tho great warrior,
demanded who hud the impertinence to push
the Duke out of door*. 'I he painter, all of a
tremble, came forward and said, " It was I, my
Lord." " And pray," r«joined the Earl, " how
cime you to do it P" " liy your orders, my
Lord." On this, his Grace turned round to
Lord ——, and, smi inn, drew a sovereign out
of bis purte, and giving it to the astonished
culprit, ««iri significantly, " You were right to
obey orders."

title: EN AVANT.
content:
EX AVAKT.
Things mav be bad, and fate's decree
uncertain :
Still iu despair an evil guest to court.
Surround your keep till falls life's final
curtain,
With walls of hope ; and fearless hold
the fort.
Recall hnvv many times along the high
way,
Blind alleys seemed to block your on
ward way ;
They opened into many a pleasant by
way,
When will had called your spirit into
play.
You travailed on, by obstacles un
daunted.
Through grim ravine you won to
flowery mead :
Faith triumphed over traitor doubts
that haunted.
And strength sufficient answered to
your need.
However far away may glow the
guerdon,
Your destined path is beckoning to
you ;
Where'er the haven lies take up your
burden,
0, valiant heart, and bear it safely
through.
MARY HOUSE.

title: IN LARFIN MEMORY OF PAS BURGELER
content:
IN LARFIN MEMORY
OF
PAS BURGELER
The Jackaroo.
AN AUSTRALIAN BUSH SONG.
I left my daddy one morning,
And never gave any warning,
But off to the bush went roving;
With my bluey I did go.
By PHIL AGNEW.
Cnoaus.
Singing Ho! Hilly Ho! for off we go
Where the kangaroo bops and the wallaby
flop?,
Singing Hilly Ho 1 Ta-ta, Good-bye—
On the wallaby we will go.
I went to Bungaroo station,
And apked for a situation ;
Said the boss, " Let's see your riding,
So jump on that moke in the yard."
Singing Oh ! Hallo! for up I did go,
And didn't he kick, and wasn't I siok—
"Hold tight 1 Look outl my bold squatte*
boy";
But I oouldn't squat there any more.
80, just to get my hand in,
I thought I'd try some branding;
So I made the iron a bright red hot,
And jabbed an old flow in the side,
And oh! Qreat Soott 1 she did perform,
And didn't I shiver, and didn't we slither
She caught the Black of my pantaloons
And landed me over the fence.
So, full of this botheration,
I cleared out from the station,
And, being a fool at location,
I lost myself in the scrub.
And oh 1 by Jove 1 Buoh brutes came round—
A ecake, by Jingo 1 and a whopping big dingo,
And an awful bird that laughed oat loud,
And leeohes crawled up my pants.
There came a mob of awful blacks
With pipeclay on their fronts and baeka,
And nulla nullas, clubs, and things,
And boomerangs and Bpeara;
Singing " Yarra go, murra go, mcc a lah."
They had a eorrobberie, oh I such a bobbarie,
Saying " Burra go, warra go, yarra go, VghV\
Yes, that was the words of their Bong.
They gave each other awful whask?, •
And yelled And screamed like mantaw;
So I scooted like old Billy Oh,
And I'm going home to ma.
So now I'm off—Tata, Good-bye
To the Bweet pickaninny without any pinny,
And kangaroos, wallabies, 'possums, and
snakes—
So-long, Ta-ta, Good-bye!

title: Dancing Lesson
content:
Dancing Lesson
[NTO the ballroom poured the sun;
The floor was smooth -as amber .
water;
ana 1— 1 was the favoured one;
I was the dancing teacher's daugh
ter. ?
Oh, there Wat something proud and
sweet
About my mother's arching feet, ??
As if a doe stepped down to drink
Of silver ? at a river's brink!
We gathered shyly in a row; ? '
Spellbound we followed where she
led, .
With slide and slide, with pointing toe,
Enchanted by her chestnut' head.
Her skirt was like the lifted wing
Of the. red-winged parrot from the
south,. ;. ?-? ?? . .
While youth and gaiety arid spring ??'
Trembled, to laughter at her;mouth.
The other mothers, stiff with care,
Signed . at a sash ' which tralledi
undone,. ' ? ;. '. :.' ;'. r. 1
Fastened, with a lock of childish hair— :?
MY mother was the dancing one!
. / , , , —BEATRICE HOLMAN.: .-' .

title: UNDER A SHOP VERANDAH DARK.
content:
UNDER A SHOP VERANDAH DARK.
When couples dally in parks ond
gardens
The imp of love will seize a chance,
And down on the foot-marked ocean
beaches
He's always urging for sweet ro
mance.
Hikers revolting out in the sunshine
Fail for his pot shots when they
park,
And lots of stunts he's always ar
ranging
Under a shop verandah dark.
A shop that shuts up soon after
night-fall
Uti'ers 'a home in front for love,
With often a low set 6tep for vest
ing.
And dew proof shelter up above.
There, where there's nought of ro
mantic flavour;
Heedless of every passing nark,
Love kocps warm until ripe for its
mating,
Under a shop verandah dark.
The parking's good whevc & snoP
stands empty.
Bark in a side street after eight;
There love thrives in the humblest of
makeshifts ;
Feet sometimes in a half numb
state.
Even away in the rural township,
Lovers love to giggle and hug-.
Scorning warmth where a cow s been
camping,
Under a shop verandah snug.
Motor-bike shrieks with shcilaa
straddling
'Rear- wheel cushions splutter awa- :
Out where the world cau't quizz their
courting ,
Or hear soft, thrilling things they
say. ,
But in where a small drab patch ot
shadow ,
Hvles from the street lamps
so-arching glare.
Love saves time that it turns to
sweetness —
(It doesn't take long lo slip round
there)
And who will say that the love's
not purer, . ^
Tfravinrr the passer's knowing grin .
Who wouldn't park w'th a good sort
sheila,
Lips to lips and chin t/- chin?
Who dare Ray that the love's not
greater ;
Fanned, perhaps, from a. dance floor
spark:
Strong enough for a cuddle in public.
Under a shop verandah dark?
L.A.S.

title: THE WESTERN CARRIER.
content:
THE WESTERN CARRIER.
(Written for this paper hy li. H. Sorensen.)
VJ th creaking wheels and jangling cnains,
Thr- carrior travels onward,
Now steering north o'er shad »liss plains,
Now slowly trending sunward;
Whore little creeks, though tiny streaks,
Incline him to bo wary,
And roloy-poll?s roll for weeks
Across the open prairie.
When night has settled cn tho track,
A score of bells aro sounding,
The burning pinewood 'gins to crack,
And euroc3 off go bounding;
For duty's sake, and thirst to slake,
Plo drawn a sparkling flagon;
Whilst she has scanty bods to make
Alcp and 'nealh tho waggon.
Around the enmp-firo dull and dim,
Tho menl anon's partaken,
Wallst Bwoet mosquitoes poster him,
And choice invectives waken;
lim carrier sighs as baby cries,
And says it's so bewlld'rin',
He cannot smoke, ns "missus" trios
To put to sleep tho children.
The morning breaks, nnd In her train,
Como flies in countless millions,
Thal e'er pursue the haploss swala,
And round him dance cotillions;
Ho harks for knells of distant bolls,
But hours a tinkle nover.
For thou that pest'lent army ftwolls,
And buzzer moro than ever.
Far distant hies a sturdy son,
Or p'rhnps a llttlo daughter;
Whence wild plain turkeys rise anon,
And omus raoo for water.
At llrst quito near tho nags appear,
But miles aro travollod over
Before tho tinkling bolls sound oloar,
That ushor lu tho drovor.
Tho eiurior pals Uio linrnopM on,
With Toni, lils li tl Io tilly;
Whilst Nollie milks tho goals u; o;i
Tho grass hohiml Ibo galley.
With break inst 1 rared, tho V.I.'Î In p'r.rc'l
Mop with baby Willy,
Tho teamster's cob with Tom ls graced,
And Nolly 'strides tho Illly.
The horses sparc, and nnnny-^nr.is,
And boarded billies follow;
A gay array in shaggy coals,
They gambol down tho hollow,
A tramping Jude with swng nbaik,
Roques!s a "smoko" on meeting;
A shearer, blessed with lorne and pm !;,
Goes by with friendly grei t'n;;.
In seasons dry, when wafer's senrco,
Tho earth with fissures riven,
Each ovo for milos o'er horbago sparse
Tho horses must bo driven;
But in the chinks tho waggon sinks
Deep down In rainy weather,
And 'sunder Hy tho weakened links
When horses pull together.
Day nitor day he meanders on,
With sundry st oros and rations,
Returning, when tho goal ls won,
With wool from Western stations;
And thou, maybe, his famlloo
Will taste tho sweets of dwelling
Hard by Wilcannia town n wee,
Whilst weary nags aro spelling.
*Z> 0 <i> <%>
Lord Kelvin, In distributing the prizes at St.
George's Hospital Medical School, said the
modern medical man must be a scientific man,
and, what was more, he must bo a philosopher.
The fundamental studies of medicino were of a
strictly materialistic kind, ibut they 'bolomred to
a different world from the
world which constituted
thoir main subject, the
world of lifo. Ho should
odd to thc subjects ho
had mentioned another
human nature. It was
with that they had lo
deal, and that carried
(hem far beyond doad
matter. Let them not
imagino (hat any hocus
pocus of electricity
or viscous fluids
would make a liv-
ing cell. Splendid and
Interesting work, of
.vhich some of thom knew,
had been recently dono in
what was formerly called
organic chemistry, a
groat French chemist
(oking tho load. That was
not the occasion for a
lecture on the border-
land between what was
(abed organic and what
v-qs called inorganic; but
I' would bo in forest big to
them to len ow that ma-
terials belonging to the
roneral class of food
p.'uf.'s, such as sugar, and
vVnt might be also called
a foodstuff, alcohol, could
1 o made out of the
chemical elements. But
lot not any of their
youthful minds be dazzled
bv i'm Imaginings of the
daily newspapers that
because Berthelot and
others had thus made
foodstuffs they could
make living things, or
that there was any pro-
spect of a process being
found in any laboratory
for making a living thing,
whether the minutest
germ ot bacteriology or
aro Illing smaller or greater. There was
an absoluto distinction between crystals
and cells. Anything that, crystallised could
bo made by the chemist. Nothing approach-
ing to the cell of a living creature had ever
yet been made. The gênerai result of an
enormous amount of exceedingly intricate and
thoroughgoing investigation by Huxley and
Hooker and others of tho present ago, and by
some of their predecessors In both tho ll)th
and 18th c n'urhs, was that no artificial pro-
cess whatever could make living matter out
of doad.

"Worrlmoe:" Mrs. George Cornwallis Wost
writes, in "Pearson's Magazine:"-"In the early
fifties, it was supposed to bo tho height of in-
breeding and vulgarity for a man to bo seen
smoking a cigar in tho street, and tho smoking
room in n country house wns generally some
miserable room, considered too unattractive for
anything else, and as far removed from tho liv-
ing-rooms as possible, Now ibo v>osf, the wärm-
est, and tho brightost is surrendered. Thoro is
a story told of a cortain lord, who wan an In-
veterate smoker, stnylng at Windsor in tho days
of tho Prince Consort; there being no placo to
smoko, this noblemnn was discovered one day
in his bedroom, lying on his back, nnd smoking
up the chimney. This was repented to the
Queen, and from that day a smoking-room was
provided." That unfortunate gentleman should
havo boen in Australia. In tho bush, and bush
towna, every room ls a smoking-room, though
tho ones that contain fireplaces are the most fa-
voured, the fireplace filling tho office of spittoon.
Many men, of the working class OBpocially, Ho
In bod and smoko. Most of thom expectorate
anywhere on tho floor, whothor in their own
house or othor pooplo's. Little notleo is falcon
of it on slab floors, and no notice nt all on
earthen or composition floors. Helpn to lay tho
dust, In fact.

of breaking through loo from twelve to twenty
Inchon thick

title: Original Poetry.
content:
Original Poetry.
[FOR THE SYDNEY GAZETTE.]
"MY LAST DOLLAR,"--A RHAPSODY,
To J. D. L. SYDNEY.
"Truly, he was the last of the rare," quoth mine host,
"and I shall never again behold the like of him any more "
ANONY.
Loquitur Dollar.
Alas! alas! my days are done,
The race appointed I have run,
My weary course must cease;
Laid by in sweltering hose to rot,
Or doomed to grace the smelting pot,
Or banished to some savage spot,
In poverty and peace.
Oft to the poor I've been a friend,
When graceless rogues their pounds would spend,
At fair, or wake, or milling;
The toper swilled and sweetly slept,
For one last dollar still he kept,
Like that famed prototype 'yclept,
Don Philip's splendid shilling.
The miser held me first in fame,
Still on his lips there dwelt my name,
And that of Ferdinando;
He clutched me, as a hawk his prey,
I 'scaped as in his palm I lay,
And flew like lightning fast away,
For keep me, no man can do.
The bard with barley water muse,
With odes arranged in threes and twos,
To flatter, fawn, and cozen;
Hath looked on me his latest store,
And purged the brain with hellebore,
To catch him one idea more,
To round him off five dozen.
The plummet plunged to depth profound,
Still felt no bottom, still no ground,
To help him to Parnassus;
His hair and beard with foul disgrace
He tore,--while snuff begrimed his face,
And lengthened out each yawning space
With, ahs! ohs! and alasses!
In lower life a constant drudge,
I've paid for food without a grudge,
To fill the aching paunches;
I've cured the ragged rogues in gyves,
I've soothed the cares of men and wives,
And saved both hogs' and horses' lives,
By medicated drenches.
To settlers clothed in dungaree,
I've been a settler, they to me,
When in the horny fist,
Lest tipping chiefs should merit blame,
I've tipped the sub to pass the name,
To higher powers, that close the game,
For land, to make them blessed.
The slave with shovel, hoe, and axe,
Unmindful of the income tax,
Forgetful of Recorder;
To prove himself a flashy blade,
A caser knaps, and then arrayed
In metal hose, attends parade
In collar of his order.
One shakes a wary loon of brass,
The 'tother bribes to make him pass,
And shares with him his riches;
For me (excuse the slang I use),
A down I bear from hat to shoes,
And now both life and freedom lose,
From renegado snitches.
I've been assigned to nobler use,
Exchanged for bearing billet doux,
And purchasing prunella;
I've bullets bought and powdered pills,
I've bought the paper ink, and quills,
Red wax, and paid the postman's bills,
For bearing love to Stella.
I served bold Donald Scot a year,
For ne'er a man my price would "speer,"
And Donald loved me well;
"Hout, tout," quoth he, "its unco sair,
"To tak the trews from him that's bare,
"I'd rather keep ye clean and fair,
"And wear the auld mysell.
"The day ye gang frae me," quo he,
"Will be your last, so let me gie
"Ae warning to your noddle;
"I'll wrap thee in my Tartan plaid,
"No sun or wind thy charms shall shade,
"Though Andrew's dinner be na paid,
"I'll pay nae plack, nor bodle."
"Oh whip the Scot," John Bullock cries,
"A Scot and sot are rife of lies,
"And both below a Par,--lo,
"Drive, drive each Celtic hero hence,
"How can a Scot have common sense?
"His pound is only twenty pence,
"And three make but a Carlo."
"Give me the shining ore," quoth Pat,
"As much as fills my crownless hat,
"Pour,--pour the dollars bright;
"On turnpike road who drives along,
"To left is right, to right is wrong,"
And this is Paddy's ceaseless song,
At morning, noon, and night.
But Patrick cries, "By night and day,
"I'll drive by right and left each way,
"The precious ore to gain;
"Whilst floating on commercial breeze,
"On paper kites let gudgeons seize,
"Give rags to them whom tatters please,
"Give me the flowers of Spain."
My dollar! when I part from thee,
My deadly dolour thou shalt be,
Shall leave me in the dumps,
No massie draught to grace my board,
No porker in my pantry stored,
But safe in death's dark haven moored,
Where spades and graves are trumps. M.
Anambaba, Feb. 1830.

A CRUISE AMONG THE
ISLANDS.
[By Seajayk]
WHEN last penning this crude sketch
of a three weeks' cruise arnong the
islands I had reached the point where,
after spending one day at South Goul-
burn Island, we ran across the divid-
ing strait on the evening of August
28, and anchored in Mullet Biy, on
the Western end of North Goulburn
Island. It blew very hard during the
night from the S.E.After breakfast
the following morning we landed on
the beach at a spot where a curling
spiral of smoke indicated the presence
of natives. The first unwelcome fea-
ture noticeible as we landed was the
presence of swarms of flies—the first
and last place at which we were trou-
bled with this pest. They were about
the size of the common house fly, and
were the most hungry, persistent, and
troublesome of their species ever en-
countered. Throughout the whole day
they proved a perpetual torment. On
the higher land, a few yards back from
the beach, we found camped four wo-
men and four piccaninnies, and within
a few minutes two very old men came
sneaking out of the bush, whither they
had retreated on seeing us approach.
There was also one miserable and
mangy dog. They were all encrusted
with fifth and dirt, some had open
sores, and all had running, bloodshot
eyes : the surrounding atmosphere was
impregnated with an odour that was
as powerful as it was dis agreeable ;
whilst the filthy flies swarmed around
like bees, paying promiscuous attention
to both blacks and whites of the party,
and inspiring a shiver of disgust as the
thought crossed one's mind that the
little demons now trying to force their
way into one's eyes and nose and mouth
and ears had probably just previously
been exploring one of the before men-
tioned natives' open sores. The two
old men and the children were stark
naked, the four women had scanty and
dirty nagas. They were about the most
pitiful looking specimens of the noble
aboriginal in his native wilds this
writer has ever seen. After vainly
endeavouring to get from therm some
information re the island, they were
presented by Mr. Holtze, on behalf of
the " Guv-ment," with some flour, to-
bacco, matches, pipes, &c. These gifts
they accepted in a calm, matter-of-fact
spirit, and certainly with no exuberant
demonstrations of delight or satisfac-
tion. In fact, the two old men were
so calmly dignified that they gave one
the impression tha they were confer-
ring rather than accepting a favour.
They could speak only a little "pigeon
English," and the only thing which
seemed to arouse in them a flicker of
interest was the mention of some white
man or lugger on the coast they had
happened to meet or know. Appar-
ently they were the only natives on
either of the islands, the great majority
being away helping white men to get
trepang in the Liverpool River or at
some other part of the mainland coast.
Leaving the natives we walked away
Eastward. In the depression behind
the sandhills, near the native camp,
we found some native wells, evidently
the source of supply for the camp just
left. After walking about a mile we
carne upon a big swamp, about a mile
long by about half a mile broad, thickly
covered with green rushes. , Old high
water fiVol marks show that it covers
a far larger surface in the wet season.
Although of such extent the water was
in no place more than about four feet
in depth. There was a remarkable
absence of feathered life on this swamp.
Possibly the birds objected to flies. We
had hoped to get rid of these pests on
leaving the vicinity of the native camp,
but the whole island apparently
swarmed with them—a rather singular
fact, considering we had not noticed a
single fly on the neighbouring island
the previous day. After walking a
mile round the S..W. corner of the
swamp we kept on along its further
edge for the South-east side of the
island, passing over blacksoil flats with
some fairly big timber. We found the
swamp at its opposite extremity merge
into mangroves, and a maze of man-
grove creeks, intersected by one or two
long, sandy, grass-covered flats, ran
interminably to the beach on the S.E.
side of the island. We arrived at this
beach at a point where the ironstone
cliffs were about 30 to 40 feet high.
An old native pad led obliquely down-
wards. At the foot of these cliffs there
was some fresh water in a depression
between the cliff foot and an old sand-
hill intervening between cliff and
beach. Right on the beach we came
on the remains of an old trepanging
station. There were two huts-one
bark-covered, the other a bare skeleton
frame of bush timbers. Near by, old
stone and antbed foundations showed
where the boilers had been set, and
lying on one ot these was a roughly
fashioned dipper made of bamboo.
There was a strong S.E. monsoon,
blowing, and the racing white-capped
waves were thundering on the exposed
beach and breaking in long lines of
spuming froth. We snatched a hasty
lunch here under the shadow of a tree,
dodging the swarming flies as best we
could. Whilst doing so our lugger
came into sight round the long sandy
point to the Westward, beating her
way up to a previously arranged ren-
dezvous on the South side of the island.
As there was no crossing the network
of mangroves and creeks on this end
of the swamp, we retraced our steps
about two miles round its farther ex-
tremity, and then tramped about four
miles in a N.E. direction up the centre
of the island. Stringybark seemed to
be the predominating timber, and al-
though nor of great size, was growing
thickly. The nest of two bald headed
eagles was noticed in the top of a tall
old gum tree—the highest tree about.
The nest as viewed from below, resem-
bled nothing more than a great bundle
of dried sticks, roughly crisscrossed,
and about four feet in diameter. Over-
head the parent birds soared in wide
leisurely circles, watching the intrud-
ers and uttering occasional shrill cries
of warning. Not long after passing
the eyrie we came across several curi-
ous sunken pits resembling graves.
Three of these were ranged side by
side, and there was another about 12
yards away. They were about half
filled with earth, whilst the upper por-
tion wis partially covered in with dead
and withered branches. The natives
with us could not explain them. With
a natural curiosity Mr. Holtze ordered
Buckley (one of the natives) to clear
the sticks, &ci., from one of the pits.
With evident superstitious reluctance
Buckley slowly dragged out the with-
ered branches and then started to bur-
row into the soft surface of earth with
his hands. From a few inches below
the surface he recovered a piece of
corkscrew palm about 18in. long by
4in. in diameter, with a wooden peg
driven fairly through its centre ; also
a native yam digging stick. Owing to
Buckley's evident strong repugnance
to the task the work of disinterment
was not pushed beyond this point, and
the mystery of the pits remained un-
solved. The natives with us volun-
teered the opinion that the blacks had
only been " play about," but the dig-
ging of such pits in the hard soil must
have been a rather arduous form of
amusement. After walking about four
miles we turned South and came out
on the beach on the South side of the
island at the point agreed upon. The
lugger had meantime beat up against
the strong S.E. wind and was anchored
about a mile off shore. Whilst wait-
ing for the boat to come ashore we had
a swim, and whilst in the water en-
joyed a few minutes respite from the
plague of flies. Someone had set fire
to the long grass through which we
had been wading during the last mile
of our tramp, and a sea of flame with
rolling billows of smoke went roaring
across the island under the impetus of
the strong wind. This wanton destruc-
tion of vegetable life vexed the soul or
our enthusiastic botanist, who, as
usual, had collected many interesting
specimens of plant life during the day.
On embarking we pulled for 200 yards
or more over a belt of live coral bor-
dering the beach, presenting beautiful
and variegated forms and colour effects
as viewed through the translucent
water. Myriads of flies followed us
into the boat, and it may be stated
here that the persistent pests accom-
panied us oh board the lugger and
made themselves a nuisance during the
greater part of they evening. As we
neared the anchored lugger we experi-
enced the full force of the wind and
sea, and owing to the carelessness of
those in charge of the boat narrowly
escaped what might have proved a
serious mishap. The deeply-laden
dinghy was pulled right under the
wildly seesawing bowsprit, instead of
being carefully brought alongside, and
would inevitably have been smashed or
capsized if it had not been for the quick-
ness of the one mani on board, who
spring out along the jibboom and
pushed the boat from under with his
feet in the nick of time. With the
strong tide racing through the strait,
the lugger at anchor, and only one man
on board, the capsizing of the boat
might have proved a serious business.
On getting on board the anchor was
at once hove up and the lugger was
run back under the shelter of the long,
low sandy point to leeward, where we
purposed anchoring till 10 or 11 p.m.
preparatory to a night run down to
McCluer Island, about 40 miles away
to the North-west.
Beyond some black and white cock-
atoos, some parrots,, and a few pigeons,
we saw no bird life on North Goulburn
Island ; and beyond signs of the pre-
sence of bush rats or bandicoots, no
animal lile was seen. We saw no in-
dications of minerals. There may be
some patches of fair soil, but it im-
pressed one on the whole as being a
more barren spot than its companion
island and if the fly plague is a chronic
feature it is certainly a place to be
avoided.
PINE CREEK RUMOURS.
[Echoed by J.H.N.]
It is rumoured that the Cosmopolitan
Battery is putting through the mill
stone from the Eleanor Mine, which is
giving a record yield of gold. Several
hundred tons of same are said to have
already yielded about five ounces to
the ton ; that there is more to follow,
equally good ; that many large nuggets
have been picked out of the ore bins ;
that the cyanide plant is being put in
order for the resumption of operations ;
and that extensive developments may
be looked for on this propeity in the
near future.
Rumours have been in the air for a
week or two to the effect that the idea
of paying Asiatics the same wages as
Europeans should be the subject of a
petition, and would be generally sup-
ported. (I commend the subject as a
good debatable one.) The idea is, of
course, that Europeans would then be
always preferred to Asiatics, and that,
the latter would be starved out of the
country without offendlng--as the Chi-
nese Government (or others) could not
object to a law which placed all on the
same level.
The steamer Empire arrived from
Southern ports on Tuesday forenoon,
moving alongside the jetty shortly af-
ter middiy. She brought eight Euro-
pean passengers inwards, and had 48
through Europeans and 208 through
Asiatic passengers. The vessel brought
about 50 tons of general cargo for this
port, and shipped about 11 tons of ex-
ports outwards. She resumed her voy-
age for Hongkong on Tuesday even-
ing
A subscriber points out that the
statement in last issue re shell being
worth £300 per ton is an exaggera-
tion. That is so, as at the last Janu-
ary shell sales we find that only one
class of shell realised that top price,
viz, " Colonial Sorted " Torres Straits
"C" shell drought from £11 17s. 6d.
to £15 per cwt. At the same sale, by
the way, best Nasau Yellow-belly tor-
toiseshell realised as much as 90s. per
pound. Is there any of tb it part-ieu
( lar class of shell on this coast ? If so,
it should be worth hunting for at above
price.

title: LITERARY
content:
LITERARY
Original Poetry.
A Bush Selection.
[WRITTEN FOR THE "QUEENSLANDER."]
An old slab house surrounded by a fence,
That once was post and rail, now mere pretence,
To save the garden; out of line it stands
Or rather hangs together, for the hands
That should have kept it flnn in its old age
Have filled the gaps with saplings. Cattle wage
Unceasing warfare 'gainst each weakened spot,
And play the mischief with the garden plot.
An old Blab house—the slabs are good as new,
Untouohed by storms, although the win-Is blow
through
The inch of space that now exists between
Each slab. The heavy raiu and west winds keen
Find easy entrance, and the folk endure
What, but for laziness, they soon could euro.
(The roof of shingles is all old and rotten —
Shingles don't stand like slabs when long forgotten-
Many are missing, and their place has been
Supplied by tin, that once held kerosene,
Cat Into squares, and easily placed between
The other shingles. Still some gaps are seen
Waiting to let the falling raindrops in;
The fanner waiting till another tin
Is empty, or, perhaps the reason why.
Waiting because the weather now is dry.
There is no stable, though there is a steed,
A long-legged, skinny, half-bred, usoless weed-
Useless for work —each farmer wants a hack
To take him to the township, there and back
In decent time—you'll Hud, in many cases,
'Twill land a fiver at the local races
If it is sent to wiu, and he can square
The butcher who has got a bettor mare.
No milking shed for the half-dozen cows—
The profit no such luxury allows—
Only grass-fed, milked in an open bail,
The half-a-dozen scarce can fill a paiL
About the house a few fruit trees still grow,
Mostly half-dead, but why he docs not Know
Who planted them in land untrenched, undrained.
"Fruit is no good," he always had maintained.
Suoh waa Jaok Thomson's home, and suoh his life,
And, M not blest with brains, be had a wife
Who bore him children, and still did contrive,
Though oft hard set, to keep them all olive.
Before effect thero must, of course, come cause,
And bush selections follow Nature's laws.
Jack gave up ploughing, not without good reason,
The land was bad, uo matter what the season.
At best he could but plant and try to raise
On hit poor soil a scanty crop of maize.
When orops were good, then down the market fell;
When crops were bid. Thomson had none to sell,
80 he gave ploughing best, and looked around
For other work, if such could but be found.
He bRd oue bit of luck, the Government,
With ample funds, on rail extension bent,
Invited tenders for a line, surveyed
Not far from Jack's selection;' to bo made
Within two years. The contract Eoon was let,
And Thomson thought " There's corn in Egypt yet."
He bad no money, but a good new dray,
On the time-payment system, straight away
He bought, and worked eight honest hours a day,
Carting for sub-contractors; but bis pay
Was not all profit, for horso feed was dear,
And his young family grew with every year.
Bat this was long ago; tho stir and life
Of rail construction, and the frequent strife
Of drunken navvies at the old main camp,
Are talked of only when tho flickering lamp "
Is lit, and in the uninviting room
Tries hard to chase away the evening gloom.
The horse and dray were sold—a backward move—
Jack takes life easy, and things don't improve.
Bush boys and girls have little of thcrfool
About them, but they must be sent to school
By force of arms. In this, 'tis such a pity,
They're not unlike their cousins of the oity.
But Nellie Thomson, though no model child—'
One likes them best—"well, just a little wild-
Was early taken with a wish to know
Why this was thus, and what was so and to.
Books Nell would read, whenever she could get them,
Till she got one on seeds and when to set them.
Nell rend of plants with names so very strange
That to pronounce them was beyond the range
Of her attainments. Soon she learned to priae
The many flowers that, as by magic, rise
To sun themselves beneath our Southern sky,
Making earth brilliant-blooms that glorify
▲ sixteen-perch allotment, if but taste
Ryflsoues the too oft bare, unsightly waste.
Nell vu the eldest, and her brothers knew
Her as their ruler—feared and loved her, too—
For oft she made them on a holiday
Work at her garden when they wished to play,
Or fish for catfish in the little creek.
The one redeeming feature of the place;
Bummer and whiter, down the waters race,
From some high spring their destiny to seek.
The bright lights thine on beauteous Brisbane belles;
Olad are the eyes that glance at other eyes!
Hark I now the music of the " anthem" twells,
The Governor I and all the people rise.
The bush selection and this scene so gay
Are brought together by our fairy's spell;
For many a plant and many a choice bouquet
Come from the home of clever little Nell.
The old slab house still stands, but on the hill
A good new house of weatherboards soon will
Defy the rain and all the winds that blow
From the four corners. Now tweet roset grow
In grand profusion down the gentle slope,
And fill wise Nellie's heart with joyful hope.
Runcorn. W. M.

title: THE MUSE.
content:
THE MUSE.
Oh! thou art laid in peace, and storms no more,
Shall reek their fury o'er thy fallen head ;
Unheeded now shall the loud tempest roar,
Nor harm thee couched beneath thine earthy bed,
Thou to eternal rest hast wearied fled.
Cold, dark and silent is this last retreat ;
O'er thy green-roof the winter rains shall shed
Their humid chillness ;— midnight blasts shall beat,
But thou in peace shalt sleep beneath the yew tree's
[feet.
In night's lorn noon, in winter's deepest hour,
When stormy skies the waning moon-beams shroud,
She shall usurp a momentary power,
And from behind the low'ring wat'ry cloud,
Tint with melancholy hue thy hillock round ;
Cold shall be her ray — pale shall be her beam,
Her sickly sight shall mark thy hallowed ground,
Then sink in shades of night, and all shall seem
A solitary desert — silent as a dream !
Above shall mournful to the shrilly blast,
The yew tree wave its aged boughs, and break
The awful stillness,— bending as it past:
It's time-worn creeking limbs alone shall wake
A grating sound — and from its silence take.
All shall be cold, and desolate, and drear ;
And on his grave the dripping boughs shall shake
The winter rain — and round the church tow'r near,
The wind shall whistling speak of midnight's bitter
[cheer.
But thou unharm'd, unawaked, in peace shall sleep,
In peace as silent as the steps of time ;
Thy lodging's dark, — thy chamber damp, — and deep
In earth's cold lap thy couch ;— but Oh ! the clime,
The change of season,— or the clayey slime
That stains thy dormitory,— the decease
Of untold ages,— the vile things that climb
And in thy bosom make long biding lease,
In thee excite no feeling.— Thou thalt sleep in peace.
X.
Pennyroyal Creek.

title: ORIGINAL POETRY.
content:
ORIGINAL POETRY.
BY T--------.
How sweet and pleasant is the crystal stream,
Which murmurs thro' the bosom of the vale;
Just as gray light of morn begins to beam,
How sweet the soft and gentle Zephyr gale;
Which with a grateful odour seems to teem;
How sweet when nature seems to glow and smile:
And all around appears with blooming pride,
And with her charms our deepest griefs subside.
How sweet to watch the calm unruffled sea,
From the retreat of an embowering shade;
Where no human eye can penetrate or see,
(That sweet retreat for sweetest pleasures made,)
Where birds melodious chant their wonted lay,
Where howling storms are all in silence laid;
And the bright sun shines on the briny wave,
And wild temptests round have ceas'd to rave.
But sweeter far the charms of one dear maid,
Whom Angels will for ever guard and love;
Whose sweet lips whisper thro' the deep'ning shade,
Such bliss this world alone can never give;
Bliss which no earthly thing can ever fade,
Nor found in India's wealth, nor balmy grove;
Bliss which soon dissipates each jarring strife,
And gilds sweet friendship thro' the gloom of life.
Sydney, 24th December 1835.
newspaper: The Sydney Gazette and New South Wales Advertiser

title: "Rejoice With the Wife of Thy Youth."
content:
"Rejoice With the Wife of Thy
Youth."
Fond lovera ye stood at the altar
When'sweet-life was at its noontide,
And:numberless blessings were showered
, , On the groom and his beautiful 'bride.
You, were manly, and stalwart^ and
' hopeful-. -
She was loving, and tender, and true-r
And life's path seemed strewed with bright
flower**,
And. earth wore a roseate hue.
Ye have fought life's fierce battle together,
And" though you are vigorous still,
The strain of-the'terrible conflict ?
Has made your wife nervous and'ill.
Her face has grown pallid and wrinkled,
And weurs an expression of truth,
But clasp the dear wreck to your bosom,
And "rejoice with the wife of thy
youth."
I f time mars the face of the dear, one,
The stronger your fond love should grow,
For the dim eyes that now greet you kindly
Lit your path in the sweet long ago.
Age may.have her bright beauty stolen,
But she's young in affection and truth,
Then prize heir above any other
" Rejoice with.the wife of thy youth."

title: The Town and Country Journal.
content:
The Town and Country
Journal.
tfrTH thia issue, the AUSTRALIAN TOWN AK
? COUNTRY JOURNAL enters into its fifteenth ye¡
of existence, and we therefore may he pardoned f<
taking our readers into our confidence by sayir
something of the "inner life."
The first issue of the TOWN AND COTJNTB
JOURNAL appeared January 8, 1870, and at one
it leaped into public favour, because it supplie
a publio want. The size of the journal was the
only 32 pages. In January, 1874, it was foun
necessary to enlarge to 40 pages, and the ii
crease of public patronage was BO gres
from all parta of Australia, that advertisers, part
cularly those interested in pastoral pursuit
cattle, sheep, horses, and other live stock, th
agriculturists including those who grow corn an
sugar, who make dairy produce, butter, cheese, &c
and the sportin gcommunity, whether horse-racing
aquatics, Cricket, or football, engaged their ind
vidual tastes-all these, and a host of others wh
had ships to convey our wealthy colonists to th
other cities or the old country ; or people wb
had anything to sell or buy, or missing friends t
find out-all these were quick to Bee the ad var
tage of advertising or proclaiming t
the publio their desire to do busines
through the TOWN AND COUNTRY JOURNA
in preference to any other weekly publicatioi
It became a very serious matter with the pr<
prietors as to the course to pursue, because c
the undue pressure upon the space occupied b
advertisers. There was nothing else for it but t
further enlarge the journal, and in 1877 the siz
was increased to 48 pages, and for th« time it wa
the largest paper in the world. Long before thi
it was stated plainly to other Australian news
paper proprietors that the circulation of th
Journal had already outstripped the old an
slow-going contemporaries, altho-igh some o
them had ten years start, but no response wa
made. With the enormous space of 48 pages a
command, we received gratifying evidences fron
all parts of the earth that the paper was fullj
appreciated. From the interior of America mei
wrote to make inquiries about our flocks an<
herds, and an experienced English - edito
said :
" 1 must compliment you on your journal. We have ni
newspaper in England like it-so comprehensivo, so in
teresting to all olnsses-and so varied in its contents
Beside tho nows from nil parts of tho world, von supply ii
onopapor what wo have to Mibtoribehere to half a dosen for
1 notice it is a FARMEBB' JOURNAL,a FIELD, a SPORTSMAN, i
QUEEN, a YOUNG LAMES' JOURNAL, an ILLUSTRATE n
ft PCIENTIFIÜ JOURNAL, and a CORNHILL, all combined ii
one Issue."
This testimony waa extremely encouraging, anc
it has been continued up to the preaent day. Th«
Christmas issue for 1883 was of a character eel
dom witnessed in any part of the world. Thc
picture, presented gratis with that issue to tht
subscribers, cost the large sum of .£1000. Al
though 50,000 copies were issued, yet it is within
the mark to add, as we could prove, that 60,OOC
copies would not have met the demand. For in
stance, the agents at Wagga Wagga, Goulburn
Bathurst, Albury, Armidale, Maitland, und thc
masB of Sydney agents and from Queensland were
almost frantic in their demands for additional
extra copies.
The enormous success has not been achieved
without large expenditure. Machine after
machine of tho newest and most approved design
has been erected, and addition after addition haa
been made to our already larere printing establish
ment. But they were not &xrfficient. We have at
laBt been compelled to look elsewhere for more
space and larger premises, and are now erect
ing an establishment in Market-street, near
George-street, on the aite of the old Waterloo
Stores, of a capacity which, we trust, will meet
our requirements for some years.
The TOWN AND COUNTRY .JOURNAL indeed oc
cupies a proud position, and this success the
conductors are fully aware is' due to -the Austra
lian people who have made thia paper their own,
and the exponent of their experiences and
(¡pinions, aa well as their wanta and grievances.
Tô-SîSîS pur thanks are due, and our efforts in
the future, ÄS the past, Bhall be to keep up
with the spirit oF tHe Si^?3i and we Bhall be glad
to have their advice at "ali Silges aa to where
improvement is possible :- "....'^.?r;:,-r--»^
Go forth then New Tear's pages
And travel round tho world, . " .
Wherever English accents ring, -
And English sail's unfurled.
Go forth throughout this island,
To cot and mansion roam ;
And further yet to foreign strand,
Where Bojonrn exiles frum our land,
Whose hearts with pleasure shall expand
To hear the news from home.
Go forth then task completed, "~
To welcome weekly toil ;
And thus our New Year's greeting bear
.To many a distant soil.
Yet ere we close our labour,
And you your path pursue,
List to a word at parting said
In yet a verse or two.
Tho band of trusty liegemen
Of pencil and of pen,
And those fair hands that wield them, too,
To aid us now and then
To fill those bulky pages,
Hath wrought both well and hard ;
And every soldier in our ranka
Has earned,our gratitude and thanka
Artist and acribe and bard 1
To you, too, gentle reader,
Where'er your lot ia oast
Wherever fate has fixed your home
^Throughout earth's regions vaBt^
The editor, so please you,
Would by these pages Bend
All wishes due for New T ear's cheer,
.t £H Kreetings for the coming year :
God speed I" from friend to friend,
Bealisingthe high appreciation by the publio
of our efforts this Christmastide, we have decided
to " go onward," to. meet the rapidly-mcreasing
taste for art combined with literature and news,
so markedly shown in the universal demand for?
the 1883 issue j and to i his end we will give a
premium of 100 guineas for the best water-colour
or oil painting painted by a colonial artist, de
, picting characteristic scenery, or Bocial life, in
Australia. This picture will be reproduced
for presentation to our subscribers next
Christmas. The terms and conditions under
which competition will be invited for the above
work will shortly be made public.

title: QUANTAS AEROPLANE SERVICE.
content:
QUANTAS AEROPLANE SERVICE.
The menus at Cloncurry cafes
Will now show bream and whiting
As long as fish at Normanton
Are plentiful and biting.
Landed by the Quantas line
Shortly after hooking
There'll be variety
In Cloncurry cooking.
Whoever thought that fish would fly
To such outlandish places
To help, along with immigrants,
Fill up the empty spaces.
Since the Normanton extension opened in
July 1927 the carriage of fish has been a
regular feature of the Normanton-Clon-
curry run, and the weights carried axe
showing a considerable increase. On one
trip during the month 593 lbs or ¼ ton of
fish was carried, the weight carried for the
month has amounted to 1274lbs, while the
total amount carried since the inception of
the service amounts to 4¾ tons.
A feature of the new Route time table
which comes into operation on April 17th.
next is the completion of the Norman on-
Longreach trip in one day. Fish taken
out of the water at 6 a.m. in Normanton
will be delivered at Longreach 526 miles
away at 3.30 p.m.

title: SELECT POETRY.
content:
SELECT POETRY.
COMPLAINT OF AN IMMIGRANT COOK.
Oft when at earliest dawn I sleeping lay,
Dreaming of home, and hopes long past away,
I hear in fancy's voice that thrilling sigh
When "Come for your water!" is the hideous cry.
How sweet it is, when Sol's meridian ray,
Bids sultry beams upon the water play,
To rest in shade, whilst sleep the eyelids kisses,
And wake to hear one bawling--"Clean your
dishes!"
And oh! at even, what soft, what soothing scene,
To watch so calmly rising--night's majestic queen,
And feel that--lonely sadness,--wond'ring if there be
Inhabitants in that bright orb--"Too late for tea!"
Oh heaven's above! that such romantic natures
Should e'er descend to boiling their own 'taters!
Oh Muses grant! thy sons may never rue it
For "Cleaning their own boots," and chopping suet!
M.S. Maitland Herald.

Some shoes that his hands had made
