title: The Most Fortunate
content:
The Most Fortunate
(An Easter Poem)
There have been many women fora
tunatc —
f Cleopatra, Shcba, Nicolcttel)
Who ran a gamut of full, well-lived
years
Sounding the depths of rapture and
regret 1 _
There have been women who thro' sin
ful lives — ? !
(Catherine. Joanna, Pompadour)
Were lapped in luxury; for them the
stars
Held always one more, suptr-gift inj
store 1
Even the women cradled by red Mars — »
(Boadicca, Joan, the Laksbmi Bail)
They drew their joy from trumpeting
of wars —
They loved and fought — and bad tbeilj
little day !
But none of them — the richest, loveliest,
best —
(Queen become beggar, beggar rai-ed to
Queen).
Ever attained the pinnacle of bliss
Which waited the poor, lonely Magdalene.
When on a morning dark she heard at
Voice—
('Mary!' it said — and worlds were in
that name!)
'Master!' she wept, and knelt then at
His feet
Wrapped in a radiance white as candle-'
flame.
A thousand years ago! Yet EVERY
year
Men tell the talc again with bated
breath —
How happy, happy, Mary paused to
bear
The Voice of Him who triumphed oyc£
Death!
Q'ld. E. M. ENGLAND,

title: To a Hospital Nurse.
content:
To a HospitaliNurse.
i Thine are the blessed tasks
? To nurse the sick and weary,
Soothe the dying, and, perohanoe,
To clothe the helpless children
Our Father in His wisdom sends thee.
i ' * ' # ? m ...::;?'#.....?;:???;#.',;?'
And when-this life's work o'er-thy soul,
Free from all sorrow, sin, and care, Bhall stand
j Before our risen Lord, to hear the sentenoe pass'd,
! Thèse are the words that fall from lips divine :
I " Well done, thou faithful one and good j
Î For thee a place has been prepar'd
! ' Within My Father's house, and robes
As pure and spotless as the driven snówi"
Into the joyous kingdom of thy Lord
Thy soul can enter now, and join
j Those little children dad like thee
! In spotless white."
AiiTiOBA PETO.
Sydney ; Maro 6,1889.

title: Poets' Corner
content:
Poet's Corner
HOW?
If you would help a girl who is a
trier,
Yet let her win her way through
on her own,
To gain a goal you know she does
aspire,
To which you think she cannot go
alone.
A nobby girl who smiles a cheery
greeting,
Each evening when you meet her
after toil.
Although you know the toil is slowly
eating
Away the higher aims, you wouldn't
spoil.
What time you know the struggle she
is making
Is hardening her heart more than
a bit.
And not for worlds you'd let her
know you're staking
On helping her to get away from
it.
How would you go about your grand
intention —
A trait that still persists in human
kind —
And how your admiration in suspen-
sion;
And keep from off you face what's
in your mind?
— L. A. SIGSWORTH.

title: GOBLIN TIME.
content:
GOBLIN TIME.
There were goblins selling a star, a gem,
And a lady walked in a diadem
Of phlox and lilies and meadowy flowers
And a bright little string of April hours.
A bell went "Ting" And I bought a charm.
I'm sure as sure that it was no harm
For Margot was playing "I see" with me,
And Margot is not quite half past three.
BERNICE MAY.

title: TO KITTY.
content:
XO KITTY.
Thou art lovely as the morning,
Thou art fairer than the 'ight,
In the home thou art adorning,
There is nothing half so bright.
The clear blue heavenly vault above thee,
Sure caa never match thine eyes.
And there's nothing but must love thoo,
In this world beneath the skies.
May tho angels always guard theo-.
Art not thou an nngol too P
May a happy lifo reward theo,
For thy heart is pure and truo.
And may never cai o or sorrow
Hender dim thy glorious eyes ;
And may each succeeding morrow
Bid now happiness arise,
May thy beauty wear for ever,
In a happy peaceful home.
And may trouble near thee never
Till the end of lite shall como.
Stars shall then look down from hoaven,
With their greetings from afar,
And their welcomo they will bo given,
To the char min cr K. M. R.
J. S. L.
July 30.

title: Australian [?]lelodies.
content:
ftttftttratfon ÎHrïouïco
No. I.
î$WT.ET maid of Australia, if, gazing on thee,
'To the realms where the heart is at rest,
The ppirit that loves thee this moment could flee,
/jT.were this moment indeed to be blest.
And the «pirit that left all on earth it could love,
.From the source of its agony riven,
W«»ld pray for that angelón earth from above,
Who could make earth below it-a heaven.
Sweet maid of Australia-shed not a tear,
If gazing on thee I expire;
The heart that adores thee to agony here,
Has, without thee-no earthy desire.
But oh ! could'st thou smile-from the depth of despair,
To cheer me a sun would be given,
To light on my path, and with rapture prepare
The heart that adores thee-for Heaven. ,

title: LITERATURE
content:
LITERATURE
Original Poetry.
A Reminiscence.
SULORAC.
We met: I was a stranger in the land;
"A little time, and we were closes mates.
How soon a little flame, though gently fanned,
Will grow in strength until it terminates
In blame grand! -
We met again: 'twaa at a festive ball—
I asked her card wherein to write my name;
The space was filled; I well remember all;
We quarrelled—yet I loved her all the same.
And that was all.
We parted; I to go my weary ways;
Bhe did not mind the anguish I was in;
Tossed to and fro on ooearTs giddy mace.
I tried to think me happy, and did grin
lho»e wretched days.
We met again; 'twas on a Bunny beaoh;
A little gonyah offered welcome shade,
And'lnto It we crept; there she did teaon
Me how to love, and fondly I obeyed—
Hands clasped in each.
We often met within that shady nook,
Amd tt«emed sweet for rotu hful was our age.
IkissedherUps-herlitUehaDdltook—
While she did tell her love as from a nage
Of Plato's book!
"To wed would only sever through the links
Of that sweet passion which in us exists;
So we will follow jost what Plato thinks."
lam quite williag—and my mate insists,
November, 1888.

title: Poetry.
content:
Poetry.
A Romaunt.
DRAMINGO.
FAR in the east the rosy sun
Uprose; the morn was cold;
When on the road I met with one,
A piteous tale who told.
"Oh! traveller, she has left me here,
In this strange, lone countrie;
I've hunted for her far and near;
Aught of her did you see?"
"Say, was she winsome, young, and fair,
With eyes bright, deep, and sad;
And had she tresses of dark hair?"—
He said, "My word, she had."
"Say, was she like the fragrant morn,
In lovely, youthful glow;
Swan neck, and head so proudly borne?"—
"You're on—she was, just so."
"Go, seek her in some lordly hall,
Or high baronial pile;
Where silken sheen and diamond gleam
Are bright as beauty's smile.
"Or, seek her in some cloister gray,
Within whose ancient walls
She may have haply fled away
From festive sports and balls.
"Or, in some garden's peaceful shade,
'Neath linden foliage green;
But errant maid in woodland glade
I really have not seen.
"Still, of my sympathy have share,
For your sad woes and trouble."
"Get out! I've lost my old black mare,
Who'se bin and broke her hobbles."

title: An Oceanic Ode.
content:
An Oceanic Ode.
(BY "THE VICTIM.")
Prodigious dampness, cramm'd with slimy fish,
Th* abode of gods and nymphs who love to swish
Their scaly tails, and lash to billowy wave.
The mass of mobile matter ! Th' unfill'd grave
Of men, and dead sea monsters, dear to science.
The poets' theme when, having placed reliance
On woman's faith, they seek for simile,
And nature points to the ever-varying sea ;
While women say 'tis boundless as their love !
Alas! too true ; for, soaring high above
Man's single love, th' ambitious female soul
Divides itself 'mong dozens,.yet remaining whole!
Strange Paradox !
Sydney; September, 1889.

title: Selected Poetry.
content:
Slected Poetry
FAINT NOT!
[By M. Burkinshaw.]
Faint not! The hills of heaven are far away,
But lower ranges show their glimmering grey,
The dawn has gone, but there is still the day --
Faint not!
Faint not! The day draws closer to the night,
The limbs are weary and the cheek is white.
Faint not, but struggle while there yet is light.
Faint not!
Faint not! The castle gate ye sought to gain
Looms ever distant through the falling rain —
Ye yet can couch upon the grassy plain.
Faint not!
Faint not because ye lost a dearer prize.
Ah me! the witchery of those lips and eyes —
Faint not, possession never satisfies —
Faint not!
Faint not! but clench the hands and hush
the cries;
If you must fall, let it be but to rise.
Somewhere there yet maybe a paradise.

title: SOMETHING WRONG.
content:
SOMETHING WRONG.
Morning sparkle on sea and shore,
Skies that wait for the rising moon,
Park-lights glowing, and how much more--
All are set to a plaintive tune.
Something whispers "She is not here;"
Something sighs "She is still away;"
And I am missing my dearest dear
Night and day.
Sea we gloried in, blue and gold,
Lonely cliffs that we wandered on,
All lie now like a story told--
Where's the soul of their beauty gone?
Something's wrong with the world, I fear,
One thing only can set it right;
And I am missing my dearest dear
Day and night.
RUTH M. BEDFORD.

title: Literary Varieties.
content:
Literary Varieties.
LOVE AND FAME UNTASTED.
H.A. BIRKBECK.
HOPE is the halo that radiates around
My sable-curtained views of human sound:
Undistinguished from others but by name,
Unknown and undadvised for so long aim
At fruits that Fame in this wide world contains,
And which, when joined to Love, swell out their worth
Into a bliss—an lien on this earth !—
A bliss towards which all extend their hands;
Attained by few, in dazzling height it stands '
To awe the fools, but animate the wise;
To shade the dull: to light the great uprise!
For, though immense the height, the poetic Muse
Sends her soft charms for the aspirant's use;
Aids them to climb the wild—the seeming waste,
Yet sues a tribute bending to her taste ;
And as its merits, so in height 'twill soar.
To dazzle future ages evermore.
Immortal recompense by her bestowed,
Yet she appears to dunces but a void
Statue veiled in mystery—devoid
Of aught attractive to ideal wastes.
Who can descry no portals to foretaste
The poetic sweets, and they perforce abstain
From what they're fated never to obtain.
Yet, as I say, great minds shall break the seal,
So that the gleams of her lustre may deal
Her touching pathos through their natural will;
That the reflective music of their souls
May get variety—what Love extols.
Thus, foot by foot, and step by step ascend
The sacred paths that lead to Love and Fun*
When found to dwell within the genial flame.
As to pure Peri, Eden now extends
Infinite bliss and pleasures without end.
Where she eternal sees the light of all
That in ecstatical joys dissolves the soul!
Can we be blamed for seeking Love and Fame ?
Tbe noblest means by which to build a name;
Assimilate, and more to perpetuate
To glorious bliss that angels above, elate,
And nappy beyond measure, evermore
Enjoy. Immortal spirits beyond compare
An much above all mortals in their bliss:
They live in strictest concord, sweetest peace,
By aught sublunar incorruptible;
To Glory, Joy, and Love susceptible!
But mortals' fame is that on earth which lights
Men through their gloom to the bright sinecure;
Where, wreathed in similes, they think themselves se
cure
From visitations which this world'abound.
Till Fortune's partial trumpet 'gain resound.
And hurl them from their pinnacle of bliss ;
From their bright halo to a dark abyss.
We, like Egyptian locusts, when they're bent
Past hills, and dales, and rivers' wide extent •
One upon the others heaped, till by excess
As countless myriads they attain access
Beyond the roaring floods though myriads drowned.
Victims to form the pontifical mound;
Yet more unscathed cross over to the plains
Of rich luxuriance caused by remote rains,—
So strive we men, enticed by glory's call,
To stem the torrent and attain our goal;
And though unnumbered sink beneath its well,
Hundreds attain of Love and Fame, the vale.
Our risk U great, yet glory's stern command
Is greater still, permitting no remand
By the sweet impetus of ladies' eyes,—
And what were Fame without fair maiden's sighs;
For maidens' sighs are liove, and Fame is Love.
To have one without the other, were to have
The Sift in a mean flcar.tinn—half a. ln»« I
Ik thb Stocks.—The sulky, treacherous
temper defies calculation. All at once a cloud
comes over the face. You hare unwittingly
touched some tore, and he Bulks. There is no
honest anger, no blaze, but the coals are alight
in the mine, and generally you must wait till
they are burned out. You can't get at the
hidden heat. It smoulders on; all work is
stopped, though the outside looks much the
same as usual. I remember a horse-dealer who
always cared a fault by indulging it. He had
once a brute sent to him which occasionally
sulked and stood still. Farmer Waistcoat had
flogged him, and he would not more for an hour.
Well, this man took the beast, pat him in his
break, and drove off. In ten minutes he came to
a dead stand. Breaker said nothing, did nothing.
Horse didn't quite know what to reply, tried to
look back with his ears, waited half an hour, and
then began to move on. "No, my friend,"
said the breaker; " you stay here all day." The
farmers passed him, going to market, with un
complimentary greetings. " What, can't you
make a move!" Breaker doeßn't look put out,
though. Tck! Farmers drive on, show their
samples, dine at the ordinary, and jog home a
trifle merrier, late in the afternoon. Breaker
still there, master of the 'position. At last he
jogged home, victorious. The horse never
stopped again, except on legitimate orthodox
occasions. So may we sometimes treat human
temper, and give the sulky something to sulk
about.— People's Magazine for August.
Thb Lawd op Boss Trass.—ln May the
soil is twice turned up, divided into squares,
and slips are then planted in holes at a distance
of 2£ feet. The slips are covered with earth,
which is kept constantly humid till the trees
appear above ground, when the irrigation is
lessened and the trees reach their natural
height of about 2} feet. At the end of Decem
ber the shoots are cut at the surface of the
ground, irrigation being recommenced for thirty
to forty days, being the time necessary for the
budding and blowing of the flower. The roses
are gathered every morning before sunrise,
while covered with dew; they are placed in an
alembic ere they dry or heat, and the distilla
tion lasts six hours. The water is white when
drawn from the alembic; that offered for sale
is generally yellowed by a mixture of water
from roses which have been infused. A feddan
gives from six to seven quintals of roses. In
1832,800 quintals were collected. By a reduc
tion of 50 per cent.-from distillation, these 800
quintals give 400, which produced 40,000 rot
toli of rose-water. A feddan planted with rose
trees costs 60 piastres for culture and taxes, and
gives three quintals, which give 300 rottoli,
which, at three piastres, produce 900 piastres
net. But no person is allowed to distil roses
for his own account, and those who cultivate
them are obliged to sell them to the Govern
ment. " The manufacture of rose-water, for
which the Fayoum was so distinguished, is re
duced to very small results. There are a few
acres of rose garden in the neighborhood of the
capital (Medineh el Fayoum), but their pro*
duoe is trifling. The monoply of rose leaves,
for which so small a sum is allowed to the cul
tivators, has rendered the cultivation by no
means worth the attention of the peasantry or
landholders. It is seldom that any cultivator
has more than a single feddan dedicated to the
production of rose trees. The price paid for
rose leaves is 25 piastres =» ss. per cantar. Of
fine rose-water a small quantity is made for the
use of the Government; bat that produced for
sale is of little value and indifferent character.
There are three qualities of rose-water produced ;
they sell for 3 piastres (7*d.), 5 piastres (Is.
id.), and 7 piastres (Is. sjd.) per bottle. Otto
of roses is not manufactured in the Fayoum,
though the free cultivation of ro.e trees would,
I am assured, enable its inhabitants to oompeto
with any part of the East in ita production.
The consequence of the monopoly is the gradual
diminution of rose trees throughout the dis
trict, tierj person being interested in producing
as few as possible.

title: To a Cow.
content:
To a Cow.
O pow, where'er you browse for food,, :
Asaume a bolder attitude, ?? ?.":>
And turn tby meek and dreamy eye -,
Triumphantly to azure sky 1 . . . .
At buxom maid switch not thy taiL
Nor overtu-n in rage tho'pail *^¿SBfc
In short, by aobion dignified,
Display to man thy proper pride.
Graze on, O oow, and chew and dream !
The milk you. give will give its oream ;
Tho oroam be niven to tho ohurn, ^ .
Whioh gives it butter, in its turn. .
To. market will tho butter go
In golden balls, in tier and row ; .
No oU nor grease, called buttsrine, j
Shall ia thy borrowed garb be seen.
Feed on, O oow-in suashino bask
Thou hast protection in tby task ; : .??
And artful mm shall not compete
With thoe. Thy viotory ia oomplete !

title: Literary Varieties.
content:
Literary Varieties.
HAPPINESS.
TRIO.
OH, happiness, thou phantom shape,
Wilt ever tantalise, escape
Our grasp, cherished, eagerly sought,
Our strivings mock, dreams end in nought,
In life's gay morn, when bright is hope,
Dreams of pleasure visions ope,
To charm too oft with Biren voice,
To taunt and mock us for our choice.
Go seek it in the festive hall-
There mirth and glee 'a on faces all;
Its votaries erewhile confess
Such vain indulgence doubtful bliss.
Let wealth the chief est meed be deem'd,
And high above aught else esteem'd;
Riches create not happiness,
Bat they too oft with cares oppress.
Would you the trump of fame still sound,
Echo your name the world around,
For deeds of glory, high renown,
Valour, genius, may proudly own,
If patriot's fire burn in thy breast,
Then proudly don the warrior's crest;
.Richest of guerdons, crown of bays,
A people's thanks, a country's praise.
But if instead thou seekst a name
To pamper vanity, covet fame,
To live on lips, not in the heart-
Go win a bauble, thy desert.
He's happy who relieves from woe,
The oppressor's iron rule lays low;
High-sounding praise does not regard,
Bat finds in other's joy reward.
Ouonr op thb Tzkk " Humbug."—When
Solomon, condescending to take part in the
exetobes of the schools, delivered hinuelf of a
Latin speech in tit. Mary's Church, he was
" Mfficiently applauded by the scholars by clap
ping of hands and humming, which, though
strange to him at first hearing," says Wood,
"yetwhen he understood, upon inquiry, what
that noise meant (which they told him signified
applause), was very well content." From the
inarticulate-fbrttery of such "hammers," as
those, who hummed James the First into good
contentment with himself, came the familiar
term of "humbug" and the signification
put upon " to hum" when the expression means
to " impose upon by insincere praise."—" Annals
of Oxford," by John Cordy Jeaffreson.
Ixhobtai. Flowers.—The snow-drop has
long been regarded as a saored flower, as the
first sign of the returning life of nature, piercing
the snow [French, perceneige). It was conse
crated to the Virgin Mary. On her Ascension
day, formerly, her images were removed from
the altars to in icate her ascension, and the spot
where each stood strewn with snow-drops. The
gnaphalium (amaranthon, the helichrysum of
Pliny, aad the chryeantbemon which Dioscorides
describes as used for chaplets), whioh we know
under so many common names—cat's foot, chas
tity, everlasting—has long had a connection with
immortality in Catholic countries, and is
gathered on Asoension-day to be hung over the
door of house and stable as a charm against
various evils, but especially lightning. It was
this flower that Emerson laid on the grave of
Thoreau. " There is," he said, a flower known
to botanists, one of the same genus with our
summer plant called ' life* everlasting,' a gnapha
lium, like that, which grows on the most inac
cessible cliffs of the Trrolese Mountains, where
the chamois dare hardly venture, and which the
hunter, tempted by its beauty and his love (for
it is immensely valued by the Swiss maidens),
climbs the cliffs to gather, and is sometimes
found dead at the foot with the flower in his
hand. It is called by the botanists Onaphalium
leontopodium, bat by the Swiss JEdeltoeisse,
whioh signifies nobic purity. Tuoreau Beamed
to me to be living iv the hope to gather this
plant, which belonged to him of right." The
superstitious value placed on it by the Swiss is
for wreaths, which are made on Ascension-day,
and said to have power under certain conditions
to render the wearer invisible. It is also an old
Suabian belief that one who on the Friday of
the full moon, or on a fete day before sunset,
pulls it up by the root, and folding it carefully
in a white cloth, wears it against the naked
breast, will thereby be made bullet-proof and
dagger proof.—'• The Sacred Flora" in Harper's
New Monthly Magazine.
Casada is moving for a grand and radical re
form in her educational system. A bill is now
before the Ontario Legislature, which provides
that all schools shall be free, and attendance
compulsory. It is also proposed to introduce
into the schools a course of studj of natural
history, chemistry and agriculture, and to es
tablish industrial schools.

title: LITERATURE
content:
LITERATURE
Original Poetry.
Lines Written by Night.
E. COLWELL.
ABOVE my head from polo to pole
A vast oxpanse of liquid blue,
The starlit heavens meet luy view,
But bring no comfort to my soul.
But bring a sense of lonclinesss;
Ah! would that one wore here to toll
In whispers low, the magic spell
Such evenings work on my distress—
The spell that works with dire effect
Would then not harm, but heal, my woe;
The wind would sing In whispers low
Sons wafted home—not husbands wreokt.
But since I stand on alion land,
Lonely in heart, though not alone,
Tho winds will murmur and make moan
Of corpses washed upon tho strand.
The curlew Bhrioka from out tho night
Liko Bomo poor spirit racked with pain,
Or ghost for ever doomed in vain
To follow still a lying light.
The wild dog, howling in tho waste.
Culls to a ghoulish feast his mate;
Now, night seems black with lust and hate,
Which once I loved as puro and chaste.
I hear no music of the spheres
As I was wont at eventide
When Btanding, friend, by thy dear sido
"In summer months of vanished years.'
The Btare wore orst the beacons clear
That angels lit, to show whero lay
Through pits and snares tho narrow way,
When I was lost in doubt^ind fear.
But now—they seem cold pitiless eyes
That watch mo flounder in the mire,
That mock me as I faint and tire,
Or, falling, strive in vain to rise.
Tho meteors that shot through spaco
I deemed as ministers of light
Sent down to guide us through the night;
Thoy now hiss <TWrath," not whisper "Grace."
And I, who breathed out to my friend
My soul, boneath the starry wain,
Seem but a speck on some vast plain
That knows no boundary and no end.
And if across the waste I call
To friends ton thousand miles away—
Whose day's my night, whose night my day-
Strange on my ears the weird sounds fall.
My voice goes wandering through the night
Liko some lost soiil that seeks a homo,
Through many a long week it must roam
Before an answer brings delight.
And yet, sometimes I hoar a voico
Such as I heard in earlier youth,
And know it Is a voice of truth,
That Bpoaks from heaven, and crios "Rejoice!"
That crieß " Rejoice,"—that "Courage" cries;
"Faint not, nor linger by tho way;
If long tho night, the coming day
Shall last through all eternities.
"And in that day that cometh soon
The truth shall stand out clear and bright.
Not scon by glimpses, by the light
Of flickering star or pallid moon.
"Alono, when God is by thy side!
And sad, when thou hast noble work t
How can such selfish Borrow lurk,
When thou remomberest Christ who died?"

title: Old and New.
content:
Old and New.
AB the oíd year sinks down in Time's ooean, < '-'v
Stand ready to launoh with the new ;
And waste no regrets-no emotion- '.
As its masts and its spars pass from view. ': - .
Weep not if some treasures go nnder, ? >'»
And sink in tho rotten ship's hold ; .
That blithe bonny bark sailing yonder \-.
May bring you more wealth than the old. .1 .
For tho world is for ever improving,
All the Past is not worth one To-day;
And whatever deserves our true loving , ¡.
_ Is stronger than death or decay.
~ "Did love ?-was it wasted devotion ? ,
Old friends?-were they weak or untrue ?
Well, these drown there in mid-ocean ; .
And proudly sail on with the new. ' .v
Throw overboard toil misdirected ;
Throw overboard ill-advis'd hope ;
With aims which your soul has detected
Have self for their centre and scope; 1
Throw overboard useless regretting ?
For deeds which you cannot undo; ; 1
And learn the great art of forgetting
Old things which embitter the new.
The old years will grant no concession
Like misers, they keep what they hold ;
The new years march on to progression
March with them, and mourn not the old. '?
Sing who will of dead years departed,
I shroud them, and bid them adieu ; ? ' <
And the song that I sing, courage-hearted,
Is a song for the glorious new ! ;

title: Poets' Corner
content:
m^ 4
[?]
IN NINETEEN THIRTY-FOUR.
I noticed changes here and there in
nineteen thirty-four,
And some I've lined and rfiymed oft
fairly pat, .
While other things, I noted, went just
as they were before; ?
And now I've got a start, well, that
is that.
I. noted mofriets had to park upon tne
? common road,
While people quite as common, every
bit,
Monopolised verandahed space, except
when mot'rists mowed
Them down, and suffered dreadfully.
for it.
I noticed coppers sleek and tat. but
none with faces lined;
Though some, I'm sure, are loaded
well with care
That couldn't very well be stowed else
where but on the mind;
Vet few have any space to spare Jii
there.
Inoticed politicians with some anxious,
worried looks;
Though all their fronts were putfeu
and coming out.
Maybe they found the cushions leathered
' now from moulting chooks,
Who do not rting cast plumage round
about.
I did not notice churchmen on the dole,
or on relief
(I wouldn't knock one back were he
in need) —
But all their faces sported almost every
thing but grief,
And none came in to me to bum a
feed.
I didn't notice any time in nineteen
thirty-four
That truth got any sort of decent
spin;
In fact I often wonder what truth's for,
it is so raw ;
Unless to harden folks thin in the
skin
I noticed through one nine three four
my funds were fairly low,
And friends were prettv often on the
bite,
But I bite them, not nicely, but as
bluntly as 1 know,
And most of them have learned to
come to light.
And that reminds me — 'credit,' that so
very useful thing,
Is now a haloed, economic creed.
Yes, mine has changed from actual fact
to, theory t that's the stirig.
A very strange coincidence, indeed.
L. A. SIGSWORTH.

title: LITERATURE
content:
LITERATURE
Original Poetry.
Jack Hayes.
BY HENRY KENDALL.
FAR back by a forested gap
Is the bend of a river of rills
That lies like a moon in the lap
Of a land at the feet of the hills—
In » home of the leaf and the blid,
He passes his nights and hii days,
As quiet aa water* unstirred—
Boio low, for I ting of Jack Hayet!
Bow low, and bt reverent now!
This crippled old loan that you im,
As white aa a wintering bough,
ii one of the angels to he.
At the clo»e of a beautiful life
It is meet that his name should be known,
Whose oouscienee is more than a wife—
Who dares to be righteous alone.
Away where the fftoe of the harsh
Wild mountain looks out of the fog,
Beyond n black furlong of marsh,
Is the hut of old Jack and his dog.
Twelrt) winter* of thundor and four
Have beateu tho bark of it thin;
But the blowing of Qod evermore
Remains with the hermit within.
The rafters are rotting away,
And bitter winds travel across
The roof with whose sorrowful gray
Is mingled the green of the moss.
In a wildernesß desolate—deep,
The ruined hut shakes in the blast;
Bnt peace is with Jack in his sleep,
And ho sticks to his home to the last
Lot only a buahman is Hayes,
Unable to read or to write;
But truth ia in all that he says,
And his heart U as pure as tho light.
A knowledge direct from Abovo
Has given him wisdom indeed,
A spirit illumined with love
And the child's irreproachable creed.
Just forty-five summer* ago
He landed in shame and in ohains;
But a soul that is fairer than snow
Is all of the " lag" that remains.
There is none of ns here who can oast
A stone of rebuke at his head:
He haa hidden the sin of the past
In the light of the life he has led.
He lias loved like the rest, and has lost
gome darlings he sorrows for now;
But a glory of hair like the frost
Beams over a passionless brow.
A cripple these twenty years past-
One maimed in the arm and the leg-
He works in the woods to the last
For the bread that he never will beg.
Karrare, the beautiful brook,
The daughter of fountains aloof,
Flows evermore down by the nook—
By the grove over Jack and his roof.
Where the psalm of the stream and the reeds
Make holy wild places untrod,
He, crowned by immaculate deeds,
Bits patiently waiting for God.

title: THE MAD PIPER.
content:
THE MAD PIPER.
A piper played in Hamelin Town
A martial rant and fine,
And Fritz has laid the hammer down,
And Hans has left the vine:
As foolish babes they turned their feet
And the piper, on before,
Has played them up the village street
From the homes they'll see no more.
Weary and long their way shall be
That follow the piper loon.
And many a lad must pay the fee
That never called the tune.
-ELLA MCFADYEN.

title: The Creek is "a Banker."
content:
' The Creek is ua Banker."
Fierce was the blast ; tho galo toro past,
And rush'd through tho tall gum trees ; v.
O'er sornb and plain tho ceaseless rain
Drove straight in tho pitiless breeze.
The magpie's Auto is hush'd and mute ; .
And its foather'd mates are going
To dreary roosts on rain-soak'd boughs ;
And the crock is " a banker" flowing.
The constant drip from t'io weeping leaves
Is heard when the wild wind drops ;
Then, rising again, tho old gnarl'd trees
Toss, and wave their defiant tops ;
Bnt the ironbark's strongth is laid at length,. ;, '
With the wattle beside it growing ;
The skies, too, frown ; and tho rain pours down,
While the creek is " a banker" flowing. . .
The station " hands," in the hut at camp, f -
In a dreary way are trying ^" .
To patch the roof where the hark shows damp
While their soak'd, wet clothes aro drying.
But no yarns are told ; and songs ot old,
Are hush'd. with the usual blowing ;
The half-mutter'd word passes unheard;
And thc creek is " a banker/' ¡flowing. ; " ., ?<
Books arennopen'd, and cards unout ;
Concertina untouch'd is lying ;
For all do fear in that station hut,
That the squatter's daughter's dying;«
The pride of the men, what wonder then,
As the dull lights lessor growing, ' ,
With sad brows knit, they listening sit,
To the creek that's " a banker " flowing ? / . ,.
The men look up from the burning brands ;
<<. -«r^Bút they lower their eyes again, . y
For the squatter stands, amidst his "hands";
And his face is all warp'd with pain,
* My child is sick-" and his voice sounds thick,
"I fear-but there is no knowing," .".'
Lest she should die ero tho night's gone by ;". ?
But the croek is " a banker " flowing.
The old man look'd his mon in the face ;
But their eyes shrank from his gazing ;
* When Harry the stockman loft his place ;
And the light from tho black log blazing
Full on his sturdy and manly form,
And h^s sun-ibrown'd face all glowing,
As he sà'id, " 'Twill be a night of storm ;
And the creek is ' a banker ' flowing." . V
" My horse is good ; ho will pull me through ;
'Tis but a few hours' good riding.
I would it were more that I could do."
And then 'cross tho hut floor striding,
Go back," he said, to your daughter's bed;
For the doctor I am going. ' . .
I'll hate him here ere this night has sped,
Though the creek be ' a banker'flowing."
The sun had set, and the night grew black,
As Harry, his roan horse urging
Down the half-seen, muddy, slippery track
To the creek, swollen and surging.
Through the wet night; the sick moonlight' ""-5 .
Was shimmering more than glowing ;
And dark was the shade the she-oaks made
- » Where the oreek was " a'banker" flowing; «
' One look behind, and a glanée "across, ' '
' 'It was death to try the crossing ; ¡ s?? >.>?
But a noble heart and gallant horse : . M"
Breasted those dark waters tossing. ?.?<.,-.
Past treacherous snags, the torrent drags i. 1
. .Two struggling forms, both knowing ¡ , tt..oi >
. The bank is steep, and the waters deep, . ;
And the creek s "a banker", flowíng.r ''iri 3 ' " j
Uprooted trees on the flood borne past,;/, j
;In a stealthy silence gliding ; .. . r- f4,0
And now-Ah ! the bridle rein is fast,' t; ,ik
Spite of tender, skilful guiding, ' ' ' ' '
Upon a branch,,that horse, so stanch,'; 11 ^ '
Is swept down all panting, blowing;
The stockman's strong ; but the swim is long;
And the creek is "a banker" flowing.
. The rushing waters gleam strangely white,
' ' Overhead the clouds dividing, '/, ' x'i>"c\ J'i\ .
""And the moon looks down, a flood of light j' ^" '1 * '
- ' Streams on those dark torrents gliding.;"" 'î^-'io<
" From a curlew's throat, a wild, weitd note^i 7.fu ¡1
* Is a doleful echo throwing ; -^tirri bitn-o'l ¡-.RV.
[?With rise and fall sounds the mournful oaíl, \-¡
Down the creek that's " a banker '^flo^wing.'.'n,\'i'{
> A'few rude posts and a few rough rails,1 ' f-i? 'st-)th,
Mark the spot where he is lying ; .-/«i'im'c
And a pale fair maid there never-faila""
When the day is spent and dying,
.. Ea the twilight hours, to tend the flowers. rt '[?.?
' That on his lone grave.are grpwing;^ ' v-r.
~ Her eyes still dim, as she thinks,of him,.-. {
,', .When the creek was " a banker,'' flowing.-.' V ",'

title: Original Poetry.
content:
Original Poetry.
SERENADE.
Air--"The Young May Moon."
I.
WHEN winds to rest are sinking, love,
And flowers the dew-fall drinking, love,
My thoughts to thee
For ever flee,
Round thy bower a charm'd ring linking, love!
There they speed like the shaft to its mark, my fair,
At the meeting of light and dark, my fair,
At the lover's day-dawn,
When the moon's on the lawn,
And the nightingale sings for the lark, my fair!
II.
When not a wave is foaming, love,
And nought but Passion roaming, love,
Let thy thoughts with mine
In memory twine,
At the soft sweet hour of gloaming, love!
Think of me when the bright stars lave, my fair,
And dance in the stream they pave, my fair,
As if every star
Had shot from afar,
To hold a ball on the wave, my fair!
III.
While all in beauty's shining, love,
And all at rest reclining, love,
Remember him
Whose heart is dim,
In the midst of peace repining, love!
And when in thy bower to heaven, my fair,
Thy spirit at night is given, my fair,
Let thy pure thoughts rise
To their kindred skies,
In a prayer for the heart thou hast riven, my fair!
E.
newspaper: The Sydney Gazette and New South Wales Advertiser

title: Sweet Music.
content:
Sweet Music.
DEDICATED TO MIBB MAUD F- S
SWEETLY tho sound on my memory lingera,
Urging the MUBO her soft numbers to tell,
Harmonies rich from thy tapering fingers,
Gladden the heart with tumultuous swell.
Such soul-stirring chords
Thy music affords,
Soothing the senseB with magnetic spell.
Rippling and tripping like waves on the streamlet,
Swift and melodious the passages glide ;
Rapt in emotion with Fate, in a dream let
The listener sink as he basks by thy side.
AR he hears the sweet sounds,
, Each pulse then rebounds,
And waking, he hail« thee of MUBÍC the bride.
H. N. M.

title: ORIGINAL POETRY.
content:
ORIGINAL POETRY.
THE HEALER.
You have sinned against the printed God,
The God prim-fashioned by priestly hands;
You have wept salt tears, have spurned the rod;
But the great Earth Mother understands.
Go to the trees! and the wind-swept places,
Press the green grass to your care-lined faces;
There is balm in breaths of the whisp'ring breeze,
There is healing sure in the songs of trees!
I know, for I too, have walked the city
With pleading eyes and a yearning heart.
Bet never a face grew soft with pity,
They hustled me in the dusty mart,
With curved and clutching finger-tips,
The greed of gold on their tight-drawn lips.
But go to the hills-to the lonely places—
To the cool, dark scrubs and the wind-swept spaces!
You are near to the God of the Untrod Ways,
The God who plans as no nan-God planned,
Who is never hungry far spoken praise,
Nor gold dealt out with a grudging hand.
The hills are here—when the churches crumble —
A silent prayer, be it e'er humble,
Goes straight to God from the lonely places,
From the contrite hearts and tear-wet faces!
M. FORREST.

title: ORIGINAL POETRY.
content:
Original Poetry
To Miss R. M. O. N.;
- IRELAND.
Tue Arab maid her native bowers
Will love where'er she roam,
Her bright Gazettes, her flagrant flowers,
Her Yemen's sunny home.
The perfume from those valleys dear,
Each gentle breeze will bear;
And every lovely object near,
Recall a fairer there.
Well may that orient clime command
Its children's love sincere,
And if less bright - our own green land-
Our Erin's not less dear!
For absent sunshine, native wit
Will gild our winter's gloom-
For costly gems we've Genius bright
Adorning Valour's tomb.
For spciy groves, we've minds all pure,
Hearts - guileless, faithful, fond;
Ah Asia hath no sweets, I'm sure,
Our own " home-ties" beyond.
The Exile from Hibernia's shore
Of every thing most fair,
Will form a likeness to restore
All that she worshipped there.
J. M.
Parramatta
6th September, 1836.
newspaper: The Sydney Gazette and New South Wales Advertiser

title: No Home.
content:
. ,,v\ ' No Home.
. , BY L. G.-WILSON.
< There is a'time-'tis evening- '
When the swallows homeward fly, : !. "
When the golden rays of sunset
v Gild anew the western Bky ;
When the varied forms of life ,
¡Throughout nature cease to roam.
; But for mo, the weary wanderer, 1
There is never moro a home. i ;,¡¡ "t
The fairest and the gayeit,
Or the humblest sons of toil, -V
Find eaoh day an hour pf respite ,.
. ' And ot rest from all turmoil.1 ?. _(:
And the palace or the oottage .
Has a comfort all its own,
While for me, the weary wanderer,
' There is never more a home.
As I eyer, ever wander
Sad and lonely, to and fro, ,
; Seeking, seeking for a something
i You in vain would ask to know.
I ! Kindly hands are oft extended,
' ; , Welcome doors are often thrown ; ..
I i- But, With all their wonted kindness, -
It can never be a home,
Thus may be I'll ever wander \,
, While the seasons come and go, -
Ever searching-never finding
. What"my heart so longs to know. ' :
But the searching will be ended, ; ?'?
.And the wanderer cease to roam, t ! '
And this weary, hungry soul shall find ''
At last, thank God, a home.

title: CEAD MILLE FAILTE.
content:
CEAD MILLE FAILTE.
ZADRIEL.
'TIS not because thou art a Prince,
That thus we welcome thee;
Or thou art first upon these shores
Of Britain's Royalty.
But that tboa art Victoria's child,
The merciful and good,
Stainless in heart, in mind, iv soul,
Stainless of human blood.
'Tie not because the Vikings' fame
Is herited by theo ;
But that thou art of Albert's blood
A nobler progeny.
Welcome, thrico welcome, to our shores;
And if you miss the state,
The pomp and pagoantry of wealth,
Which wait upon the great j
We are but in babyhood,
Yet Queensland offers thee
Cead mille faille, a thousand times,
From British loyalty.
Free Selectobs' Tbotoles.—Circumstance!
are constantly occurring (says the Deniliquin
Chronicle) showing the inconveniences which are
created to the selector himself through the
operation of selection before surrey. Some two
years since a selector, named G. W. Middlemiss,
took up forty acres on the Tumudgerie run, in
the neighborhood of Deniliquin ; be settled on
" some" land, built his house, enclosed a por
tion, cultivated the ground, and brought the
produce into the town and disposed of it; he is
well known, his name has been for years on the
jury list, and in his turn ho has been served
with summonses at his residence on the ground
by the officials of our Courts. At last the sur
veyor arrived to adjust the descriptions the
selector had given by his more correct method,
and found that the former had described a por
tion of land other than that occupied. That, in
fact, the selector had described one piece of land
and lived on and occupied another. In obedienco
to the new light the selector removes his house,
and months paBS on with their improvements,
and then comes a letter from the Lands Depart
ment stating it has reason to believe that he has
not fulfilled the residence clause in respect to
the land he had selected, and inquiring what
reason he can allege for its non-forfeiture ? Wo
are not awaro whethor the case is complicated
by any one asserting a claim to the land which
has actually been occupied; but wo shall not be
surprised that it is so—it would only present a
muddle which is so apt to occur, either from
accident or design. It must, hoirever, be
evident that, maugre the incorrectness of the
description, the- selector has acted in perfect
good fnith and within the meaning of the Act
with regard to residence, and that the land in
tended to be selected, however erroneously de
scribed, is that which has been occupied and
cultivated. No Executive that desired to inter
pret the Act with honesty, either to tho com
munity or to the private citizen would, we
inmgine, seek to oust a selector under such cir
cunntance?.

title: ENGLAND.
content:
ENGLAND.
England is mine, and I am England's own!
All that is best within me lives for her alone.
That which is base and vile I spurn from me
Lest she with her unsleeping eyes should see,
And me condemn. She bore me in her womb
Where wild winds blew; and through the storm-
lashed gloom
Came ocean's boom.
And I was wove a living thread here strung
In the vast loom.
She was my mother mighty-voiced. I hung
Upon her breasts and greedy-mouthed did drink
Her noble sustenance. And on the brink
Of secret things I stood, when sweet and high
Her slumber songs lulled me to sleep, and I
Heard through their mounting cadence, wild and
free,
The low andante beating of a sea.
England is mine, and I am England's own!
I am a singing harp, and hers the hand alone
That plays the strings. Without, I am a thing,
Dead, dumb, inanimate. So shall I sing!
Here at the door-way of her room I keep
A ceaseless watch, untouched by straying sleep --
Dream shadowed, deep.
A living flame of fire from out its sheath
My sword shall leap,
If I should hear her proud soul moan beneath
A weight of woe. My voice shall beat the stars
And thund'ring shake the might of Heaven's bars
Till earth's dark caverns echo with the cry: --
"Here, mother, mighty-souled, O England, I
Am here to serve! Born of the wind and sea
I give thee back the life thou gav'st to me!"
MYRA MORRIS, St. James.

title: Sanctuary.
content:
Sanctuary.
VmiERE sunshine softly lingers and
* * the nerfumed breezes play
Among" the tall white lilies by laugh-
ing waterfalls;
Where the charm and wondrous beauty
of each untroubled day
Seem to leave a mellow languor
within the temple walls,
Is found my sanctuary.
For sometimes I can hear the sound
of Shantung lutes,
Or the song of the Shen-yin tree
grows clear in the moonlit nights;
And mignonette and violets wreathe
the flutes
That sing of Shanghai days and
dreamy Honan sights,
Within my sanctuary.
Within the walls come whispers from
the outside ways of men,
But now they cannot take away my
happiness,
Though memories are thronging swift
-of moor and fen,
Of lake and river, coral isles in love-
liness
To me in sanctuary.
But'here a gentle music playing weaves
a spell
Of magic greater far than Life's wide
wand'ring ways;
I ask but to stay until the weary mind
is well,
And then I'll take the beauty,
through the crowded days,
Of my dear sanctuary.
A. MURRAY SMITH.

title: Original Poetry.
content:
Original Poetry.
TO A FRIEND IN THE MOTHER COUNTRY.
MY friend, in hours of thought and care,
In evening hours of holy musing,
When converse sweet we wont to share,
Thy words the balm of peace infusing,
No more I meet thy smile of love,
I gaze around my little room,
And start to hear thy footstep move,
As it was gently wont to come.
In vain--in different paths we tread--
And thou no more mayest soothe or cheer,
Yet have those hours of friendship shed,
A sweetness that still lingers here.
And many a deep and holy thought
And high resolve shall breathe of thee,
And hours of toil and duties fraught,
Shall consecrate thy memory.
And when I breathe the voice of praise,
Or tune the lighter lay of gladness--
Or when the fainting prayer I raise
In the dark hours of pain and sadness.
In joy--in grief thy image still,
Shall beam in brightness on my way,
My soul with holier faith to fill,
And guide me to a happier day.
Then not in vain I've seen those scenes,
Though distance does our love divide;
Though the dark ocean intervenes
And time and change our fates betide.
Yet life in all its varying lot,
Of bliss or suffering, will not view
The hour when thou wilt be forgot,
Or friendship's prayer arise less true.
FILIUS CANTABRIGIÆ.
newspaper: The Sydney Gazette and New South Wales Advertiser

title: MATINS.
content:
MATINS. I
The trembling pulses oE the dawn
fill with faint gold the violet skies,
And on the moist day-smitten lawn
The peace of morning lies.
A blessed truce of woe and sin,
A glad surcease of care's annoy,
The waking world has pleasure m
Its matin light and joy.
And all the joy that fills the air,
And all the light that gilds the blue
I see it in your eyes and hair,
I know it, love, in you.
O'er lips and eyes and golden floss
There floats a oharm I cannot reaoh
A wealth of love, a threat of loss,
Beyond my subtlest speech.
The amethyst flush will fade above
Into the dust-dim glare of noon ;
The love of youth, the youth of love,
Will fade and pass as seon.
Kiss close, beloved ! for never yet
Oould love its bloom unchanging keep;
There are no hoarts but they forgot,
There are no eyes but sleep.

title: The Poet.
content:
The Poet.
No. 10.
Great God, who was, ere time begau,
And will be, when its years shall cease
Look pitying on thy servant man,
And forward roll the ago of peace.
The soid, that through life's prison bars,
Half sees th« angel's shadowy wings
And holds communion with the stars,
And souls of all created things !
Alas ! hears also all the cries !
And sadden'd, sees with tears, the tears
Of all that suffering lives and dies,
Throughout times iron-footed years !
Youth suffers ! but whilst suffering hopes
And sees tho dawn beyond the night !
Whilst Age, worn hopeless, feebly copes
With woes which dim life's evening light.
Through all tho thick-sown coming years,
Innumerable as ocean's waves,
Sad man shall still siled saddening tears,
And reap his crops o'er levelled graves.
His world to him (in vigorous youth)
Shall bo as bright ns 'twas to us !
His faith as largo in time and truth
But all its ending*-shall be thus !
To find his nearest friends betray
His fearless and chivalric trust.
And hope, towards his latter day,
Ground down with sadness in thc dust.
Perchanco if happior than his kind,
Ono priceless treasure ho may gain ;
A loviug soul, and noble mind,
To share his lifo, and soothe its pain !
And if so blest, lifo will not he
Whato'er its curses-wholly curst;
Por souls thus mutual, strengthened, see
Through time, and learn to bear earth's ,worst.
Believing that, howover late,
In this lifo or thc next, or long
The trial of their trust, some fate
Will compénsate lif o's weary wrong.
And placo them in some loftier sphere,
Where every life is nobly planned,
With love for law, unknowing fear,
And wisdom rules with gentle hand.
J ' Iv. A.
If a Bedouin should IOHO his teeth, would he talk gum
Arabic?
When is a lover like a tailor ?-"When ho presses his
suit.
Tho Homo Circuit.-Walking about with n baby at
night.
No other'living thing can go so slow as a boy on an
errand.
Spicer thinks the German glazier's cry of "Glass
pudin'" furnishes " food for reflection."
De Quincey somewhere teilt»' an anecdote of a man
who, on hoing threatened ' with assault by eighteen
tailors, cried out, " Come on, both of you !"
"Mynheer, do you know for what wc call our boy
Hans" "Do not really." "Well, I toll you. Der
reason dat wo call our boy Hans, dat ish his narnu."
Barney Williams was once acting at Philadelphia,
and, being disturbed by a child's cries, said, " Shurc
there's a nurse wanted." Tho woman retorted, " No
Irish need apply," and retired triumphantly.
At a party, wliile a young lady was playing with pe
culiar brilliancy of touch, a by-standcr bachelor ex
claimed, "Pd give tho world forthoso lingers !" "Per
haps you might get the whole hand by asking," said the
young lady's observant mamma.
Not so bad of tho Japanese student, who wrote hom o
to his ma that in Boston they had boen trying for years
to raiso tho grade of the Common by carting on ice,
and had spent very much cash that way, forgetful that
the coming spring would every year reduce the masses
piled up to their former level.
A certain young clergyman, modest almost to bash
fulness, was once asked by a country apothecary of a
contrary character, in a public and crowded assembly,
and in a tone of voice sufficient to . catch tho attention
of the whole company, how it happened that the pa
triarchs lived to such extremo old agc. To which
question tho clergyman replied, " Perhaps they took
no physic."
The customers of a cooper in the Highlands caused
him a great deal of vexation by their saving habits
and persistency in getting their tubs and casks re
paired, buying very little now work. "I stood it long
enough, however,'' said he, " until ono day old M'Caw
brie brought in an old bung-hole, to which ho said ho
wanted a new barrel made. Then I quitted tho North
in disgust."
A dog was accidentally present during divino servieo
in a Scotch kirk, where the worthy minister was in tho
habit of speaking very loud in the sermon, and, in fact,
when he got warmed with his subject, of shouting
almost to tho top of his voice. Tho dog, who hi the
early part had been very quiet, became quite excited,
ns is not uncommon with somo dogs when hearing a
noise ; and from whining and whining, as tho speaker's
voice rose loud and strong, at last began to bark and
howl. Tho minister naturally much annoyed at the
interruption, called upon tho beadle to put out tho dog ;
and ho at once expressed his readiness to obey the
order, but could not resist thc temptutation to look up
to tho pulpit, and to say, very significantly "Ay, ay,
Sir ; but indoed it was yoursel' began it."
Snooks had occasion to call on the reverend Dominie
Thomas Atrachard while he was at Glasgow. " Is the
dominie in ?" ho inquired of a portly dame who opened
the door. " He's at hame, but ho's no in," replied the
lady. " Ho's in tho yard, sooperintendin' Sauncrs, tho
carpenter. You can sec him the noo if your business
I is vera precise." Snooks assented, and walked through
I thc door pointed out to him into the yard, where ho
; boheld a carpenter briskly planing a joint, to thc air of
Maggie Lauder, and the worthy dominic standing by.
Unwilling to intrude on their conversation, Snooks
stepped, unseen, behind a water cask, and heard :
"Sauners !" No answer from the carpenter. "Sauners !
I say. Can you hear me ?" " Yes, miuister, I hear ye.
What's your wull?" "Can ye no whistle some muir
solemn and godly tune while ye're at work ?" "A-wcel,
minister, if it bc your wull, I'll e'en do it." Upon which
lie changed the air to Hie Dead March in Saul, greatly
to thc hinderanco of what was now painful planing. Thc
dominie looked on somo minutes in silence, nnd then
said, " Sauncrs. I hue anithcr word to say till ye. Did
the gudowifc hire ye by tho day's darg or by thc job ?"
"Tho day's darg was our agreeing, maister." "Then,
on tho whole, Sauuers, I think yo maun justas wcel gae
back to whistling bonnie Moggie Lauder."

title: REFLECTIONS.
content:
REFLECTIONS.
I AM up, once more, like a pheonix from his
ashes,
To talk about wild things, such as carbines and
sashes.
A friend indeed is very good, should he never
net with spite;
I'm mv very greatest enemy, for lately I've been
""tight,"
About insolvency, indeed, wo havo got our
share;
" Any honest boys from homo," how they blink
nnd swear.
The honest-minded publican, who keeps suoh
good Martell?
But what's tho use of all this, while others
spurious sell?
Periodically I take'a glass, and givo ono kindly
too ;
If "ticking" be tho order, it's Ibero they'll
tickle you.
It's ruminating " bosh" to talk about our bills j
I luugh, indeed, good humorcdly, at how it acts
in tills.
Tho Maryborough troopers are dressed so nico
in blue,
Strong hearts within bosoms though?this ought
surely do,
With good sabres and carbines?but never speak
of " sacks."
" Charge bo tho cry," with spurs applied?its
then you'll gooso the blacks.
Tho " blacks," indeed, aro pretty fair, tho best
of the soil,
Though never yet wero bred on tho lovely plains
of Boyle.
Yot spouters talk out freely, in corners very
brief,
"Put your nags in running motion; they'll
frighten any thief I"
Mr. Brown, bo easy, boy, and nover talk of
"four;"
For among such humble units ono might givo a
sore.
Discuss your matters freely, avoid your witty
puns ;
Off! you go " shuogueing," and livo on colonial
buns.
Jonms-Y Raw.

title: FROM MY WINDOW.
content:
FROM MY WINDOW.
Before the night had closed the latest flower
I drew the blind aside, and saw the world
Lay sleeping. 'Twas so still, till three half-curled
Red rose-leaves fluttered in a show'r
perfumed
From out their sleep-locked, moonlight-circled bower
. Athwart tho casement on ray scattered books.
A bird peeped 'neath tho eaves with frightened
looks—
So small a sound is heard at this still hoar.
The moon, lust stealing from a broken cloud,
Half-slow as if 'twere k>tb to leave its shroud,
Shone on a lattice clothed in sleeping flow'rs
That sparkled in their dreams with tender sbow'rs
Down-dropt from heav'n on their ethereal blue,
To keep them fresh to waken with the dew.

title: SUNDAY READING.
content:
SUNDAY READING.
The Psalm of Time.
In our childhood's roveroat reading of the ancien
Hook of Book?),
How wo pictured Abraham watching o'er hi
flookH by Syria's brook«,
And our fancy fondly lingered iu that past ou
soul rovoieB,
When man's life was nursed by nature inti
patriarchal years :
Whon the field, the forge, the study, claimed n>
life-exhausting toil,
And the sons of men lived simply-from thi
kindly-natured soil.
Growing hore a grove of dato palms, garnering
theie a litt lo grain,
. Faring frugal, sleeping soundly, living lives thal
laughed at pain.
Strong and active, tough and tireless, opei
hearted kindly souled,
Such as poets love to picture iu the far off ago 01
gold -
When the rainbow-pinioned seraphs fount
another heaven on earth,'
As they lived aud loved enraptured with theil
brides of mortal birch.
Lo ! with earliest dewy morning, see the shep
herd-king arise,
Shaking slumber from his eyelids, gazing on the
brightening skies,
Where the fading stars shine fainter, as the
jewelled robo of night
Glides from off^orcation'a shoulders, blushing
with tho kira of light.
His, the glorious tabernacle, whonce hi3 prayers
could freely risc
All tho mountains for his altar ! -for his templo,
all the skies !
Where the wandering winds of Heaven cadenced
every song of praise,
And, with God's cathedral round him, all his
week was Sabbath days.
Thou, the human heart was reverent I for
mankind believed its creeds :
Now the ancient faiths wail feebly, lest a
younger ono sucoeeds.
But true faith can never altor-born on high
and teaching good
Which behoves in God the Father, and Christ's
human brotherhood.
As the clouds which darken Heaven burst in
storms to clear its skies,
Sci forms change, but Faith survives them-for
- Religion never dies !
Though tho oity's toil-worn worker, shut from
Nature's hnalthior sod.
Feels tho squalid suffering round Mm almost shako bis
faith iu God !
For his presout seems so dreary, with its weary gas-lit
toil,
Whilst his soul and body sicken, shut from earth's free
air aud soil.
Woe the hurry ! woo tho worry ! woo tho selfish, strug
gling strife :
Which this bastard cultivation foroos on our doily life.
Woo the long bard hours of labour, making e'en it«
thought abhorred,
Where the master fears his servant, and tho servani
hates his lord.
Seo tho drunkard ! see tho outoast ! soe the pauper
soe the gaol !
Hoar tho work-worn weakly murmur-does not civiliza
tion fail?
No ! with earnest tongue saya Wisdom-oven on eartl
God's justified
Wore the world to grow no bettor Christ had vainlj
lived and died !
Wiser sense shall mould man's labour to a handmaid
fair of health
Loftier faith and tonderer conscience bid him from his
hoarded wealth
Feed tho school to starve the prison-raze the hovel,
build tho home,'
Lighten labour, lift the lowly, teaoh the fallen hope to
come
Give to each his birthright, knowledge -wisdom follows,
which shall teach
Universal need of virtue, and tho equal rights of each ;
Showing all this truth-that trouble, pain and wrong,
and pestilence, .
Spring alone from vice olid folly-not from God's good
providence !
Tko dawn of brighter days is breaking slowly o'er life's
twilight sea,
Every earnest heart awaking to tho glories yofc to bo.
When its sunburst clnavos tho darkness which divides
man'B brotherhood,
Showing tho enlightened natious-" to bo wiso ia to bc
good"
Cultured man is man tho Christian ! seeking good and
shunning criino !
And, when Cb.rint.hui teaching triumphs, earth shall seo
its golden primo.
Mightier mimls than ours surround us, moulding all our
puny plans
To the wide world's larger welfare, thwarting oft tho
leanor man's.
Like tho ruin clouds drifting seaward, wasting freshness
o'or the main,
So full many a soul strong-purposod, scorns to livo its
lifo in vain.
But . as evory straggling sunbeam works God's will
through unknown space,
So niAti'o loneliest, scattered efforts, blend nt last to
help his rn co !
? Egypt's pyramids are trophies built by nameless slaves,
whoao lives
Aro. forgotten, yet not vainly died they whilst their
work survives 1
Shall I labour1, saith tho selfish, for a harvest not my
own ?
Saith tho nobler, I will do so : I or time will reap
what's novvn.
Therefore, fellow-workers, faint not, though tho ond wo
may not soo.
Every worthy thought or action helps to mould futu
rity.
For we'ro fathers of tba future, as wo'ro children of tho
past
Let us leavo this generation hotter thnn we found tho
last.
Yes, bo hopeful ! oh my brothers ! for tho storm pro
cedes tho shine,
Through tho clouds of darkness roll we on today-dawns
moró divino.
Seo tho cities of the futuro ! groves and gardens, domes
and towers,
Whore each homo's a freomnn's palace, graced with
pictures, fountains, flowers.
Where tho loftiest art makes lovely all life's lowliest
common needs,
And wiso soieuau, widoly-workinrr, from lifo'a refuse all
lifo feeds,
Theu tho world shall thrill with music, aa each day's ;
short labours ceuso.
And the setting suns shine gladly over universal penoe.
That which has been may again be, and as knowledge
makes all wise,
Love shall change this ravaged Eden to a newer para
dise, i
Where Eve's daughters, truor-hearted, grown to perfect
womanhood,
Prove, that every outward beauty is reflooted inner
good.
I Lovely as are little ohildron in their infancy's first
yoarB,
Yet with childhood's growth thoy alter-beauty fades
or disappears
-For a season ! till, Uko sunrise, blushing through tho
morning skies,
Youth gains freshor charms and fairer-softer looks and
brighter oyes
Gathering graceful strength and figure, till tho soul
perfected form
Is as fairer than the infant's, as the butterfly its worm.
Lo I tho vineyard's purple cluster* burst with juices
cool and sweet
Crush them in the wine-press, soe them foam with
swelling froth and heat.
For a season, till tho earth-born particles are purified,
And the sun-born spirit sparkles-clearer than tho
vine's red tide.
So, tho curront of creation like an eddying river flows,
Though awhile tho stream may falter, yet it wider,
stronger grows.
E'en tho very stars of hoavon somotimes seem to back
ward stray,
Yet through countless ages each ono circles on ita cor
tain way,
Wiser grows tho world and better, and tho growing
years shall find
That tho sonnons of the Saviour sway tho souls of all
mankind.
For the lowering love of luoro, oaauged shall grow to
lovo for worth ;
And the commonwealth of nations-baptized to abettor
birth
Scorning ' wrong, and selfish struggles, iu a rivalry of
good
Livo through long and golden ages, linked in loving
brotherhood.
ll. A.
Sydney, September. 1SG7.

title: LITERATURE
content:
LITERATURE
Original Poetry.
The Plaint of a Marechal Niel
Rose.
ARCHIBALD BIRT.
I came to my birth when the beautiful Earth
Awoke on a morning in May,
And I nodded the Moon and the Stars "Good-night
As the dawn broke over the Bay.
I looked at tbe Sun rising over the sea.
And, as he wont high and moro high,
I wondered if he would look down at me
From his home in the fathomless sky.
And he saw me, and stooped, and pressed a warm kiss
On my heart as it surged with its love;
While I gloried to think that now 1 was hi.
Who ruled all the World from above.
But my petal oheeks blushed at the warmth of hit
touch,
And my sight for a moment went dim
As I thought of tho kiss which to me meant to much—
80 much, yet so little to him.
And I hang my bead as the great king sped
On his way, tflj he went to his rest;
And sadly I watched him descend to his bed
In tbe gold-burnished cloud, of tbe west.
But I saw him again, gleaming over the main.
As he warmed me once moro with tbe touch
Which to him meant so little, the thought cam. with
Sain—
tie 1 to me to much. -
Then there came a koea thrab shooting up to my
heart, . ■ * .
And I knew that asm again h
Would I hang on tbe tree bis beauty to see,
Tossed by th. broeze and bathed by the rain.
But now I am pressed to a fair woman's breast,
I can hear bar heart beating low,
And I feel her soft breath as I wait for my death-
Come qulckl sinoe it most be so,
But I am content, though my life is all spent,
My petal cheeks blush as I die.
My king's touch has blest me, fair hands have oarested
me;
I am dying away from God's sky,
Southport.

title: HELP FRANCE.
content:
IIELP FRANCE.
O sitios of bhrnlng graclousnesa.
To-day your golden glance
Throw warm upon the hoarts that elvo
To Franco.
South Wind, spread wide tbo tender wings
Of Charity's sweet chance.
And in remotest corner breatho
For Fiauco.
In homestead sad and ruined town
Thot mar her fair expanse,
Lot Southern benediction beal
Brav, o Fiance.
Tain heroes, patient women, there,
Tbo Hcarrod of war's red lance;
And little chlldron, weeping, pray.
Help France I
Help Franco, who helps a world to nave,
Lot gratitude onhanco
All that our love could ever give.
Great France.
B. BEAUFILS LAMB.

title: Great Hartley.
content:
iy; Great Hartley.
A etan ter on the mona tain-top-a walk
Down the grim pass to the secluded yale
Surrounded with a precipice ooronal
A bracing gallop mingled with blithe talk,
As wo passed by the shoulder of Mount York,
And we are at Great Hartley. Once the dale
Was all alive with toam and coach of mail :
And church and courthouse still attest the work
Which erst was done there. Now tho wayside Bomb
Has English cherry, quinoe and apple tree
Gleaming bosido the sombre native Borub,
Ann heaps of stones where ohimneys used to be,
A type of many a thing which once was fair
Bv modern progress left behind and bare.
DOUGLAS B. W. SLADEN.

title: Review.
content:
Review.
PUNCH STAFF PAPERIS. A collection of tales, sketches,
'&c, in prose and verse, by the members of tho staff
of Sydney Punch. Gordon and Gotch.
Tho authors of this really handsome volume, believe
1 apparently in the motto that " union is strength." At
, any rate they have chosen to tempt their literary fate
. 'in company, and upon the whole a very goodly company
; thoy aro. Somo of thom ore men whose names as public
writers aro already familiar ; most of thom, we believe,
looking to their pons and their wit3 for a livelihood,
i Critics themselves, they invite criticism, and in common
courtesy to their professional position as men of letters
must oxpoct to be tried by a somewhat higher standard
1 than if merely so mauy literary neophytes.
PUNCH STAFF PAPERS is tho outcome of a band of
s literary brothers, who with a good deal to say for them
I selves havo hitherto had but small chanco of saying it.
. In their own words the literary man in Australia " has
1 littlo or no opportunity of associating himself with his
work, und is thus in a great measure debarred from
attaining that notoriety which is the first step on tho
ladder of faino aud fortuno." Tho complaint is no
doubt quite true, though whether the inability of
the local literary mau to identify himself with
1 his own work has always been to disadvantage
may possibly bo doubted. To bo appreciated of
course, ono mush bo known, but ifc by no means
follows that to bo known must always moan to bo ap
preciated. Begarding, however, this joint production
1 of their several unappreciated pons as au effort to
attain that important " first stop," wo may say at onco
that if fame and fortune are to be reachod by a series of
such steps, the Punch staff may be congratulated on
their prospects. With so much varied ability at com
' maud, abundant ' brains, an accomplished artist, an
accommodating printer, and it is to bo hopod an ap
preciative public, there is no reason why a succossion
of similar handsome volumes should uot follow each
other with tho regularity of an English monthly, nnd
thus tho ladder be mounted and fame's tall templo
gained within, say, tho next twelvemonths. Wo are
ufrnid, though, that most of these plucky aspirants for
literary honour and reward have a longer way before
them. Tho/are clevor, no doubt, but they are also
somewhat crudo-gems, possibly, yet dostmcd to glitter
in tho front of Australia's literary diadem, but just now
decidedly in the rough, requiriug much patient cutting
and polishing befuro the needful lustre is likely to bo
developed. It will not do, however, as ono of the best
papors in tho book reminds us, to " despise the day of
small things," and wo havo certainly no intention of
depreciating tho work of authors who if not a;l or any
of them geniuses, are at least tho nearest approach to
tho genuine article that tho country seems at pre
sent to possoss. The modesty indeed of the
writers - for nothing could well bo milder than
their protonsions, as set forth in tho unas
suming preface--should be itself sufficient protection
against anything like severity of criticism Not only is
their calling, tho production of light reading, defined as
a" profitless pursuit," but tho book itself is described
ns only a fair snmple of tho " average work" of " liter
ary hacke," poor and unappreciated because unknown.
Gentlemen who so characterise themselves and their labors
would deserve to be tenderly treated, even were there
far greater ground to treat them otherwise than the
very little there happily is. Thoy have at least done
their best to vindicate their position as local men of
letters, and have given tho public an excellent opportu
nity^ improving their taste, aud in the matter of ap
preciation of local talent, mending their ways, which we
shall bo delighted to hear has been as largely used as it
certainly deserves to be.
Perhaps the first thing to strike a reader of tho new
book as somewhat remarkable will be that, tho produc
tion of professed Punch writers, thero should be in it
so vei-y litttlo Punch. Of humour, indeed, there is abund
ance, but of tho witty play of fan and fancy, the jokes
and the gibes that one is apt to associate with tho laugh
ing philosopher of tho hump, thero is little enough"
Perhaps the authors were anxious to show that though
Punch contributors, they were something more than
mero jokers, in which case their success ? has certainly
been complete. _ Perhaps " fun and fancy" are expensivo
items scarcoly included in tho average work of a local
" literary hack." We must except, however, in this
case tho charming verses of Mr. M'Crae, of Melbourne
entitled tho Aubergo, whero thero is certainly plenty
of both. Such linea as these are far above tho " average
work" of the rhymesters who do duty in our local
literature aa poets :
THE AUBERG-«.
SouvEian OF NORMANDS.-.
I love a tavern old, wherein
To.pass a night or so-no sin,
Altho"tis pleasant
And drink, enjoying well-earned ease.
Before I taste my Switzer cheese.
Macon with pheasant 1
.Por mn the brilliant bougies burn,
To mo the omelette comes in turn
With brandy blazing!
Whilst on the hearth 'twe«n iron dogs,
Roars up the ruddy fire of log«.
With glow amazing !
In snob a cosy nook can I
Tile world and time aud care defy,
And eat my penr;
And quaff my Ohab'lis while I think
Of Austral vintages and drink
My petit verre 1
The softest, blandest, eau dc vie,
Whose warmth soon enters into me
My heart to soften ;
And cafe noir in tiny sips,
As the cigar forsakes my lips
Slow and not often. ,
j Thero is some fun, too, of the practical joke order, in
I Mr. Moser's well told story of the Budgeree School Con
cert, and there ia a good deal of capital fun and fancy
too, in Mr. Grosvenor Bunster's grotesque yarn of
" Kai Tamaruo and the Devil." Maigre a few unplea
sant mannerisms, Mr. Bunster is an excellent atory
teller. If hjs humour is occasionally a little rough, it
is always hearty and genuine, and if his style sometimes
moro than verges upon the vulgar it is generally fresh
and vigorous as a breeze at Manly But he should avoid
sentiment and sweet-hearts, whether of "long ago" or of
yesterday, and especially aweet-hearts in verse.
Women aro " kittle-cattle" nlwaya, but an old flame that
won't go out, bnt on the contrary grows stronger and
stronger still, '"as yearby year doth pass away," must be
a nuisance for a gentleman to carry about with him,
especially if involving tho necessity of au occasional tri
buto of verso to the memory of old kisses. Mr. Bunster's
verses to his " Sweet-heart long ago" are as good as that
sort of thing usually is when middle-aired gentlemen get
into such a sentimental f ramo of mind as suggests such
profound reflections ns these : -
Por if life's cares and changes mark
Their stern prints on tho fae«, />'
Tho loving heart is armour proof
Against Time's swiftest race.
« And e'en when old, as day by day, *
Weall of us must grow,
Iiotnembrance keeps ns youthful yet
My sweet-heart long ugo.
He is moro at home when the sentimental mood lias
passed away, and ho gets back into thc moro congenial
atmosphere of a " Roundabout Paper," and slashes
roundly the prevailing fashion of the period-cant.
That he doesn't mince matters maybe judged from the
following, which ia also a fair specimen of his literary
style :
The church I spoke of is a most beautiful edifice. It is fur
I nished most comfortably. In hot weather it is as cool as a
cellar, in cold weather it is carefully warmed. I should say
that soma thousands of pounds have been spent on it. Wor
ship in sucha church must be really a luxury But how to
get away from this ? The money spent upon this und other
I ohurehc'3 might have saved many a poor wretch from death or
I crime; reared manya youngster in worldly respectability.
It. strikes me that tho founder of Christianity did not ask for
! such luxurious churches. Ho was content with God's ohurch
-the hill-tops, the woods, tho mountain-side, the plain, were
his cathedrals; thu smile of nature, the green {award, the fra
grant flowers, the Atting furniture. And when at his ieet
thero gathered the rich and poor, tho rugs of the one were as
proper in his sight as the rich robes of the other. Ask an ill
dressed man or woman why they don't go to church nnd the
answer is, in tho trne servility ot cant, " I'm too shabby."
And the ministers and their congregations endorse this cant,
so that it coinés to pass if a poor dovil can never raiso a good
coat to worship in lie stands a fair chinee of damnation. All
because of tho c"at ! It ia wonderfuljhow those, small matters
tull on our destinies.
If this sounds to people with good coats a little
like the reasoning of Bohemia-well, wo suppose tho
writer would say, that is cunt agnin. Mr. Harold Ste
phen is, wo believe, a late acquisition to the Sydney press
and ho promises to bo a good one. Nothing bettor inuits
way has been published boro for years than his amusing
burlesque legetid of Prague, Hans Von Schloffonbachs,
and ono is left to wonder why a writer who can bo so
funny in prose should think it worth bia whilo to be so
funereal in verso. His blank verse effort "My Dream"
is certainly ti powerful productioutjiu one sense, but
it is not .a pleasant sense. Tho nightmare is no doubt
a sutiieiontly disagreeable experience, but if afflicted
with it the last thing a really humano mun would think
of doiucr would bo to try to give it to other people
ThiH one lapse into something very liko bathos is tho
more to be regretted as most of Mr. Stephen's other
poetical productions are airy and graceful enough.
Blank vorse, however, seems to bo rather a favourito
exorcise with the Punch staff, no less than four of tho
contributors having tried their hands at it, ono of them
in two placea. In " Basil Moss." Mr. Henry Kendall
recounts with terrible reality, tho struggles of aman of
genius caught iu tho grip.of tho demon Iutemperauce :
A story shining with a woman's love ! .
Ami who that knows that love can ever donbe
How dear, divine, sublime a thing lt Is;
Po'- while the talo of Basil Mass was one
Not oluokfiied with those stark, witauio sins
Which call tor superhuman sacrifiée,
tBt.ilI from the records ol' the world's sad lifo
This great, sweet, gladdening fact ut length we've learneu
ThTo's nota depth to which a man can fall.
No slough of crime in which such one can lie.
Stoned with the scorn ai.d curses of hie kind,
Hut that Hoiwo tender woman can bo found
To love and shield him still.
Unfortunately for tho poor women, very often, that is toe
true; but Mr. Kendall makes his touching talo of Basil
Moss" end happily with the reformation of tho drunken
gonius and the assurance : -
That Love, that sweet »uthentio messenger
Prom God, «an never fail while there is lett
Within tho fallen one a single pulse
Of what the angels call Immunity.
Tho worst of "it is ' tHat," so often, that " pulso" has
stopped.

title: The Fleet Sails
content:
The Fleet Sails
ByLydiaM.D. O'Neil
GOODBYE, Brisbane ! Best regards to all!
It you.' re lucky, we shall write you from the nearest port of call.
We spent our money freely and we had a lovely time —
Eiaht hell* and all's well ? liiten tn 'em chime ! *
When we're rolling down the river, when We're steaming out to tea,
When we're sliding past the mangroves thick and green,
We'll be thinking of the races, and the pretty frocks and faces,
And of all the pleasant places we have seen.
Goodbye, Brisbane ! You've done ? the Navy proud,
And we'll be glad to call again next year if we're allowed.
Your Show was ' really charming and we had a gorgeous fling. ''
Eight bells and all's well — listen to 'em ring ! '
When we're painting up the iron-work and polishing the brass, *
We'll be thinking, ewrt/ lonely sailor-lad,
Of the whispers and the glances and tkt kisses and the dances, . ,
Aad tht ftitndihipt aed tomancu tbat W* badl '?

title: Poetry.
content:
Poetry.
Little Bessie,
AND THE WAY IN WHICH SHE FELL ASLEEP.
HUG me closer, claser, mother,
Put your arms around me tight;
I am cold and tired, mother,
And I feel so strange to-night;
Something hurt* me hen, dear mother,
Like a atone upon my brewt;
Oh, I wonder, wonder, mother,
Why it is I cannot rest.
All day Ion; while yon were working,
As I lay npon my bed,
I wm trying to be patieut.
And to think of what yon said ;
How the kind and bleaaed Jesu*
Lores His lambs to watch and keep ;
And I wished He'd come and take me
In His arms, that I might sleep.
Just before the lamp was lighted,
Just before the children came,
While the room was very quiet,
I heard someone call my name.
And at once the window ojiened :
In a field where lambs and sheep—
Borne from ont a brjok were drinking,
Some were lying fast asleep.
Bnt I could not see the Savionr, •
Though I strained my eyes to see ;
.And I wondered if He saw me,
Would He »]>eak to such as me?
In a moment I was looking
On a world *o bright and fair,
Which was full of little children,
And they seemed so liappy theie t
They were singing, oh, so sweetly !
Sweeter songs 1 never heard !
They were singing sweeter, mother,
Than enn »iug our yellow bird,
And while I my breath was holding,
One ao bright upon me smiled;
And I knew it must, be Jesus,
When he »nid, " O.me here, my child !
Come up here, my little Bessie
Come up here uinl live with me,
Where the children never suffer.
But are happier than you see!"
Then I thought of all you told me
Of that bright and hapity land ;
I was going when you called me,
When you came and kissed my hand.
And at Srrt I felt bo sorry
You bad called me !—I would go—
Oh ! to sleep, and never suiier !
Mother, dois't be crying so !
Hug me closer, closer, mother,
Put your anna around me tight;
Oh ! how much I love you, mother,
Uitt I feel so strange to-night!"
And the mother pressed her closer
To her over-burdened bresiKt ;
On the heart so near t» breaking,
Lay the heart to near its rest.
At the solemn hour of midnight,
In the darkness, calm and deep,
Lying on her mother's bosom,
Little Bessie fell ;u>leep !
The Farewell Business.—An old man up in
Connecticut had a poor cranky bit of a wife,
who regularly once a week got up in the night
and invited the family to see her die. She gave
away her things, spoke her last words, made her
peace with heaven, and then about 8 she got up
in the usual way and disappointed everybody by
going at her household duties as if nothing had
happened. The oK man got sick of it finally, '
and went out and got a coffin, a real nice cash
mere shroud, a wreath of immortelles with
" Farewell, Mary Ann," worked in, and a hand
ful of silver-plated screws. Laying the screw
driver beside the collection, he invited her to
just holler " die" once more. "Do it," said he,
" and in you go, and this farewell business is
over." Mary Ann is at this moment baking
buckwheat cakes for a large and admiring
family, while they dry apples in the coffin up in
the garret
Theue is a Connecticut widower who declares
that nothing reminds him of his poor dear wife
so much as to live within earshot of a sawmill
duriug a busy season.
