TO THE ELECTORS OF CENTRAL
. CDMBIïBLAND.
GENTLEMEN,-At tho insUcco of an influential
deputation of electois, 1 beg to announce myself a can-
didate for your suffrages at the approaching tkctieo.
Identified with tho colony at large, and having a
personal stake in its prosperity and welfare, 1 feel that
I may with some confidence lay claim to your Bupport,
provided my political views aro in accordance with
those of the constituency.
1 avow myself a warm supporter of the Publie
Schools Act, conceiving that tho Ministry that intro
duced it and the Aesetnlly that | neted it uro enti ltd
to the especial thanks of tho community for thc gt. ut
benefits it has conferred oa the people cf th« colony.
The question of State-aid 1 look up n as finally
settled it; a manner equit-iblo and just to'll parties
ooneerned and my vote ihitll never ba given to re-open
any discussion referring thereto.
KotrenohmeHt I regard an a question nf ergent im-
portance tu the present condition of our rimmers, but
one must bo token that in making reductions we do
not impair th» efficiency of tho public sorvioe.
I shall have suoh frequent opportunities of meeting
you during my canvass, ana of expounding my views
on various other subjeets on which you may desire to
be informed, that I am unsolved from the necessity of
extending my prisent «ddress.
I have the honor to be, Gentlemen,
Yours obediently,
S»MUliL LYONS.
Parramatta, 27th November, 1868.
TO THE ELECTORS OF CENTRAL
CUMBERLAND.
GENTLEMEN,-Since the publication of my address ta
you, I lind that there aro two Candidates for your
suffrages - one onerpotically supported hythe late, and
the other by the present Government; and as I am
not a party man I am unwilling to contest against an
influence so powerful as either. Therefore, and ucoauao
it is tho general belief that a dissolution of Parliament
will soon take pla:o, I have determined to withdraw
from tho content. Thanking you for the many offen
of support which have been kindly tendered.
I am. Gentlemen, your obedient servant,
A. H. M CULLOCH.
P
HILIP M'CARROLL, PITT-STREET.
M'OABROLL'S not been long in getting in supplies,
To stop both beef and mutton making any further
rise ;
It waa very hard on people for many, weeks non post,
But seo tho prices blown b.-lovr-ho's brought them
down at last.
Tho timos are' bad enough ; men working at a trade
Find labour v.-ty hatd to get, and then but poorly piid.
The rate of -wages ruling now, foed ought at least be
ohesp,
A pair of honda must find it hard a family to keep.
M'OARBOLL always does his best in every way he
can
To smooth the road that lies before tho honest labour
¡ag man;
This week: he's lowered the prices, they'll all be glad to
Lee,
Nor is there one amongst thom that feels more glad
than he.
What is there can be.better, or what caji do more good,
Than keeping down the prices of a leading thing of
food T
It choers tho heart of labonr, makes mind and bod;
?trong,
With plenty beef a man oan work, he finds no day toe
long.
In this M'OABROLL'S done his part through mun;
years-of trade.
Tho' well he knows by doing so the enemies he made.

title: THE POETS' CORNER.
content:
THE POETS' CORNER.
The Mountain Splitter.
He works in the glen where the waratah grows,
And the gums and the ashes are tall,
'Neath cliffs that re-echo the sound of his blows
When the wedges leap in from the mall.
He comes of a hardy old immigrant race ;
And he feels not the rain or the "drouth."
His sinews are tougher than wire ; and his face
Has been tann'd by the sun of the south.
Now doom'd to be shorn of its glory at last
Is the stately old tree he attacks ;
Its moments of life he is numbering fast
With the keen steady strokes of his axe.
Loud cracks at the butt ; and the strong wood is
burst ;
And the splitter steps backward, and turns
His eyes to the boughs that move slowly at first
Ere they rush to their grave in the ferns.
He strips off the bark with slight effort of strength
And stretches it out on the weeds,
And marks off the trunk with a measure the length
Of the rails or the palings he needs.
The teeth of his crosscut so truly are set
That it swings from his elbow at ease ;
And the song of the saw — I am hearing it yet —
Has the music of wind in the trees.
Strong blows on the wedge, and a rip and a tear,
And the log opens up to the butt ;
And, spreading around thro' the pure mountain air,
Is the scent of the wood newly cut.
A lover of comfort and cronies is he ;
And when the day's work is behind,
A fire, and a yarn, and pint of good tea,
At the hut of the splitter you'll find.
His custom is sought in the town by the range ;
For well to the future he looks :
His cheques in an instant the storekeepers change ;
And his name is the best on the books.
HENRY LAWSON.
Sydney ; April, 1889.

title: STANZAS.
content:
STANZAS.
O! do not think because I smile,
My bosom's free from sorrow,
The flower that blows to day, awhile,
May wither e'er to morrow.
The brightest joys that life adorn,
May feel misfortune's hour;
And e'en the blushes of the morn,
Be followed with a shower.
The bud of hope may blossom fair,
But blighted droop and languish;
And pleasure's eye grow dim with care
And love be lost in anguish.
Then do not think because I smile,
My bosom's free from sorrow;
For hope to-day, blows awhile,
And wither ere to morrow.

title: LADIES.
content:
LADIE S.
Make ye cages and not nets,
Ladies, ladies;
To keep, not win, weave amulets,
Ladies.
For, when youv'e caught the wayward bird
With sweeter look and honey'd word,
Forget not then each playful wile,
Nor careless dress, nor careless smile,
Or you will lose him,
Ladies.
Make ye cages and not nets,
Ladies, ladies;
The fondest heart sometimes forgets
Ladies.
Have ye not varied ways to charm him,
Or loving words and means to calm him,
Soon, soon your bird will wing the air
And find a bosom kind elsewhere
Will try to keep him,
Ladies.
Make ye cages and not nets,
Ladies, ladies,
And save a world of vain regrets.
Ladies.
For let but once the cord decay,
Be ever dull from day to day,
Be all the wife, the mistress none.
Be never as you first begun,
Youv'e cut the fetters,
Ladies.
Make ye cages and not nets,
Ladies, ladies;
Love's sun 'mid clouds too often sets.
Ladies.
Hope's dawn uplifts its joyous head,
And life looks all one flower bed;
There floats one little cloud above.
The heaven of your early love,
Which tells a tempest,
Ladies.
Make ye cages and not nets,
Ladies, ladies;
Affection claims in full its debts
Ladies.
The sweetest Paradise which blooms
Is home enriched by Truth's perfumes :
O ! never let the serpent breath
Of doubting chill its charm to death-—
'Twill no more blossom,
Ladies.
Make ye cages and not nets,
Ladies, ladies;
Too oft your charming ways are jets
Ladies,
Which, like the trees the fountain throws,
Fall earthward while it brighest glows;
Be proud to win a manly heart
Be prouder of that nobler part,
To try and keep it,
Ladies.
Make ye cages and not nets,
Ladies, ladies;
The tether'd bird for ever frets,
Ladies!
Sweets; then be kind, be varied, gay,
Nor smile, nor sigh, nor weep alway;
Put not your wish, to please asleep,
And you the wildest bird will keep,
And never lose him,
Ladies.
W. J. R.

title: Queensland To Britain
content:
Queensland
To
Britain
[These verses were contributed to 'The
Queenslander'. by . GEORGE ESSEX
EVANS, in May 1901, to commemorate
the visit of the Duke and Duchess of
Cornwall and York.]
White Rose of England,
White flower of May,
These lands of Summer domed by softer
blue
' Are Halls of Welcome, and not lets thy
home '
Than the grey North with- frontiers set
in foam. ?? ' :
'Tic from her heart that Queensland
sends to-day .??-
This Austral song to Britain and to you.
-.'?'- ?.'.?.? * '- ? ??«.,?.,
Britain, Mother of Nations,
Maker of days like these,
Steeled in thine ocean-fortress.
Walled by the swinging seas.
Hark, as ' the welcome thunders!
Hark, as the shout goes forth!. ]'
The heart of the South is singing—
'Remember the North!'
Grey on the yellow hummock,
Grim on the gaunt hillside.
Glistening white in the noontide light.
Over the desert wide —
Bones of the brave ye lent me
Ere ever my youth was' strong!
Britain, Mother of Nations,
This is my battle song.
They dreamt of the English meadows,
And the cool of the leafy lanes,
They died in my central desert.
They died on my western plains —
Isles in the Northern water.
Blood of your best was mine!
Swords of the South have answerc'3—
'Blood of our best is thine.'
O, Shadows of Shattered Empires!
O, Sceptres, low in the dust!
Their might is a broken sabre
Who hold not their power on trus*
Fighting the great world's battles.
Forward for Freedom then,
Britain, Mother of Nations!
Britain, Maker of Mm!

title: BODALLA.
content:
BODALLA.
A GLIMPSE oi? ENGLAND AMID AUSTRALIAN HILLS.
Amid the range tliat nears the southern coast
Bodalla lies-a smiling valley green
So green that to home-loving eyes it seems
E'en like n quiet dream of England, hid
And nestled in the wild Australian hills.
There gleam tho still blue lake and winding stream.
The golden corn-fields and the sunny slope ;
While here and there are cottage homes and farms,
With browsing herds in clover pastures fed ;
And furrowed land o'er which the plough has passed,
In winter readiness for English seed
That here unconscious of an allen soil,
With old-world freshness still will spring and grow.
The very air of all this peaceful land
Is soft and still, for sheltering mountains rise
And, glooming blue and dark with varying shade,
Shut out the blighting winds, that restless blow
Yet cannot pass the tree-clad ramparts high ;
While all the moisture steaming from the earth
Held in, though rising, turns to dewy mist
And veils th' enclosing hills in sweet revenge.
Thus softly soothing all their rugged lines,
Deep'ning their shadows-adding richer glow.
And through alluvial flats tho Tuross winds.
At first a serpentining silver stream.
But widening with blue waters to the sea,
And overhung by blossoming wattles green ;
Or like a liquid pathway glancing broad
Between a solemn avenue of oaks
Swamp-oaks, with fibrous fir-like leaves that droop
Till dark reflections quiver in the deeps.
And thro' whoso cords the gentlest wind will sigh
With soft /Eolian sounds that lull the soul,
Yet stir its depths with longings vague and sweet.
A happy vale 1 that any man might love
To call his own and cherish to his heart !
See, in the midst, upon a rising slope
Beneath the shelter of the Bumbo Mount,
There gleams the homestead-gabled cottage white
With creeping vines and garden flowers bright ;
Wliile on one side stand gold-brown stacks of hay.
The dairy and surroundings of tho farm.
The clustering village of thc workers' homes,
The quick steam-engine and the blacksmith's forge.
Then in tile front, o'er mignonetted beds.
The eye looks on a meadow rich and broad.
Its glistening tints in double greenness shown
And thrown out by tho fringing ranges dark ;
While round tho holds the bending river flows
And almost makes an island of tho spot
Whicn seems so English-like, that wc could look
And half believe ourselves again at home.
Or think this were a memory taking form,
A reminiscence sweet, or waking dream !
Ah Comerang 1 shall I picturo thee at morn ?
While still the valley sleeps in robe of mist.
And lowing cows of varied hue and form
Thro' frosty fields are driven to the sheds
Where childish milkmaids, rosy-faced und bright,
"With skillful hands press out tile creamy milk.
Or shall I paint thee in the golden hues
Of evening light?- which e'er the sun has set,
Hoods all the fields with tinted radiance soft
And glances bright through lengthening shadows deep;
While in tho west the purpling mountains glow,
Or faintly redden with a parting blush
As day's king, ling'rlng o er his last good night,
Illumes tho heights o'er which his glory sinks.
Nay, there is still a sweeter, holier time 1
The sacred stillness of the Sunday morn,
When all the sounds of industry have ceased.
And labour's garments for a while put off,
The people answer to the echoing bell
That calls them to the work of prayer and praise.
Now, like a family gathered in tile hull
The homestead hall with church-like hangings deokt,
They listen to the words, and pray the prayers
That thousand brethren e'en aro lifting up
In distant churches, at the selfsame hour ;
And music sweet, and joyous hymns resound
In men's deep bass, and children's voices high
Rising, thro' country air so pure and shrill,,
To the Great Father of the fruitful earth, '
Comerang, Bodalla, May 30, 1372.
AUSTRALIE.
A "WHOLESALE house advertises : "Wanted-women
to sell on commission." Gals, there's your chance.
SENTENCE or DEATH.-Sentence of death was once
in this manner passed np on a notorious villian by *
popular New York judge, who desired to maintain and
extend his popularity, and was willing to conciliate the
freebooters as well as tho other classes of his acquaint
ances :-" Mr. Green you have been found guilty. Will
you have the kindness to stand up, Mr. Green ? I
really would not trouble you, Mr. Green, but such is
the established custom of tho court. As I was saying.
Mr. Green, you have just been found guilty hy the jury
Mr. Green, of-of-I bolievo you called it murder, Mr.
Foreniau of the jury ?--yes, murder. You will please
take notice, Mr. Green, that is the jury who find you
guilty ; not I, Mr. Green, I express no opinion on the
subject ; but I am compelled by the law-it's a mero
formality so far as I am concerned, Mr. Green-to sen
tence you to bo hung by thc uock till you aro dead
dead. At what time would it bo agreeable to you to bo
hung, Mr. Green?"

title: Charley.
content:
Charley.
F. MACKIE-GOODWIN.
Brisbane.
There is a gleam of summer sun
That glistens in our little home;
It fills the air with golden light,
And drives the gloom from every room
every room;
It makes the flower* of love spring up,
Aud Bweetly burdcuH un with joy ;
'Tfs but a littlo gleam of light—
'Tis but our little blue-eyed boy!
He's suuh a merry little man,
This white-haired blue-eyed boy of ours;
We caunot feel that life is dull,
Or lagsomti are the sunny hours,
"Whilist his untiring cherub feet
Go pattering e'er the cottage floor;
Or when his childish face uplift*
To greet his "papa" at tho door.
Ho may perchance, in years to come,
When in his lusty youthful pride,
Forget the ''mamma" he once loved,
And his 4I old governor" deride :
Still will his memory live with us,
When he was once our bright-eyed joy—
The one sweot gloam on life's dull roud
Will ever be our cherub boy!

title: Original Poetry.
content:
Original Poetry.
To the Editor of the Sydney Gazette.
Sir,
The insertion of the following original lines, in
your instructive and popular paper, will much
oblige
A CONSTANT READER.
AMSTERDAM.*
Written at Sea, January 31, 1830,
LONELY isle in solitude,
'Mid the ocean dark and rude;
Far from scenes of care and strife,
Busy world and earthly life;
Reft in some far ancient age,
By volcanic's fiery rage,
From the dark recess of waves,
(?) the hapless seamen's graves,
(?) then been rolling on
(?) when time begun.
Now with crag and lava graced,
Mantling o'er a barren waste,
Still a sterile spot appears,
Lonely as in former years;
Rudely decked with stony rock,
Proudly daring ocean's shock,
Should its fiercest tempests dare
All the strength of ocean war:
Now secure it safely stands
Far away from other lands,
(?) by its clayey red
(?) in wat'ry bed,
Where the sounding wild waves foam,
There was erst its olden home.
(?) on the crater's edge,
Now the sea-dash'd precipice,
Tells of former fiery days,
When the ocean-land in blaze
Was a bright and burning pile,
Not a sea, and scarce an isle;
Now the sea bird builds its nest,
Safe in solitude and rest,
In the rugged cliffs afar
From human reach in lofty scaur;
There its young secure are bred,
There its offspring safely fed,
Screaming their wild notes to the air,
They dwell in lone security there.
When the soul is ill at ease,
When delights all fail to please,
When the strength and power of art
Fail a solace to impart
To the wretched bleeding heart;
Then this lone and stilly place,
Destitute of every grace,
Would be hail'd as welcome spot
For the solitary's lot;
Where, secure from ill of man,
He could measure out his span,
Worshipping his Maker, far
From the din of worldly jar;
Still improving in the ways,
Thus his mighty Master please,
Then from earth to pass away,
Stilly, to the realms of day,
Bidding life a glad farewell,
Calm'd by high Religion's spell.
Lonely isle! I ne'er again
Shall view thee from the foaming main;
Ne'er climb thy rocks, or sea-fowl chase
Back to their rocky nestling place;
A stranger thro' the world I roam,
Without a resting place or home.
Far from thy cliffy sides the last
Remains of life will soon be past;
Yet the firm hopes of future bliss,
In bright abodes of happiness,
Do well atone for every strife,
And toil and care that darken life.
* Amsterdam, or St. Paul's, a small uninhabited island in
the Indian Ocean.
newspaper: The Sydney Gazette and New South Wales Advertiser

title: Original poetry.
content:
Original Poetry.
(FOR THE SYDNEY GAZETTE).
MY HARP.
In Imitation of the 1st Ode of Anacreon.
I SEIZED my harp, and changed each chord,
And vowed no more to sing of love;
I swept me o'er the strings and board,
And sounded Nature, War, and Jove;
But all I did, the truth to tell,
Was bound by some romantic spell.
I sung how Nature clothes the year
With flowers, and fruits, and swelling grain;
How burdened fields the peasants cheer,
And load the master's purse with gain;
How bursting cobs salute the eye,
And tell that harvest home's are nigh.
I sung how o'er each verdant field
The stately stalks their fruits supply;
How vallies richest pastures yield,
And deep in clover oxen lie:--
'Tis vain--no pleasing ditty flows;
I sound my theme in rounded prose.
I sung how peaches, pears, and vines,
Their fruits present most sweet to see;
Loquets, and limes, and nectarines,
And quinces load each bending tree:--
'Tis ail all in vain, for high or low ,
Or long or short, no numbers flow.
I changed my theme, and called to mind
The scenes of home, to wake my strain;
The falling stream, the scented wind,
The gurgling rill, the jocund plain,
The snowy cliffs, and misty isle,
Where groves, and towers, and turrets smile.
I swept the chords with wond'rous might,
And sounded floods, and rains, and hail,
When milkmaids crowd the fire by night,
And frozen milk bring home in pail:--
Of such, alas! 'tis vain to sing,
For love still sounds from every string.
I changed my strings, and trimmed my harp,
Resolved to sing of deeds of blood,
And words most sounding, fierce, and sharp,
Rolled from my tongue like rolling flood:
Of gun, drum, trumpet, pistol, pike,
I sung,--as none e'er heard the like:
But when I saw the crimson tide
Had dyed my hands with purple gore,
I said, "Such scenes I can't abide,
And will not--for a year,--or more."
"No, no!" said I, "if you do please,
"I'll bid good bye to scenes like these."
Once more I changed each sounding string,
And all my craft and skill applied,
And strove Minerva's praise to sing,
Her wisdom, and heroic pride;
Of Juno, too, I sung the praise,
And lived,--on Ceres,--many days.
Of Mars in awe I always stood,
His nodding plumes were not for me:
I knew he dealt in deeds of blood,
To friend and foe--or bond or free;
I always kept beyond his spear,
And thus my heart felt kindred fear.
Of Mercury, I fairly own,
I never touched my sounding lyre;
The rogues, with hearts as hard as stone,
That follow him, I don't admire;
For every sober man believes
That he, and they are--rogues and thieves.
Of him who wears the lion's skin,
Whose strength no mortal man can slay,
Whose club might serve as rolling pin
For Brobdignagian lads to play,
But who--oh shame to hearts of steel!--
Sat down,--and turned a spinning wheel!
--Of him who fiends and monsters smote,
And travelled earth's remotest bounds;
Now clothed in cap and petticoat,
Now covered o'er with scars and wounds:
--Of him, I say, I strove to sing,
But not a sound flew from the string.
At higher game my numbers flew;
I tried to sing of Father Jove,
But when his acts came in review,
I found them only acts of--love .
Alas! Alas! I'll snap the chord--
And break the keys--and burn the board,
"But first," says I, "let's sing awhile
"Of Venus, and her rosy son;
"One may at least an hour beguile,
"And, when 'tis past, then I am done:
"I feel my heart as mute and chill
"As marble bust or icy hill."
I swept the chords,--my fingers flew
O'er every string with force and fire;
"Why this," says I, "to me is new,
"But this is just what I desire.
"Let Nature, War, and Father Jove,
"Succumb to Venus, Grace, and Love."
But sure if these in one unite,
As they in Y------- do,
It must give more than pure delight
To sing of her and Venus too:
For shape, and youth, and form, and air,
And soul, denote perfection there.
Well; since the kindred fates decree
A destiny so far above
The one that Nature formed for me,
I'll teach my harp the songs of love:
If others blame my voice, why then--
I'll think them less--or more--than men.
Anambaba, February, 1829.
M.
newspaper: The Sydney Gazette and New South Wales Advertiser

title: POEMS BY CHARLES HARPUR.
content:
POEMS BY CHARLES HARPUR.
XXXVI.
STANZAS.
Dear Henry, forbear to complain
That my Muse so much singeth of Love,
Since ever employed in like strain
Are the fire-winged Seraphs above.
In Freedom's high praises, aloft
I will soar-I will thunder at Wrong !
But still let me sweeten more oft
With the manna of Beauty my song.
And what is there under the skies
So complete for the voice of the Muse,
When gracious, as beautiful eyes,
And young cheeks with their rosiate hues ?
And lips that as twin cherries smile,
Breathing balm like an Indian Spring ;
And all these expressive the while
Of the exquisite Spirit I sing?
And though these should fade, being crost,
Then the more our remembrance should claim,
The love-dreaming Girl that was lost
In the measureless strength of her flame.
Then never again disapprove
Of the passionate Lay ! Were it wrong,
Would the Stars sing together of love,
And the Angels rejoice in their song?
XXXVII.
THE TERRORS OF BEAUTY.
Thy fairy feet, thy sylphic waist,
And those twin innocents, as they
Fill up like doves whose nestward haste
Had flurried them ; those lips that play
Apart so clovenly and rich;
Those pinky cheeks, and, thou sweet Witch,
Those eyes the loveliest in the world,
And that fair forehead overcurled
With tresses in their darkness bright,
Like darkness of a starry night;
All fill me with such sweet dismay,
That still, for looking though the more
In love,-for Love I've less to say
Than when I looked before.
newspaper: The Maitland Mercury and Hunter River General Advertiser

title: THE POETS' CORNER.
content:
THE POETS' CORNER.
Resignation.
Kb ; I care not for gladness-I have Been my god of
day,
Which-a fool and in my folly-I had thought would
shine for aye,
On a fool and on his folly I had thought for aye would
shine,
T have seen its downward passage, leaving me and
leaving mino;
And I've known the awful terror at the fading of the
light,
Known the utter, utter blackness at the coming of
the night.
Nay ! mine eyes are used to darkness ; they would
illy bear the day ;
Leave me in my realm of shadows, where at length
I've used to stay.
Long and dreary was the pathway leading to this
dull content ;
And I dare not tread it over, now the agony is
spent,
Bare no moro to snatch at pleasure, fearing still the
loser's pain,
Nor, for dread of tho awaking, tempt the glorious
dreams again.

title: Notes for town and Country
content:
^7
Notes for town and Country
pur ON POLE BY TANTALUS. ^
IT is very irritating to the rußhlights oE our
Assembly that thosV newspaper fellows should
distinctly make statements of political impor
tance before they (tht rushlights) become awaro
of the facts. There ii that visit of our versatile
Premier to Amerioa anl the old country, for in
stance. It was pretty well known last week that
Sir Henry was going-that the doctors who keep
a run of his physical system told him he must go, or
risk the consequences, that he has become
literally used up with the nagging and worry of
political life; and that, to make the most of the
stamina still in him, a long trip by sea, new
scenes, and complete severance from tho grind to
which he has been subjected, were recommended.
The Premier took tho advice offered. Be saw its
force, and determined to go. That there might be
less chance of drawing back, a passage was taken
in the Californian mail steamer sailing on
tho 29th. Sir Henry, " therefore, will
just, .hare tluoo to spend Christmas at
horne hore in the colony, see tho Christmas issue
of the TOWN AND COTJNTRT (which, I am told, will
he something unusual), and then off for his holi
day. Peace be with him. T expect we will get
along very well in his absence, for it is surprising
how men glide into holding the helm of the State,
and hold it very well too. I hope he'll have a good
time, and if ho don't come back, that he may be
able to get that seat in tho greater House
at Westminster whioh it is rumoured he is
hankering after. It was said in last week's Notes
he was going, and if hon. members desire to
verify the situation, instead of wasting time in
Parliament, a «all in at the office of the Pacific
Mail Co. will enlighten them (if that's what they
want). Tnere's a list there of the passengers
booked for the outgoing boat, and the name of
Sir Henry Parkes is amongst the lot.
" Tips" are not much in my way, but tho most
beautiful thing of the kind I ever got has been
spoiled. Here have I been labouring away at a
Note concerning tho visit of the Premier to Eng
land (after doing America). That same Note is
before me, and it winds up with the startling dis
closure that the main object of that visit was to
select Bix of the perfect order of god-like mortals
described during the dobates on tho Sydney
Magistrates' Bill as being of tho ealibre suit
able to sit and dispense justice in the
Sydney police courts. But it's all off
now, as the Bportfl say. I hadn't an
idea, you see, that there sat around, or lay
spread out on the Assembly honchos during
Monday night, the full number of incipient can
didates who considered themselves fit and cap
able persons to fill tho billets in question. And
that sticking out of tho coat pockets, or depos
ited in the drawers of other hon. members were
letters and testimonials from three times as
many aspirants lor those police magistrateships
as there are chairs to fill. When to that con
tingent is added two or three aspiring members
of the Upper House, who believe they could
still do their country service-for ¿800 a
yoar-and quito a crowd of outsiders whoBO
ambition has boen fired l y the eloquent descrip
tions of model police magistrates, there is no
occasion whatever for tho Premier to beat up tho
elite of England for right and proper persons.
That's where tho point of my Noto is blunted. It
is almost startling to find we have such numbers
of high-toned mortals amongst us who are flowing
over with tho sorb of wisdom whioh henceforth is
(that is, soon as provision for paying tho screw
is made) to decorate the magisterial honchos of
Sydney. I thought every one of thoso wonderful
beings described by tho Government would have
to bo imported, and all my lamentation that we
had no such mon amongst ourselvos is labour lost.
Tho mon aro hero, and eager to commonco opera
tions, and draw tho paltry salary immortalised in
tho pages of " Hansard " by tho eloquent mem
ber for Shoalhaven.
On Tuesday, -when tho Assembly mat. Mr.
Cameron went for b^meone whom he supposed had
jeen saying m the pa^Wrs untrue things of him
is chairman of committees. Tho explanation was
Not a succeBB. Mr. Cameron's efforts'bf that kind
»Jdom are. On Tuesday he put »nore foot in it
th« the bulk of his body would warrant, ana
t'orfct all about a good old aphorism that abase is
not tegument. Such words as ** blackguard " flo
nobsovnd weii fromtheohairmanof committees of
New Suth WaleB.
Thero\eing something in the form of a cruelty
to animaiKorganisation in this colony of ours, for
goodness slte j.et them overhaul the cattle carried
in our railwy* trucks. Until I saw those dena of
cruel torture\the belief was on me that it was
more humanoNp aend cattle by rail than travel
them from, sayWellington. But a trip over the
Sahara, with d&th by the way, would bo luxury
for bullooks in comparison with a voyage in those
truckB. They're frightful, and very much in keep
ing with our railwayÑrrangements generally. The
said tracks are not wio^enough for grown bullocks,
to start with, and af tex a journey of 100 miles or
less the tortured occupants ore found to be
barked all . round the ruup and tail j the head
and knees als > present masses and patches oE raw
.kin. So muoh for cattle who are able to hold

down, and many do, the other occupants of the

cruel, and I should like to see some of those who
are responsible arrested and made to pay the
penalty of cruelty to animals. Constitu

as they can manag9 with minorities. But
deliberate torture and injury to the carcasses of
cattle are not covered by the constitution. There's
aohance for the eruelty to animals society to go

cattle cars.

title: LITERATURE
content:
LITERATURE
Reconciliation.
Original Poetry.
WM. GAY.
Bendigo, Victoria, May, 1896.
I saw of late ono running hero and ihorc
About the wor d, who beat his breast and cried,
"O God,.art Thou dethroned, and dost Thou hide,
All impotent, in his infernal lair, . - ';
Who now, meseenifl, Thy Godhood seeks to wear
And Thy jnst laws in scorn to override,
Bestowing pain where joy should moat abide,
And cursing Innocence with Hell's despair?"
Then saw I later one of ordered mien,
With meekest dignity he passed along,
And said (as to a friend at bis right hand),
"Foolish my cries, who ne'er of p»in had seen. .
The heart divine,—o Lord, forgive the wrong!
Now have I suffered, and now understand."

title: POETRY.
content:
POETRY-;
ON HEARING OF WORDSWORTH'S
PENSION.
Bright beings, gather'd to the realms of rest,
Whose names have glorified dead empires,
stood
Looking upon our world, to see the good,
Delight in honouring him who had done best:
And, foremost of that band of immortals blest,
The grand old Greek, beloved in every mood,
For Troy's sublimest song, claim'd brother-
hood
With the great island-minstrel " further west."
Our Milton turn'd to Homer, with a smile
Worn only by such sainted glorious one,
Then, unremembering Cromwell's day the
while,
With sweet approval look'd our Queen upon--
" This royal act is worthy Britain's Isle,
Thou, crowned lady, of old England's throne !"
Sydney, May 8.
H. P.

title: Literary Matters.
content:
Literary Matters.
A LOVING VOICE.
L.N.
ACROSS the seething and forging sea
Comes a loving voice from a distant land;
Sounding as clear and as sweet to me
As heavenly hymn of the seraph band.
It stirs my soul to its inmost depth,
With its gentle, tender, and pleading tone;
Breathing fond wishes from those I left
In the dear old land and the olden home.
It calms the wild spirit with soft words,
Fraught with the memories of long ago ;
like sweetest warbUngs of happy birds,
la leafy wood, or 'neath the green hedgerow.
Bids the lone heart be patient and true.
Looking to the future with hope and faith:
To bear the burden aa right to do,
Cheerfolr/, bravely, not -dnUof beneath.
O loving voice from that distant shore,
I hail thy advent with joyous delight;
Brighten my path, and I fear no more
The clouds and shadows that darken my sight.
Oome still to comfort me, welcome voioe;
Speed o'er the wide sea on thy swiftest wing;
Gladden my ear, bid my heart rejoice
In the good tidings ye an wont to bring.

title: Tags of Terse.
content:
Tags of Terse,
CHILDREN.
How beautiful the child! ita smile how sweet! ' ~
Its trust unshaken, voice , with charms replete.
Brief tears soon changed to ,blis3; / . . ''ly-.
Gazing around with -.wondering raptured sight, . '
The young soul reaching out to life and light, ?
The Ups to meet our kiss. , -
0 Lord, preserve me, and preserve all those.
1 love-friends, brothers, kin, and e'en my foea
On whom blind fate has smiled
From seeing summer without flowers arrive,
Gage with no bird, and without bees the hive;.
The house without the child;

title: If You Were Here.
content:
If You Were Here.
If you were hero, how pleasant life would he;
How swoot tho twilight of tho oloaing year ;
Tho fire, how warm and bright, my heart how free,
If you wore here I
Whato'or hofoll, I would not shed a tear,
So I might spend my life in ministry
On you, whom death haa made BO passing dear.
Do you o'er mourn tho paßt, and think of me P
AIBB ! I would not need my heart to oheer ?
With hopes forlorn-nor from dark dreams to floe,
If you wero hore ! . ! '

title: THE RACES O.
content:
THE RACES O.
A New Song to an Old Tune.
"O what a day !"— Tom Thumb.
Old travellers, folks say, who from here to there are dancing,
On foreign sights and novelties to satisfy their eyes,
When on their travels gain a passion, for romancing,
And gull their simple readers with a volumn full of lies.
But I, who never look'd upon the wonderfuls. of Italy,
Like roving lords cannot descant upon them all so wittily ;
So, 'stead of writing books about old Vulcan's naked daughter O,
I'll sing ot something wonderful, in stanza's that are shorter O.
Then, my neighbours then, with good humour in your faces, ,
Attend unto my rhyming, and don't treat it with a frown ;
I sing of no unworthy deeds, but of Sydney Races,
That late inspir'd, and boldly fir'd, our great equestrian town.
The morn scarce dawn'd 'fore each horse was buckled to the traces,
As glowing fancy bodied forth the glories of the day ;
The ladies drest, in all their best—in muslins and in laces,
And sweeter than Diana look'd when riding forth in may.
Now mounted high, in Stanhope gig, in Buggy, or in Dennet, O,
With elbows squared, each thriving lord low bows to neighbour
Bennett, O ;
And, as he looks behind, in pride to see what gables follow, O,
Thinks, himself, in driving skill, Phaeton or Apollo, O.
Master Catch'em led the van—in company with Simkins,
The antipodes of all that's just, mannerly, and good ;
Next mister Quiver trembling rides, while his neighbour Jenkins,
Kept the " tenor of his way," just as steady as he could.
Now Captain Speedwell in his gig, with reins and whipcord la-
bours O,
" I travel post," he laughing cries, and. dashes past his neigh-
bours, O ;
And sure enough he " posted it,'' for 'midst his dashing paces O,
He runs against a gate and snaps his new-imported traces O.
Simon Trueheart ambling rides and amorously given,
Gallantly tries his ladylove with burning vows to please;
" Constancy alone," he sighs, '' 'tis makes this earth a heaven,
And madam I'm devoutly yours, I'll swear upon my knees."
Just then his Rosinante tripp'd, and 'midst the ladies squalling O
Beside-her frighted steed, he drops upon his trotters sprawling O
When she look'd down and leering cries, " I'll meet you at the
steeple O.
But pray don't swear my doating swain before so many people O.?
The Race ground gained, that place of fun, the knavish world's
epitome,
Where jockeys jostle, honest men, who jostle too in scorn ;
Where men lay bare their secret thoughts, and skilful in anatomy.
Just try to bleed their trusting frie'nds, who try to bleed in turn.
Great Epsom Downs with all their show, their bon ton, their
horses O,
Newmarket too with all her dukes, her buckels and her crosses O ;
Could ne'er display so bright a day—that day light, full was
dawning O,
Upon the Course of Botany on a fine September morning O.
But to mention every one who rode with magnanimity,
Would take more, time and doggrel rhyme than I can now
afford ;
Knights there were that pois'd the lance, and Baronets of dignity,
And Lords that cut up Holland like old Iervis by the yard.
Some would quiet friends and foes by lecturing it and proctering ;
Others took a shorter cut, nnd so cut them off by doctoring ;
But just to make amends for this, they'd kindly the next mi-
nute O,
Repair the loss the world sustain'd by bringing others in it O.
Merchants gay with hawking men familiarly imbrangled ;
Sad plaintiffs and defendants too—the wise man and the fool ;
Tailors, tinkers, justice's together were entangled,
As if distinction now no more—equality's the rule.
Fun and mirth kept jubilee, with laughter and drollery ;
Every scene was leeling drunk with humour, wit, and drollery ;
As up and down the course, they drove, cantering and parading it,
You'd swore the court of momus was at Belle Vue—masquerad-
ing it.
Each heart agog for sporting fun with challenges vociferous ;
Five to four on this, and then with offers round they, go—
The mania spreads for sportsmen know that betting is petiforous,
And like a fever is not cured till patients are brought low.
Now dashing from the starting post they gallop and they sidle O
And quick as fancy jockeys spur and whip, and chafe the bridle O
In daring skill each rider seems precisely of a kidney O !
For neck or nothing—is nothing new to sporting blades of
Sydney O.
Now the races all gone through, each kindred horse of Dante's
Prancing turns his snorting nose towards the distant town—
But each tit that's cousin to, the the steed of old Cervante's,
Contented with his feather bed, in quiet lays him down,
midst the din of sporting noise, Inmcntingsnnd of praises O—
Rattling dash on the carts, the coaches, and the chaises O—
For every one drives home so fast, you'd think they had no
leisure O.
To stop and take another sup of quick receding pleasure O.
Now fill high the foaming glass and quickly as it passes,
Toast off success to racing joy's, those antidotes of woe ;
For what is man with all his cares, and what are pray the lasses,
If pleasure's sunshine never beams upon this life of snow ?
Shut out from sports the mind contracts woe seizes on the spirits O
And gloom profound, and hopeless care, man feels he but in-
herits O ;
But wearied hearts, whose blood is spent in sorrow's own em-
ployments O,
Will blithly meet the iron toil that follows on enjoyments O.
J. M.

title: MUSIC.
content:
MUSIC.
GEORGE VOWLES.
Ipswich.
A SOUND of music so stirs my soul
That it wakens the thoughts that had flown,
Till around me in visions the beautiful roll—<*>
My childhood's (air days and what fancy has known—
▲ breath of the rammer—m ray of the sun—
AH these from the put are most certainly won;
The spring-day of 700 th, when the dark eye was glisten-
The bright daw of courtship and love;
When affection tat near me and llatening.
Brought Heaven to earth from above.
Ah. Muic! thon bindert with fetten
_ The bosom to what is most tender;
Karth's dsniums are thy fond debtors.
To tbee precious time tbey rarrender.
when sorrow droops pensively on the warm breast,
And care and deceit hover ronnd with unrest; '
A* toe sun burning fiercely dispels the dense shades,
So contest thon, sweet, with such seal,
The heart, till then mournful, a rapture pervades,
And nothing but pleasure we feat
The tyrant may bind with his chains,
In a dungeon the strong may confine;
If a note of soft music his sorrow attains,
He thinks of his freedom and ceases to pine.
Thou art the repressor, oh Music! of wrongs;
The bosom exuftingly fires at thy songs.
Where misery lingers, where man is deplorin*,
Shouldst thou in thy richness oome there ■—
As the sky after storms when thunders ceased roaring,
All things that we see are most fair.
Thy tones have aroused in my bosom
A joy free descended from heaven;
£ess brilliant is dew on the blossom
Than eyes which sparkle for what thou hast given.
Oh, Music! if Eden be yet on the earth,
It delights and it gladdens when thou hast thy birth;
It scatters around me its trees and its flowers,
And leads me where Adam has trod;
I soar like the angels and ride on the hours,
To the home of Lord andGod.
Cuinrinoir to the mind is as necessary as
food is to the body.
Lbt this be thy brazen wall of defence—to
be conscious of no guilt, and not to turn pale
on any charge.— Horace.
It is a base temper in mankind that they will
not take the smallest slight at theshands of those
who have done them the greatest kindness.
Thx time we live ought not to be computed
by the number of years, but by the use that has
been made of that time beneficiently given us. \
Take heed of jesting; many have been ruined
by it. It is hard to jest and not sometimes jeer,
too; which oftentimes sinks deeper than was
intended, or expected.
Enjoy the blessings of this day if Godsends
them; and the evils bear patiently and serenely.
For this day only is ours; we are dead to yester
day, and we are not born to to-morrow.
When you see an old man amiable, mild, equ
able, content, and good-humoured, be sure that
in his youth he was iust, generous, and forbear
ing. Inbisend he does not lament the past nor
dread the future. He is like the evening of a
fine day.
Thx Ant.—The celebrated conqueror, Timour
the Tartar, was once forced to take shelter from
his enemies in a ruined building. There he sat
alone for ae/eraf hours. After tome time,
desirous of diverting his mind from bis hope
less condition, he fixed his attention on an ant,
which was attempting to carry a grain of corn
larger than itaelf up a high wall; its effort,
• however, were unsuccessful. Again and again
it strove to accomplish its object and failed,
still undaunted, it returned to its task, and
sixty-nine times did Timour see the grain fall to
the ground: but the seventieth time the ant
reached the top of the wall with the prise, and
" the sight," said the conqueror, who had just
before been despairing, "gave me courage at
the moment, and I have never forgotten the
lesson it conveyed." Application. —Nor should
we forget it. We should first see if the tiling
it worth doing, and if it be, and we fail, we
should try again and again, and persevere until
it is accomplished.' If an ant was not dis
couraged by sixty-nine failures, why should
mankind be disheartened ?
Temptations.—'Scarcely anyone in the
Christian world at this day knows whence
temptations are. He who undergoes them be
lieves not otherwise than that they are torments
arising from the' evils which are inwardly with
man, and which first render him unquiet, next
anxious, and finally torment him; but he is al
together ignorant that they are effected by the
evU spirits which are with him; that he is
ignorant of this is because he does not believe
that he is in fellowship with spirits while he
live* in the world, and scaroely that there is any
spirit with him, when yet man, as to the in
teriors, is continually in the society of spirits and
angels. As to what concerns temptations, they
tab place when man is in the act of regenera
tion, for no one can be regenerated unless he
also undergoes temptations; and then they
exist by evil spirits who are about him; for
man is then let into the state of evil in which
he is, that is, in which is that which constitutes
his proprium, and when he comes into this
state, evil or infernal spirits encompass him, and
when they perceive that he is interiorly pro
tected by angels, the evil spirits excite the ideas
which he had thought, and the evils which he
had done, but the angels from the interior de
fend him. It is this combat which is perceived
by man as temptation, but so obscurely that he
scaroely knows otherwise than that it is merely
an anxiety; for man, especially he who believes
nothing concerning influx, is in a. state alto
gether obscure, and scaroely perceives a
thousaadeth part of those things concerning
which evil spirits and angels combat; never
theless, man and his eternal salvation
are then at stake, and the determination
of the stake is for man (ci agUmr ex
hominej for the combat is carried on from
those things which are with man and con
cerning them. Temptations also give the
quality of the perception of good and truth,
by the opposite* which evil spirits then infuse;
for no one knows what good is, unless he also'
knows what is not good; nor what truth is
unless he knows what is not true. Temptations
also confirm goods and truths, for man then
fights against evils and false*, and by conquer
ing he comes into a stronger affirmative. More
over, also, by temptations evils and falses are
subdued, that tbey may no longer attempt to
rise up; thus evils and wises are rejected to the
sides, whereas goods and truths are in the
midst, and according to the seal of affection are
elevated upwards, thus to heaven towards the
Lord, from whom is the elevation. Whosoever is
engaged in the combats of temptation, and con
quers in them, acquires to himself more and
more power over evil spirits, till at length they
dare not assault him. The Lord Himself im
mediately, and mediately by bis angels, is pre
sent with those who are in temptation, and re
sists, by refuting the falses of the infernal
spirits, and by dissipating their evil, whence
comes refreshment, hope, and victory; thus the
brother of faith and the goods of charity are
more inwardly implanted and more strongly
oonfirmed. This is the means whereby spiritual
life is bestowed.— Old Author.
To Cubs a Felon.—A correspondent says:
When indications of a felon appear, take a piece
of rennet and soak it in warm milk until it be
comes soft, then apply it to the part affected,
renewing it occasionally, and keeping on until a
cure is produced.
To Kill Wartb. —The following is said never
to fail, if properly applied : Make a strong steep,
from red oak bark, in hot water; when cold,
apply as convenient, the oftener the better. In
a few days the wart will disappear.
Use of Gebanium Leaves.—lt is not gene*
rally known that the leaves of a geranium are
an excellent application for cuts, where the skin
is rubbed off, and other wounds of that kind.
One or two leaves must be bruised and applied
to the part, and the wound will be cicatrised in
a short time.
To Clean Black Lace.—Take the lace, and
wipe off the dust carefully with a cambric hand
kerchief, then pin it out on a bed, inserting a
pin in each projecting point of the lace. Sponge
it all over with table beer, and do not remove
tiie pins till it is perfectly dry. It will look
quite fresh and new.
Baspbebbx Vixxgab-—Carefully pick 6
pounds of fine ripe raspberries, and pour on
them four pints of the very finest vinegar.
Leave them thus for four days, frequently stir-1
ring, but not nothing the fruit so as to bruise
the seeds : then place a piece of clean washed
linen or flannel in a sieve, and filter through it
the vinegar, to each pint of juice adding two
pounds of loaf sugar; put it into a glazed jar
or pan, which place in hot water, and keep
there till tbe juice boils thick and sirupy. Let
it become cold, then bottle it. The whole pro
cess should be carried on in glazed earthen
Tatjals.

title: LITERATURE
content:
LITERATURE
Original Poetry.
[WRITTEN FOR THE QUEENSLANDER.]
At Morn, At Noon, At Eve.
F.C. URQUHART.
Cloncurry, 3rd January, 1888.
I said to my love at the dawning:
"Arise, love, and come with me
To gather the flowers of morning
That are fresh and fair like thee."
And the lark was carolling far above
His song of happiness, joy, and love ;
And the music fell from the vault on high
As a welcome to her from the morning sky.
I said to my love at the noonday:
" O stay, love, and rest thee here
In this fair green glade by Nature made
For the child she holds most dear."
And the sunlight glinted beneath the shade
As she rested with head on her nosegays laid,
And the bright beams played with her golden hair
As if they had found their sisters there.
I cried to my love at evening:
" O, love, leave me not alone!
O plead for me to be joined with thee
In bliss near the Great White Throne!"
And the cypress is waving to and fro
O'er the grave where my hopes are lying low,
And an angel is echoing far away
The song of the skylark at break of day.

title: ENIGMA.
content:
ENIGMA.
I eofl^e with Majesty and pciwer, j
' I come with pomp and sway,
To make! the grass and herbs to flower,.
' Botht here, and far away.
And oft I come in times of need
?: 'When there is much distress : ' '.
?But seldom lam found indeed, ?
; In a barren wilderness.
I am no stranger here on earth, ^ . ;
For me the world must know ;,
But little all, this land was worth, v
Before I came below.
Sometimes I make a great delay,
, Yet still I am protected, ,
And hover in some curious way,
.. Then come quite1 unexpected.
My home is almost every where,
. I well nigh visit all ;
But there are countries you're aware,
On which I never call.
I'll leave you now my name to guess,
And X have little doubt, '
But what you'al^ without distress,
Will quickly find it out. ?
O.P.Q.
Bathurstv i -

title: THE RAIN COMBS SOBBING TO THE DOOR.
content:
THE RAIN COMES SOBBING TO THE DOOR.
The night grows dark, and weird and cold; and thick drops
patter on the pane;
There comes a w ailing from the sea-the wind is weary of the rain!
The red cecils click beneath the flame ; and sec ! with Blow and
silent feet,
The hooded shadows cross the woods, to where the twilight waters
heat !
Now, funwise from the ruddy flic, a brilliance sweeps athwart the
floor ;
As, streaming down the lattices, the lain conies sobbing to the
dooi !
As, sti earning down the lattices,
The ram comes sobbing to the door !
Dull echoes round the casement fall, and thro' the empty cham-
bers go,
Like forms unseen whom we can hear, on tiptoe stealing? to and
fro!
Hut fill your glasses to the brim, and, through a mist of smile»
and tears.
Our ejes shall tell how much we love to toxst the shades of other
years !
And hither they will flock again, the ghosts of things that aro n»
more ;
While, streaming down the lattices, the rain comes sobbing to the
door !
While, streaming down the lattices,
The rain comes sobbing to the door !
The tempest-trodden wastelands moan-the trees arc threshing at.
the blast ;
And now they come the pallid shapes of dreams that perish'd i» '
the past ! < ?
And, when we lift the windows up, a smothei-'d whisper round us
strays,
Like some lone wandering voice from graves that hold the wreck» ,
of bygone days !
I tell ye that I love the storm, for think we not of thoughts of yore,
When, streaming down the lattices, the rain comes sobbing to the .
dooi !
When, stroming down the lattices,
The rain comes sobbing to the door !
We'll drink to those we sadly miss, and sing some mournful
song we know,
Since they may chance to hear it all, and muse on friends they've
left below !
Who know6-if soul? in bliss can leave the borders of their Eden
home
But w hat some loving one may now about the ancient threshold, .?
roam Î
Oh ! like an exile ho would hail a glimpso of the familiar floor ;
Though, streaming down the lattices, the rain comes sobbing t» '
the door !
Though, str«uning down the lattices, :
